fields.headline: Whatever Happened To Harold Smith?
fields.trailText: Peter Bradshaw: The film soon collapses into vacuous whimsy and it's far from clear exactly what age-range this is supposed to be aimed it's difficult to avoid the sense that this is the sort of so-so script that would not have got made without the Lottery slush fund
fields.body:
Whatever Happened To Harold Smith? is an amiable British Lottery funded comedy, boasting a first-rate cast, that I'd desperately hoped to like. Set in the 70s, with the now obligatory tongue-in-cheek appearances by telly heroes of the time, it's the story of teenage disco fan Vince (Michael Legge) who falls in star-crossed love with beautiful young punk Joanna (Laura Fraser). His life is further complicated when his old dad Harold (an almost catatonically gentle Tom Courtenay) is revealed to have strange powers.

Stephen Fry gives a gentle, charming, un-show-offy performance as Joanna's father, and as her precocious younger sister Lucy, Charlotte Roberts gets the biggest laugh of the film, reading out a priggish poem about Joanna's smoking. But the film soon collapses into vacuous whimsy and it's far from clear exactly what age-range this is supposed to be aimed at - arch thirtsomething retro buffs? Modern teens? Both groups are going to be left cold, and once again it's difficult to avoid the sense that this is the sort of so-so script that would not have got made without the Lottery slush fund.

fields.headline: Lola und Bilidikid
fields.trailText: Peter Bradshaw: A powerful film about politics, sexuality and alienation in contemporary Berlin
fields.body:
Kutlug Ataman's Lola und Bilidikid is a powerful film about politics, sexuality and alienation in contemporary Berlin. It is a kind of gay Streetcar Named Desire, a movie quite at variance with the placid, middlebrow mood of the aspirational Bürgertum we are told is the prevailing cultural flavour of modern Germany.

Lola is a Turkish transvestite, part of a cross-dressing belly-dance troupe called Die Gästarbeiter, performing in nightclubs. His lover is the leather-clad Brandoid boy Bilidikid (as in 'Billy-the-kid') who wishes Lola to have the operation so that he can live with him as man and wife, and in his macho way scorns the identity of homosexual. Their story ends in catastrophe, but amidst the self-conscious exoticism and depravity, Ataman's movie slyly encompasses comedy and tenderness.

fields.headline: SLC Punk!
fields.trailText: Peter Bradshaw: For punkology students only
fields.body:
SLC Punk!, is an odd autobiographical flick from horror director James Merendino about disaffected youth embracing the nihilistic punk ethic in Salt Lake City in the 80s. Despite the nostalgic glow with which Merendino attempts to immerse the belated punk scene in Reagan's America, he is very candid about something that many punk scholars lightly pass over: punk's infatuation with violence, real violence, not "cultural" or "ideological" violence.

A lot of punks, over here and over there, were quite as into beating people up as skinheads, and sure enough, this movie shows Stevo (Matthew Lillard) and Bob (Michael Goorjian) taking fists and baseball bats to rednecks, who do not provoke the violence at all. In other scenes, our mohawk-haired heroes are just witty, affectionate, vulnerable guys, and it is difficult to tell whether the resulting, creepy effect is accidental or not. For punkology students only.

fields.headline: Next Friday
fields.trailText: Peter Bradshaw: Strictly direct-to-Blockbuster
fields.body:
Elsewhere on display as a Gulf Warrior in Three Kings, Ice Cube is back this week in Fresh-Prince-Of-Bel-Air comedy territory with Next Friday, a sequel to his 1995 comedy Friday. The bully he once beat up escapes from prison, and fearing for his life, Craig (Ice Cube) goes to stay with his nouveau lottery millionaire cousins in the 'burbs.

Much knockabout stuff kicks off, including a lot of good old-fashioned fart jokes - though nothing much disturbs Ice Cube's impassive cool. There are one or two funny moments, especially when he tries using a Hoover attachment to suck up the incriminating weed fragrance while smoking, but this is strictly direct-to-Blockbuster.

fields.headline: The best contact scene
fields.standfirst: The Insider
fields.trailText: Having received a mysterious bundle of documents concerning the tobacco industry, Lowell Bergman (Al Pacino) - a producer on CBS' renowned 60 Minutes - is looking for someone to decode them. The number passed on to him is that of Jeffrey Wigand, a supposed expert in the field. In the CBS offices, Bergman dials Wigand's number.
fields.body:
Having received a mysterious bundle of documents concerning the tobacco industry, Lowell Bergman (Al Pacino) - a producer on CBS' renowned 60 Minutes - is looking for someone to decode them. The number passed on to him is that of Jeffrey Wigand, a supposed expert in the field. In the CBS offices, Bergman dials Wigand's number.

After two rings, a little girl answers: Barbara Wigand (Hallie Kate Eisenberg), Jeffrey's daughter.

"Hello?"

"Hello? Mr Wigand, please."

No answer. After a moment, a woman's voice comes on the line - this time, it's Wigand's wife, Liane (Diane Venora).

"Hello?"

"Ah, my name is Lowell Bergman -"

"Mr Bergen?"

"No, Bergman. B-e-r-g-m-a-n. I'm a producer with 60 Minutes."

"60 Minutes the television show?"

"Yeah."

"He doesn't want to talk to you."

"How does he know he doesn't want to talk to me? He doesn't know what I want to talk about?"

"He doesn't care to know."

The line goes dead. Bergman dials again: an ansaphone clicks on.

"WIGANDS. LEAVE A MESSAGE."

"Ah, this is Lowell Bergman from 60 Minutes. I have scientific documents from a tobacco company, and I could use your help in explaining these documents to me. My number is area code 510-555-0199. And I'll be here at this number if you want to call me."

At the other end of the line, Wigand (Russell Crowe) listens pensively as Bergman replaces the receiver.

See also: All The President's Men, The China Syndrome, Velvet Goldmine

Don't see also: Godzilla

Pointless trivia: Al Pacino turned down the role of Han Solo in Star Wars

webTitle: Seaman and co complete Spanish campaign for spiked Gunners

fields.headline: Seaman and co complete Spanish campaign for spiked Gunners
fields.standfirst: Victor 69, Ivan Perez 90 | Henry 63
fields.trailText: Arsenal may have shown little of the scintillating form of a week ago but, having done the hard work at Highbury, there was no need for that. After withstanding an early assault, they gladly watched the game peter out and once Thierry Henry had scored just after the hour they might as well have retired to the nearby beach.
fields.byline: Jon Brodkin  at the Riazor stadium
fields.body:
Arsenal may have shown little of the scintillating form of a week ago but, having done the hard work at Highbury, there was no need for that. After withstanding an early assault, they gladly watched the game peter out and once Thierry Henry had scored just after the hour they might as well have retired to the nearby beach.

Goals from the substitutes Victor and Ivan Perez sent Arsenal to defeat but could not prevent them progressing to the quarter-finals of this competition for the first time since 1971.

Arsenal could hardly have anticipated an easy night. Robbed of four natural centre-backs by injury and suspension their defence did not look at its intimidating best. At the heart of it stood Oleg Luzhny, who has played almost exclusively at full-back, and the midfielder Emmanuel Petit.

It was an indication of local pessimism that the 35,000-capacity stadium was less than half full despite slashed prices. The fans seemed to believe they had more chance of getting a 10pm tan at the beach than seeing their team go through.

The players, though, seemed fired up, with the dismissal of Djalminha at Highbury adding spice to the proceedings. The feeling here is that Gilles Grimandi made not just a meal but a banquet of the incident. And a much-changed and more attacking Deportivo side twice went close to scoring in the opening nine minutes.

First, from a Jaime free-kick, the tall Ramis exploited slack marking to send a free header over the bar. Then David Seaman produced a brilliant reaction save to keep out Pauleta's fierce close-range shot.

But Deportivo's adventurous strategy left them vulnerable on the counter-attack, where the pace of Thierry Henry continued to trouble them. The French striker could have put the tie beyond doubt in the 10th minute but, after rounding the goalkeeper Peter Kouba, his effort was hacked clear by Nourredine Naybet.

Although Deportivo pressed dangerously and almost inces santly, they could create little from open play. Luzhny looked increasingly assured and Ray Parlour worked tirelessly on the right of a midfield that featured Nigel Winterburn in an unaccustomed central role.

From set pieces, though, the home side caused havoc. When the Arsenal wall carelessly allowed a Turu Flores free-kick through, Seaman dived low to save. In the 33rd minute the England goalkeeper was rescued by his left post as Jaime's free-kick from near the touchline evaded everyone.

Seaman continued his out standing display by denying the impressive Jaime. And his opposite number had to be alert to stop Freddie Ljungberg's deflected shot as half-time approached.

But as the game continued goalless and Deportivo's slim hopes became ever slimmer, the competitive edge was blunted and Arsenal started to play with more freedom. With Deportivo resigned to their fate, Henry collected Kanu's clever pass and beat Kouba from 15 yards just to make sure.

 Arsenal will play Werder Bremen in the quarter-finals after the Germans beat Parma 3-1 at home last night.

 Celta Vigo completed a miserable week for Italian clubs in a competition they have won eight times in the past 11 years by knocking out the favourites Juventus 4-1 on aggregate after a 4-0 win in Spain last night, South Africa's Benny McCarthy scoring twice.

Deportivo La Coruna (4-4-2): Kouba; Scaloni, Ramis, Naybet, Manel; Jaime (Fran, 64min), Mauro Silva, Turu Flores, Fernando (Ivan Perez, 80); Makaay (Victor, 56), Pauleta.

Arsenal (4-4-1-1): Seaman; Dixon, Luzhny, Petit, Silvinho; Parlour, Vieira, Winterburn (Vernazza, 84), Ljungberg; Kanu (Malz, 83); Henry (Suker, 79).

Referee: O Sarvan (Turkey).

fields.headline: Liverpool secure Heskey for £11m
fields.trailText: Emile Heskey became the most expensive player in Liverpool's history last night when he finally agreed to leave Leicester City in an £11m deal.
fields.body:
Emile Heskey became the most expensive player in Liverpool's history last night when he finally agreed to leave Leicester City in an £11m deal.

Some six months after the transfer to Anfield of the 22-year-old England striker was first mooted the two clubs struck a deal, Liverpool's manager Gérard Houllier reluctantly agreeing to raise by £1.8m his initial bid lodged late last year.

This morning, less than a fortnight after Heskey helped Leicester to success over Tranmere Rovers in the Worthington Cup final at Wembley, he will travel to Merseyside to add his considerable weight to Liverpool's attempt to secure a place in next season's Champions League by way of a top-three Premiership finish.

If he successfully negotiates a lunchtime medical examination and is registered as a Liverpool player with the Football Association before 5pm, he may make his debut in tomorrow's Premiership match with Sunderland at Anfield.

Heskey had declined Leicester's offer of an extended contract which would have netted him £25,000 a week.

The deal will smash Liverpool's transfer record, set five years ago when they paid Nottingham Forest £8.5m for Stan Collymore, who coincidentally joined Leicester last month and immediately formed a fruitful strike partnership with Heskey.

webTitle: United in the hope of an almighty slip-up

fields.headline: United in the hope of an almighty slip-up
fields.trailText: United will probably win the Premiership again and then spend another fortune on players in the summer. So how does all this make Arsenal or Chelsea feel? And what about Charlton Athletic?
fields.body:
Manchester United, football's first £1bn business, are now apparently worth more than the combined value of the high street chains House of Fraser, Selfridges, Courtaulds and The Body Shop. At this rate the United Party will soon be taking office at Westminster.

United will probably win the Premiership again. And possibly the Champions League. They'll spend another fortune on players in the summer, continue to exploit their worldwide brand, establish themselves as leaders of the new media age and still keep supporters and shareholders happy.

So how does all this make Arsenal or Chelsea feel? And what about Charlton Athletic? Unless this column puts the complete mockers on them, the south Londoners will be playing United in the top flight again next season. But can they really compete?

Charlton were relegated from the Premiership last season and, conforming to football's yo-yo law, are now top of the First Division, as dominant in their domain as United are in the world: 12 straight league wins, 24 victories from 34 games, a goal difference of plus 34 and 12 points more than second-placed Ipswich.

Watford and Bradford will return whence they came in May, supported by a parachute payment from the Premier League to soften the blow of reduced television income and no doubt psychologically enriched by the experience of playing at Old Trafford, Anfield, Elland Road and Highbury. And no doubt both clubs will be at the top of the First Division this time next year.

So what's the point? Well, according to the wiser owners of would-be major clubs, it all comes down to how you react when you win that promotion.

Don't go crazy and start chucking money at players who might keep you in the Premiership. In all probability you won't survive up there even if you remortgage the ground, raid your players' pension funds and invest your money in lastminute.com. This way, at least you are not saddled with a crippling wage bill and expensive players whom you can't sell in a hurry come the end of the season and relegation.

And, most important of all, be patient. The players who get you up and send you back down again will have learned something from the experience. They will be better equipped to cope when you make the jump next time.

And finally, don't sack your manager. He too will grow into a man worthy of a knighthood.

This sounds a pretty depressing scenario, but men who have been there and got the T-shirt insist that clubs such as Watford, Bradford and Charlton will eventually get to the point where the players, the stadiums and the accountants find a level to be able to live with the Uniteds and the Arsenals of this world. It might take a decade, but this prudent policy will reap dividends.

The problem with all this is that long-term planning may suit the number-crunchers but is no damn good to the supporters. Patience is not their strongest collective virtue.

But it is certainly a strategy which will continue to be embraced by clubs such as Charlton.

In the mid-80s I spent week after week reporting on Charlton's battle for survival in the high court in the days of a young chairman called Mark Hulyer and his mysterious Nigerian backer Chief Francis Nzeribe.

Those were the days of Derek Hales and his sidekick Allan Simonsen, the former European footballer of the year who had a short and surreal stay at the Valley. The days when they played piped cheering over the Tannoy system to give the little Dane the impression he had just stepped on to the pitch at the Maracana.

Charlton were conjuring money from thin air as they followed the "speculate-to-accumulate" mantra of Thatcherism. Crystal Palace, with whom they ground-shared after being forced to vacate the Valley, have paid the price for a similar gamble recently.

Before tomorrow's home game with Swindon at the now-restored Valley, Charlton will unveil a bust of Jimmy Seed, the club's most successful manager who led them to FA Cup victory in 1947. The present manager and former player Alan Curbishley also has the pedigree to achieve great things for Charlton.

It is wonderful for the English game that Manchester United are such a breathtaking success story. But I can't help thinking that football could do with United taking their eye off the ball for a few years just to give the rest of the league the opportunity to catch them up and make football interesting again. For the fans, not the shareholders.

webTitle: Di Canio is fined £5,000 for insulting gesture

fields.headline: Di Canio is fined £5,000 for insulting gesture
fields.trailText: Paolo di Canio was yesterday fined £5,000 and severely censured by the Football Association for making an insulting gesture during West Ham United's Premiership match with Aston Villa at Upton Park on January 15.
fields.body:
Paolo di Canio was yesterday fined £5,000 and severely censured by the Football Association for making an insulting gesture during West Ham United's Premiership match with Aston Villa at Upton Park on January 15.

Di Canio was caught on camera, middle digit aloft, but there was no indication to whom the gesture was aimed.

Villa fans had barracked Di Canio during the game because they believed he had dived to win a penalty, which he then missed, in the replayed Worthington Cup tie between the teams four days earlier. He was also involved in a skirmish with Villa's goalkeeper David James at the end of the cup tie.

Harry Redknapp, the West Ham manager, claimed that a Villa player had been responsible for provoking Di Canio during the series of games between the clubs, but refused to name the culprit and said Di Canio had not wanted to name him in the hearing.

The FA spokesman Steve Double said the disciplinary committee had accepted that the gesture was aimed at a Villa player and not the crowd. "We accept he was provoked but he has been severely censured and warned that if he's guilty of anything similar in future there will be a suspension."

Redknapp said: "It was a fair hearing and I think it was the right decision. It was frustration on his behalf. He had been getting abuse and he reacted to it. It was a gesture and it didn't hurt anybody."

Di Canio was banned for 11 matches for pushing over the referee Paul Alcock at Hillsborough 18 months ago, his last match for Sheffield Wednesday. Tomorrow he returns there for the first time.

fields.headline: Murali's star turn clinches series
fields.trailText: Muthiah Muralitharan finished with 10 wickets in the match as Sri Lanka beat Pakistan by 57 runs in the second Test and took the series 2-0.
fields.body:
Muthiah Muralitharan finished with 10 wickets in the match as Sri Lanka beat Pakistan by 57 runs in the second Test and took the series 2-0.

The tourists needed only nine balls to dismiss Pakistan for 236 on the final morning in Peshawar to win their third straight Test series.

Pakistan resumed the final morning on 222 for eight with their hopes resting on their captain Saeed Anwar, but it was virtually over in nine min utes when he holed out in the covers off Chaminda Vaas for 36.

Muralitharan finished the job. A deserved man of the match, the off-spinner missed out on a hat-trick but his match figures were 10-148, his third 10-wicket Test haul. "I never expected it would be a turning pitch but I enjoyed bowling here and am happy that I played my part in the win," he said.

The third Test begins in Karachi on Sunday. The middle-order batsman Ijaz Ahmed has been recalled to the Pakistan squad, as has the leg-spinner Mushtaq Ahmed and Wasim Akram, but the opener Aamir Sohail has been dropped.

India beat South Africa by three wickets in a dramatic limited-overs match in Cochin yesterday, reaching the target of 302 with two balls left. Robin Singh and Anil Kumble returned to the crease with three balls to go after an umpire's wrong call for four runs gave the impression that India had won.

 Ronnie Irani has replaced the England captain Nasser Hussain as Essex captain.

fields.headline: Big Tobacco's last gasp
fields.standfirst: Peter Bradshaw finds Michael Mann's conspiracy thriller a riveting addition to the smoking debate
fields.trailText: Peter Bradshaw: Big, brash, thrilling, and exhilaratingly contemporary, and pretty addictive on its own
fields.body:
The Insider, Michael Mann's clammily intense and faintly hallucinatory conspiracy thriller, re-writes Lyndon Johnson's warning about the military-industrial complex. In the 21st century, it has evolved into a corporate-legal complex. Here is the new threat: global behemoths commanding platoons of besuited lawyers to intimidate and enforce silence. Able to do so, moreover, with more money and power than many nation states, unencumbered by their quaint checks and balances - yet with all the paranoia, secrecy and sleek determination of any nation state on a war footing.

Mann's riveting film is based on the true story of Jeffrey Wigand (Russell Crowe), a scientist and disgruntled employee of a giant US Big Tobacco firm. He comes to Lowell Bergman (Al Pacino), a producer on the CBS 60 Minutes television show, with a sensational story. Despite the cigarette moguls' sworn testimony that their product is not addictive, Wigand says his entire career has been devoted to making it precisely that - designing cigarettes as miniaturised "nicotine delivery systems" and enhancing their addictive properties. Instantly, his firm unleashes its nuclear arsenal of threats and writs; Wigand and his family are mysteriously threatened, and sinister corporate influences induce CBS to take Wigand's explosive interview off air.

Like his 1995 mega-thriller Heat, Mann's picture unfolds across a big canvas and yet cinematographer Dante Spinotti focuses with fanatical, almost dysfunctional intensity on the textures and surfaces of ordinary life - the car dash, the take-out coffee cup, the wiry grain of chain-hotel carpeting: all this is represented with a compulsively strange, jittery urgency as Wigand conducts his panicky secret conversations with Bergman.

The most important surface Mann picks out is that of Wigand's face, looming in almost unendurable close-up, pale, sweaty, on the edge of cracking up. This is a very strong performance from Russell Crowe: a completely believable human complex of vanity, courage, self-doubt, fear and despair. Al Pacino is not as impressive, turning in essentially a similar tough-guy performance as his Vincent Hanna in Heat - only this time without a badge and a gun - Pacino does the same even, middleweight job. He has machismo and tough professionalism, and does a lot of curious emotionless shouting in that croaky wrecked voice (a 40-a-day man, surely?). There is simply not much light-and-shade in Pacino's screen presence, no sense of self-questioning or vulnerability, and the fact that he is forced into a very similar position as Wigand at the end points up the material superiority of Crowe's performance. Pacino could play a cop, a mafioso, an investigative journalist, a jockey, a vet - and I fear it would all sound the same.

Mann's new thriller appears at a turning point in the cultural history of cigarettes. Just as the tobacco giants are beginning to concede vital points in the courts, thus exposing themselves to the lawsuits they have feared for so long, a libertarian current of politics has made fags fashionable again. Authors like Richard Klein have dashingly made the case for their place in the arena of individual responsibility and pleasure, and revived a Wildean sense of the cigarette as the self-consuming icon of useless delight. However, in the daily drizzle of media commentary, this means that the politically correct anti-smoking bore has been replaced by the equally tiresome opposite: dullard pundits and salaryman columnists incessantly ordering us to admire their adorable courage and sheer intellectual gristle in smoking fags.

Mann's film, as well as being in the enjoyable line of conspiracy thrillers like The Conversation, has its own intelligible and lucid relationship to this debate. It is a refreshing corrective to the cigarette industry's sleight-of-hand claims to victim status: a chilling study of a gigantic corporate overdog ruthlessly exercising its unexamined prerogative to threaten and bully the individual. It is based on an article by Marie Brenner for Vanity Fair. As it happens, I have long fantasised about a cigarette conspiracy thriller based on Michael Massing's essay for the New York Review of Books in July 1996, which among other things, discussed Big Tobacco's nastiest secret - the central importance to the industry of children taking up smoking, the seed-corn of long-term addiction without which the cigarette business would go broke in one generation.

But The Insider does more than enough in this and every other regard: it is big, brash, thrilling, and exhilaratingly contemporary, and pretty addictive on its own.

webTitle: ITN tried to crush critical leftwing journal, jury told

fields.headline: ITN tried to crush critical leftwing journal, jury told
fields.trailText: ITN attempted to "completely destroy" a leftwing magazine which criticised its coverage of the Bosnian war, a jury at the high court in London heard yesterday.
fields.body:
ITN attempted to "completely destroy" a leftwing magazine which criticised its coverage of the Bosnian war, a jury at the high court in London heard yesterday.

Mick Hume, the editor of LM magazine (formerly Living Marxism), was giving evidence in a libel case brought by ITN and two reporters against the magazine. Mr Hume, 40, defended his decision to publish the article by Thomas Deichmann in his magazine in February 1997 which claimed ITN reporters had misrepresented the image of an emaciated Bosnian Muslim standing behind barbed wire in their award-winning report on the Serb-run Trnopolje camp in August 1992.

He said it was a "great piece of investigative journalism that deserved to be published", and which involved important issues about journalistic standards and the "use and misuse of the Holocaust".

Mr Hume said he had not contacted ITN to get its version of events before publishing the article, saying: "I was worried that if I was to contact an institution like ITN for their reaction they would attempt to suppress that story before it was ever published."

He said his decision had been vindicated because, after the article was published, ITN had "attempted to have my magazine completely destroyed".

He said he had "no personal malice or grudge" against ITN or the two ITN reporters, Penny Marshall and Ian Williams, who are claiming damages over a press release, editorial and article headed The picture that fooled the world, published in 1997.

LM, which denies libel and pleads justification and fair comment, had asserted that there was no barbed wire surrounding Trnopolje but that it was around the news team, who were filming from a small enclosure next to the camp.

Mr Hume said it was unprecedented for a large media organisation like ITN to sue a small, independent magazine for libel, adding: "I believe the truth should be judged in the court of public opinion. I believe in press freedom and the right of the public themselves to decide the truth and not for them to have that decided by ITN or the high court."

He added: "I felt these two reporters were guilty of taking sides, not with Muslims, but the victims. I felt they had developed an emotional involvement with the story and had presented a sensational image of the suffering of those victims, knowing it would be taken as an image of concentration camps."

Mr Hume said he had taken no side in the Bosnian civil war but criticised the tendency to make "easy and casual" comparisons between the Holocaust and conflicts around the globe which does "a disservice to victims of the Holocaust".

Giving evidence, Mr Deichmann said he had visited Trnopolje in 1996 and stood by his claim that inmates at the camp could leave at any time.

The case continues today.

webTitle: My reply: the cash was real

fields.headline: My reply: the cash was real
fields.standfirst: Blunkett's £19bn for schools is just a 'conjuring trick', wrote the Guardian's Nick Davies this week
fields.trailText: It takes a special kind of magic to obscure the best education settlement in decades in the manner of Nick Davies.
fields.body:
It takes a special kind of magic to obscure the best education settlement in decades in the manner of Nick Davies.

Let's start with an independent fact. The Institute of Fiscal Studies confirmed in its Green Budget that "by 2002, Labour will have achieved an annualised real increase in education spending of 3.2%, double that of the last administration and more than twice that of the Conservatives over their entire term of office from 1979 to 1997".

Sustained increases are going into schools in a way which never happened before. The Conservatives had a one-off increase in 1992 and cut spending afterwards. Real spending per pupil fell by £50 in last three Conservative budgets. In contrast, there will be a real terms increase of £200 per pupil in this parliament.

Of course, we are still in the first year of the three-year spending review, so only a magician would expect schools to have seen results of the whole three years before the first year is over.

When we were elected, the 1997-8 Budget (which Davies seems to think I was responsible for) had already been agreed and distributed. With Gordon Brown we took immediate action to give schools an emergency injection of £835m extra cash for 1998-9, avoiding a further £40 real terms cut per pupil.

Nick Davies dismisses increased spending on repairs. Yet twice as much is now being spent as under the Conservatives. With the new deal for schools, over 10,000 schools have already had or are undergoing improvement: much of it substantial. As well as new classrooms for infants and the removal of the last outside toilets, 260 schools are benefiting from substantial buildings improvement or replacement projects through public-private partnerships.

Graciously, Nick Davies concedes that we have increased the standards fund. Yet he has made several errors here too. Few grants rely on bids now. The fund which enables us to provide grants for literacy and numeracy or teacher training has increased from £190m in 1997-8 to over £820m in grant in 2001-2. Some programmes involve 50% (not 60%) match funding from authorities. Others like class sizes and computer funding are funded fully by the government. This is also true from this coming April of the highly popular excellence in cities programme.

Is any of this making a difference? The evidence certainly suggests it is. Standards in the 3Rs have risen as a result of the literacy and numeracy hours. The recent Guardian/ICM poll showed that most primary school parents believed standards in their own primary school had risen as a result. Four times as many primary schools are linked to the internet and schools are being equipped with com puters. Teachers are being trained to use the net.

We are able to fund £2,000 increases in annual pay for good teachers - on top of the annual 3.3% award. Schools in the inner cities have got extra money for mentors to help tackle disaffection as well as new units for disruptive pupils and programmes for able children. I'm acting so that we don't simply leave weak and failing schools to sink as the Tories were happy to do (and as Nick Davies advocated on Monday), but at the same time we recognise that good schools should have the chance to flourish without excessive intervention.

We are spending £140m this year on tackling truancy and exclusions compared with £22m a year under the Conservatives. We are spending £160m this year on cutting class sizes - something ignored by the last government.

I know that further and higher education are often relegated to section two of the Guardian on a Tuesday, but that is no reason for your star investigator to miss them completely in his lengthy and supposedly comprehensive piece. In fact, further education colleges which educate over 4m students have seen their budgets increase from £3.1bn in 1997-98 to almost £3.9 bn in 2001-2. Similarly, extra research funding and more money for standards and access means that universities will get an extra £1bn in spending by 2002, together with £1.4bn for research from the government and Wellcome Trust for research.

Let us imagine two other scenarios. The Liberal Democrats argued for an extra "penny on income tax" at the last election to fund education. Had they done so, there would have been an extra £2bn a year on top of Conservative spending plans - less than half of what we are spending. Had the Conservatives won the election, we would have had even less funding in real terms than in their last Budget in 1997.

Of course we need to make sure as much of the money as possible gets directly to schools - and I have taken steps to ensure that happens. We need to sustain increased investment in the years to come. The prime minister recognises that as much as I do. But it is as absurd to pretend that what is happening now represents little change from the past as it would be to suggest that we didn't need to see more money for education in the future.

 David Blunkett is secretary of state for education.

webTitle: Love letters expose the patriot poet

fields.headline: Love letters expose the patriot poet
fields.standfirst:
Edwardian golden boy Rupert Brooke was cruel and selfish, rejected lover's account suggests

Rupert Brooke

Rupert Brooke Society
fields.trailText:
If I should die, think only this of me:

That there's some corner of a foreign field

That is for ever England.

- from The Soldier by Rupert Brooke
fields.body:
If I should die, think only this of me:

That there's some corner of a foreign field

That is for ever England.

- from The Soldier by Rupert Brooke

Rupert Brooke's image as the great unsullied patriot poet took another dent yesterday when a cache of letters to a previously unknown lover showed him to be cruel, sadistic and unbearably selfish.

The discovery of his passionate correspondence with a young art student, Phyllis Gardner, and her own distressing account of how he dumped her, show the golden boy of Edwardian letters to be a far more complex and less appealing character than the one whose early death came to symbolise the waste of the first world war.

Although Brooke never faced a single bullet - he died on his way to Gallipoli after being bitten by a mosquito - a martyr cult grew up around his "beautiful corpse" and his few slim volumes. Nostalgic poems like The Soldier and Old Vicarage Grantchester, in which he poignantly asked "Is there honey still for tea?", hold a special place in the English psyche.

But what is clear from his letters to Phyllis, and her own long-lost kiss-and-tell, is that there were far more enticing things on the menu at the poet's home near Cambridge, now owned by Jeffrey Archer.

Her 90-page memoir, which was found with the letters in a sealed case in the British Library after being locked away unrecognised for 51 years, tells how the two young "bohemian pagans" once swam naked in the river Cam before making love in a field.

The post-coital glow in several of the letters is palpable, and they also prove that Brooke's most explicit poem, Beauty and Beauty, was written for Phyllis to celebrate their coupling. He also writes her a vivid and highly suggestive letter from his bed describing their love-making: "You are incredibly beautiful when you are naked and your wonderful hair is blowing about you. Fire runs through me, to think of it you devil. I remember every inch of you lying there in that strange light."

But their 18-month affair ended badly in 1913 when as with many of his lovers - male and female - Brooke tired of Phyllis. She claims he tortured her emotionally, was sadistic, selfish and threatening.

A British Library spokesman who has read the text - which is not yet been cleared for release - said: "After treating her very badly he eventually dumped her unceremoniously for another woman who had taken his eye.

"After his death she had flashes of him standing in the middle of her room, and she had difficulty separating the vision from reality," he added. "It agonised her greatly and she nearly went insane."

He said Phyllis wrote the book only three years after Brooke's dead, "so the feelings are still raw. It's pretty visceral stuff." She died in the thirties, her own small reputation resting on a book about wolfhounds.

Nigel Jones, whose recent biography Rupert Brooke: Life, Death and Myth, questioned the man behind the fabled beauty and charm, said the find was "absolute dynamite. This has really thrown open another door on Brooke's quite astoundingly complicated private life. The myth of him as a plaster saint is still very strong. He was in fact both very devious and very randy."

He said the fact that Brooke had a breakdown around the time of the relationship - caused by his former paramour Ka Cox going off with another man - may explain his particularly cruel treatment of Phyllis. "He had a tendency to make overblown wild statements threatening to kill himself or hint that he might kill his lovers, but they were never anything more than rhetoric."

Mr Jones said more than his cruelty, the letters show his gift for secrecy and his ability to manipulate even beyond the grave. (His friend Geoffrey Keynes famously expunged much material likely to be detrimental to his reputation from the poet's own letters after his death.)

"Just when you think his life has been thoroughly raked over, up pops another lover. It is a testament to his ability to compartmentalise his life that we are still discovering new lovers now. He had amazing charisma, and a hold on almost everyone who met him."

Jones said Brooke was such a successful lothario he could run three or four relationships at the same time. He had simultaneous affairs with the Olivier sisters, Bryn and Noel (cousins of the actor Lord Olivier), without either of them knowing. "They would sit around the breakfast table in the morning," said Jones, "each opening billets doux from him, neither aware he was cheating on them both."

Although his early death robbed him of the chance to mature as a poet, Jones insists that "as a letter writer Brooke has few rivals in English literature since Byron".

From Phyllis's descriptions of their romps, it is clear he entertained her in "Byron's pool", a spot at the foot of the Granchester vicarage garden where he also swam naked with the writer Virginia Woolf. According to Jones, it was also there where Brooke loved to show off his unique party trick - diving into the water and emerging with an instant erection. "No one could remain unimpressed by such a feat," said Jones.

Brooke's ambivalent sexuality is a matter of intense academic debate, with some scholars arguing that his affairs with other boys at Rugby school and later at Cambridge are proof of his homosexuality. But Jones said the affair with Phyllis - coming around the same time as relationships with at least four other women - proved that once he "left the exclusive company of men there was no stopping his heterosexual instincts".

Brooke went on to have a child, which he shunned, by a Tahitian woman, Taatamata, the following year during a world tour. His affairs were usually short and intense, and he even came to depise his great love, Ka Cox, after briefly winning her back from the painter Henry Lamb.

The newly-discovered documents were in a parcel deposited with the British Library in 1948 by Phyllis Gardner's sister Delphis, who specified the collection of 50 letters could not be opened for 50 years.

The leather case lay unopened until after the British Library's move to its new home at St Pancras, north London, because it had been catalogued under her name, and made no reference to its explosive revelations about Brooke. Parts of their correspondence will now go on display at the library as part of the Chapter and Verse show which opens today.

'Fire runs through me to think of it'

Extracts from letters between Rupert Brooke and Phyllis Gardner

Well, you strange Phyllis, what I had wanted to say was this; you are incredibly beautiful when you are naked and your wonderful hair is blowing about you.

Fire runs through me, to think of it, you devil. I remember every inch of you lying there in that strange light.

Now I'm ensconced in Berlin, a hideous town but for me. Quiet - only two people I know here. I mean to work like anything for a month.

When shall I see you again. I'm leaving you at your direction to get the Poetry Review. But I copy out here Beauty and Beauty. I told you about it. I write it from memory, so it may not be quite the same as the printed version. But I wanted to give it to you.

You might send me out a few others of your verses.

In Berlin everybody's hair is muddy brown. You're a fine creature. It's funny, that you should be blown together by the winds to be like that.

Write to me, tell me how you are and how London is. I shall write you a letter soon.

Goodbye, golden one.

With love,

Rupert

Phyllis replies:

Bless you, I wanted you to write first and I'm glad you did. Thank you for the poem.

There is a saying that "every woman is at heart a savage" - every man too I suppose. I love the poem. It has a way of ringing through one's head. You're a fine singer.

Write soon.

Phyllis

webTitle: Defector attacks Hague's 'repugnant' stance on race

fields.headline: Defector attacks Hague's 'repugnant' stance on race
fields.standfirst:
Tories in opposition: special report
Race issues in the UK: special report
fields.trailText: Shaun Woodward, the former Tory spin doctor who defected to the Labour party, attacked William Hague yesterday for holding "repugnant" views on race relations.
fields.body:
Shaun Woodward, the former Tory spin doctor who defected to the Labour party, attacked William Hague yesterday for holding "repugnant" views on race relations.

In a Commons debate on the race relations bill, Mr Woodward reeled off recent remarks by senior Tories which he said demonstrated that the party was still playing the race card.

"Such views should be repugnant to any decent person, not championed by the leader of the opposition," he said

Jack Straw yesterday introduced the race relations (amendment) bill, which implements the recommendations of the Macpherson report on the murder of the black teenager Stephen Lawrence.

Mr Woodward told MPs that the fight against racism was being hampered by the Tory leadership's failure to grasp the report's importance. He quoted the shadow cabinet office minister, Andrew Lansley, as saying that immigration was an issue that had "potential to hurt", and the shadow foreign secretary, Francis Maude, as saying that the bill had "very little to do" with most people.

Mr Woodward said: "What an indictment of the role of leadership. Where is the decency in such an admission? Does [Mr Maude] really think that the majority of decent people in Britain are not concerned about the death of Stephen Lawrence?"

He rounded on the shadow home secretary, Ann Widdecombe, for saying that a Tory government would restore the "pernicious and divisive" primary purpose rule, allowing officials in embassies and high commissions to ask couples hoping to settle in Britain intimate questions to discover if their marriage was genuine.

The rightwing Tory MP Gerald Howarth called for abolition of all race relations legislation. He accused Sir Herman Ouseley, head of the commission for racial equality, of racism for saying black children should be taught about black culture.

fields.headline: Cholera strikes disaster island
fields.standfirst:
Aid plea for forgotten island
Mozambique floods: special report
fields.trailText: An outbreak of cholera has struck the Indian Ocean of Madagascar, adding to the plight of thousands of people made homeless by massive flooding caused by the same weather patterns that have devastated Mozambique.
fields.body:
An outbreak of cholera has struck the Indian Ocean of Madagascar, adding to the plight of thousands of people made homeless by massive flooding caused by the same weather patterns that have devastated Mozambique.

About 10,000 cases of the disease have broken out in the last two months, claiming about 700 lives. Aid workers now fear that the rate of incidents could rocket in the insanitary conditions that exist in wide swathes of the island following massive rains and flooding.

Cholera had been eradicated from Madagascar until March last year, when it was reimported from east Africa.

The World Food Programme (WFP) is set to begin an airlift of emergency food rations today in an attempt to help tens of thousands of people trapped by the flooding in remote areas.

The WFP plans to carry 25 tonnes of food to Mahanoro, a town of 30,000 on the east coast, followed by another 375 tonnes to communities in the north-east and west where no aid has yet arrived.

The latest figures suggest that at least 130 people have died and more than 10,000 have been made homeless by two cyclones that ripped across the island.

Cyclone Eline struck last month before moving on to cause devastating floods in Mozambique 400km across the Mozambique Channel. Then Cyclone Gloria hit the north-east of the island last week.

The United Nations has appealed for donations of food, medicines, blankets and water purification tablets. The UN secretary general, Kofi Annan, has warned that the huge scale of the crisis in Mozambique has deflected attention away from the dramatic plight of Madagascar.

So far the extent of the disaster is only partially understood as flooded areas can only be approached by helicopter. It is thought that about 12,000 people are cut off by flooding and are likely to be running out of food and clean water.

Apart from the human suffering, there is likely to have been substantial damage to Madagascar's unique ecosystem.

As the world's fourth largest island, it is home to thousands of plants and animals found nowhere else, including 40 species of lemurs and many types of chameleons.

Eyewitnesses say hundreds of birds and animals - such as the monkey-like lemur - have been spotted dead in the floodwaters.

webTitle: Chemical warfare trials short of volunteers

fields.headline: Chemical warfare trials short of volunteers
fields.standfirst: Poor rewards and overstretched units mean forces personnel are slow to respond to appeals for 'guinea pigs' from Porton Down scientists
fields.trailText: Military scientists have had difficulty in recruiting enough human "guinea pigs" for their chemical warfare experiments in recent years, internal documents from the ministry of defence reveal.
fields.body:
Military scientists have had difficulty in recruiting enough human "guinea pigs" for their chemical warfare experiments in recent years, internal documents from the ministry of defence reveal.

The shortage has slowed the rate of experiments at the secretive Porton Down chemical defence establishment in Wiltshire, a source said.

An official history of the human trials, obtained by the Guardian, catalogues how Porton Down frequently struggled to attract enough volunteers for its experiments between the 1920s and the 1960s.

Its recruitment practices during the cold war are being investigated by Wiltshire police after human guinea pigs complained that they were tricked into taking part in poison gas experiments.

The guinea pigs claim that they had volunteered for research to find a cure for the common cold but ended up in Porton Down's gas chambers.

Wiltshire detectives are also examining the death of Ronald Maddison, 20, an airman who had nerve gas dripped on to his arm in a 1953 trial.

Porton Down is believed to have conducted the longest running programme of chemical warfare experiments on humans in the world. At least 20,000 volunteers have taken part in the past 80 years, although even this number has not been enough to satisfy the scientists' demands.

The volunteers, recruited from military units, often spend around two weeks at Porton Down.

Recent recruitment figures are in annual reports of the establishment's independent ethics committee, which monitors the tests, and have been released to the Liberal Democrats' economy spokesman, Matthew Taylor.

The latest figures show that 72 volunteers took part in the experiments in 1998, two thirds of the overall number requested.

In 1996 50 volunteers were recruited, just under half of the total wanted. In other years since 1994, between 71% and 77% of the number requested took part in tests.

Mr Taylor said yesterday: "Given Porton Down's record, no wonder it's having problems getting volunteers for its experiments.

"Many volunteers from the past are complaining that their health has been damaged by tests at Porton Down. The government has failed to investigate their health problems properly.

"This does not inspire confidence among service men and women to make themselves available for the tests."

The shortage of volunteers has not prevented tests from being completed.

A source close to Porton Down suggested that military personnel were reluctant to volunteer because they were worried about what the scientists would do to them; the financial inducements were poor and their commanding officers were unwilling to let them leave their units.

A spokeswoman said Britain's military commitments abroad, for example in the former Yugoslavia, prevented some personnel from volunteering. "It may not be easy for military units to release service personnel to go to Porton for two week periods." Recruitment had improved in recent months, but figures could not be released.

Compared with the cold war period, Porton Down's programme of experiments has been much scaled down, typically using fewer than 100 volunteers a year.

The volunteers mainly test equipment which protects individuals from chemical and biological weapons. They are also given anti-gas drugs to see if they have any unpleasant side effects. Volunteers have not been exposed to poison gases since 1989.

The official history of the trials - unearthed in the public records office - charts Porton Down's woes in recruiting volunteers.

In 1927 the scientists complained that the flow of subjects for their experiments was "insufficient". In 1937 they were again grumbling about the "irregular supply".

In the late 1940s they lamented that "each year saw the perennial crisis with regard to supply".

By the 1960s the response to appeals for volunteers remained "poor".

It was suggested that the decline in numbers "was closely linked" to the end of national service, which had provided 30% of the human guinea pigs.

fields.headline: Microsoft takes on Playstation
fields.standfirst: But is it any good? Find out here
fields.trailText: Later today in San Jose, California, Bill Gates will announce plans to go head-to-head with Japan's Sony Corporation for the games console market. Gates is speaking at a game developers conference, but Microsoft's console - code-named X-Box - has already been unveiled in Japan and in Europe, because of time differences.
fields.body:
Later today in San Jose, California, Bill Gates will announce plans to go head-to-head with Japan's Sony Corporation for the games console market. Gates is speaking at a game developers conference, but Microsoft's console - code-named X-Box - has already been unveiled in Japan and in Europe, because of time differences.

At the European launch at the Hempel Hotel in London this morning, Microsoft said its console was designed to deliver three times the performance of the Sony PlayStation 2, which went on sale in Japan on March 4. The X-Box will not reach the market until the autumn in 2001.

Microsoft also committed to spending the kind of money needed to attack the console market, which is currently being contested mainly by three Japanese suppliers, Sony, Sega and Nintendo.

J Allard, general manager of the X-Box platform and Microsoft's "Minister of Fun", said: "Microsoft will come out with a branded product and a clear marketing message, and the budget we have is astronomical. The launch of Windows 95 is going to look like a whisper compared with what we are going to do on the X-Box."

The X-Box is based on PC technology including a 600MHz Intel Pentium processor, an Nvidia graphics chip, 3D audio sound, and an 8 gigabyte hard disk drive - the first hard drive to appear in a games console. The operating system - which will be invisible to the user - will be based on Microsoft's latest Windows 2000 and Windows' DirectX games software, though the system demonstrated was running Windows 98.

Allard said the machine had three times the power of Sony's PlayStation 2, which has just gone on sale in Japan, and would "blow people's socks off".

However, the business model is taken directly from the games console market. Like rival machines, the X-Box will be a proprietary design with a fixed specification. It will be manufactured under contract and sold under the Microsoft brand label, not made by a variety of PC manufacturers such as Compaq, Dell, and IBM.

Allard said Microsoft had looked at the possibility of licensing the design but - from the failure of earlier attempts such as the 3D0 console and Philips' CDi (Compact Disc Interactive) - felt this approach would not work in the console market.

The X-Box will not run games written for PCs, and X-Box games will not run on PCs. The two types of device will be kept completely separate. However, games developers will be able to create one game for both machines with only the "finishing off" being different.

"We're not confused: this is a single-function device entirely focused on the games market," said Allard.

Like other console manufacturers, Microsoft plans to sell its machines at a minimal profit, and rely on sales of games to make money.

Microsoft has been selling games for 20 years, starting with a Decathlon sports game for the Apple II, but has not so far had much success in that market.

John O'Rourke, Microsoft's director of games marketing, said Microsoft remained "totally committed to PC gaming" and would increase its efforts in the PC games market, as well as supporting the X-Box.
fields.bodyText: Later today in San Jose, California, Bill Gates will announce plans to go head-to-head with Japan's Sony Corporation for the games console market. Gates is speaking at a game developers conference, but Microsoft's console - code-named X-Box - has already been unveiled in Japan and in Europe, because of time differences. At the European launch at the Hempel Hotel in London this morning, Microsoft said its console was designed to deliver three times the performance of the Sony PlayStation 2, which went on sale in Japan on March 4. The X-Box will not reach the market until the autumn in 2001. Microsoft also committed to spending the kind of money needed to attack the console market, which is currently being contested mainly by three Japanese suppliers, Sony, Sega and Nintendo. J Allard, general manager of the X-Box platform and Microsoft's "Minister of Fun", said: "Microsoft will come out with a branded product and a clear marketing message, and the budget we have is astronomical. The launch of Windows 95 is going to look like a whisper compared with what we are going to do on the X-Box." The X-Box is based on PC technology including a 600MHz Intel Pentium processor, an Nvidia graphics chip, 3D audio sound, and an 8 gigabyte hard disk drive - the first hard drive to appear in a games console. The operating system - which will be invisible to the user - will be based on Microsoft's latest Windows 2000 and Windows' DirectX games software, though the system demonstrated was running Windows 98. Allard said the machine had three times the power of Sony's PlayStation 2, which has just gone on sale in Japan, and would "blow people's socks off". However, the business model is taken directly from the games console market. Like rival machines, the X-Box will be a proprietary design with a fixed specification. It will be manufactured under contract and sold under the Microsoft brand label, not made by a variety of PC manufacturers such as Compaq, Dell, and IBM. Allard said Microsoft had looked at the possibility of licensing the design but - from the failure of earlier attempts such as the 3D0 console and Philips' CDi (Compact Disc Interactive) - felt this approach would not work in the console market. The X-Box will not run games written for PCs, and X-Box games will not run on PCs. The two types of device will be kept completely separate. However, games developers will be able to create one game for both machines with only the "finishing off" being different. "We're not confused: this is a single-function device entirely focused on the games market," said Allard. Like other console manufacturers, Microsoft plans to sell its machines at a minimal profit, and rely on sales of games to make money. Microsoft has been selling games for 20 years, starting with a Decathlon sports game for the Apple II, but has not so far had much success in that market. John O'Rourke, Microsoft's director of games marketing, said Microsoft remained "totally committed to PC gaming" and would increase its efforts in the PC games market, as well as supporting the X-Box.

webTitle: Can Microsoft beat the mighty Playstation?

fields.headline: Can Microsoft beat the mighty Playstation?
fields.standfirst: Microsoft takes on Playstation
fields.trailText: Friday, 4.45pm: Jack Schofield looks at Microsoft's new games machine, the X-box.
fields.body:
Games consoles are getting more powerful; PCs are getting cheaper. What could be more natural than a games console built using cheap PC parts?

That's what Microsoft is proposing with the X-Box, which will do battle with the latest generation of games consoles including the Sony PlayStation 2, Sega Dreamcast and forthcoming Nintendo Dolphin.

Personal computers already have about a third of the games market, and many of the best games: Championship Manager, Civilization, DOOM, Half-Life, The Sims, Quake etc.

However, PCs are expensive - around UKP1,000 for a hot box - and relatively hard to use. Games consoles are much easier to use and they cost a lot less, with prices ranging from about UKP70 to UKP300.

The X-Box has the power of a PC, and will be able to run the most advanced PC-style games. However, its power is packaged to make it as easy to use as a console, and it will have a comparable price.

But the console design also involves making sacrifices. The X-Box will not be able to provide the flexibility, adaptability and upgradeability that makes PCs so useful. Also, the X-Box that ships before Christmas next year will have to be functionally identical to the one that ships in five years time, while the PC design will have gone through another five iterations by then.

Microsoft says it does not see any conflict between the two types of device, and J Allard, general manager of the X-Box platform, says about three-quarters of PC gamers also own a games console. "Sometimes they want to play on their PC and sometimes they want to play on the big TV in the lounge with their chums and a table full of pizza. It's a social thing."

The console's lack of upgradeability leads to breaks in the continuity of the games console market. So far, each new generation of technology has been dominated by a different supplier. First it was Atari, then Nintendo, Sega and, most recently, Sony.

Sony hopes to be the first company to dominate successive generations of hardware with the PlayStation and PlayStation 2. Microsoft plans to stop it.

fields.headline: Seeing red (and purple)
fields.standfirst: Fashion editor  Laura Craik explains why all things bright are beautiful this spring
fields.trailText: Happy, happy, happy! Aren't you? Can't you smell the sweet waft of spring in the air? No? Maybe it's just my colleague's deodorant, then. But for the first time this year, I left the house without a coat and still managed to build up a sweat by the time I reached the tube station.
fields.body:
Happy, happy, happy! Aren't you? Can't you smell the sweet waft of spring in the air? No? Maybe it's just my colleague's deodorant, then. But for the first time this year, I left the house without a coat and still managed to build up a sweat by the time I reached the tube station. Due in no small part to accelerated global warming, March has turned out uncharacteristically mild. And we know what that means. Time for a wardrobe change.

The first thing you'll notice when you hit the high street in pursuit of said wardrobe is the colour and pattern running riot across every shop floor. Black? Fuggedaboudit. Beige? Not even in The Gap. Without the slightest regard for the British public's deep-rooted hatred of anything bright and loud, those optimistic store buyers have thrown caution to the wind and stocked up on the sort of clothes more commonly worn by over-zealous kids' TV presenters on a Saturday morning. There's something childlike in the spirit of this spring's key looks: polka-dots, stripes and bold blocks of colour are very nursery school. Strong, graphic and instantly cheering, they're a joy to behold after autumn's subtle browns, olives and heathery purples.

They are also a nightmare to wear. Let's not pretend otherwise. Unless you're a size six (I don't remember a size six existing in Britain before this spring, yet Miss Selfridge is full of them), stripes and spots will fill you with classic "Do I look fatter than I really am?" anxiety. The trick is to be selective. Top Shop's polka-dot halter is best not contemplated by those of us weighing in above a B cup, but anyone can integrate a spotty chiffon scarf into an outfit. Round your neck or threaded through the loopholes of your jeans, it's an instant moderniser.

Black might make you look thinner, but it is also deeply unflattering to most people's skin tones. Everyone has at least one bright colour that suits them, if only they'd experiment. Now is the time to do so. You might just be pleasantly surprised.

fields.headline: Squeeze me, please me
fields.standfirst: It's clingy, comfortable, sexy, sensible. A must for models and matrons alike. A whisper of science next to your skin.  Susannah Barron  waxes lyrical about Lycra
fields.trailText: In this month's Harper's Bazaar, former New York Post gossip columnist Jeane MacIntosh describes picking up the phone to find a less-than-pleased Mariah Carey on the other end. "Annoyed that I repeatedly referred to her as 'the spandex-sporting sexpot', she called to set the record straight," MacIntosh recalls. " 'I do not wear spandex,' she informed me. 'I may wear Lycra and cotton blends, but never spandex. It makes my skin break out.' "
fields.body:
In this month's Harper's Bazaar, former New York Post gossip columnist Jeane MacIntosh describes picking up the phone to find a less-than-pleased Mariah Carey on the other end. "Annoyed that I repeatedly referred to her as 'the spandex-sporting sexpot', she called to set the record straight," MacIntosh recalls. " 'I do not wear spandex,' she informed me. 'I may wear Lycra and cotton blends, but never spandex. It makes my skin break out.' "

MacIntosh ran a clarification the next day but perhaps she needn't have. Lycra is, in fact, a brand of spandex, the term used in Canada and the US for what the rest of the world knows as elastene. But the pop diva is not the only one to get it wrong. In the 40 years since it was invented, Lycra has so permeated mainstream consciousness that, like Hoover, it's often mistaken for a generic term.

Can you believe a fabric with such modern connotations is already 40? Lycra was invented in 1958 by Joe Shivers, an engineer for science company DuPont. Originally known as Fiber K, it was given the name Lycra precisely because it didn't mean anything: DuPont had a computer programme designed to come up with five- or six-letter words that were meaningless in every language and therefore easier to sell globally. Once christened, Lycra began to replace rubber in corsets; in 1962, it appeared in support tights. Swimwear came next (1974), followed by sheer hosiery (1979), sportswear (1985), clothing (1993) and wool (1996). These days, you can find the magical stretchy fibre in everything from Gucci shoes and Hugo Boss suits to your humble M&S knickers.

To describe somebody as "Lycra-clad" is to conjure a picture of 80s-style black leggings and tight stretchy tops. But the fabric is actually a lot more versatile than that. As DuPont Lycra global brand manager Linda Kearns points out: "Stretchy and clingy don't have to go together."

Lycra isn't used as a fabric on its own but is blended with other fibres, such as cotton, nylon and wool, where its impressive stretching capabilities (it can stretch up to 600% and return to its original shape) do more than simply make things tighter. Certainly 20% Lycra content will keep your swimwear clinging in all the right places; slightly less will be enough to mould your leggings to your body. But add just 2% to a pair of khakis and you'll stop them bagging at the knees; add a smidgeon to a full skirt and you'll simply improve its drape; blend with linen and you will give the famously crinkly fibre new crease-resistant properties.

All of which is certainly impressive and welcome in modern wardrobes. But why is Lycra believed to do this better than any other brand of elastene? Mariah Carey is not the only one who thinks it's somehow superior to every other stretchy fibre - we all look for LYCRA in our knickers.

According to Kearns, this is down to two factors: Lycra's unique formulations are obviously important, but DuPont also spends more on research and development, she says, than all its competitors combined. As a result, it has come up with such innovations as leather with Lycra and the sportswear fibre LYCRAPOWER, said to improve performance by up to 30%.

As for Lycra's relationship with its partners: "We don't just stop at selling the fibre." DuPont stays with them all the way, getting involved in everything from quality specifications to marketing of the finished garments. The company wants to be able to guarantee the quality of everything that has a Lycra swing ticket attached.

Marketing has obviously had a lot to do with it. It is DuPont's business to make you care what brand of manmade fibre keeps your underwear stretchy. Over the years, the company has actively pursued the fashion vote; it enlisted legendary photographer Richard Avedon to shoot a 1994 promotional campaign and continues to seek celebrity endorsements. This year, DuPont sponsored the glossy fashion tome Millennium Mode, which featured designers' visions for the 21st century, while the Lycra website proudly quotes the likes of Calvin Klein ("Lycra isn't in or out of fashion. It's a way of life") and American designer Mark Eisen ("Lycra has changed the entire dynamics of fit").

The teen market, meanwhile, is being convinced of the benefits of Lycra thanks to the brand's sponsorship of events such as Summer Music Mania, featuring the likes of Britney Spears. "The teen audience is influencing fashion trends around the world," Kearns explains. "We want them to understand that not all stretch is created equal."

Do the kids care? DuPont thinks so. Recent research commissioned by the company found close to 40% of young people in Europe and 50% in the US claim they check the fibre content of the clothes they buy. Educate them young and, presumably, they'll be looking for Lycra in everything.

fields.headline: Pucci
fields.trailText: Pucci is enjoying a moment. The label's psychedelic swirls are everywhere this spring. At the just-gone autumn/winter collections, Donatella Versace and Allessandro Dell'Acqua used Pucci-esque prints on silk blouses, while Missoni mixed them with its trademark zigzags for extra graphic appeal.
fields.body:
Pucci is enjoying a moment. The label's psychedelic swirls are everywhere this spring. At the just-gone autumn/winter collections, Donatella Versace and Allessandro Dell'Acqua used Pucci-esque prints on silk blouses, while Missoni mixed them with its trademark zigzags for extra graphic appeal. On the high street, a million Pucci-inspired hanky tops scream "Buy me!" They're the perfect bright accompaniment to your dark-wash denim jeans.

Emilio Pucci died 10 years ago: he fell into fashion by accident when, in 1947, a photographer from Harper's Bazaar snapped the dashing aristocrat on the slopes of St Moritz. The ski-wear he was sporting was his own design and soon generated a lot of interest. Inspired by Renaissance and local Italian art, Pucci went on to create graphically printed fabric in bright and pastel colours, turning it into featherlight dresses that caught the imagination of the burgeoning 60s jetset. Soon the print was appearing on luggage, shoes, swimwear and nightwear. Pucci even made it to the moon: the Apollo 15 crew took one of his flags up with them.

Pucci doesn't yet have the clout of Gucci, but watch this space. Last month fashion behemoth LVMH bought a 67% share in the company, which can only mean world domination is soon to follow. New stores and new products are planned, and thankfully we don't now have to schlep to Florence or New York (the only two stand-alone stores in the world) to get our Pucci fix. A new Pucci concession opens at Harvey Nichols next week. Get some in!

fields.headline: Most everywhere:  skin jewellery
fields.trailText: Bored of clunky bangles and chunky chokers? This spring, the fasherati are travelling light
fields.body:
Bored of clunky bangles and chunky chokers? This spring, the fasherati are travelling light: they don't want to be weighed down by heavy jewellery when there are far more artful ways to decorate their persons. Their latest obsession is Skin Jewellery, ingeniously created by Londoner J Maskrey and being used by more designers than you can shake a glitter stick at. Models wore them at the Emanuel Ungaro couture show in January, they appeared on Tristan Webber's catwalk in February and Sonia Rykiel has used them to spice up her latest ad campaign.

So what exactly are they? Basically, adhesive stickers covered in diamanté jewels/feathers/Swarovski crystals, shaped into the most delicate flowers/ butterflies/graphic shapes. They can be applied to any part of the body: the shoulder is a favourite spot, especially when worn with a modish asymmetric top. Celebrity endorsement comes from the likes of Lauryn Hill, Nicole Kidman, Bjork, Shirley Manson and photographer Mario Testino.

They have become so popular, in fact, that J Maskrey held her first Skin Jewellery show at London Fashion Week last month. They look great, they're original and, with a bit of Pritt stick, you can re-use them as often as you like. From £40, from Browns Focus, 0171 491 7833.

fields.headline: Several injured in Waterloo crash
fields.standfirst:
South West Trains
British Transport Police
fields.trailText: Britain's railways came under renewed questioning today after a crash at Waterloo station that resulted in minor injuries to at least 25 people.
fields.body:
Britain's railways came under renewed questioning today after a crash at Waterloo station that resulted in minor injuries to at least 25 people.

In the latest blow to the country's embattled rail system, a South West Trains service hit a stationary train as it entered a platform at the busy terminus at about 1.50pm.

A British transport police official said: "A train hit another stationary train as it arrived at the station. About 30 passengers were on board and there were a large number of injuries but they are not believed to be serious."

Ambulance crews were at the scene on platform five treating whiplash-type injuries, he added. A London ambulance service official said there were three stretcher cases and 15 others had minor injuries.

Ten ambulances and two motor cycle paramedics went to the scene after the service was alerted.

South West Trains said the incident involved an empty train which had travelled to Waterloo from nearby Clapham. The train was due to link up with a train from Hampton Court to form the 1352 service from Waterloo to Chessington.

A spokesman for Scotland Yard said: "At about 2pm, police were called by the London ambulance service in response to reports of an incident at Waterloo. At this early stage, it appears a slow moving train coming into the station was in collision with a stationary train at platform five. This second train was empty. We are told that there are about 25 walking wounded, and no serious injuries."

The British rail system came under intense criticism after the train crash just outside Paddington last October that killed 31 people.

Last month, a report into the Southall train crash cited a breakdown of the safety system and the fragmentation of the rail industry since privatisation for the 1997 accident.

The two incidents and numerous lapses in rail safety have brought new pressures on the government to reverse the rail sell-off.
