webTitle: Ready to rumble: the life and fights of Muhammed Ali

fields.headline: Ready to rumble: the life and fights of Muhammed Ali
fields.standfirst: In this exclusive online essay taken from the current edition of the London Review of Books, John Upton considers the boxing phenomenon Muhammed Ali
fields.trailText: John Upton on the greatest boxer of them all
fields.body:
King of the World: Muhammad Ali and the Rise of an American Hero by David Remnick.
(Picador, 326 pp., £14.99, 22 October 1999, 0 330 37188 6) Buy it at BOL

Muhammad Ali:Ringside edited by John Miller and Aaron Kenedi.
(Virgin, 128 pp., £14.99, 16 September 1999, 1 85227 852 8) Buy it at BOL

'Some day they're gonna write a blues song for fighters. It'll just be for slow guitar, soft trumpet and a bell.' So said Sonny Liston in 1962, after he'd beaten his closest rival, Floyd Patterson, and become Heavyweight Champion of the World. Liston was not known for his sensitivity. Indeed, the facts of his life read like a blueprint for a Hollywood film of the flawed fighter. He was born in Arkansas, the 24th of 25 children. He never knew the date or exact place of his birth, and he was illiterate. He was sent out to work in the fields at the age of eight, picking cotton, peanuts and sweet potato. He was beaten prodigiously by his father and the welts he received were still visible on his adult body. When his mother left Arkansas to find work in St Louis he followed her, but he was unable to hold down a job and turned to crime. By the age of 16 Liston was over six feet tall and weighed more than 200 pounds. He was violent as well as strong and earned his first title, that of 'Number One Negro' on the St Louis police wanted list, in 1949. In 1950, he was convicted of armed robbery (his haul was $37). He was introduced to boxing at the Missouri State Penitentiary.

On his release, Liston began a professional boxing career while at the same time working as a 'head breaker' for the Mafia. He was an outstanding success in both roles. In 1956, he was convicted of assaulting a policeman and received a nine-month prison sentence, after which sabbatical he became far more deeply involved with New York mobsters and made Philadelphia his home. He was by now loathed by the press and feared by the public. When he won the world title in 1962 he flew back to his adoptive city expecting a reception committee. There was no one at the airport to greet him and in 1963 he left Philadelphia in disgust, remarking: 'I'd rather be a lamp-post in Denver than mayor of Philadelphia.'

If Liston led a complicated public life, his arch rival's inner life was far from straightforward. Floyd Patterson grew up in Brooklyn. 'I don't like that boy!' he would say to his mother, pointing to a photograph of himself. At the age of nine, he took the photograph down and scratched crosses over the face. He, too, turned to petty crime and was sent to reform school. This proved to be a redemptive experience and when he returned to New York he took up boxing, under the tutelage of Cus D'Amato at the Gramercy Gym: in 1952 he won a gold medal at the Helsinki Olympics. He was much smaller than many of his opponents and learned to overcome this handicap by leaping into them - almost the Patterson trademark. He became World Heavyweight Champion at 21, the youngest there had ever been.

Patterson's neuroses pursued him into adulthood: he was so prone to introspection that boxing writers nicknamed him Freud Patterson. He worried about his opponents getting hurt and refused to make eye contact with them at weigh-ins or press conferences, saying: 'We're going to fight, which is not a nice thing.' A devout Roman Catholic, he took it on himself to be the champion of Christendom and the Civil Rights movement. When he was beaten by Liston, he pasted on a false beard - he had brought one with him in case of defeat - and took a flight to Madrid, where he walked around the poor quarters of the city faking a limp and eating only soup 'because that's what old men do'.

Patterson and Liston dominated boxing in the 1950s and early 1960s, and in the eyes of the public, all was well with the world. In one corner, Patterson, integrationist, scared of upsetting the white neighbours, grateful for his opportunities. In the other, Liston, who was without politics but stood for black criminality, sexual menace and resentment. Even better, the two men knew their place. Patterson was summoned to the White House before the Liston fight: 'You've got to beat this guy,' JFK told him, showing what could be gained by conforming to white rules. Liston's behaviour simply affirmed the stereotype of the 'bad nigger', justifying discrimination against those who stepped out of line.

Enter Muhammad Ali, who over the next few years was to change the face of boxing. David Remnick's book in fact concentrates on the two astonishing fights Ali had with Liston (Ali won the title in the first and defended it successfully in the second), and on the relationship between Ali, Liston and Patterson. For Remnick, as for most people, there is no one greater than Ali: he is not just a boxing phenomenon but a figure commanding world-wide veneration. He does not come out of the book as well as he might, however. So perfect is he made to seem that his character lacks vibrancy. Remnick's reader knows that every adversary will be conquered or contained by a mixture of charm, mischief and grace. And so Liston, Patterson and other characters on the periphery seem to have more life.

In their fighting days the reverse was the case. The public felt they understood the two older boxers, and it was Ali who had the room to experiment, to create uncertainty in the minds of both the public and his fellow boxers. To watch Prince Naseem or Chris Eubank today is to see a clumsy rehash of Ali in the early years, when he seemed so threatening, so unconstrained by the social rules willingly or unconsciously accepted by Liston or Patterson. The space in which imagination and conjecture could float freely has long since been filled in, however. Nowadays, Ali is a secular saint and every off-the-cuff remark he ever made has been set down as Holy Writ. It is out of the sadness or failure of his contemporaries that genuine expressions of humanity are more likely to emerge.

Cassius Clay was born in 1942 into the Southern black middle class. He seems to have had a heightened racial awareness from an early age. As a four-year-old he asked his father: 'Daddy, I go to the grocery and the grocery man is white. The bus driver is white. What do the coloured people do?' When he was 12, his bike was stolen and he went to complain to a police officer who happened to run a boxing gym. He was persuaded to try the sport and quickly showed himself to be a natural. He also had the rigid discipline to go with his talent, and became obsessed with training. He was never violent outside the ring and was such a model student in every way except the academic that when he didn't get the results needed to graduate from high school, his headmaster made an impassioned speech to the rest of the staff: 'One day our greatest claim to fame is going to be that we knew Cassius Clay or taught him . . . Do you think I'm going to be the principal of a school that Cassius Clay didn't finish? If every teacher here fails him, he's still not going to fail. He's not going to fail in my school. I'm going to say I taught him!' You can almost hear the opening number of 'Ali the Musical', as the headmaster and a troupe of dancing teachers prepare to sing the showstopper: 'He's a knock-out not a drop-out.' Clay graduated and went on to win an Olympic title in Rome in 1960.

When he turned professional, he won backing from a group of wealthy Louisville businessmen. A few years earlier he might have followed Liston into the arms of the Mob: instead, he was drawn to the Nation of Islam, which sustained him spiritually and socially. In 1964, he earned the right to challenge Liston. Both fighters were intensely disliked by the public, with Clay slightly ahead on points. The fight was viewed as a dangerous mismatch and there were real fears that Clay would be seriously injured. At the weigh-in he worked himself into such hysteria that his pulse rose from 54 to 120 beats a minute: 'I'm ready to rumble now! I can beat you any time, chump! Somebody's gonna die at ringside tonight! I am a great performer! You're too ugly! You are a bear! You're a chump, a chump, a chump,' he ranted.

At the end of round four, Ali began screaming that he had a burning sensation in his eyes: Liston's corner had rubbed an ointment of some description on his gloves in order to blind Ali. Ali sat on his stool demanding that the fight be stopped; Angelo Dundee, his trainer, sent him back out. Ali boxed the fifth round almost blind, then recovered his sight and began to dominate. Liston retired after the sixth round, claiming a shoulder injury.

The rematch in 1965 was even more controversial. Halfway through the first round, Liston fell to the canvas; there had been a vague movement from Ali but no visible punch. The angle of the shot in the video record of the fight makes it impossible to determine whether the knockout was the result of a perfectly timed punch or of a word whispered in Liston's ear before the fight by the Mafia or the Nation of Islam.

More than any other sportsman, the boxer lives his life in a series of intense exposures. But as soon as a punch is translated into prose, its force is severely diminished. Attempts to represent the impact of a fist on the temple or nose, and the physical and psychological effect this has on the boxer, have led to a whole school of waffle. Remnick captures the seedy machismo of the downtown gym while at the same time expressing a sense of innocent wonder at the achievements of these freakishly gifted men. He is conscious of boxing's literary tradition and is at pains to distance himself from those among his predecessors whose writing appears to be the product of an unholy union between Papa Hemingway and the features editor of Euro Boy. Neither does he fall entirely into the boxing-as-metaphor school, as favoured by macho liberals, who use boxing as a way of running with the homeboys without having to leave the safety of their desks.

There's a convenient ambivalence in those who look for deeper meaning in boxing. If their chosen hero prevails, they can nail their colours to his mast; if he self-destructs, an instrument is created with which to chart the demise of the American dream. The boxing world's association with organised crime, drugs and race inspires dark feelings and is an element of the harsh romance that white writers pursue with black ghetto life. In contrast, the relationship British heavyweight champions have enjoyed with the nation has been - superficially at least - far more harmonious. From Our 'Enry through Gary Mason and Big Frank Bruno (but not Joe Bugner, who was Hungarian, refused to play the game and was disliked by all on both counts) the cult of the deferential, smiling bruiser still holds sway. We expect our fighters to behave like Sergeant Paine in The Third Man who punches the drunk Holly Martins to the floor before picking him up and dusting him down, all under the approving eye of his commanding officer.

Issues of race and class form a second narrative strain in Remnick's book, which recalls incidents from boxing's racist past, as when the great Jack Johnson entered the ring to chants of 'Kill the nigger!' Ali's antics caused a sort of panic, disguised as abhorrence of his undignified behaviour. The conservative fight establishment still held Joe 'He's a credit to his race, the human race' Louis up as the yardstick by which to judge behaviour outside the ring. Ali drove a pink bus with 'The World's Most Colourful Fighter' painted on its side, while turning from the wheel to lecture his travelling companions; he ambushed Sonny Liston at his house in the middle of the night (Liston's greeting a pithy, 'What you want, you black motherfucker?'); he was given to manic outbursts of verse. In almost every way, he flew in the face of what was to be expected from a black man. The old order's failure to come to terms with the new was well illustrated by the differing reactions of Liston and Ali on encountering the Beatles. The Louisville Lip engaged in cool banter with John and Ringo. Liston's reaction, like his boxing style, was rather blunt. 'Are those the motherfuckers that everyone's been talking about?' he asked when he saw them on the Ed Sullivan Show. 'My dog plays drums better than the kid with the big nose.'

After he'd beaten Liston, Ali officially proclaimed his adherence to Islam - or rather, the Nation of Islam. It was Malcolm X's view that the Nation manipulated Ali, just as other boxers were manipulated by other pressure groups, but the bravery he showed in refusing to go to Vietnam, for example, is not in doubt. With an IQ of 78 he was initially classified as unfit to serve in the Army. It was only when the conflict escalated that standards were lowered sufficiently to make him eligible for active service. Thanks to a ruling by the Supreme Court he didn't serve any of his prison sentence but he was stripped of his titles, lost his licence to box in America and was placed under surveillance by the FBI. On the other hand, his substantive contribution to black politics was much less than is frequently asserted. More generally, his physical achievements have come to be seen as conscious political acts, just as his good looks were somehow taken as evidence of moral stature. This is not to dismiss his significance - he attracted enormous attention to the black cause - but Remnick allows him to overshadow the period in which he rose to prominence. Like the rest of us, he is mesmerised, and with good reason: watch footage from the fights - Ali's wide eyes, the impact of his punch - and just for a second, between the flashes of ringside cameras and the wreaths of cigar smoke, it's impossible not to see this heroic prodigy as the embodiment of hope and freedom. Here, though, is the difficulty: the phenomenon of Ali is inseparably tied to physical prowess. Boxing is a visceral, visual experience akin to dancing or bullfighting. You have to see Ali to understand his impact in and out of the ring. The photographs in Muhammad Ali: Ringside go some way to illustrating the hold he has over many people. Each one is a devotional tableau, with an essay in tribute printed alongside. The essays themselves (all reprints) are the full hagiographic shilling, written by the usual suspects - Mailer, Alex Haley, Joyce Carol Oates - but the pictures do manage to convey something of Ali's tremendous physical presence.

Take the picture on page 17. In it, Ali is wearing a white towelling dressing-gown and is baring his teeth, his top lip tucked up Jimmy Cagney style. His expression is a combination of manic elation and apprehension. He exudes a barely controlled, barely understood humour, but no aggression. A man is standing behind him, his face obscured, his arms wrapped around Ali, whether to restrain or protect him. Ali is pointing to someone off camera and in his eyes I imagine I can see the relief of a child who has been saved from himself. This childishness was carried over with destructive effect into the ring, where punches of massive force were flicked from his body without any apparent effort, in comparison with the jarring haymakers thrown by Liston or, later, Joe Frazier.

In another photograph from the same decade, Sonny Liston stands square on to the camera, on the scales at a weigh-in. We are drawn to his massive biceps, trapeziuses and hands like shovels. Around him stand his disciples and members of his entourage, staring at the scales. Some are wearing pork-pie hats, others thin black ties or sunglasses. Liston's eyes look downwards and to the side: he is staring at an intruder, at Ali, whose head and torso are poking through the forest of bodies. He, too, is examining the scales but with an altogether different expression on his face, the overly sincere look of the practical joker. Liston's face shows wariness and bafflement in equal measure and, below the surface, the aggression of a king insulted in his own court.

Remnick does not deal with the subsequent 20 years of Ali's career: with the fights of the 1970s - the 'Rumble in the Jungle' and the 'Thrilla in Manila'. His fights against Frazier were in fact the zenith of his career and he was never the same after them. The later, farcical fights that proved so disastrous for his health do not figure, nor does the change in the public's perception of him, as the uppity nigger who became a symbol of global peace. By the end of his career, Ali had fought 61 professional fights, of which he won 56 and lost five. He had won the world heavyweight championship three times.

Remnick's triumvirate continue to fulfil their allotted roles right to the end of the book. Ali was still the non-pareil who performed magic tricks and played practical jokes when Remnick went to interview him in Atlanta in 1996, an autumnal encounter well described in Remnick's wistful, adulatory prose. Sonny Liston meanwhile, after working as an enforcer and declining as a boxer, was found dead in his bedroom in January 1971. The police discovered a small amount of marijuana, heroin and a syringe; a revolver and a glass of vodka stood next to his bed. The post-mortem recorded the presence of heroin in the body. The most common theory is that a contract killer, possibly a policeman, gave him a lethal dose of the drug. In 1996, his spiritual successor, Iron Mike Tyson, laid flowers on his grave at the Paradise Memorial Gardens, Las Vegas.

Floyd Patterson retired from boxing in 1972. In 1995, he was appointed to a sinecure as the head of the New York State Athletic Commission. In 1998, he gave evidence in legal proceedings concerning 'ultimate fighting', a hybrid of brawling and martial arts that is banned in New York. He was cross-examined by counsel for the promoters of the sport and could not remember whom he had fought for the heavyweight title, the names of his fellow commissioners or even the telephone number of his office. Patterson resigned, devastated. He had once again failed the establishment whose acceptance he had always sought.

He, too, is examining the scales but with an altogether different expression on his face, the overly sincere look of the practical joker. Liston's face shows wariness and bafflement in equal measure and, below the surface, the aggression of a king insulted in his own court. Remnick does not deal with the subsequent 20 years of Ali's career: with the fights of the 1970s - the 'Rumble in the Jungle' and the 'Thrilla in Manila'. His fights against Frazier were in fact the zenith of his career and he was never the same after them. The later, farcical fights that proved so disastrous for his health do not figure, nor does the change in the public's perception of him, as the uppity nigger who became a symbol of global peace. By the end of his career, Ali had fought 61 professional fights, of which he won 56 and lost five. He had won the world heavyweight championship three times. Remnick's triumvirate continue to fulfil their allotted roles right to the end of the book. Ali was still the non-pareil who performed magic tricks and played practical jokes when Remnick went to interview him in Atlanta in 1996, an autumnal encounter well described in Remnick's wistful, adulatory prose. Sonny Liston meanwhile, after working as an enforcer and declining as a boxer, was found dead in his bedroom in January 1971. The police discovered a small amount of marijuana, heroin and a syringe; a revolver and a glass of vodka stood next to his bed. The post-mortem recorded the presence of heroin in the body. The most common theory is that a contract killer, possibly a policeman, gave him a lethal dose of the drug. In 1996, his spiritual successor, Iron Mike Tyson, laid flowers on his grave at the Paradise Memorial Gardens, Las Vegas. Floyd Patterson retired from boxing in 1972. In 1995, he was appointed to a sinecure as the head of the New York State Athletic Commission. In 1998, he gave evidence in legal proceedings concerning 'ultimate fighting', a hybrid of brawling and martial arts that is banned in New York. He was cross-examined by counsel for the promoters of the sport and could not remember whom he had fought for the heavyweight title, the names of his fellow commissioners or even the telephone number of his office. Patterson resigned, devastated. He had once again failed the establishment whose acceptance he had always sought.  To read more online essays from the current edition of the London Review of Books visit the LRB. webTitle: Wrong reaction to Japan's nuclear fears

fields.headline: Wrong reaction to Japan's nuclear fears
fields.trailText: I was credited with having "discovered that BNFL was paying the foreign office" to meet the costs of their secondee in the Tokyo embassy (BNFL pays to put own man in Tokyo embassy, March 8). In fact I first learned of it at a public meeting in London on Monday. But I have long been concerned that the advice and information from the embassy has been unduly favourable to BNFL. When Thorp's fate was being discussed in the early 1990s, I found that officials in London had a lop-sided view that the Japanese government and industry were solidly behind Thorp.
fields.body:
I was credited with having "discovered that BNFL was paying the foreign office" to meet the costs of their secondee in the Tokyo embassy (BNFL pays to put own man in Tokyo embassy, March 8). In fact I first learned of it at a public meeting in London on Monday. But I have long been concerned that the advice and information from the embassy has been unduly favourable to BNFL. When Thorp's fate was being discussed in the early 1990s, I found that officials in London had a lop-sided view that the Japanese government and industry were solidly behind Thorp.

As I knew this to be wrong, I wrote to the FO. I found that opinion in Tokyo was divided. One camp believed setbacks in Europe "could give strength to nuclear opposition in Japan and make it even more difficult to proceed with the [Rokkasho-mura] reprocessing plant". The other argued that "Japanese nuclear and foreign policy interests are already being badly damaged by the coming expansion of reprocessing and that problems might be eased by the demise of European programmes."

I also pointed out that "when asked how Japan might react to a decision by the British government not to operate Thorp, the answer was usually the same - they would be accommodating providing that the British helped them with spent fuel storage".

A main argument in Whitehall for allowing Thorp to operate was that Britain's relations with Japan would be jeopardised by its abandonment. I have never believed this. Any setback would have been temporary and many in Tokyo would have been relieved to find the "plutonium pressure" lifted. By precipitating the downfall of Rokkasho-mura, utilities would have saved a vast amount of money and attention would have had to focus on developing realistic waste management policies.

There is still a deal to be struck with Japan that would save everyone a great deal of bother while bringing BNFL safe profits. The spent fuel delivered to Sellafield would be stored there long-term, leaving the option of returning it later. The recent decision to return defective fuel to Britain can be seen as the opening manoeuvre in a belated effort by Japanese utilities to achieve a sensible outcome.

Prof William Walker University of St Andrews

fields.headline: Miss Wyoming by Douglas Coupland
fields.standfirst:
Flamingo (£9.99) digested in the style of the original
Buy it at BOL
fields.trailText: Two Hollywood bit-part players take an airbrush to their lives and journey through shopping malls, fast-food outlets and a glitzkrieg of self-consciously slick phrasemaking in search of redemption.
fields.body:
Susan Colgate and John Johnson broke Hollywood's golden rule. They walked to a restaurant in LA. But that wasn't all. Three years ago, Susan Colgate, the utensilised, polymered, tetracyclined princess of Tinseltown trailer-park trash, walked out of her life. She had had enough of out-Barbieing Barbie after Marilyn, her mom, had plasticised her through the teen pageant circuit. She finally ditched her Mom at the same time she ditched Miss USA Teen but found new meaninglessness in the soap, Meet The Blooms. When that bombed, she married gay Brit Thrash Metal star, Chris Thraice, for a Hollywood smokescreen deal worth $10,000 per month.

Her needle was well into the red, way past empty, so when her plane crashed and she was the only survivor amid a body zone of scorched, dismembered flesh, Susan reckoned she could just get lost. One year later, she reappeared; the media sucked insatiably at her resurrection but she kept her story unsouled.

Johnson was an action film star (Bel Air PI and Bel Air PI 2) addicted to hard sex and harder drugs. But it was flu not methamphetamine that almost killed him, and while in Cedars-Sinai he had a vision of Susan. When he got out he gave away his designer life to rinse his soul in a cold, clear lake.

He set out on the road. He ate out of dumpsters. He slept under bridges. He met Nobodies. He went nowhere. His skin turned into pig leather and he didn't learn a goddamn thing. One morning, he realised Susan hadn't been a vision; he'd been watching a pixilated rerun of Meet The Blooms. So he went home.

California had only one taboo: loneliness. Johnson had seen it in the anti-matter of Susan's eyes and believed they could connect. After his lunch with Susan, he got her number from Ryan, another Susaphile, at the video store but she never called him back. This time she really had gone missing.

Susan had spent most of the year after the air crash reclused with Eugene Lindsay, a mail fraudster and former beauty pageant judge. She got pregnant. Eugene died in an explosion so Susan kept on driving to hole up with Randy, a four-time loser and cyber rumour monger, who had once left a poem to Suze near the crash site. Eugene junior was born that night. Two months later, the day after her mom won a $4m settlement from the airline for her daughter's death, Susan turned herself in. Eugene Junior remained a secret; pure, untainted by the talons of the talentless. Until Marilyn found out and kidnapped him. John and Ryan tracked Marilyn down to Wyoming; so too did Susan.

They all met at high noon on a garage forecourt. Susan and John headed back west into the deep, healing amber glow of the sub-atomic half-life of the LA sunset.

And if you really are pressed: The digested read, digested

webTitle: Exhilarating, drunkenly dangerous and wholly absorbing

fields.headline: Exhilarating, drunkenly dangerous and wholly absorbing
fields.standfirst: Tim Waterstone, Chairman, HMV Media Group
fields.trailText: We're asked to describe the best - or worst - financial decision we've ever made. I suppose I should be reticent and modest in the English way, and tell you of the several disasters I've had with my houses, buying, as I have, every single time at the very top of the market, and then selling just at the moment when it has hit the very bottom.
fields.body:
We're asked to describe the best - or worst - financial decision we've ever made. I suppose I should be reticent and modest in the English way, and tell you of the several disasters I've had with my houses, buying, as I have, every single time at the very top of the market, and then selling just at the moment when it has hit the very bottom.

Or about one of the many little investments I have made over the years in what have turned out to be perfectly hopeless business start-ups. To this day a shiver comes over me when I pass a certain little publisher's office tucked away in a South Kensington mews.

Or the corner site in Chelsea where a picture framer and art gallery business - supposed to be the first of a national, nay international chain - folded in rather less time than it is taking to write this piece.

But I'm going to be un-English and un-reticent and un-amusing and honest, and say that overwhelmingly the best financial decision I've ever made in my life or indeed decision of any sort, was to follow my sacking by WH Smith in 1982 with the creation of Waterstone's a few months later.

I was so completely broke at that time that it wasn't so much courage I needed to get Waterstone's on its journey as a bland indifference to my fate. Matched up with a desire to go down, if I was to go down, in a happy haze of doing what I really wanted to do, in style, in perfect content, and surrounded by colleagues whose company I really enjoyed.

Once started, of course, the journey was exhilarating, drunkenly dangerous and wholly absorbing. The happy haze of bland content was replaced immediately by a raw determination of all of us to build Waterstone's to become in time the biggest player around. We already thought of ourselves as being the best. Modesty - see above - was never perhaps our strongest suit. Nor measured caution. At times we went far too fast at it. But got there we did.

The original investors with me in Waterstone's, who paid 10p to 12p for their shares, were given the opportunity to exit ten years later for well over £5. So starting Waterstone's was a good financial decision not just for me but for everyone (including many of the staff) who took a punt.

webTitle: Take time out on Lastminute dot.com

fields.headline: Take time out on Lastminute dot.com
fields.standfirst:
Wait and see is the best advice
E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Investors looking for a last minute view on whether they should be throwing money at Lastminute.com - the online retailer which yesterday upped its flotation price by a cool 66% to £520m - need some sensible advice, such as "don't bother".
fields.body:
Investors looking for a last minute view on whether they should be throwing money at Lastminute.com - the online retailer which yesterday upped its flotation price by a cool 66% to £520m - need some sensible advice, such as "don't bother".

But then these are not sensible times. At one end of the spectrum we have the grotesque sight of the old-new media, known as television, finally catching up with the story that a football club named Manchester United is now worth £1bn on the back of its internet-related prospects.

Suddenly the whole new economy needs discussing, and so a good selection of our most esteemed broadcasters have been queuing up this week to declare their incredulity that something which loses money, such as a dot com firm, can possibly have a "value."

They have decided the country has gone potty, and they want Gordon Brown to do something about it.

At the other end of the spectrum there are those legions of greedy, greedy stock punters who set up an online broking account 20 minutes ago and think that by playing this "technology stocks only go up" game they will be able to retire some time around lunchtime on Tuesday.

Somewhere in between these two extremes of outrage and indulgence, the basics about why stock markets exist and how they function have been lost. Equities carry a risk premium because businesses can and do go down the pan - and this fact applies as much to Lastminute.com as any other company.

Lastminute's numbers defy traditional analysis and even stretch the newly hatched internet valuation models.

Everyone gasped when Freeserve joined the market at a price which valued each customer at about £1,000 - but the share price still multiplied more than sixfold before the recent slump. Lastminute, meanwhile, is carrying a "per customer" price tag of close to £20,000.

The extraordinary demand for a piece of the float - which has pushed the price up - has been driven not only by the American experience of soaraway public offerings but also the tendency closer to home among middle-aged newspaper City editors to get all excited over the fact that Lastminute was co- founded by a 27-year-old woman with blonde hair, Martha Lane Fox.

So we can assume that when trading in the new shares kicks off on Tuesday, the price will go up - probably substantially. All those investors allotted shares will make a quick paper turn - although the raw size of the profit tends to shrink as the number of investors applying for stock rises, cutting allocations as it does.

An alternative scenario might be the discovery that the web deforms babies, or some other crash-inducing event. The talented and charming Martha, indeed, may turn out to be a man. Equities carry risk.

Lastminute.com has a business. It reckons it can make money selling all manner of things to asset-rich or time-poor customers around the world - at the last minute.

The idea itself and the infrastucture built so far has a value - and that value may prove to be many times the flotation price. But serious investors should just stand back from the frenzy of anticiption, hype and counter-claim - all mixed in with those apocalyptic predicitons of financial meltdown - and wait.

Shares in Lastminute.com may not be as cheap in a month's time, but the "risk" will be a lot easier to assess.

Old passions

The Blair administration is passionate in its support for the concept that the British economy should be at the cutting edge of technology, that it should have the skills and resources required to compete in a world of the internet and dot.com entrepreneurs. New Labour, new economy, you might say.

But the government is not entirely forgetful of the old economy, either.

It is already facing the possibility of trouble with the EC over state aid for the Rover plant at Longbridge. Latterly it is working hard to protect Harland & Wolff from the closure which appears inevitable if the 139-year-old shipyard fails to win the contract to build the Queen Mary II for Cunard.

The government is said to have been lobbying energetically - to put it politely - for the contract to go to the Belfast shipyard, rather than to rival bidder Chantiers de L'Atlantique.

It is also putting a substantial amount of money where its mouth is, providing a loan under the home shipbuilding credit guarantee system. But cars and ships? Surely they are a trifle uncool?

Well, not for the people whose livelihood depends on the companies which build them. New Labour has not been so long in office that it has forgotten that to stay there you need old economy votes, too.

webTitle: Freeserve stands to bounce back well

fields.headline: Freeserve stands to bounce back well
fields.standfirst:
Market forces

E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: US private investors have become programmed to "buy on the dips". If the price of Freeserve is any guide, this sort of thinking has yet to cross the Atlantic.
fields.body:
US private investors have become programmed to "buy on the dips". If the price of Freeserve is any guide, this sort of thinking has yet to cross the Atlantic.

Shares in the free internet services provider were floated at 150p in August and actually spent part of their first few months underwater. Then in November the price took off as the whole British internet punting thing got under way.

At one stage at the beginning of March the price hit 920p, valuing Freeserve at close to £10bn. The sell-off since then has been violent. Yesterday, the shares closed another 61p lower at 640p - almost a third of the company's value wiped out in the space of week.

The culprit, of course, is the explosion of competition to provide supposedly free telephone access to the web, with new packages offered by Altavista, NTL and British Telecom. A good portion of Freeserve's revenues to date have come from a cut of the local call telephone charges users clock up - so an end to "metered narrowband access", to use the lingo, would seem to upset Freeserve's business model.

But holders of the stock should not despair, according to Tarek Robbaitl and Paul Norris, analysts at Lehman Brothers. They reckon broadband access to the web will come to Freeserve's rescue. The company is already running trials with fast digital subscriber line technology. The real issue longer term, Lehman says, is whether the company can retain its position as the leading portal - which relies on content and "reach".

In short, the market has overreacted and the shares will outperform from here.

fields.headline: Easynet expands in Europe
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Internet service provider Easynet Group plans to build a digital subscriber line network in Germany, invest in an additional data centre facility in London and enhance its European network with an expansion of operations into Italy and Switzerland.
fields.body:
Internet service provider Easynet Group plans to build a digital subscriber line network in Germany, invest in an additional data centre facility in London and enhance its European network with an expansion of operations into Italy and Switzerland.

The projects will be funded by a placing and open offer of £2.48m new ordinary shares at 2,200p each to raise approximately £51.8m.

The company warned that "due to the investment in infrastructure and operations" it is expected group profitability will be affected.

The comments came as the group revealed a pre-tax loss of £929,000 in the year to December, compared with a loss of £575,000 a year earlier.

Sales of £27.74m were up 78% when compared with £15.59m in 1998.

The loss per share was 5.64p for the period under review, against a loss per share of 1.81p in 1998.

fields.body:
Ian Brady, the Moors murderer who started a hunger strike five months ago, today lost his fight for the right to starve himself to death.

Mr Justice Maurice Kay ruled at the high court sitting in Liverpool that medical staff had been acting lawfully in force-feeding Brady, who has been on hunger strike since last September. Refusing Brady's application for a judicial review, the judge said the doctors' decision had been "in all respects lawful, rational and fair".

Brady, 62, spent five days last week trying to persuade the high court that staff at Ashworth hospital in Maghull, north Merseyside, where he is being held, had no right to feed him during a hunger strike he started last year after being moved from one ward to another.

Last week's hearing, which was held behind closed doors at the request of Brady and his lawyers, was the first time the notorious killer had been in court since being convicted along with former lover Myra Hindley for the sadistic murders of three children at Chester assizes in 1966.

Two years after he was moved to the secure hospital in Maghull, where he is serving a life sentence, Brady confessed in 1987 to the murders of two more children.

Brady began his hunger strike when he was transferred from a relatively relaxed ward to a more secure ward, for patients with severe personality disorders. Brady spoke about his death wish in a long letter he sent to the BBC. He expressed envy of his accomplice Hindley, who is suffering from a life-threatening brain condition.

"Myra gets the potentially fatal brain condition, whilst I have to fight simply to die. I have had enough. I want nothing, my objective is to die and release myself from this once and for all," he wrote. "So you see my death strike is rational and pragmatic. I'm only sorry I didn't do it decades ago, and I'm eager to leave this cesspit in a coffin."

As a general rule, adults who are capable of taking their own decisions - even those who are mentally ill - cannot lawfully be fed against their will. In 1994, a high court judge ruled that prisoners who were mentally competent were free to starve themselves to death.

But Brady is no longer in the prison system, having been transferred to Ashworth in 1985. The appeal court ruled in another case in 1994 that an adult detained under the mental health act could be force-fed if self-starvation was a consequence or symptom of the mental disorder.

During the hearing, his lawyers argued that the hospital had no legal right to force-feed him by tube. Apart from arguing that Brady was capable of deciding for himself, his lawyers said that force-feeding him was a breach of his right to a private life under the European convention on human rights.

A leaked report of an independent investigation into Brady's complaints about his treatment by Professor David Sines of South Bank university in London links his hunger strike with the way he was transferred to the new ward.

The report accuses the hospital authorities of mismanaging the transfer, stating Brady was marched without warning into the new ward by six members of the hospital's restraint and control team. Two were wearing shields, even though Brady had never been violent to staff, the report says.

fields.headline: Grand prix
fields.trailText: 1. Sunday's grand prix is the first of this year's formula one season - and the action is already hotting up.
fields.body:
1. Sunday's grand prix is the first of this year's formula one season - and the action is already hotting up.

2. In Melbourne's Albert Park at 2pm local time (1am on Sunday morning in the UK) the world's leading racing drivers will battle it out between themselves to be first to reach the checkered flag.

3. And luckily for the drivers and spectators the weather should be good.

4. Michael Schumacher set the fastest time at the practice but also crashed his Ferrari as he slammed into a tyre barrier on the Melbourne track.

5. The last time Schumacher crashed (in July) he left Silverstone in an ambulance with his right leg broken in two places below the knee.

6. Motor racing had an inauspicious start - at the first event, the 1887 Paris Velocipede, only one driver turned up and the event had to be abandoned.

7. For many, the sport peaked with the introduction of formula one in the post-war period when sleek, curvy cars racing around the Monaco circuit gave fast cars a glamour of their own.

8. Then Jaguar was in the ascendent. Today the team has less success: British driver Eddie Irvine was forced off the track with technical problems.

9. But the international, jet-setting side of formula one lives on. After Melbourne come races in Brazil, San Marino and Spain.

10. Those of a less Eurotrash disposition can log on for a full race report on The Observer.

fields.headline: What they're reading in China
fields.trailText: Little the Chinese read these days is available in translation outside specialised journals, while almost nothing written abroad about China is accessible to the Chinese. The obvious exceptions are the great classics from Confucius to The Dream of the Red Chamber - though few bother to read them now in China. A few copies of Wild Swans, Jung Chang's generational memoir, do circulate there: Chinese who lived through the Maoist decades say, "I should write a book like that too."
fields.body:
Little the Chinese read these days is available in translation outside specialised journals, while almost nothing written abroad about China is accessible to the Chinese. The obvious exceptions are the great classics from Confucius to The Dream of the Red Chamber - though few bother to read them now in China. A few copies of Wild Swans, Jung Chang's generational memoir, do circulate there: Chinese who lived through the Maoist decades say, "I should write a book like that too."

Yet much of interest is being published. Serious studies of post-1949 history are allowed as long as they avoid the most neuralgic episodes like the 1989 Beijing Massacre. Many books on "what is wrong with China" touch sensitive issues such as the rich-poor divide. Others on "what is right with China" appeal to a xenophobic vein. Modern Chinese novelists are all on sale.

China Remembers, by Zhang Lijia and Calum Macleod (OUP)
These vivid recollections by more than 30 Chinese, from entrepreneurs to writers, are told in the same simple style as mainland reminiscences.
Buy it from BOL

Gao Village, by Mobo C F Gao (C Hurst)
An antidote to the recent swathe of romanticised emigré tales, Gao's transition from peasant youth to university lecturer abroad is exceptional: the real history of post-1949 rural China emerges.
Buy it from BOL

Ocean of Words, by Ha Jin (Vintage Books)
These tightly written stories about the Cultural Revolution, though written in the US and in English, are in the style of the mainland "literature of the wounded" popular in the early 80s.
Interview
Home page

Playing for Thrills, by Wang Shuo (No Exit Press)
At last, a real translation! Wang is China's literary bad boy: the novel's antihero zooms around Beijing drinking beer and having sex. For the work of an earlier bad boy, read Zhang Xianliang's memories of prison camp in Half of Man Is Woman (Penguin, 1996).
Brief Playing for Thrills review from Crimetime.

fields.headline: BA chief bails out
fields.trailText: Bob Ayling, one of Britain's most high-profile businessmen, today announced his resignation as chief executive of British Airways after four turbulent years at the top of the country's biggest airline.
fields.body:
Bob Ayling, one of Britain's most high-profile businessmen, today announced his resignation as chief executive of British Airways after four turbulent years at the top of the country's biggest airline.

Mr Ayling said that the demands of the job had "taken their toll" and that it was "time for a new chief executive to take up the challenge".

BA chairman Lord Colin Marshall will take over as chief executive while the company searches for a successor. Mr Ayling, 54, spent a total of 15 years at BA.

Shares in BA surged on Mr Ayling's announcement, reflecting investor disenchantment with him in the last few years.

The stock had lagged the overall market by 25% so far this year and 62% in the last five years. Mr Ayling had sought to lift the company's fortunes by cutting capacity and focusing on higher-margin business travellers.

"Ayling didn't have a bad strategy, but was implementing it badly and that's something his successor will have to face," said an airline industry analyst. "The fundamentals remain the same - it's a horrible market to be operating in and they are losing market share, their position is weakening."

SG Securities airlines analyst Matthew Stainer agreed: "He's had some great ideas but the implementation has been less than optimal."

The airline has faced intense competition in recent years, particularly on its transatlantic routes to the US.

Under Mr Ayling's leadership, BA tried to woo business customers, introducing first-class sleeper beds and increasing the number of premium seats on its flights.

At the same time, competition from low-cost airlines has threatened BA on many of its European routes, which led the airline to respond by starting its own low-cost carrier, Go.

Mr Ayling introduced cost-cutting measures that have so far saved the company £1bn. In November, however, the airline reported a 38% drop in its half-year profits.

"The past four years have been tough and stimulating," he said. "Inevitably, the pressures have affected my family, and I owe it to them to take some time off and spend it with them."

During his time at BA, Mr Ayling has attracted more than his fair share of controversy. He was criticised for the brusque sacking of Jennie Page as chief executive of the millennium dome.

Mr Ayling is chairman of the New Millennium Experience company which runs the dome, and he is believed to have forced her out after poor attendance at the Greenwich site.

Mr Ayling's plans for an alliance with American Airlines were frustrated by regulators and a cost-cutting drive led to a cabin crew strike shortly after he took over.

He also caused uproar by replacing Britain's union flag on its tailfins with a variety of ethnic designs from around the world. However, the airline made a u-turn and reinstated the union flag last year.

webTitle: Dahl beats all competitors to collect honour as nation's favourite author

fields.headline: Dahl beats all competitors to collect honour as nation's favourite author
fields.trailText: The sly, cruel sorcerer of the modern children's story, Roald Dahl, reached from beyond the grave yesterday to beat Harry Potter's creator JK Rowling in a big poll for Britain's favourite author.
fields.body:
The sly, cruel sorcerer of the modern children's story, Roald Dahl, reached from beyond the grave yesterday to beat Harry Potter's creator JK Rowling in a big poll for Britain's favourite author.

Ten years after his death, Dahl's control freak magicians and big, friendly giant won 4.5% of a nationwide vote by 40,000 people for World Book Day.

Rowling, who also deals in wizards, got 3.5% - seen as an exceptional achievement for a writer who has only produced three books, though these have dominated bestseller lists for the last year.

But the most remarkable coup was by Jane Austen as the only classic writer to reach the top 10. She came eighth, ahead of Dick Francis, the world's bestselling horror writer Stephen King, Danielle Steele, Tolkien, Wilbur Smith and John Grisham.

The poll was carried out at 4,000 bookshops and libraries, in schools and on the web. Its results were heavily slewed towards parental and children's book purchases and the book-buying tastes of young people.

If only adult votes had been counted, Austen - helped by television adaptations including a shot of Colin Firth in wet, semi-transparent underclothes - would have come fourth.

Among adults alone, the top three were Catherine Cookson, Terry Pratchett and Maeve Binchy. Dick Francis's horse-racing mysteries were fifth.

In the poll counting both adults and children, Pratchett was third and Cookson, who died in 1998, fourth. However the survey reported signs that the popularity of her stoical working class and lower middle class novels about the north east is beginning to slip among younger adult readers; an ominous trend, if continued, for the memory of an earnest author who hoped to be remembered as a serious mainstream writer.

In this overall poll, Jacque line Wilson was fifth, Binchy sixth, Francis eighth, King ninth and Steele tenth.

They were followed by Tolkien, RL Stine, Charles Dickens, Wilbur Smith and Patricia Cornwell. Stine's high place emphasises the playground popularity of the jokey, gore-filled work of a 53-year-old New Yorker who is little publicised in the British book trade.

Earlier this year he emerged from another survey as the author most borrowed from British secondary school libraries - beating Dahl and Rowling.

The two favourite children's writers of the post-second world war generation, Enid Blyton and CS Lewis, creator of the Narnia stories, came 17th and 24th in the overall survey. Nearly 40 years after his death, Lewis was only one ranking below Agatha Christie.

Blyton and Lewis remained ahead of a clutch of more recent high sellers including Joanna Trollope, Patrick O'Brian, Ruth Rendell, Jack Higgins, Mary Higgins Clark and Ellis Peters in the top 40.

Apart from Austen and Dickens, only five classic authors made the top 50. They were Thomas Hardy (19th), George Orwell (44th), Graham Greene (45th), PG Wodehouse (48th) and Shakespeare (50th).

fields.headline: The guzzler
fields.trailText:
Cheapskate . . . where to eat out for under £15 :

Goolies Bar & Restaurant , 21 Abingdon Road, London W8. Tel: 0171 938 1122
fields.body:
Cheapskate . . . where to eat out for under £15 :

Goolies Bar & Restaurant , 21 Abingdon Road, London W8. Tel: 0171 938 1122

The name's a bit of a stopper, but you could easily pass by this nifty little eatery tucked away on a side road off Kensington High Street. It looks a bit like a dining room on a floating gin palace, but the food is another matter. Fusion is the name of the game - ostrich leg with sweet potato dauphinoise; duck leg curry on soba noodles; grilled scallops with sweet chilli sauce and crème frache - but carried out with unusual vim and clarity. The spicy crab cakes and their sauce are about the best in London (although the caramelised pine-apple is a bit of a distraction). Puddings are what you might call eventful (warm Black Forest gateau?). Fixed price lunch: £10.95 for two courses, £13.95 for three.

Quick bites . . . where to eat out in under 15 minutes :
Sticky Fingers , 1a Phillimore Gardens, London W8. Tel: 0171 938 5338

Bill Wyman's it may be, but it isn't really rock'n'roll, and it's certainly not drugs or sex - memorabilia and music notwithstanding. It's for kids and their parents. It's for fun and mucking about. It's for fast eating and slow moving. It's about burgers weighing in at 6oz with a host of splodgy sauces, barbecued chicken wings, deep-fried potato skins and belter sandwiches such as the multi-layer house club (chicken, bacon, tomato, lettuce, mayo), all at a consistently high standard. There's pasta or grilled salmon/roast cod too, for the more sophisticated eater. A bit pricier than some of the competition, but the overall quality is superior, too, and the service is slick.

Cheats' kitchen : Food on the net

Mixed hors d'oeuvre, serves four

2 tin sardines in olive oil

1 jar artichokes in oil

1 jar small pickled gherkins

12 slices of salami

100g bought-in pté de campagne

4 eggs

4 waxy potatoes

1 jar mayonnaise

Black olives and Parmesan

1 Hard-boil eggs, cool and slice in half.

2 Boil the potatoes in their skins. Chop and mix with mayonnaise.

3 Open tins and jars and arrange contents decoratively around the plate. Add olives and gherkins. Serve with French bread.

F Witney, Redditch, Herts

www.inquisitivecook.com

If you're the kind of cook who wonders why prawns turn orange when cooked (something related to carotenoid pigments), you can find the answers here. The inquisitive cooks are Anne Gardiner and Sue Wilson, who have been teaching the "chemistry of cooking" for nearly 20 years; the site is very science-minded, though fortunately aimed at those of us who aren't.

Pros: Questions on all manner of cooking techniques are answered direct by the cooks, and previous Q&As are easy to track down. Recommended cookbooks are stringently tested.

Cons: Some might find questions posed by the (mostly American) site users perplexing - eg "What is self-rising [sic] flour?"

On the menu: Waygu beef :

So what's so special about Waygu beef? The Japanese love it.

No, no. They love Kobe beef. Kobe beef is Waygu beef with beer massaged into it.

So Waygu is the breed? You're catching on.

webTitle: Harland and Wolff loses lifeline contract

fields.headline: Harland and Wolff loses lifeline contract
fields.trailText: Harland and Wolff, the Belfast shipyard that launched the Titanic, today suffered a crushing blow as Cunard Line awarded a contract to build the Queen Mary II cruise liner to a rival French company.
fields.body:
Harland and Wolff, the Belfast shipyard that launched the Titanic, today suffered a crushing blow as Cunard Line awarded a contract to build the Queen Mary II cruise liner to a rival French company.

More than 1,700 workers at Harland and Wolff had pinned their hopes on winning the contract that would have ensured the company's survival. Now the business that was once the world's largest shipyard faces extinction.

Cunard, a unit of Carnival Corp, said in Miami it had signed a letter of intent to build the Queen Mary II at the Alstom subsidiary Chantiers de l'Atlantique shipyard in Saint-Nazaire, France.

An official for the 140-year-old facility, one of the props of the Northern Ireland economy, said it was disappointed and would now have to consider all the implications of the devastating blow.

He said a last-minute finance package put forward by the British government was "too little, too late". The shipyard, whose giant yellow cranes dominate the Belfast skyline, said yesterday that its 1,745 workers could lose their jobs if it did not land the $600m contract.

Harland and Wolff, now majority-owned by Norway's Fred Olsen Energy, has just two orders left on its books. Its prospects are grim.

It is known above all for building Titanic, the luxury liner which sank in 1912 after hitting an iceberg on its maiden voyage to America.

Efforts to save the yard have been hampered by the political stalemate in Northern Ireland and the suspension of a fledgling home-rule government last month in response to the IRA's reluctance to disarm.

"This is the announcement we have all been dreading," said Sir Reg Empey, investment minister in Northern Ireland's short-lived local administration.

Peter Robinson, the local member of parliament for the Belfast yard, told the BBC: "I'm gutted. Clearly this had been a potential lifeline for the yard and perhaps the best chance from a long-term point of view for Harland and Wolff.

"We do have to sit down with management and look to government to see what can be done, but it is a difficult task to see what our options are other than the ministry of defence bringing forward their timetable for aircraft carriers or some other work."

He also questioned the terms of the offer by the French yard. "If (the French) package was so much better... I would have to doubt if it was within the terms of the European Union's rules," he said.

The trade unions were equally pessimistic. GMB union spokesman George Matchett said: "I'm absolutely amazed. We will have to get back into talks with the company and as quickly as possible, see where the next possible contract is, [see] if we require the government to bring those contracts forward."

Workers were in despondent mood when signing on for the early morning shift. "This is sickening," said one. "It is a disgrace. This is the Queen Mary. Where is the Queen from? From the UK," said another.

"Britain only has two yards of sufficient size to build such a vessel - Harland and Wolff and Kvaerner Govan in Glasgow - and frankly they are on their last legs," said Staunton-Lambert, a member of the Royal Institute of Naval Architects.

"They do not have the track record for building vessels of this type and Chantiers de l'Atlantique does. Everybody is struggling to survive and it cannot be a great surprise that the yard with the expertise won."

Chantiers de l'Atlantique, formerly a state-owned yard which was sold to engineering giant Alstom, was turned into a viable concern after stringent "rationalisation" or job cuts. The French company also has an American arm - Marine Service Partners based in Miami - which provides maintenance and sells expertise to US cruise companies.

fields.headline: Today's other news
fields.trailText: The Beach attracts more controversy in Thailand, Stephen King's new book to get internet-only release, Get Carter remake set for summer release, Kevin Smith's sitcom postponed, and Eddie Murphey on the casting couch
fields.body:
 Released today in Thailand, The Beach is now set to become involved in yet another controversy. A Thai parliamentary committee wants the film banned because it portrays a negative image of Buddhism. At the premiere of the movie on Tuesday a spokesman for the Parliament House Committee on Religion, Arts and Culture said the opening scene of the film misleads moviegoers into believing that a Buddha image would actually be placed on a footpath in an entertainment zone in Thailand. A Fox source defended the film, arguing that the intention of the opening Buddha scene was merely to identify Thailand "The movie has already been approved by the Thai Film Board for distribution."

 Stephen King, whose latest offering The Green Mile is currently doing the rounds at British cinemas, has announced that his new book, a 66-page tale called Riding the Bullet will be available exclusively on-line. The e-book, which King describes as a "ghost story in the grand manner", will be available on March 14, and marks the first time a major author has published a novel solely in digital form. King wrote the new story while convalescing from near-fatal injuries suffered when he was hit by a van last summer. "I'm curious to see what sort of response there is and whether or not this is the future," the horror writer said. It's not known whether the obligatory film adaptation of the book will also be shown online or whether it will make it to the big screen.

 The remake of Get Carter, with Sylvester Stallone playing the Michael Caine role of the racketeer hell-bent on avenging his brother's death at the hand of some underworld gangsters - one of whom is played by the similarly incongruously cast Alan Cumming - is likely to get a summer release after the successful screening of the trailer. According to a rumour on Dark Horizons, Warner Bros is so confident about its new action thriller it is thinking of moving it up from its autumn release to an August 11 summer blockbuster spot.

 Another trailer which has also impressed the industry at ShoWest, the annual trade convention for cinema owners, distributors, and other movie insiders held in Las Vegas and finishing today, is that for Paul Verhoeven's new sci-fi thriller, Hollow Man, which stars Kevin Bacon and Elizabeth Shue. Apparently Bacon is extremely good, even though he is completely transparent for most of the film.

 Hum Drum, an Oscar-nominated short film featuring a cast of shadow puppets has been named the people's favourite animated film of the past year. The film, directed by Peter Peake and featuring the voice of comedian Jack Docherty, won the public choice for favourite film at the annual British Animation Awards.

 American broadcaster ABC has decided to postpone the debut of Kevin Smith's new animated sitcom, Clerks, because, according to fans of the controversial director, the executives at Disney didn't understand the humour at a recent test screening. An outraged fan on Smith's own site (surely not the director himself?) slams the company's decision to give the show a summer release because this "almost ensures the show's failure". The disgruntled fan continues, "Don't give Disney what they want, when this show airs, watch it if only to spite the Mouse."

 The embarrassed US Post Office has told the Motion Picture Academy that it will not be charged postage for the second batch of Oscar ballots which had to be sent out after the original set of voting slips were cast adrift in the outskirts of LA. In a desperate face-saving exercise the Post Office has also offered to pay for the printing and the labour costs involved in the second mail-out. The deadline for voting has had to be extended by two days because of the cock-up. Accompanying the new ballots is a letter from Academy president Bob Rehme which requests that members do not discuss their Oscar choices with the Wall Street Journal. The paper has reportedly been polling members to preempt the ceremony on March 26.

Casting Couch

 Eddie Murphy is being cut down to size and more for his next film. The actor who expanded to gargantuan proportions in The Nutty Professor, will star in Shrinking, a remake of the 1957 film about a man who starts to get smaller after being exposed to a strange fog. Peter Segal who made Tommy Boy will direct.

 Nick Cassavetes is on course to direct John Q, a story of a man who takes accident and emergency staff hostage when his son is taken off the donor recipient list because the family doesn't have adequate health insurance.

webTitle: Trailer for Mission Impossible: 2 gets sneak preview on the internet

fields.headline: Trailer for Mission Impossible: 2 gets sneak preview on the internet
fields.trailText: Due to be revealed last Christmas, Tom Cruise's Mission Impossible: 2 now has a summer release, four years after the original was made
fields.body:
Due to be revealed last Christmas, Tom Cruise's Mission Impossible: 2 now has a summer release, four years after the original was made. The sequel sees Cruise, reprising his role as the CIA agent Ethan Hawke, trying to stop a lethal virus from destroying the world.

Unlike the well-publicised bust-ups between the perfectionist star and director John Woo, over schedule delays and a spiralling budget, the details of the film have been a well-kept secret - although Mission spies report that Hawke sends in fellow agent and lover Thandie Newton to seduce disloyal agent Dougray Scott who posseses information about the antidote to the virus.

The teaser came out a few months ago with a snippet of Cruise - who has done all his own stunts - dangling from the edge of vertiginous cliff by his fingernails to the strains of the Lalo Schifrin's jazzy theme. Now the trailer with all the Woo trademarks - Cruise dispatching enemies with martial arts kicks to enemies in crowds of pigeons - has been released. It won't be seen at the cinemas for a few weeks yet and won't be on the official site until tomorrow but Dark Horizons has an exclusive screening of the trailer which promises to be the first of this summer's blockbusters.

 To see the trailer click here and follow the links.

fields.headline: Best in hospital after 'stomach pains'
fields.trailText: Former Manchester United football legend George Best was today undergoing a series of liver and stomach tests after he was admitted to hospital complaining of severe stomach pains.
fields.body:
Former Manchester United football legend George Best was today undergoing a series of liver and stomach tests after he was admitted to hospital complaining of severe stomach pains.

But Best's agent, Phil Hughes, denied tabloid rumours that the 53-year-old star was suffering from liver failure and was fighting for his life.

"He is unwell and may be in hospital for a few days or could be out as soon as tomorrow," said Hughes. "He isn't well, but it's not life-threatening - at least I hope not."

This morning's Sun quoted Best's 27-year-old wife Alex as saying: "He is in hospital and looks terrible. We're all worried about him."

According to reports, Best was taken to hospital after his skin turned yellow - a symptom of jaundice, one of the first signs of cirrhosis of the liver caused by alcoholism - which kills 2,500 people a year.

The manager of the Phene Arms in Chelsea, where Best is a regular, said he was last seen at the pub three days ago.

Best's dazzling career in the 60s and 70s was prematurely curtailed by his fast living.

Despite public efforts to stop drinking, the star has been involved in a string of drunken escapades, from appearing inebriated on Wogan to being jailed for three months in 1984 for drink-driving and assaulting a police officer. He is now a pundit for Sky Sports.

webTitle: Estate agents go from laggards to leaders

fields.headline: Estate agents go from laggards to leaders
fields.standfirst:
House sellers team up in move that could hit smaller rivals

E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: In the face of the challenge posed by growing numbers of internet-based property services, four of Britain's biggest traditional estate agency groups have decided that if you can't beat them, join them.
fields.body:
In the face of the challenge posed by growing numbers of internet-based property services, four of Britain's biggest traditional estate agency groups have decided that if you can't beat them, join them.

Countrywide Assured, Connells, and the estate agency divisions of the Halifax and Royal & SunAlliance have teamed up on a property website to try and keep their dominance and preserve their commissions.

Their move comes at a time of burgeoning consumer interest in net services such as Easier and HomeFreeHome, which offer people the chance to go it alone and save hundreds of pounds by advertising their property online for free.

The four - whose regional brands include well-known names such as Bairstow Eve, William H Brown and Barnard Marcus -are launching Rightmove, which will carry the property details of more than 1,700 estate agents across the UK.

At a stroke the four have gone from perceived net laggards to leaders in the online property market, and will legitimately be able to claim that they will be offering the most comprehensive site.

By summer Rightmove will carry details of almost 120,000 properties for sale -around 20% of all those on the market. The four companies are in talks with several other major estate agency groups and are writing to scores of smaller firms to invite them to sign up. They aim to have more than 50% of all UK properties for sale up on the site by the end of this year.

If they achieve their target, they will be well on the way to creating a UK equivalent to Realtor.com, the US website that carries details of more than 1.3m homes with 93% of all US estate agents on it.

The four are splashing out on national TV advertising but, for all its hi-tech, online sheen, Rightmove is all about steering sellers towards their offline local estate agent branch, a far cry from sites that allow vendors to break free of the costly traditional house-selling process. Individuals wanting to advertise their properties on Rightmove will have to register with a subscribing local estate agent. They won't have to pay an additional fee but then the services of an estate agent can be as much as £2,000 on a £100,000 home. What the individual will get is a website entry including a small photo of the property and a description.

If he or she opted to sell privately with a firm such as> HouseWeb, one of the best-known homebuying and selling websites, they would pay £40 to advertise the property. They can upload text and photos directly from their computer - some people have as many as half a dozen photos showing the insides of rooms.

While the sites obviously allow people to bypass estate agents completely, HouseWeb managing director Mark Desvaux said growing numbers of vendors are doubling their chances of striking lucky by using an estate agent and a website. "People are going to the estate agent and saying: 'We are going to advertise on HouseWeb, and if we sell our house privately you don't get your commission.' It is putting pressure on the estate agent to try hard to help the homeowner."

Rightmove could also prove a very bad move indeed for the multitude of other online sites that collect together property information submitted by estate agents. The four companies could squeeze smaller rivals out of the picture.

James Chapman at Royal & Sun Alliance Property Services, said as much when he revealed that his company would now be withdrawing from all other property websites apart from Rightmove. He said his company was being "pestered" almost on a daily basis by people inviting it to "come on their super new sites".

Mr Chapman added: "This is going to make life difficult for the people looking to set up websites on the property scene. If they can't get the big boys to sign up, they are going to have to spend a lot of money trying to get the one and two-office firms. However, I suspect the smaller firms would far rather be on our portal."

If they can't get the big boys to sign up, they are going to have to spend a lot of money trying to get the one and two-office firms. However, I suspect the smaller firms would far rather be on our portal."

fields.headline: Joan of Arc
fields.trailText: Peter Bradshaw: There will be many who have not the stomach for the fray, and find the element of preposterousness just too much. I am not among them
fields.body:
There is a terrible moment near the beginning of Luc Besson's glittering new epic Joan Of Arc. It is 1420 or thereabouts and the infant Joan is cowering, terrified by the thuggish English soldiers who are sacking her home village of Domrémy. As Joan hides in a cupboard, a vile, smelly, unshaven and revolting specimen of perfidious Albion espies her delectable elder sister Catherine. In close-up, he leers horribly: "Now that's what I call booty!" Bernard Matthews lives. And there is many an instant when, with Joan's ecstatic seizures and visions among the galloping peasant soldiery - all the flashbacks and throwbacks - when we appear to be uncomfortably close to Blackadder territory or the terrible Knights Who Say Ni.

There will be many who have not the stomach for the fray, and find the element of preposterousness just too much. I am not among them. For me, this very enjoyable two-and-three-quarter-hour picture simply sped past, with wonderful energy and brash storytelling vitality.

Besson hits a confident stride very early on and carries off the battle scenes, especially Joan's stirring victory at Orleans, with dash and expertise. Joan's encounters with Christ-like manifestations are sometimes a bit pop video, but they have internal coherence and mesh persuasively with the rest of the action.

Besson's leading lady, Milla Jovovich, does a perfectly respectable job as Joan: palely intense, girlishly stubborn and a good figure on a horse. She does not appear to have been victimised the way Otto Preminger victimised Jean Seberg, but Besson does at one stage require Jovovich to fall backwards facing the camera from a fortified wall with an arrow in her, a sheer drop of perhaps a hundred feet, to be caught by her comrades below, in shot the entire time - a magnificent stunt if no computer effects were involved. The supporting cast includes John Malkovich, who gives it loads as the highly-strung Dauphin, his face a picture of tremulous delight as the crown is finally placed on his head: a very Being-John-Malkovich moment. Dustin Hoffman's gravelly-voiced portrayal of Joan's Conscience is a bit trying sometimes, but quite in keeping with the pleasingly Old Hollywood feel of the film.

Finally, Joan agonisingly, and conveniently, can't remember killing or injuring anyone in battle and the strangely passive-aggressive legend of Joan's martyrdom, traditionally deployed in the service of catholic nationalism, still carries a curious charge in an age in which the present pope is pleased to call modern France the "eldest daughter of the church". But ultimately Besson offers us nothing more pointed than a Gallic Braveheart: roistering, swashbuckling, enjoyable stuff.

fields.headline: Labour spends £20m on euro
fields.standfirst: Economic and Monetary Union: special report
fields.trailText: The government is to spend £20m in the coming year to upgrade the IT systems of department of social security, inland revenue and customs and excise for possible British entry into the single currency, the treasury said yesterday.
fields.body:
The government is to spend £20m in the coming year to upgrade the IT systems of department of social security, inland revenue and customs and excise for possible British entry into the single currency, the treasury said yesterday.

Publication of the second outline national changeover plan prompted a new row between supporters and opponents of monetary union but Gordon Brown, the chancellor, said it was consistent with Labour's policy of "prepare and decide".

The treasury said that the public sector was on track to be ready should the UK make a decision early in the next parliament to join monetary union, and that working in partnership with business was "producing real results" in the private sector.

Treasury officials said they could not say how many companies had actually started making preparations for pos sible euro entry nor what the total cost was expected to be.

Simon Buckby, the Britain in Europe Campaign director, said: "This shows that the government's euro preparation plan is on track, despite the alarmist tactics being pursued by the anti-Europeans.

"It is right for business and government to prepare now so that the electorate has a real choice should there be a referendum," he said.

Dominic Cummings, head of research at business for sterling, which opposes joining the single currency, said: "The Government's £36bn plan is opposed by more than two-thirds of the public and business and will damage the development of the internet and e-commerce.

"Almost 90% of businesses have rejected the government's call for 'intensive euro preparations' which would cost the country the whole NHS budget for a year. People would rather spend the money on health or the development of the internet."

fields.headline: Berg: Wozzeck
fields.trailText: In our series on building a classical library, Andrew Clements selects the definitive recording of Berg's Wozzeck.
fields.body:
Wozzeck is arguably the most influential of all 20th-century operas, yet for a work of such significance and power it is meagrely represented by great interpretations on disc. It took Berg nine years to shape Georg Büchner's play into a taut music drama, which packs a tragedy of immense proportions into 80 minutes of music, and it was another three years before he saw it performed; Erich Kleiber conducted the premiere in Berlin in 1925.

Even now the performing challenges are formidable. The intensity of the orchestral writing is underpinned by an intricate formalism which has to be most carefully paced, while singers of a special order are needed for the roles of Wozzeck and Marie; artists that can pitch Berg's Sprechgesang convincingly between fully fledged song and rhythmatised speech, and make their characters more than just histrionic victims of society.

The first recording (Philips), conducted by Dmitri Mitropoulos in 1951, is too spattered with wrong notes to rival later versions, although there is a tremendous theatrical buzz about the performance, while the recording conducted by Pierre Boulez (Sony Classical) is full of vocal inaccuracies, as if he despaired of getting the precision from his singers that he regularly obtains from instrumentalists.

Christoph von Dohnanyi (Decca) has the best of all Maries in Anja Silja and obtains warm playing from the Vienna Philharmonic, but the centre is missing - Eberhard Waechter's Wozzeck is fatally insecure.

The final choice comes down to three, all from stage performances. There is Karl Böhm (Deutsche Grammophon) from 1968, with the Deutsche Oper Berlin, and Dietrich Fischer-Dieskau and Evelyn Lear heading the cast, though this is only available as part of a four-disc set. Böhm, however, understands more than anyone how intensely Viennese much of Berg's writing is, and Fischer-Dieskau is fascinating in whatever he sings. Released last year, Ingo Metzmacher's version (EMI) is founded on superb playing from the Hamburg State Opera Orchestra; Bo Skovhus is a lyrical Wozzeck, a dreamer rather than a schemer, and Angela Denoke's Marie is touching too.

But both of these are edged out by Claudio Abbado and the Vienna State Opera in 1987. In Franz Grundheber, Abbado has the best Wozzeck of recent times, in Hildegard Behrens the most compelling Marie since Silja. Abbado above all conductors understands how delicately balanced between expressionism and late romanticism Berg's score is; however sweetly expressive the playing becomes there is always a core of steel just beneath its surface.

Key recording: Abbado, Deutsche Grammophon 423 587-2
