webTitle: Keep the change, refugee voucher stores are told

fields.headline: Keep the change, refugee voucher stores are told
fields.standfirst:
System demeaning and discriminatory, says asylum charity
Refugees in Britain: special report
The issue explained: How to claim asylum
fields.trailText: The private company running the home office's new voucher system has told supermarkets they can keep the change due to asylum seekers who shop with them as a cash incentive to take part in the scheme.
fields.body:
The private company running the home office's new voucher system has told supermarkets they can keep the change due to asylum seekers who shop with them as a cash incentive to take part in the scheme.

Sodexho Pass, a French company that already runs a similar asylum voucher scheme in Germany, has told potential "trading partners" that the decision to end the cash system of benefits for 30,000 asylum seekers a year gives them a chance to benefit from their "Buy-Pass" voucher initiative.

"Several major multiple groups have already signed up as Sodexho Pass Trading Partners - don't miss this revenue-making opportunity," say promotional brochures being circulated by the company. Sainsbury's and Asda are among the chains signed up to the scheme due to start next month.

Sodexho goes on to spell out how some of that extra revenue might be raised. "Vouchers cannot be exchanged for cash. Change should not be given, eg if goods to the value of £4.50 are purchased with a £5 voucher the 50p change should not be handed back, but you as a Trading Partner will receive the full £5 value for that voucher."

Refugee groups last night said they were appalled that adult asylum seekers who will have to live on vouchers worth £36.54 a week and are banned from working could face being further impoverished.

Under the "cashless" system - which comes into place on April 1 at the same time as the national dispersal programme is phased in as part of Jack Straw's tougher asylum law - asylum seekers will be issued with vouchers at their local post office each week in £5, £1 and 50p denominations. They will include special vouchers worth £10 a week that can be exchanged for cash.

The scheme has been attacked by critics as inventing a new currency, the "asylo", simply to avoid paying welfare benefits direct to asylum seekers. The "Buy-Pass" vouchers are to be used only at "designated Sodexho Pass Trading Partners in order to purchase essential living needs".

As a measure to guard against fraud asylum seekers will be banned from using the vouchers to order goods for home delivery, and the French company promises the shops that "there will only be checks on security features at the till" so that "it will not slow down the process for customers".

Shops which take part in the scheme will be given a special window sticker to use at their entrance so asylum seekers know that the store is part of the scheme: "As an outlet selling essential products with a high population of asylum seekers in your area, the home office is giving you an opportunity to benefit from the new 'Buy-Pass' voucher initiative," Sodexho is telling supermarkets and others.

Zoe Harper of the charity Asylum Aid said: "The whole voucher system is demeaning and discriminatory and will have an extremely damaging impact on survivors of torture and persecution who seek protection in the UK.

Asylum seekers are already being forced to live at a level of support below the rest of the population. We are appalled that they will face impoverishment through not being able to receive their change when they spend the vouchers."

A home office spokesman said that since asylum seekers would have £10 cash to spend each week there was no need for them to pay only in vouchers and not receive any change. "They can use the cash to supplement the vouchers so they do not end up buying shopping for less than the value of the vouchers they have."

webTitle: Labour rules out purge of Livingstone supporters to avert party split

fields.headline: Labour rules out purge of Livingstone supporters to avert party split
fields.standfirst: The London mayor: special report
fields.trailText: The Labour leadership is seeking to heal the wounds caused by Ken Livingstone's departure by promising his supporters that they will not be expelled from the party if they refrain from campaigning overtly on behalf of the former Greater London council leader.
fields.body:
The Labour leadership is seeking to heal the wounds caused by Ken Livingstone's departure by promising his supporters that they will not be expelled from the party if they refrain from campaigning overtly on behalf of the former Greater London council leader.

In a move that shows the unease at Millbank at the prospect of a new split in the party, senior officials have made clear that they have no plans for a purge of Livingstone supporters.

A Millbank source added last night: "We are not looking for a purge. But anyone who openly urges people to vote for Livingstone will risk disciplinary action."

The decision shows that the party leadership has resigned itself to the prospect of thousands of traditional supporters throwing their lot in with Mr Livingstone.

The party will not tolerate any members who sign Mr Livingstone's nomination papers or join his campaign team. But anyone who offers low-level support, or makes clear that they are voting for Mr Livingstone, will escape punishment.

Millbank insisted last night that it was not planning to grant an amnesty to Livingstone supporters. But the admission that there will be no purge shows that the leadership is coming to terms with Mr Livingstone's daunting lead in the polls. Within hours of his announcement on Monday that he would abandon the Labour party, an ICM poll for the Guardian recorded support for Mr Livingstone at 68% - 55% above Frank Dobson, the official Labour candidate.

With such a commanding lead Millbank has calculated that the party would only damage itself if the leadership hounded out members who offer tacit support to Mr Livingstone.

However, the leadership has taken heart after resignations in the wake of Mr Livingstone's announcement proved smaller than expected. These are believed to be in three figures - endorsing the view of Labour's general secretary, Margaret McDonagh, who said resignations would be kept to a minimum if Mr Livingstone were beaten in a vote, however controversial, rather than blocking him altogether.

Mr Livingstone won important moral support yesterday from Dennis Canavan, who was elected as an independent MSP after the Labour leadership excluded him from its list of candidates for the Scottish parliamentary election.

During the prime minister's first visit to the Scottish parliament yesterday, Mr Canavan held up a placard that said "Vote Ken".

The MSP for West Falkirk, who was expelled from the party, predicted that Mr Livingstone would win the "toughest and dirtiest fight of his political career. Ken will win because the people of London will recognise the corrupt selection system to which Ken Livingstone fell victim," Mr Canavan said.

"They talk about New Labour's election machine being very efficient, but it is certainly not invincible." Mr Canavan recalled how the leadership spent thousands of pounds trying to undermine his election campaign which only backfired.

"Ironically, they spent far more trying to get rid of me than they would have spent if I had been an official Labour candidate," he said.

"Now New Labour will spend hundreds of thousands of pounds trying to stop Ken, but I still think he will win because the people of London will smell the stench of corruption in New Labour and will not want to vote for the puppet, Frank Dobson, the official Labour candidate."

fields.headline: National Roundup
fields.trailText: 'Evil' killer slit throat of neighbour
fields.body:
'Evil' killer slit throat of neighbour

An 'evil and depraved' killer who slit the throat of her neighbour during a petty robbery was jailed for life yesterday. The mother of her 22-year-old victim wept at the back of the high court in Aberdeen as Pamela Gourlay, 20, was sentenced, with the judge recommending she serve a minimum of 14 years.

"You are an evil young woman indeed," Lord Marnoch told Gourlay, a cafe bar chef. "To put on rubber gloves, arm yourself with a knife and then burst in on a neighbour and slit her throat in the course of a sustained attack all for the sake of some 20 or 30 pounds and some personal items is a crime of unequivocal depravity."

The jury took 4 hours and 40 minutes to reach the majority verdict, and rejected Gourlay's defence that the killing had been committed by her then boyfriend, Kris Taylor, 24.

He denied having any involvement in the murder and was called as a crown witness.

Melanie Sturton, 22, who worked at an old people's home run by nuns, was murdered on a Saturday morning last October after Gourlay had said goodbye to her boyfriend, who had spent the night at her bedsit.

Gourlay went downstairs to where Miss Sturton lived and stabbed her and slit her throat before robbing her.

Miss Sturton was found lying face down in her blood-soaked pyjamas by police officers the following Monday after she failed to turn up as expected at the family home in Deeside.

Officers who searched Gourlay's flat found a kitchen knife with blood on it, a pair of rubber surgical gloves and bloodstained clothes.

Farming 'threat to river life'

A purge on Britain's intensive farming methods which were throttling the life out of rivers and streams was demanded by government freshwater fisheries advisers in a report yesterday.

They called for tougher action against pollution through agricultural pesticides, the phasing out of many sheep dips, and grants to encourage farmers to stop livestock tramping down the banks of watercourses.

They suggested new environmental courts might be needed to impose penalties. New methods of combating salmon poaching - which would include every carcass offered for sale having to be tagged - were proposed.

The salmon and freshwater fisheries review group also called on the government to promote angling, especially among the young, an appeal quickly endorsed by the countryside minister, Elliot Morley.

But the chairwoman, Lynda Warren, of the university of Wales, Aberystwyth, said animal welfare issues had not been considered.

The advisers made clear that government moves to reward farmers who embarked on eco-friendly farming methods went nowhere near far enough, and contrasted the £32m paid to just four opera and ballet companies in 1998-99 with the £3.2m set aside for fisheries work in England next year.

The advisers also recommended controls on eel and salmon fishing, tighter rules to prevent new building damaging flood plains and a rule that new dams must include fish runs. - James Meikle

Kidnapping raises fears for peace

Police on both sides of the Irish border were last night hunting a 22-year-old man abducted from a house in Armagh in an operation which appeared to be a paramilitary kidnap.

The RUC admitted it was increasingly concerned for the safety of Mark Kelly.

Five masked men grabbed Mr Kelly just before mid night on Wednesday. He was bundled into a white Ford Transit and driven away at speed.

His family was refusing all requests for interviews last night. Police were unable to provide the media with a photograph or even a detailed description of the missing man.

Detectives were reluctant to discuss a motive for the abduction, but there was speculation last night that it might be related to a dispute between dissident and mainstream republicans.

They believe the white van was driven towards the border 10 miles away. They think it was heading towards Monaghan.

Mr Kelly was standing outside a house in Greenpark Manor, a middle class area, when the masked gang struck. Neighbours were yesterday unable to throw much light on the incident and said they knew little about Mr Kelly.

If the IRA proves to be responsible, it will be a serious blow to the peace process. It has virtually ended all punishment beatings since Sinn Fein issued a strong condemndation of them at the end of ex-US senator George Mitchell's review of the Good Friday agreement four months ago. - John Mullin

Man dies urinating on live rail line

A man was electrocuted after urinating on a live railway line, an inquest heard yesterday.

Six hundred volts of electricity formed an arc into the tip of Saliamin Akrami's penis, causing him to convulse and collapse on top of the live rail, Hornsey coroners court was told.

Afghan asylum seeker Mr Akrami, 32, of Willesden, north-west London, was discovered by a group of workmen repairing the track at deserted Kensal Green station in the early hours of October 23 last year.

Pathologist Rufus Crompton said the cause of death was electrocution. The only injuries were burns but the most telling was a tiny, precise burn mark to the urinary opening of the penis.

Mr Crompton told the court that, in his opinion, a stream of urine hitting electricity was the only way this type of injury could be caused.

The alcohol level present was 198mg - more than twice the drink-drive limit - and it was likely Mr Akrami was drunk.

The jury returned a verdict of misadventure.

The case was reconvened yesterday after an adjournment on Tuesday to allow relatives to examine CCTV footage of Mr Akrami on the station platform.

Woman banker wins payout

A former City banker has agreed a secret settlement after winning a claim of unfair dismissal from her £300,000-a-year job.

Speculation last night suggested that the deal could be worth up to £1m.

Kay Swinburne, 32, who was falsely accused by a manager at Deutsche Bank of sleeping with a client, agreed the settlement. One of the conditions was that neither side would comment on the payout.

The central London employment tribunal found the bank guilty of sex discrimination, breach of contract and constructive dismissal.

Mrs Swinburne, of Wimbledon, south London, who is married with one child, told the tribunal her manager, Hugh Tidbury, had referred to women as "hot totty", accused her of having an affair with a client, and ridiculed her for complaining about escort girls at an office party.

The bank apologised, but denied that her career had been affected.

GP cleared of kerb crawling

A police surgeon was cleared of kerb crawling yesterday after a woman he allegedly tried to solicit failed to turn up at court.

Patrick Gallagher, 47, a GP who worked with Co Durham police, was arrested on May 13 by British Transport Police near Middlesbrough railway station.

He denied trying to pick up a woman in the red light district of St Hilda's in Middlesbrough and told a previous court hearing that he was trying to gather information for a report he was preparing for the Association of Police Surgeons.

Robert Galley, prosecuting, told Teesside magistrates court yesterday that he could offer no evidence when his main witness, a woman in her 20s, failed to show at court. The woman arrived at court five minutes after the magistrate, Robin Cook, had dismissed the charge of soliciting from a vehicle.

Dr Gallagher, from Peterlee, said afterwards: "I'm relieved it's all over."

A transport police spokesman said: "We are very disappointed with the outcome of the court hearing."

Craig Brown, Dr Gallagher's solicitor, had earlier told magistrates that Dr Gallagher could not be identified by the woman and police had not staged an ID parade.
Linus Gregoriadis

A woman soldier serving with the army on a peace-keeping mission in the Balkans has been killed after stepping into the blades of a helicopter on the day she was due to return home to Britain.

Lance Corporal Katie Tranter, 19, from Sutton Coldrield, was leaving a Lynx helicopter at the airport in Split, Croatia, when she was struck by the rear rotor blade.

Ms Tranter, who had been serving with the Signals Regiment since December, had been flown from Bosnia to Croatia on February 24 before a transfer flight back to Britain.

She was brought back to Birmingham for treatment but died in hospital. A spokesman for the ministry of defence confirmed that she was caught in the helicopter's tail rotor blade.

Her 55-year-old father, Roy Cutts, said he and his former partner, Jo Tranter, were "absolutely shattered" by the accident.

Their daughter will be buried today.

Mr Cutts said: "She lived life to the full and speaking as her father, I think she was a beautiful girl.

"She had been going on about joining the army for a few years and when she left school in 1997 she did sign up."

The ministry of defence has launched an investigation into the circumstances surrounding her death.

An MoD spokesman said yesterday: "An inquiry has been started, and until that finishes we cannot really comment on the circumstances further." Linus Gregoriadis
fields.bodyText: 'Evil' killer slit throat of neighbour An 'evil and depraved' killer who slit the throat of her neighbour during a petty robbery was jailed for life yesterday. The mother of her 22-year-old victim wept at the back of the high court in Aberdeen as Pamela Gourlay, 20, was sentenced, with the judge recommending she serve a minimum of 14 years. "You are an evil young woman indeed," Lord Marnoch told Gourlay, a cafe bar chef. "To put on rubber gloves, arm yourself with a knife and then burst in on a neighbour and slit her throat in the course of a sustained attack all for the sake of some 20 or 30 pounds and some personal items is a crime of unequivocal depravity." The jury took 4 hours and 40 minutes to reach the majority verdict, and rejected Gourlay's defence that the killing had been committed by her then boyfriend, Kris Taylor, 24. He denied having any involvement in the murder and was called as a crown witness. Melanie Sturton, 22, who worked at an old people's home run by nuns, was murdered on a Saturday morning last October after Gourlay had said goodbye to her boyfriend, who had spent the night at her bedsit. Gourlay went downstairs to where Miss Sturton lived and stabbed her and slit her throat before robbing her. Miss Sturton was found lying face down in her blood-soaked pyjamas by police officers the following Monday after she failed to turn up as expected at the family home in Deeside. Officers who searched Gourlay's flat found a kitchen knife with blood on it, a pair of rubber surgical gloves and bloodstained clothes. They called for tougher action against pollution through agricultural pesticides, the phasing out of many sheep dips, and grants to encourage farmers to stop livestock tramping down the banks of watercourses. They suggested new environmental courts might be needed to impose penalties. New methods of combating salmon poaching - which would include every carcass offered for sale having to be tagged - were proposed. The salmon and freshwater fisheries review group also called on the government to promote angling, especially among the young, an appeal quickly endorsed by the countryside minister, Elliot Morley. But the chairwoman, Lynda Warren, of the university of Wales, Aberystwyth, said animal welfare issues had not been considered. The advisers made clear that government moves to reward farmers who embarked on eco-friendly farming methods went nowhere near far enough, and contrasted the £32m paid to just four opera and ballet companies in 1998-99 with the £3.2m set aside for fisheries work in England next year. The advisers also recommended controls on eel and salmon fishing, tighter rules to prevent new building damaging flood plains and a rule that new dams must include fish runs. - James Meikle Kidnapping raises fears for peace Police on both sides of the Irish border were last night hunting a 22-year-old man abducted from a house in Armagh in an operation which appeared to be a paramilitary kidnap. The RUC admitted it was increasingly concerned for the safety of Mark Kelly. Five masked men grabbed Mr Kelly just before mid night on Wednesday. He was bundled into a white Ford Transit and driven away at speed. His family was refusing all requests for interviews last night. Police were unable to provide the media with a photograph or even a detailed description of the missing man. Detectives were reluctant to discuss a motive for the abduction, but there was speculation last night that it might be related to a dispute between dissident and mainstream republicans. They believe the white van was driven towards the border 10 miles away. They think it was heading towards Monaghan. Mr Kelly was standing outside a house in Greenpark Manor, a middle class area, when the masked gang struck. Neighbours were yesterday unable to throw much light on the incident and said they knew little about Mr Kelly. If the IRA proves to be responsible, it will be a serious blow to the peace process. It has virtually ended all punishment beatings since Sinn Fein issued a strong condemndation of them at the end of ex-US senator George Mitchell's review of the Good Friday agreement four months ago. - John Mullin Man dies urinating on live rail line A man was electrocuted after urinating on a live railway line, an inquest heard yesterday. fields.headline: Green pledge topples Norwegian government
fields.trailText: The Norwegian prime minister, Kjell Magne Bondevik, and his minority government are to resign today after losing a vote of confidence yesterday in a key environmental dispute with parliament.
fields.body:
The Norwegian prime minister, Kjell Magne Bondevik, and his minority government are to resign today after losing a vote of confidence yesterday in a key environmental dispute with parliament.

Mr Bondevik of the Christian Democrats said he would deliver his formal resignation to King Harald.

"I will also advise his majesty to approach the parliamentary leader of the largest party, Labour's Jens Stoltenberg [about forming a new government]," he added.

Mr Bondevik had staked the three-party government he formed in 1997 on a dispute with the parliamentary majority over a move which he claimed would weaken Norway's environmental laws.

The government, with 42 seats in the 165-member parliament, opposed proposals to build electrical power plants to burn some of Norway's vast natural gas supplies.

The country derives virtually all its electricity from clean hydroelectric plants, and the Bondevik government wanted to postpone natural gas plants until new technology could make them pollution free.

Parliament's majority - led by Labour and Conservatives in an uneasy alliance - wants work on the plants to start immediately, even if means amending the country's strict anti-pollution laws to allow carbon dioxide emissions.

In a last-ditch effort to save the government, Mr Bondevik, who is a Lutheran clergyman, said he could accept parliament's will if it would pass his additional resolution guaranteeing that any changes would not weaken Norway's overall environmental legislation. Otherwise, he said, he would have to resign.

He lost the vote 81-71, with 13 members absent.

fields.headline: Housework 'still done by women'
fields.standfirst: International women's day: special report
fields.trailText: Working mothers spend more hours a week on housework than on their full-time job, a survey revealed yesterday. Full-time working mothers spend 56 hours a week on housework, part-time working mothers do 68 hours and housewives put in 76 hours, while fathers do only 31.
fields.body:
Working mothers spend more hours a week on housework than on their full-time job, a survey revealed yesterday. Full-time working mothers spend 56 hours a week on housework, part-time working mothers do 68 hours and housewives put in 76 hours, while fathers do only 31.

Mothers who spend an average of 67 hours a week on household chores would earn around £21,000 a year if they were paid for housework, the survey showed.

Housework was valued at £377.90 per week, just less than the average annual salary of £20,919, according to research based on figures from the office for national statistics.

Mothers of children aged three or under spend up to 84 hours a week on housework, but a man's quota is not affected by his children's age.

Mothers spend around 14 hours a week cooking (valued at £6), compared with fathers' four hours, and 21 hours washing and ironing (£5.60), compared with eight and a half hours for men.

Mothers clean for 13 hours a week (£4.90) compared with their husbands' four hours and women spend about an hour sewing (£5.10) compared with 10 minutes for men.

Fathers do four hours a week of gardening (£6.20), an hour more than mothers.

Not surprisingly 64% of parents would pay someone else to do their housework, with 24% choosing washing and ironing as their least favourite task.

The survey of 543 parents of children under 18 was carried out for Legal & General.

fields.headline: Aid plea for forgotten island
fields.standfirst: Mozambique floods: special report
fields.trailText: Coffins floated in the floodwaters of northern Madagascar yesterday as aid workers tried to reach remote villages cut off by rains which have killed at least 130 people.
fields.body:
Coffins floated in the floodwaters of northern Madagascar yesterday as aid workers tried to reach remote villages cut off by rains which have killed at least 130 people.

The government said nearly 750,000 people had been affected by the floods, which left 10,000 people homeless and more than 12,000 stranded.

Cyclone Eline tore across the middle of the Indian ocean island last month before moving on to Mozambique. It was followed last week by cyclone Gloria.

Many of the worst-affected areas are surrounded with water, and the government aid agencies have carried out only rough assessments of the needs from the air.

The government has asked aid agencies for food, medicines and blankets, but has yet to make a public appeal to the international community.

Sergio Soro of Unicef said that while attention was on Mozambique, Madagascar was in desperate need of assistance. "Unfortunately we are not bathed in the limelight of the world's television cameras, and our plight is dramatic," he said.
Reuters, Antananarivo

webTitle: 'My house I can rebuild. My crops will grow again'

fields.headline: 'My house I can rebuild. My crops will grow again'
fields.standfirst: Mozambique floods: special report
fields.trailText: For nearly two weeks, Joao Nhassengo had no idea whether his family was even alive.
fields.body:
For nearly two weeks, Joao Nhassengo had no idea whether his family was even alive.

He first heard of the floods devastating his native Mozambique on the radio at the miners' hostel in Johannesburg's gold fields where he works. With a one-week pass from work in hand, the 28-year-old miner rushed home, where he discovered his village underwater and his family gone.

"That was much worse than finding that your house is destroyed. I looked for anyone I knew who could tell me anything about them, but there were so many people from such a big area it was hard to find anyone," he says.

So Mr Nhassengo waited, terrified for the fate of his three children. The youngest is 11 months, the eldest just six years. To make matters worse, he stayed away from work for longer than his pass permitted, and worried that this would cost him a valuable job.

When the floods began to subside last weekend, he again made his way back to his home near Calanga, in the north of the country. The water had dropped to knee deep but there was still no word of his family.

Then two days ago his wife, Beatriz, returned. She came alone.

"When I saw her across the field coming on her own, I thought the children must be dead or very sick."

But to his joy, he learned from Beatriz that the children had survived. She told him "they were in the camp but conditions were hard and now they would all come home".

Now they are all together and taking stock. The children complain of stomach pains, perhaps caused by drinking the polluted floodwater, even though their mother boils it first. But the medics in the camp said they did not have malaria.

The family is alive but its home is wrecked. The house is just four rooms. The force of water smashed all the windows and ripped the doors from their hinges. It tore away part of the roof.

Beatriz Nhassengo, has searched the house and looked outside, but the missing parts of her home are nowhere to be seen. The flood drove all the furniture against the wall of the living room. As the waters receded, the chairs were sealed under a thick layer of mud.

Next to the window, where the silt sat in the scorching sun that has come and gone in recent days, a thick crust formed. She cracked it open with a ladle and peeled the dirt from her furniture.

Although the bed frame and kitchen utensils can be salvaged, the mattresses and chairs are wrecked. Even when they dry out, the stench will always be there. Ms Nhassengo holds up her only pair of shoes that are not flip-flops. They too are ruined.

The pigs and ducks are gone. Drowned, presumably. It is a great loss. The ducks were for breeding. The children played with the sow, but she too was for breeding.

The drop toilet has collapsed. Another will have to be dug.

But most important are the crops. Ms Nhassengo, who is 21, worked the patch of ground -nearly five metres wide by 12 metres long - that fed her family and supplied a little extra cash if there was a surplus harvest. The hoes are still in the house. That is a start. But the maize is ruined.

At first glance it looks well enough, if a little battered. But closer inspection reveals the rot that had set in from the rubbish tip. The entire harvest is a write- off.

There is worse. The field is a bog. The water appears to have drained away but one step from the path and and a person sinks in the mud up to the shin. Another step, and it is up to the knee.

Beatriz Nhassengo wonders how long it will take for the land to dry out. "We cannot replant in this. Even if we put in new seed, it will not grow right. The seed will come to the surface when the land dries out," she says.

Floods come and go in Mozambique. So do droughts that drag on for years. But this is the worst natural calamity that anyone under the age of 50 can remember.

Almost everyone compares the flood to the war. Some say it was worse than the barbarity inflicted on Mozambique in that conflict from 1976-92 by the Renamo rebels, a creation of Rhodesia that later got South Africa's support. At the same time, it could be that the war that gave Mozambicans the stoicism they have exhibited in this flood disaster.

Joao Nhassengo has the advantage of money - his miner's wages - to help rebuild his home. If he wants to hold on to his job he must go back to Johannesburg. His wife will be left to complete the cleanup and revive the fields.

Her task wasn't made any easier yesterday by another heavy downpour that washed silt back into the house.

"It is something to survive. My children are alive. My house I can rebuild. My crops will grow again. There are many struggles in life. This is just one," she said.

webTitle: Our man in Harare recalled in row over diplomatic bag

fields.headline: Our man in Harare recalled in row over diplomatic bag
fields.standfirst:
Hain accuses Mugabe regime of 'totally unacceptable behaviour'

Zimbabwe special report
The foreign office
Zimbabwe government online
fields.trailText: Relations between Britain and Zimbabwe deterioriated significantly yesterday when the foreign office recalled its high commissioner in Harare for consultations after Robert Mugabe's government broke open an impounded British diplomatic bag.
fields.byline: Andrew Meldrum  in Harare and  Michael White
fields.body:
Relations between Britain and Zimbabwe deterioriated significantly yesterday when the foreign office recalled its high commissioner in Harare for consultations after Robert Mugabe's government broke open an impounded British diplomatic bag.

Foreign office minister Peter Hain called in Zimbabwe's high commissioner in London to protest about the incident. He said: "This is not the act of a civilised country. This is a grave breach of the Vienna convention. Zimbabwe should be in no doubt that this is totally unacceptable behaviour." The opening of the bag showed the "level of paranoia" gripping the ailing Mugabe regime.

Zimbabwean television has been showing pictures of the diplomatic container amid semi-official hints that it could contain arms, sophisticated spying equipment or other subversive material. Accord ing to Whitehall officials, the local media has suggested the material is intended to help opposition parties or beleagured white farmers. In fact, Mr Hain said, it was "routine equipment" to provide "protective screening" for diplomatic communications.

The equipment is now back in British hands, but may have to be sent back to London in case it has been tampered with or damaged.

The foreign office is determined to put the incident behind it quickly and resume urgent efforts to restart constructive dialogue with Harare over its economic problems and uncertain political future.

Britain's high commissioner, Peter Longworth, flew to London on Wednesday night. Calling his Zimbabwean counterpart, Simbarashe Mumben gegwi, in to see Mr Hain, the veteran South African anti-apartheid campaigner, was seen as a lesser option to sending him home.

Mr Hain said the Mugabe government had led Zimbabwe into "economic chaos and increasing social instability and political isolation. The level of paranoia with which it views the international community could not be more ably demonstrated than by its need to open a diplomatic bag without our consent, against international law and all the norms of sensible civilised conduct between countries."

Zimbabwe's crises include widespread invasions of white-owned farms, inflation of 60%, economic decline and a desperate shortage of foreign exchange that has caused a crippling fuel shortage.

"He really didn't need to know what was in that bag. He just wanted to show that he could give Britain a black eye," said John Makumbe, a political science lecturer at the university of Zimbabwe. "But it is unwise and unstatesmanlike. It is a disaster for Zimbabwe."

Mr Makumbe said that Mr Mugabe was "in a fury because he had just returned from Kuwait empty-handed". Mr Mugabe had been expected to get a $100m loan to solve the country's fuel shortages. Instead Kuwait said that Zimbabwe was not creditworthy.

"Mr Mugabe must believe that Britain and the US got to the Kuwaitis before he did and convinced them not to give money," said Mr Makumbe. "He is angry and lashing out at the international community. But this is so short-sighted."

The deterioration in diplomatic relations with Britain and the invasions of white-owned farms by Mr Mugabe's supporters may well increase international opposition to his government. "Companies and investors are watching their interests go up in smoke," said Mr Makumbe. "They may well decide to back any opposition to Mugabe and by any means."
fields.bodyText: Relations between Britain and Zimbabwe deterioriated significantly yesterday when the foreign office recalled its high commissioner in Harare for consultations after Robert Mugabe's government broke open an impounded British diplomatic bag. Foreign office minister Peter Hain called in Zimbabwe's high commissioner in London to protest about the incident. He said: "This is not the act of a civilised country. This is a grave breach of the Vienna convention. Zimbabwe should be in no doubt that this is totally unacceptable behaviour." The opening of the bag showed the "level of paranoia" gripping the ailing Mugabe regime. Zimbabwean television has been showing pictures of the diplomatic container amid semi-official hints that it could contain arms, sophisticated spying equipment or other subversive material. Accord ing to Whitehall officials, the local media has suggested the material is intended to help opposition parties or beleagured white farmers. In fact, Mr Hain said, it was "routine equipment" to provide "protective screening" for diplomatic communications. The equipment is now back in British hands, but may have to be sent back to London in case it has been tampered with or damaged. The foreign office is determined to put the incident behind it quickly and resume urgent efforts to restart constructive dialogue with Harare over its economic problems and uncertain political future. Britain's high commissioner, Peter Longworth, flew to London on Wednesday night. Calling his Zimbabwean counterpart, Simbarashe Mumben gegwi, in to see Mr Hain, the veteran South African anti-apartheid campaigner, was seen as a lesser option to sending him home. Mr Hain said the Mugabe government had led Zimbabwe into "economic chaos and increasing social instability and political isolation. The level of paranoia with which it views the international community could not be more ably demonstrated than by its need to open a diplomatic bag without our consent, against international law and all the norms of sensible civilised conduct between countries." Zimbabwe's crises include widespread invasions of white-owned farms, inflation of 60%, economic decline and a desperate shortage of foreign exchange that has caused a crippling fuel shortage. "He really didn't need to know what was in that bag. He just wanted to show that he could give Britain a black eye," said John Makumbe, a political science lecturer at the university of Zimbabwe. "But it is unwise and unstatesmanlike. It is a disaster for Zimbabwe." Mr Makumbe said that Mr Mugabe was "in a fury because he had just returned from Kuwait empty-handed". Mr Mugabe had been expected to get a $100m loan to solve the country's fuel shortages. Instead Kuwait said that Zimbabwe was not creditworthy. "Mr Mugabe must believe that Britain and the US got to the Kuwaitis before he did and convinced them not to give money," said Mr Makumbe. "He is angry and lashing out at the international community. But this is so short-sighted." The deterioration in diplomatic relations with Britain and the invasions of white-owned farms by Mr Mugabe's supporters may well increase international opposition to his government. "Companies and investors are watching their interests go up in smoke," said Mr Makumbe. "They may well decide to back any opposition to Mugabe and by any means."

fields.trailText: Twenty Afghans, some parents and their children, have lodged an official appeal against their deportation, which was ordered by the home secretary, Jack Straw, after the Stansted airport siege last month.
fields.body:
Twenty Afghans, some parents and their children, have lodged an official appeal against their deportation, which was ordered by the home secretary, Jack Straw, after the Stansted airport siege last month.

The Immigration Advisory Service announced the appeal yesterday; the case is expected to take some months. After the peaceful conclusion, 15 Afghans were charged with hijack, 27 asked for asylum, and the rest elected to go back.

fields.headline: Mystery death of Kremlin critic
fields.standfirst:
Journalist who was outspoken opponent of Putin-led war against Chechnya killed in Moscow air crash

Russia: special report
fields.trailText: A prominent Russian journalist and media magnate who specialised in investigative exposés of the Kremlin was killed in a mystery air crash at Moscow airport yesterday. Artyom Borovik was one of the loudest critics in Moscow of the acting president, Vladimir Putin, and of Mr Putin's war against Chechnya.
fields.body:
A prominent Russian journalist and media magnate who specialised in investigative exposés of the Kremlin was killed in a mystery air crash at Moscow airport yesterday. Artyom Borovik was one of the loudest critics in Moscow of the acting president, Vladimir Putin, and of Mr Putin's war against Chechnya.

The small Yak-40 aircraft crashed immediately on take-off at Sheremetevo airport, killing all nine people, four passengers and five crew, on board. The cause of the crash was unknown. Police recovered the flight recorder and launched an inquiry, saying that they did not exclude the possibility of a terrorist act.

Borovik, 39, the son of a prominent Soviet journalist, had just taken off for Kiev, accompanying the oil industry executive Ziya Bazayev, a Chechen businessman who heads the Alliance Group oil company.

In more peaceful times, Bazayev worked in the oil industry in Grozny, the Chechen capital which has been destroyed by Russian bombardment and is occupied by Russian troops.

"It's very difficult these days for a Chechen to be in the oil industry in Russia," said the former Russian prime minister Sergei Kiriyenko, fuelling speculation about foul play.

The three-engined passenger jet is generally regarded as a reliable aircraft. The plane that crashed yesterday had been in use for 24 years.

Pilots at Sheremetevo told Russian television that even if all three engines had failed on takeoff, the plane would still have been able to land relatively safely.

"I don't think oil magnates use unreliable aircraft," said Vsevolod Bogdanov, head of the Russian journalists' union.

Such remarks encouraged speculation that the crash was caused by a criminal plot, though there was no fire or explosion. Commentators surmised that enemies of the oil executive in Russia's notoriously ruthless business mafias were responsible for the deaths, or enemies of Borovik whose newspapers and television shows crusaded against corruption in Russia's political and economic elites.

"Power in Russia is not in the hands of the democrats or the communists, it's in the hands of organised crime and the mafia," Borovik once famously declared. He was well connected politically and a respected, outspoken opponent of Mr Putin.

Russian state television, servile to the Kremlin, took his Top Secret programme off the air last year, a decision that Borovik ascribed to the looming election campaigns for the Russian parliament and presidency. He often appeared in his own TV production, reporting on and denouncing the graft-filled netherworlds of Russian politics.

"We often talk of the media wars here, forgetting the real danger," said Mr Bogdanov. "Artyom [Borovik] brings to more than 20 the journalists who have gone."

"His reporting was acute, honest and principled. He took risks. But I don't want to speculate," said the dead journalist's father, Genrik Borovik, a veteran Soviet-era journalist who worked for years as a correspondent in the US.

Mr Borovik's newspapers, Top Secret and Versiya, concentrated on juicy revelations of the venality and the corruption among Russia's rich and powerful. In recent months, the Borovik publications have been bitterly critical of Mr Putin, his erstwhile KGB connections, and his closeness to the entourage of the former president Boris Yeltsin.

The front page of this week's edition of Versiya is headlined "The Routine Genocide" in reference to alleged atrocities perpetrated in Chechnya by Russian troops. Highly unusually for the generally compliant Russian media, the news paper features a two-page report on alleged atrocities.

The main article in the most recent issue of the monthly Top Secret warns that Mr Putin could be a dictator bent on "liquidating liberalism" who is exploiting the Chechen war to mask his dearth of policy ideas.

In January, police sought to detain another prominent investigative journalist, Alexander Khinshteyn, and revive an old KGB practice by sending him to a psychiatric clinic run by the interior ministry outside Moscow.

At the weekend the Kremlin warned the Russian media that it would take action against "fabrications and provocations" in the election campaign.

"The press service will detect all facts of lies with respect to acting President Putin and reserves the right to use all means necessary for an asymmetrical response to provocations," said a statement from the Putin campaign's media office.

fields.headline: Diary
fields.body:
 A most extraordinary development at the Spectator. No longer sated by his own weekly column, Paul Johnson has sequestered a second which he writes under the sobriquet "Stephen Glover". All my sane and rational friend's stylistic hallmarks are here - the regal contempt for facts (there's so much we could teach him about accuracy, if he'd only let us); the unfettered fascination with his own victimhood; and, of course, the endearingly hilarious obsession with us. Reiterating a recent claim that the Guardian is run by the IRA, Paul/Steve concludes: "no amount of dark threats of retribution delivered against me, no wild accusations of 'McCarthyism', will deter me from speaking out." Hurrah! You may recall near identical musings from Paul a while ago when he was promising a book unveiling our myriad wickednesses. Dear, dear, what a pickle he's in. For God's sake, but he's even insolent to me! The phrase "clanking wit" is deployed (ouch!!!), while more distressing is the public unveiling of my slavish obeisance to the editor. He's right, of course. I am sick to death of fighting the editor's battles. From now on, pal, you'll have to learn to stand up for yourself.

 On a point of fact, meanwhile, a tiny and most untypical error has crept into Paul/Steve's otherwise splendid article. The author claims that the two items here sympathising with Steve about the unfortunate brevity of his career as an editor (and by no means everyone in this business regards Janet Street-Porter as the least able editor of the Independent on Sunday) were "seemingly unconnected" with his own original article. What in fact appeared here a week ago was "Stephen Glover, who recently accused this paper of being run by an IRA cell". Ah well, it can't be helped: not everyone can cope with English comprehension, any more than everyone can edit a newspaper. No shame in that, so let's put the whole affair behind us and hear no more about it.

 Malcolm McLaren's mayoral campaign shies away from over-slickness. A colleague arranged a brief phone interview with Malcolm, but when the appointed time came it emerged that both McLaren phones - his assistant's mobile and his campaign hotline - were occupied so a mobile was biked over to him for the duration of the interview. Very Primary Colors.

 Yesterday morning, meanwhile, Malcolm joined the other candidates in Vauxhall for the unveiling at 11am of a huge poster encouraging black and Asian electors to vote. Countless TV and newspaper cameras were there to record the event, says reader Michael Bailey who had a fine view from his office window. The same view he had less than an hour later when, with all candidates and cameras gone, the poster was pasted over by the same advertisement for ISAs that had been on the billboard at the start of the day.

 The London Wildlife Trust reports an approach from a reporter on the Daily Dome newspaper, asking for happy stories about all the rare birds that "are using the site now it's decontaminated and landscaped". How droll. The truth, famously, is that where the site used to be incredibly rich in rare birds such as the black redstart, the development has driven them away and they are unlikely ever to return. "Oh, we're not going to mention anything about that," said the Daily Dome's Kate Morris when this was explained, "because of our relationship with the New Millennium Experience Company." Mmmm.

 As you read this, a number of "Oooh, You Amaze Me!" T-shirts are being printed exclusively for Diary readers. Some of these will be given to those who suggest filmic speeches for Dobbo Does The Movies (on Tuesday, it's Casablanca), others will be for sale. Details of prices and how to order will appear next week.

webTitle: I am trying to right my mistake, says Kohl

fields.headline: I am trying to right my mistake, says Kohl
fields.standfirst:
British publisher contributes to ex-chancellor's funds to pay fine

German corruption scandal: special report
fields.trailText: Looking confident, relaxed, even boisterous, the former German chancellor Helmut Kohl yesterday revealed that he had collected almost all the money needed to pay the huge fine his party faces because of his earlier, illegal fundraising.
fields.body:
Looking confident, relaxed, even boisterous, the former German chancellor Helmut Kohl yesterday revealed that he had collected almost all the money needed to pay the huge fine his party faces because of his earlier, illegal fundraising.

Most of the DM5.9m (£1.84m) already secured had come from friends and acquaintances, he told a press conference in Berlin, including a donation from the British publisher Lord Weidenfeld. Mr Kohl said he and his wife, Hannelore, had personally pledged about £220,000.

The Christian Democrat Union (CDU) is struggling to emerge from the worst crisis in its history, caused by evidence that, under Mr Kohl's leadership, it raised tens of millions of pounds without identifying the donors, as required by law. At the heart of the scandal is the question of whether party officials were covering up the trading of cash for government favours - an allegation the former chancellor indignantly denied.

Mr Kohl, who admits that he personally accepted £650,000 while chancellor, has doggedly refused to name his benefactors, saying he guaranteed them anonymity.

Yesterday, he stood by his refusal. "I have not named the names and I will not name them," he said.

He did, however, reveal the full list of those who had come to the CDU's aid this time. The list of 34 names included industrialists, celebrities and personal friends.

The biggest single contribution came from the media tycoon Leo Kirch. Lord Weidenfeld, who has long been active in promoting Anglo-German relations, was listed as having put up £9,300.

Mr Kohl and his wife will contribute about £62,000 in cash; the rest will come from a loan secured against their house in the former chancellor's home town of Ludwigshafen. But despite behaving like a man who had just put behind him a rather distasteful episode - Mr Kohl grinned frequently and bantered with correspondents - he is still in deep trouble.

He is under criminal investigation by prosecutors in Bonn. His refusal to clear up the origin of party funds is in blatant defiance of a law which his own government introduced. And it has won him the enmity of many previously loyal supporters among the Christian Democrats.

Mr Kohl denied he was trying to buy back popularity and influence. "I see no reason to have to make up with the party," he said. "I'm trying to right my mistake. I was and am still in the party. It's my political home."

Though several Christian Democrat MPs have called on him to give up his seat in parliament, the former chancellor said he had no intention of doing so.

His latest collection came under attack from the ruling Social Democrats. "He is trying to shirk responsibility by having third persons fund his breach of the law," said the MP Frank Hofmann.

His successor as leader of the CDU, Wolfgang Schäuble, said the party welcomed all contributions. But, with one eye on the critics, he added: "[The] loss of credibility cannot be redressed with money alone."

Support for Germany's conservatives has slumped since the scandal broke, though they put up a creditable showing in the regional election in Schleswig-Holstein last month. Mr Kohl's latest - entirely legal - venture into fundraising should strengthen his behind-the-scenes influence on the party he led for 25 years. But his clout will be tested in the coming weeks as the CDU prepares to choose a new leader, and the signs are that other interests will prevail.

Mr Schäuble, who was also caught up in the scandal, will give up the leadership next month. Last weekend one of the main contenders for the leadership, the former defence minister Volker Rühe, ruled himself out, leaving the field apparently clear for the party's general secretary, Angela Merkel.

Though a former favourite of Mr Kohl's, Ms Merkel was the first senior party official to openly disown him after the scandal broke. She is not liked by the wing of the party that remains loyal to the former chancellor, but polls have shown that she is the preferred choice of most of the rank and file.

On Wednesday she won the valuable endorsement of the CDU's new parliamentary leader, Friedrich Merz.

Although the amount of the fine has yet to be set for his party's illegal funding, the law allows for a figure of up to three times the amount found to have been kept off the books. The CDU is expecting to have to pay about £2m.

The former chancellor said he was confident he could raise the entire amount by the time the CDU meets in conference next month.

A much bigger penalty of £12.8m has already been imposed for illegal fundraising by a regional branch of the party from Hesse. Earlier this week the CDU began an appeal.

webTitle: BT plays catch-up on wap phones

fields.headline: BT plays catch-up on wap phones
fields.standfirst:
E-finance: special report
WAP explained
fields.trailText: BT yesterday said there was no immediate plan to spin off its prized Cellnet mobile arm but refused to rule out a sale as it launched Britain's first pre-paid mobile internet phone.
fields.body:
BT yesterday said there was no immediate plan to spin off its prizedCellnet mobile arm but refused to rule out a sale as it launched Britain's first pre-paid mobile internet phone.

The telecommunications group, which has been portrayed as an industry laggard in recent months, attempted to damp down speculation that its 12% slump in value would force a sale.

"We're not just going to roll Cellnet off," said Andy Green, the company's group director of corporate strategy. But he conceded the company never said "no to anything".

A sale would highlight the value of Cellnet to BT, with a price tag suggested between £20bn to £25bn, and support the group's languishing share price.BT's shares, however, received a boost yesterday as the company unveiled its latest round of strategic initiatives for its mobile internet brand Genie. The stock jumped 141p to 1315p.

BT said it had struck partnerships with more than 30 companies and content providers to enhance Genie and additionally planned a £160m investment in mobile applications and services. The company also intends to offer in April the UK's first pre-paid wireless application protocol mobile internet phone for £99.99, predicting sales of 500,000 handsets within three months of its launch.

Chris Godsmark, analyst at Investec Henderson Crosthwaite, said the move would allow BT to wrest back the initiative from rivals. "It's a more positive and more aggressive piece of news from BT than we've seen for some time. It shows BT leading the way in wireless data," he said.

While BT argued the phone's cost provided a cheap way on to the web compared to buying a PC, the net connection charges on a mobile remained at least 10p a minute. BT's £99.99 package would come with 200 minutes of free weekend net access or voice calls.

Peter Erskine, the managing director of BT CellNet, said mobile telephones would be the main vehicle in the future for consumers to access the internet and would meet the government's demand for the web to be available to the UK mass market.

BT is also expected to launch a packaged mobile internet offering to business shortly as well as trying to strike further alliances with content providers for its Genie service.

The biggest content agreement on display was with Freeserve, the UK's largest internet service provider.

BT's new internet mobiles will be able to receive the emails of Freeserve's 2m account holders.

Other services available to customers on BT internet mobiles range from football results from 365 Corporation, through music provided by EMI to banking online with Halifax, Abbey National or First Direct.

The list stretches even further for those providing the support and applications for the operation of BT's internet mobiles - Microsoft, Logica, Phone.com, Ericsson, Psion and Motorola.

But phone sales may be affected by the introduction of higher speed mobile networks, such as General Packet Radio Services and, over the next few years, the Universal Mobile Telecommunications service - customers may not want to upgrade mobile phones constantly with the changing network arrangements.

BT also revealed that it has won a UTMS licence for the Isle of Man scheduled for introduction next year. BT is at present bidding against 12 other companies for one of five UTMS licences in the UK.

The company also intends to offer in April the UK's first pre-paid wireless application protocol mobile internet phone for £99.99, predicting sales of 500,000 handsets within three months of its launch. Chris Godsmark, analyst at Investec Henderson Crosthwaite, said the move would allow BT to wrest back the initiative from rivals. "It's a more positive and more aggressive piece of news from BT than we've seen for some time. It shows BT leading the way in wireless data," he said. While BT argued the phone's cost provided a cheap way on to the web compared to buying a PC, the net connection charges on a mobile remained at least 10p a minute. BT's £99.99 package would come with 200 minutes of free weekend net access or voice calls. Peter Erskine, the managing director of BT CellNet, said mobile telephones would be the main vehicle in the future for consumers to access the internet and would meet the government's demand for the web to be available to the UK mass market. BT is also expected to launch a packaged mobile internet offering to business shortly as well as trying to strike further alliances with content providers for its Genie service. The biggest content agreement on display was with Freeserve, the UK's largest internet service provider. BT's new internet mobiles will be able to receive the emails of Freeserve's 2m account holders. Other services available to customers on BT internet mobiles range from football results from 365 Corporation, through music provided by EMI to banking online with Halifax, Abbey National or First Direct. The list stretches even further for those providing the support and applications for the operation of BT's internet mobiles - Microsoft, Logica, Phone.com, Ericsson, Psion and Motorola. But phone sales may be affected by the introduction of higher speed mobile networks, such as General Packet Radio Services and, over the next few years, the Universal Mobile Telecommunications service - customers may not want to upgrade mobile phones constantly with the changing network arrangements. BT also revealed that it has won a UTMS licence for the Isle of Man scheduled for introduction next year. BT is at present bidding against 12 other companies for one of five UTMS licences in the UK.

webTitle: Stock exchange holds the line over hi-tech listings

fields.headline: Stock exchange holds the line over hi-tech listings
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: The stock exchange is standing firm and refusing to ease its strict listing rules in order to ease a backlog of hi-tech companies desperate to float their shares while "dot.com" mania lasts.
fields.body:
The stock exchange is standing firm and refusing to ease its strict listing rules in order to ease a backlog of hi-tech companies desperate to float their shares while "dot.com" mania lasts.

It is thought a number of flotation candidates have been told to get their paperwork in order, with the result that 30 to 40 businesses are being kept off the exchange until they can satisfy regulatory requirements.

Unmoved by threats from some quarters that impatient hi-tech ventures may choose instead to list on New York's Nasdaq market, an exchange source insisted last night that "trends come and go . . . [rules] evolve and develop, but principles stay the same".

The chief principle is, he added, that "the listing rules are ultimately there to protect investors".

So called dot.com stocks are catered for by a new rule, chapter 25, introduced at the start of the year, which recognises such companies are unlikely to meet the traditional criterion of a trading record stretching back several years. Instead, it provides an alternative set of criteria, including a £50m minimum capitalisation, of which at least £20m must be floated, and quarterly reporting.

But chapter 25, exchange insiders insist, is supposed to be a different route to the same high standard, not an easier set of standards in itself.

A linked complaint from the hi-tech sector about London listing rules is that the new breed "incubator" companies, which have sprung up to nurture internet-based ventures and bring them to market, are themselves being kept off the exchange by being required to comply with the rules governing traditional investment trusts.

The exchange does impose one set of "investment entity rules". Incubators, said a source, can be listed provided they comply with these rules, but "many do not".

An adviser to one incubator fund that has an experienced managment team, heavyweight institutional backing and a leading brokerage advising it warned: "The exchange risks missing a trick here and it won't be for the first time.

"We would rather be on the main exchange but will go to Nasdaq if we have to. The exchange risks missing out on a potential bunch of flotations unless it is more forward thinking."

Refusing to dilute its listing rules has brought the exchange a swelling chorus of criticism from some of the fringier would-be flotation candidates, but it is believed exchange insiders took heart from yesterday's comments from the chancellor, Gordon Brown, warning investors to exercise caution before piling into dot.com shares.

One source said: "[The] sense is that as with all markets . . . there is this herd instinct".

The stock exchange pointed out that chapter 25 was not specifically aimed at any one type of company, and said it would impose neither stricter nor more lenient standards on any company simply because that company was involved in a certain type of business.

Control of market listing is set to be transferred later this year to the chief City regulator, the financial services authority, but this is unlikely to bring any relaxation in standards.

fields.headline: Give more
fields.standfirst:
The chancellor wants businesses to donate cash to good causes. But this approach to corporate philanthropy is no longer up-to-date

Chancellor's pre-budget speech: special report
fields.trailText: In the Budget, Gordon Brown will pitch for philanthropy. British business, the chancellor thinks, is lagging behind the US in corporate giving. Last month he chastised its miserliness. In the Budget he promises to remove red tape to encourage the business world to enter "the giving age".
fields.body:
In the Budget, Gordon Brown will pitch for philanthropy. British business, the chancellor thinks, is lagging behind the US in corporate giving. Last month he chastised its miserliness. In the Budget he promises to remove red tape to encourage the business world to enter "the giving age".

These moves will be welcomed by charities, reeling from the loss of tax rebates on dividend income. And just about everybody (except hard-nosed shareholders) will welcome a higher share of soaring profits siphoned off into "good causes".

So far so good. But there are dangers in companies being encouraged to think that they fulfil their responsibilities to society merely by handing over a penny in the pound to charity. (In fact, the UK is nearer a quarter of 1%, as the chart shows.) Mr Brown is behind the times in latching on to an American approach which is already going out of fashion even in the US, and which has never been as important in Europe as more intensive community involvement and more fund by private firms.

According to some calculations, 80% of US businesses give nothing to charity, despite the tax breaks. Those that do have often been looking for shallow public relations benefits. By contrast the modern approach, according to the Conference Board, a research body, is "strategic philanthropy". In a report last year it noted: "The contributions function is being linked to other areas of the business, with the dual emphases of meeting the needs of beneficiaries as well as those of the corporation. This is a marked departure from the origins of contribution earlier in this century, when the size of the giving budget and the direction gifts took were essentially matters of executive whim."

The notion that businesses need to get some benefit from the money they give away may be discomforting. But according to Business in the Community, support which is integrated in a business is likely to be more sustainable. It runs the Percent Club, whose 1% target includes gifts in kind, staff time and management costs. But most of the organisation's work is concerned with business-community activity, employment policies and environmental performance. These are to do with the way business are run, not old-fashioned philanthropy where, come the bad times, the cash disappears.

Support which is part of the marketing or human resources budget, on the other hand, tends to be more resilient, though not unaffected by falling sales. Cause-related marketing, as it is known, such as Tesco's computers for schools scheme, Marks & Spencer and Children's Promise, or Persil and red nose day, can set alarm bells ringing in the voluntary sector. At its worst, this kind of liaison is just a cynical public relations gimmick. At its best it provides long-term support for charity which is likely to produce much more money over a longer period because it comes from the swollen marketing budget - and because companies get something out of it, too.

The same applies to giving in the form of employees' time. If this is just philanthropy it will be a chore, resented by managers who see staff disappear from work for a day, or who are themselves dispatched to "mentor" a teacher or a recalcitrant teenager in a local school.

But many companies have discovered that giving staff community challenges is a valuable part of employee development, and much more effective in team-building than traditional external courses or "adventure" challenges. The consultancy Cap-Gemini, for example, has added a week to its graduate induction course, during which the new recruits are sent out to community projects to give them a taste of how the other half live before they become immersed in the corporate rat race.

And the great thing about giving employee time, it seems, is that these workers are then much more likely to give cash through mechanisms such as payroll giving. So the chancellor is right to emphasise the need for more volunteering, even if his style is a little Old Tory.

Philanthropy, in whatever form, can have a dark side, though. It can avoid any notion of wider social responsibility by focusing on how much money is handed out rather than how the money is made. Great American philanthropists such as Rockefeller may have been driven by guilt to give some of their money away; his money was certainly made by monopolistic means.

Corporate responsibility concentrates on how communities are affected by the way a company makes its money, rather than merely giving a bit of the profit away once it has been counted. It is the difference between a company implementing rigorous diversity policies rather than just handing out cash to ethnic minority groups. It is the difference between Starbucks, which has attracted plenty of positive publicity for funding good causes, and European companies such as CafeDirect or Percol which espouse "fair trade", aiming to leave the coffee growers with more money in the first place.

Similarly, it is more important for drinks companies to stop getting people drunk than to fund charities which help alcoholics; more important for a lottery operator to avoid getting people hooked than to support organisa tions helping those with gambling problems; better for toy manufacturers to curb advertising to children than to give away products to toddler groups.

Money is important - especially to the charities on the receiving end. But the most progressive companies are looking at their community responsibility in their marketing, their recruitment, their trading practices. A company pursuing what the chancellor described as "civic patriotism" should be examining all their business practices, from the way they buy products and materials to the way they reward executives.

And a chancellor looking for ways to support communities might look at tax breaks for investing to create sustainable communities, not just handouts for a temporary reprieve.

 Roger Cowe writes on business and society

webTitle: Fake crash aimed to deter joyriding

fields.headline: Fake crash aimed to deter joyriding
fields.standfirst: Transport in Britain: special report
fields.trailText: Police and youth workers in south Wales yesterday defended their decision to help stage a road crash to shock a group of teenagers into thinking about the dangers of joyriding and other forms of car crime.
fields.body:
Police and youth workers in south Wales yesterday defended their decision to help stage a road crash to shock a group of teenagers into thinking about the dangers of joyriding and other forms of car crime.

The exercise was staged in Merthyr Tydfil, where more than a third of reported crime last year was car related.

South Wales police joined other emergency services and a local youth group to hammer home the message to 10 boys and girls aged 14 to 17 as part of a project involving young people identified as actual or potential car thieves.

The youngsters were being taken by minibus on what they were told was an outing to an outdoor activity centre when they saw fire, police and ambulance officers battling to save what appeared to be four casualties from a head-on collision between an Alfa Romeo and an Austin Montego.

Police said the teenagers were told that the accident was faked for their benefit and that they should ask questions and learn from the incident.

However, Simon Hunt, 32, who works for Merthyr Tydfil's Oasis youth project, acknowledged that some of the group had been upset at what they saw, but counsellors and youth workers had been on hand to give support.

"It was done to highlight the fact that so-called joyriding is leading to the deaths of young people and has a devastating effect on families. If this can save one life and stop people pinching cars and causing accidents it will have been a success."

Parental consent was given before the exercise, but it nevertheless drew criticism yesterday from the National Association for the Care and Resettlement of Offenders.

Keith Towler, head of Nacro Cymru, said: "You have to question the exposure of youngsters to such a traumatic incident. Even though trained counsellors were around to help, it was a risky and potentially dangerous approach."

Dawn Hubbard, the acting inspector in charge of South Wales police's community safety team in Merthyr Tydfil, said the exercise was meant to be realistic but not traumatic.

"I didn't see one boy in tears, but I did see one turn round and say he would never steal another car again."

fields.headline: Prescott dumps London Tube chief
fields.standfirst: Transport in Britain: special report
fields.trailText: The deputy prime minister, John Prescott, yesterday removed the head of the London Underground, Denis Tunnicliffe from his £305,000 a year job, in a move to keep tighter political control of the £7bn partial sale of the Tube.
fields.body:
The deputy prime minister, John Prescott, yesterday removed the head of the London Underground, Denis Tunnicliffe from his £305,000 a year job, in a move to keep tighter political control of the £7bn partial sale of the Tube.

The possibility that Ken Livingstone might become mayor of London and influence the sale of the Tube forced Mr Prescott to ask the reluctant Mr Tunnicliffe to go early. He had planned to stay on until April 2001 at least, but the slow progress of the sale made Mr Prescott, an old ally of Mr Tunnicliffe, change his mind.

The departure was yesterday presented as an early retirement. But a member of London Transport's board said: "We were surprised at the news. Denis has undoubtedly been pushed, and is not very happy."

Mr Prescott offered Mr Tunnicliffe fulsome praise, saying that he had seen the organisation through a period "of great change and challenge, and has been one of the major architects of the private/public partnership".

Mr Prescott said that Mr Tunnicliffe had been involved from the beginning of the Jubilee extension of the Underground, but omitted to say that its costs had more than doubled from £1.9bn to approaching £4bn. It is still not complete.

Mr Tunnicliffe will leave the board of London Transport in the summer. Close colleagues last night suggested that the government was likely to reward him with a seat in the house of lords.

LT's chairman, Sir Malcolm Bates, paid tribute to Mr Tunnicliffe's contribution. "He took a railway from the tragedy of King's Cross to the triumph of the new Jubilee." He described Mr Tunnicliffe as a "staunch ally and a good friend".

Sir Malcolm's position will become more powerful with the departure of Mr Tunnicliffe. Mr Tunnicliffe will not be replaced, but Derek Smith, LU's managing director will move across to join Sir Malcolm on a smaller board.

Mr Tunnicliffe has been held largely responsible for insufficient progress on the partial privatisation of the Underground. Five main bidders have lined up behind the project, but there have been de lays as Railtrack dropped out of the reckoning for one of the bids following the Paddington rail crash in October.

This threw the government's plans into disarray, but ministers now insist that the timetable is back on track. They have a little over 12 months to complete the transformation of the Tube before it has to be handed over to the new Mayor. If the deal is incomplete ministers would lose control of the project and could, as a last resort, retain the Underground in the public sector.

In a message to staff, Mr Tunnicliffe praised their "magnificent achievement". He added: "I'll miss being part of such an exciting organisation, but will take a keen interest in the improvements you will continue to deliver."

He has been severely criticised in recent years for the extremely poor performance of the Tube, including daily delays and breakdowns. Although there have been regular promises of improvements, thousands of passengers frequently experience overcrowding and cancellations. He was appointed chief executive of LT two years ago with Mr Prescott's backing.

webTitle: Minister orders late cut to NHS report

fields.headline: Minister orders late cut to NHS report
fields.standfirst:
The future of the NHS: special report

New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: Health officials sat down with craft knives, rulers and 2,500 copies of a report on the future of the NHS after a health minister demanded his foreward be excised after belatedly realising what the document said.
fields.body:
Health officials sat down with craft knives, rulers and 2,500 copies of a report on the future of the NHS after a health minister demanded his foreward be excised after belatedly realising what the document said.

The minister, John Denham, had written that the report by the NHS Alliance was "a valuable contribution" to debate on health service change. But his view apparently changed when the content was studied.

After the alliance was told that Mr Denham was demanding withdrawal of his endorsement, staff had less than 48 hours to cut the foreword page from each printed copy.

The episode reflects Labour's acute sensitivity on NHS issues. The alliance, which represents primary care groups that commission health care at local level, is regarded as strongly supportive of government policy.

The report, published yesterday, is presented as a radical recipe for change in the way the health service operates. Recommendations include scrapping half of all hospital outpatient clinics, allowing GPs to refer patients direct for routine procedures, and drawing up lists of all treatments available on the NHS.

Perhaps the most controversial proposal would remove the NHS from direct political control and set it up as an independent public body.

Mr Denham's foreword had said: "This thoughtful and challenging document is a valuable contribution to the debate about the way the NHS should meet the demands of today and the needs of tomorrow."

A health department spokeswoman said yesterday that the foreword had been prepared at a time when the minister "was not given a clear view of what the report said".

Michael Dixon, chairman of the alliance, said Mr Denham had been sent a copy of the report "two or three weeks ago".

Although the ideas were challenging, its thrust was consistent with government thinking on the separation of health care commissioning and provision, and partnership working.

The alliance, which represents primary care groups that commission health care at local level, is regarded as strongly supportive of government policy. The report, published yesterday, is presented as a radical recipe for change in the way the health service operates. Recommendations include scrapping half of all hospital outpatient clinics, allowing GPs to refer patients direct for routine procedures, and drawing up lists of all treatments available on the NHS. Perhaps the most controversial proposal would remove the NHS from direct political control and set it up as an independent public body. Mr Denham's foreword had said: "This thoughtful and challenging document is a valuable contribution to the debate about the way the NHS should meet the demands of today and the needs of tomorrow." A health department spokeswoman said yesterday that the foreword had been prepared at a time when the minister "was not given a clear view of what the report said". Michael Dixon, chairman of the alliance, said Mr Denham had been sent a copy of the report "two or three weeks ago". Although the ideas were challenging, its thrust was consistent with government thinking on the separation of health care commissioning and provision, and partnership working.
