webTitle: Children become prime asset in emotional blackmail

fields.headline: Children become prime asset in emotional blackmail
fields.standfirst:
Refugees in Britain: special report
The issue explained: How to claim asylum
fields.trailText: Anton, at seven months old, does not appreciate why he must spend day after day on the pavements of Oxford Street in central London. But to the asylum seekers, begging from the shoppers, workers and tourists, Anton is a prime asset. He brings the sympathy of passers by and more of their loose change. Because of this, Anton is passed around as a beggar's aid.
fields.body:
Anton, at seven months old, does not appreciate why he must spend day after day on the pavements of Oxford Street in central London. But to the asylum seekers, begging from the shoppers, workers and tourists, Anton is a prime asset. He brings the sympathy of passers by and more of their loose change. Because of this, Anton is passed around as a beggar's aid.

Yesterday Anton was at work on the streets again. So were countless other babies and young children that accompany the city's refugee beggars. They were joined by three children, all under the age of 10, playing accordion along the busy Oxford Street pavements.

Among Anton's minders were a number of groups of women, all Romany, and all wearing their distinctive outfits of scarves, long skirts, bright coats and all with children. Instead of sitting asking for money, they walked right up to pedestrians, put their hand out for money then motioned towards their mouths.

One young girl, who said she was called Linka, was 14 and came from Bosnia, was holding Anton, asking for cash. But when asked, she admitted that the baby she was holding was not hers. She said Anton was the child of a woman further up the road. Then she changed her mind and said he belonged the woman standing next to her.

A moment later a boy of around 15, claimed to be the child's father and said that Linka was the child's mother and that she was his wife. Though the beggars are almost always women, their men are never very far away. Police sources said a number of men gathered in Hyde Park, central London, where they would put out food. The beggars would come to eat and leave their money there.

As a walk up Oxford Street shows, the police are becoming increasingly concerned by the number of beggars with young children on the capital's streets. Using them this way is breaking the law.

The problem has become so bad that police, social services, the crown prosecution service and the London boroughs are soon to hold a meeting to develop a strategy to combat the situation.

Elsewhere in London, women walk on to the road with their children, banging on car doors as they wait at traffic lights. At the Angel in Islington, north London, the women weave in and out of the speeding vehicles, risking injury to themselves and the babies in their arms. The same happens at Euston and Baker Street in central London and at other busy spots across the city.

Last night, commander Bob Currie, in charge of policing Westminster, said: "Begging itself is illegal, begging with children is more serious and brings into question the welfare of the children themslves. We are working together with social services and all relevant agencies to alleviate this."

fields.headline: As mean as it gets
fields.standfirst:
Asylum seekers deserve decent treatment

Refugees in Britain: special report

The issue explained: How to claim asylum
fields.trailText: An uninformed magistrate threatens to send beggars using babes in arms to jail - seemingly unaware that begging is not an imprisonable offence. It requires menace. London transport police talk about the number of beggars doubling. The tabloids go into hysteria about the rise in asylum seekers and the invidious way Britain is seen as an easy touch.
fields.body:
An uninformed magistrate threatens to send beggars using babes in arms to jail - seemingly unaware that begging is not an imprisonable offence. It requires menace. London transport police talk about the number of beggars doubling. The tabloids go into hysteria about the rise in asylum seekers and the invidious way Britain is seen as an easy touch.

Feeding the frenzy, Ann Widdecombe wants them locked up "before they get a chance to go on to the streets to beg". Time for a few basic facts. Two decades ago there were 2.5m refugees in the world compared to last year's 21m. Kosovo alone produced 1m. Yet the total number of asylum seekers arriving in the UK was a mere 71,160. Of the 32,000 cases decided, 36% were granted refugee status and 11% given exceptional leave to remain. So much for the UK's soft touch.

The fact that begging is on the increase could only surprise the blindfolded policy-makers in the immigration department. The backlog of asylum seekers now exceeds 100,000. None are allowed to work. From this April, new arrivals were due to be dispersed across Britain and lose all chance of benefits, having to survive instead on vouchers plus - after an intense parliamentary battle - £10 in cash. Now this policy is in disarray. Earlier this week ministers conceded they did not have the accommodation to disperse this year's expected 70,000 applicants. Instead, only the 40% who claim asylum on the day they arrive (port applicants) will be dispersed.

As if this was not bad enough, our home affairs editor reports today on a new scandal. A circular has been sent to retailers enrolling in the voucher scheme instructing them not to give refugees any change. If their purchased goods are worth £4.50, the store should pocket the £5 voucher but give no cash back. All compassion was wrung out of our wretched asylum procedure long ago. But this piece of meanness marks a new low. Jack Straw must rescind it today.

webTitle: East Europeans lead growing army of beggars

fields.headline: East Europeans lead growing army of beggars
fields.standfirst:
Women with babies in arms elicit hostile reaction as police report double the number of begging cases on the London underground

Refugees in Britain: special report
The issue explained: How to claim asylum
fields.trailText: The debate over asylum seekers intensified yesterday after police claimed that the number of east Europeans begging on London's tube network had doubled.
fields.body:
The debate over asylum seekers intensified yesterday after police claimed that the number of east Europeans begging on London's tube network had doubled.

British transport police said they detected a trend for east European women to use children in an attempt to elicit sympathy and money from underground passengers.

But police said court action would not provide a long term solution as those caught begging were believed to be living on state benefits or even less.

The Tory home affair's spokeswoman, Ann Widdecombe, said: "The asylum seekers should be detained before they get a chance to go on to the streets to beg."

Chief Superintendent Steve Hotston of British transport police said reports of east European women begging on the tube with children could double by the end of this year.

Such an increase would come against a 55% increase in asylum seekers over the last year, according to home office figures.

BTP said 87 reports of women begging with children on the tube were recorded in 1998, rising to 121 last year. The first two months this year had seen 27 reports, which Chief Superintendent Hotston said could lead to 200-250 reports by the end of December.

At Horseferry Road court in central London on Wednesday, a magistrate, Roger Davies hit out at the practice amid claims his court was dealing with up to 20 cases a week. Fining a 21-year-old Romanian mother £75, Mr Davies said: "Tell all your friends that if they come before me they will go to prison. People are fed up with it. You are living on the generosity of the British people."

Chief Superintendent Hotston said jailing women was not the solution: "In reality these people come to the UK in distress. Taking people from eastern Europe who are begging on the underground to court will achieve little in the long term. There needs to be a social solution. We need to get together with other agencies."

He said the east Europeans worked in family groups.

The woman would beg with her child, and regularly hand money to a male relative as a safeguard against being arrested and the money being confiscated.

Mr Hotston stressed that only a small number of east Europeans were begging, adding: "I don't believe it is a racket. It would be a reasonable assumption that they consider themselves to be short of money. There's no Mr Big behind it."

Mr Hotston said that tube passengers found the style of begging used by east Europeans objectionable.

"They get close to you, or have a child with them, and British society doesn't cope well with that. That's why people find it intimidating and sometimes aggressive."

Police intelligence had found that some had travelled to other cities and towns in the south-east, such as Cambridge and Oxford, believing that tourists were more likely to give money.

An Oxford MP said yesterday that organised groups of beggars had travelled by train to the city. Evan Harris, liberal democrat MP for Oxford West and Abingdon, said police confirmed to him that the beggars were generally Romanians based in Slough and London.

He said children had been going from door to door to beg and tugging on the jackets of people taking out money from cash machines.

Under home office rules, people who claim asylum when they enter Britain can claim 90% of income support, up to £46 a week, and housing benefit, and an extra sum if they have children. But those who claim after entering have to rely on local councils for vouchers, food parcels and lodging.

Growing numbers of asylum seekers are making their claims after entering Britain. In 1998 the number was 22,670, growing to 41,700 last year while those applying at a port of entry rose from 23,345 in 1998 to 29,455.

Charles Smith, chairman of the Gypsy Council, called for greater understanding. "There are people begging on the underground and some are Gypsies. You need to look at the wider picture, it's part of their culture. Very often they're the poorest people in their own country and that's how they earn a living there, where there's 80-90% unemployment."

webTitle: Stop-go debate on economy fuels boredom boom

fields.headline: Stop-go debate on economy fuels boredom boom
fields.standfirst: Parliament: special report
fields.trailText:
Michael Portillo and Gordon Brown were due to face each other in the Commons yesterday. 

It should have been a majestic struggle, an epic conflict between the man some call our de facto prime minister and the one alleged to be biding his time before he crushes William Hague and ascends to be leader of the Tory party, if you can call   that an ascent. But it wasn't like that.
fields.body:
Michael Portillo and Gordon Brown were due to face each other in the Commons yesterday.

It should have been a majestic struggle, an epic conflict between the man some call our de facto prime minister and the one alleged to be biding his time before he crushes William Hague and ascends to be leader of the Tory party, if you can call that an ascent. But it wasn't like that.

Instead picture this nightmare: you have foolishly invited an independent financial adviser into your sitting room. He bores on and on, producing graphs, pie charts and reams of statistics. If you express any doubt, he repeats them in a louder voice.

Then a rival adviser shoulders his way in. He has contempt for the first chap's figures, and - worse - is backed by a team. So the original adviser brings in his assistants, and before long your house is filled with these appalling people with their fake arguments and spurious statistics.

You pray that it's a dream and try to force yourself awake, but you can not, for the gruesome truth is that it is really happening.

At one point during treasury questions yesterday, while the junior minister Melanie Johnson was droning about Labour and growth and unemployment - "who would trust the British people with the economy, er, who would trust the Tory party?" - a voice could be heard shouting: "Shut up. Shut up. Just shut up!" I was shocked to realise that it sounded so loud because it was me.

The chancellor appeared to believe that the most important thing for him was to denounce "stop-go economics, and boom-and-bust" as often as possible. Every time MPs made the reasonable point that the high pound was creating problems for exporters, he said the same thing: "What our exporters fear most of all is a return to the Tory policies which brought us stop-go and boom-and-bust."

Really? Do none of them ever mention the overvalued pound? I am constantly astonished by the way our politicians listen only to what they want to hear.

Even when Labour's Barry Jones, normally as loyal as Good Dog Tray, gingerly inquired about the effect of the strong pound on his local steelworks, Mr Brown replied: "Steelmakers have told me that they want no return to boom-and-bust."

Tories had tabled questions on the amount of income that goes in tax. The chief secretary to the treasury, Andrew Smith, has the same whiney voice as the kind of chap who stops you in the street and asks you to "take part in a survey" that is no such thing.

He had all kinds of statistics. "37.4% last year ... 37% this year, and 38.8% next year on the measures to date ... on a typical family, 18.9% next year ... " Nothing would stop him.

At one point Mr Smith decided that it was time to recite all the Labour government's achievements in the financial field. Paralysed with boredom, we listened: "We promised not to put VAT on children's clothes and books, and we did not!" (That's an achievement?)

Then Mr Portillo stood up with a heart-rending plea for the victims of Labour taxes. If we thought Mr Smith was boring, we were now reduced to a narcoleptic heap.

Labour had cut the married couples' allowance, for people "whose only sin is that they are married", on mortgage relief - "their only sin is that they saved to get a house" - and for smokers, "whose only sin is that they want to die after months of agony". Of course he didn't say that, but we expected it.

Moments later, Dawn Primarolo, the paymaster general, said: "Perhaps you need to be reminded of the things this government has done for small businesses," and began to read them all out.

"Aaargh!" I thought, "No more! Get these people out of the house!"

fields.headline: Ken's hip parade
fields.standfirst:
He's got no party machine, no envelope stuffers, and a paltry sum in the bank. But the renegade mayoral candidate has one very modern weapon that Millbank's apparatchiks may not have bargained for. Gary Younge on how a handful of celebrity backers could help Livingstone win the battle for London

The London mayor: special report
fields.trailText: He's got no party machine, no envelope stuffers, and a paltry sum in the bank. But the renegade mayoral candidate has one very modern weapon that Millbank's apparatchiks may not have bargained for.  Gary Younge on how a handful of celebrity backers could help Livingstone win the battle for London
fields.body:
The New Musical Express Premier awards early last month were a good night for Damon Albarn. The lead singer of Blur made several trips to the podium to collect awards for the best single, best video and the much-cherished prize of best band. But when Albarn got to the mic his victory speech was short and clear; his message was not about pop but politics. "Ken Livingstone, good luck," he said on one occasion; "Big up to Ken Livingstone," he declared on another. Livingstone received another endorsement from Fatboy Slim, who wished the (then) Labour leftwinger luck as he collected the award for Best DJ.

Livingstone, who was in the audience, looked on with glee. "I prefer to be here having a good laugh rather than sitting in the House of Commons listening to that lot drone on," he said. It was February 1 - just over a month ago but a different political age altogether. A time when Livingstone still held out hope that he could carry enough Labour party members and trade union votes to secure the official nomination and was telling everyone who would listen that if he failed within the party he would not stand outside it.

Now he stands not only outside it, but above it in the polls and, having already been suspended and about to be expelled, beyond it in terms of censure. But with neither party machine nor an alternative organisation to back him, support of the likes of Blur and Fatboy Slim takes on a whole new significance. They are no longer the smart bombs in his phoney war against the hapless official Labour candidate, Frank Dobson, but they could well become the most potent weapons in his populist assault on New Labour.

His line-up in the world of popular music, even at this early stage, is impressive. Along with Fatboy Slim and Albarn there are the Chemical Brothers, Pink Floyd guitarist, Dave Gilmour, as well as the expected defection of Alan McGee - who discovered Oasis - from the clutches of the maverick candidate, Malcolm Maclaren. With the actor, Neil Pearson, as his unofficial fundraising manager, comes the likelihood of further support from stage and screen - comedian Jo Brand and film director Ken Loach are already on board.

Backing from the beautiful people is nothing new in politics. Almost since there has been pop music the stars and politicians have been in search of the kind of mutual endorsement that would boost both sales and poll ratings. It is not difficult to see why. Stars want to be taken seriously and make a stand; politicians want to broaden their appeal, particularly among the young. The love affair rarely lasts and the break-up is usually messy. Political success demands not just popularity but respectability before an electoral audience who are, on average, in their 40s; success in the pop music industry requires, for the most part, that you keep pace with the spirit of youth which, almost by definition, tends towards the rebellious and hedonistic. When invited to Downing Street with the rest of Britpop shortly after the last election, Albarn declined for precisely this reason. "I wouldn't have dreamed of going, because you don't expect politicians to make records and pop stars shouldn't mix in politics," he said.

What begins as a mutually advantageous embrace ends in mutual recrimination; what at first appears symbiotic soon becomes antagonistic. "Ministers were in love with the bands when they all turned up at the Brit awards," said Craig McLean, the assistant editor of the Face. "But as soon as it started to turn a bit rock 'n' roll, they branded them drunken layabouts. Of course they're drunken layabouts - they're pop stars. If you climb into bed with a tiger, you shouldn't be surprised if you get your bum nipped."

But the alliance between pop and politics isn't simply self-serving. It usually represents a genuine confluence between popular sentiment and political expression. Harold Wilson's photo-opportunity with the Beatles was symbolic of the new modern era where the "white heat of technology" would transform both our economy and our culture. Billy Bragg's Red Wedge tapped into a general feeling of disenfranchisement among young Britain during the Thatcher period. Even Cool Britannia had its roots in a new beginning after 18 years of Thatcherism. Similarly Livingstone's candidacy taps into a popular mood of anti-authoritarian local politics brought about by the contradictory trends of centralisation within the Labour party and the devolution of power it has brought about.

On one level, Livingstone's independent candidacy provides a focus for most of this frustration that had risked descending into a pit of introspective disaffection. But not all of it. "I don't know why people think all of the anti-politician frustration is going to go to Livingstone," says Alice Nutter of Chumbawumba. "At the end of the day, he's a state politician. I'd rather him than Dobson but he's not an alternative to New Labour. He's still a career politician."

But Livingstone's relationship with pop music goes beyond this. As the frontrunner and the renegade, he will be attacked from every possible angle at every possible opportunity. And with less than two months to go, he has no leafletters - let alone leaflets - envelope stuffers or door knockers to defend him. Since any Labour party member who supports him will find themselves expelled from the party, he is unlikely to get help from that quarter. If proof were ever needed that his decision to run was taken very recently surely it can be found in the organisation of his campaign which is, at present risible. Of the four phone numbers available to contact his camp, two are permanently engaged, one rings off the hook and the other, a mobile phone, has so many unanswered messages on it that the voice mail politely informs you that it is full.

Things will improve somewhat in the next week or so but the fact remains that, paradoxically given the characterisation of him as an old Labour dinosaur, his campaign will be more modern than anything Millbank has ever been involved in. The only distinctive policy that he has - funding the tube through bond issues - is shared by the Liberal Democrat candidate Susan Kramer. The genuine affection that many Londoners of all political persuasions have for him is far more about style than substance. With a great deal of help from the Labour party hierarchy, he has carefully cultivated a media-image as a likeable rogue who has been badly mistreated by party bigwigs.

His decision to break with 30 years of personal loyalty to the Labour party was made, by his own admission, on the basis of opinion polls, emails and the comments of people he met on the street.

He declared his decision to stand on the comment pages of the London Evening Standard. With little in the way of a press team and few footsoldiers, Livingstone will need the media, including the internet, to respond to most of his opponents' accusations. And in this context, the momentum of his campaign will hinge heavily on the number of personalities with media-recognition that he can get on board in the coming weeks. Fatboy Slim and the Chemical Brothers have already agreed to do a fundraising gig and Gilmour has also offered his services; if and when support grows among comedians and actors, so does the potential for benefit shows which raise both cash and support, and do no harm to the image of a popular insurgency.

This alliance between the populist candidate and the world of pop is not accidental. In anticipation of his long-trailed candidacy - independent or otherwise - Livingstone has been courting the pop world since soon after the last election. "This government will only do what it is forced to do," he told the NME in early 1998. In a statement that could have formed the strategy basis for his own campaign for mayor, he continued: "If there's enough rebellion and pressure from below then they'll have to take notice - otherwise they'll just roll right over everybody. Get along there and give them some stick." Livingstone's relationship with Blur goes way back. As long ago as 1995 he appeared on Blur's album The Great Escape. Albarn has already spoken alongside Livingstone at a meeting in the Commons to support free higher education and at a rally late last year.

The warm reception he received at the London School of Economics earlier this week suggests that the combination of personality and policies give him a strong appeal among the young. They call him Ken; he is a regular at National Union of Students conference; there is already a direct link between the NME's website and his own. T-shirts already exist of him as Che Guevara; it will not be long before other titbits of popular iconography start to appear on campuses and in bars. He is the natural candidate of youth. Not difficult when you consider the appeal of the other candidates. They are at best avuncular and at worst dull - Livingstone has radical cheek. (SIC)

The government's introduction of tuition fees, its welfare-to-work scheme, a proposed curfew scheme for under-18s and hardline stance on soft drugs eroded much of the goodwill that had been built up between pop figures and the government very quickly. Soon after Labour's landslide victory many stars descended on Downing Street at the invitation of Tony Blair which cemented his image as the leader of a new, dynamic government that had placed Britpop at the centre of its branding of Cool Britannia.

Within a year Blair would find his face on the front page of the NME alongside the banner headline "Ever had the feeling you've been cheated". Inside an editorial entitled "Betrayal" declared: "Our music, our culture, our collective sweat of our groovy brows has been bundled up and neatly repackaged and given a cute little brand name and is being used by New Labour spin doctors to give this hideously reactionary New Labour government a cachet or radical credibility. A credibility of whch it is utterly undeserving." This line was backed by Jarvis Cocker, the Verve, Cast, Primal Scream and Blur - to mention a few. A few weeks before publication Danbert Nobacon of Chumbawumba memorably poured a bucket of water over John Prescott's head.

At the time the government dismissed these outbursts as disappointment in the "post-euphoria, pre-delivery phase". "Sometimes these guys think they are more in touch than they actually are," said one government spokesman. "What you don't do is elect a new government and suddenly the world is all put to rights."

Two years later, many feel that the euphoria has evaporated and the goods are yet to arrive. They want Blair to change his tune. And for now, at least, Livingstone is the leader of this merry band.
fields.bodyText: The New Musical Express Premier awards early last month were a good night for Damon Albarn. The lead singer of Blur made several trips to the podium to collect awards for the best single, best video and the much-cherished prize of best band. But when Albarn got to the mic his victory speech was short and clear; his message was not about pop but politics. "Ken Livingstone, good luck," he said on one occasion; "Big up to Ken Livingstone," he declared on another. Livingstone received another endorsement from Fatboy Slim, who wished the (then) Labour leftwinger luck as he collected the award for Best DJ. Livingstone, who was in the audience, looked on with glee. "I prefer to be here having a good laugh rather than sitting in the House of Commons listening to that lot drone on," he said. It was February 1 - just over a month ago but a different political age altogether. A time when Livingstone still held out hope that he could carry enough Labour party members and trade union votes to secure the official nomination and was telling everyone who would listen that if he failed within the party he would not stand outside it. Now he stands not only outside it, but above it in the polls and, having already been suspended and about to be expelled, beyond it in terms of censure. But with neither party machine nor an alternative organisation to back him, support of the likes of Blur and Fatboy Slim takes on a whole new significance. They are no longer the smart bombs in his phoney war against the hapless official Labour candidate, Frank Dobson, but they could well become the most potent weapons in his populist assault on New Labour. His line-up in the world of popular music, even at this early stage, is impressive. Along with Fatboy Slim and Albarn there are the Chemical Brothers, Pink Floyd guitarist, Dave Gilmour, as well as the expected defection of Alan McGee - who discovered Oasis - from the clutches of the maverick candidate, Malcolm Maclaren. With the actor, Neil Pearson, as his unofficial fundraising manager, comes the likelihood of further support from stage and screen - comedian Jo Brand and film director Ken Loach are already on board. Backing from the beautiful people is nothing new in politics. Almost since there has been pop music the stars and politicians have been in search of the kind of mutual endorsement that would boost both sales and poll ratings. It is not difficult to see why. Stars want to be taken seriously and make a stand; politicians want to broaden their appeal, particularly among the young. The love affair rarely lasts and the break-up is usually messy. Political success demands not just popularity but respectability before an electoral audience who are, on average, in their 40s; success in the pop music industry requires, for the most part, that you keep pace with the spirit of youth which, almost by definition, tends towards the rebellious and hedonistic. When invited to Downing Street with the rest of Britpop shortly after the last election, Albarn declined for precisely this reason. "I wouldn't have dreamed of going, because you don't expect politicians to make records and pop stars shouldn't mix in politics," he said. What begins as a mutually advantageous embrace ends in mutual recrimination; what at first appears symbiotic soon becomes antagonistic. "Ministers were in love with the bands when they all turned up at the Brit awards," said Craig McLean, the assistant editor of the Face. "But as soon as it started to turn a bit rock 'n' roll, they branded them drunken layabouts. Of course they're drunken layabouts - they're pop stars. If you climb into bed with a tiger, you shouldn't be surprised if you get your bum nipped." But the alliance between pop and politics isn't simply self-serving. It usually represents a genuine confluence between popular sentiment and political expression. Harold Wilson's photo-opportunity with the Beatles was symbolic of the new modern era where the "white heat of technology" would transform both our economy and our culture. Billy Bragg's Red Wedge tapped into a general feeling of disenfranchisement among young Britain during the Thatcher period. Even Cool Britannia had its roots in a new beginning after 18 years of Thatcherism. Similarly Livingstone's candidacy taps into a popular mood of anti-authoritarian local politics brought about by the contradictory trends of centralisation within the Labour party and the devolution of power it has brought about. On one level, Livingstone's independent candidacy provides a focus for most of this frustration that had risked descending into a pit of introspective disaffection. But not all of it. "I don't know why people think all of the anti-politician frustration is going to go to Livingstone," says Alice Nutter of Chumbawumba. "At the end of the day, he's a state politician. I'd rather him than Dobson but he's not an alternative to New Labour. He's still a career politician." But Livingstone's relationship with pop music goes beyond this. webTitle: Education: more lessons to be learnt

fields.headline: Education: more lessons to be learnt
fields.trailText: Nick Davies is right in his analysis of David Blunkett's confidence trick on education spending (Schools in crisis, March 8). Labour has been fiddling the figures to a staggering extent. A few weeks ago we added up all the re-announcements of money that Labour have made on funding in education. The total came to a staggering £185bn - more than the GDP of Sweden.
fields.body:
Nick Davies is right in his analysis of David Blunkett's confidence trick on education spending (Schools in crisis, March 8). Labour has been fiddling the figures to a staggering extent. A few weeks ago we added up all the re-announcements of money that Labour have made on funding in education. The total came to a staggering £185bn - more than the GDP of Sweden.

They have broken their manifesto commitment to spend a higher proportion of national income on education. House of Commons figures show that education spending as a proportion of GDP is going to be less under Labour than it was under the Conservatives. This is all part of the great Labour lie and proves that they say one thing then do another. Indeed, to match the proportion of GDP spent on education under the last Conservative government, and to honour their manifesto pledge, Labour should be spending an extra £32bn rather than the so-called £19bn on education.

Theresa May MP
Shadow secretary of state for education

 Nick Davies writes: "If you deny the role of social justice in education, you remove any logical justification for universal schooling ... it makes no economic sense at all."

There are logical economic justifications. These include higher tax revenues from the higher incomes generated from a better educated working class (empirically evident). Advancements in technology can be utilised more fully by an educated workforce. Education also provides child care that allows working class parents to work during the day, thus contributing to economic growth. And it makes economic sense from an employer's perspective to recruit the most able and productive workers. Higher education can be used to screen prospective employees, sorting the wheat from the chaff irrespective of social class.

D Brockton and N Wrigley
Exeter

 Education. Education. Education. How hollow those words now sound to me as a parent of three state school children. Nick Davies's magnificent articles have helped to expose the profound superficiality of New Labour, and explain the depth of disillusionment at what has been achieved by the most powerful governing party ever seen in this country.

Martin Beaver
London martin.beaver@btinternet.com

 Why haven't I known these things before? This sort of analysis should be on the school curriculum and be required content for every school prospectus.

Ralph Crouch
Wakefield, W Yorks

fields.headline: www.netsceptic.com
fields.trailText: Internet service providers are not charities (BT rivals scorn £30 internet package, March 9). They will only provide internet access free at the point of use if somebody, somehow, is paying for it. Who will offer free internet access to users who are too poor to subscribe to other telecommunications services, or to be worth advertising to? Will service providers "cherry pick", competing to reward the already rich with further blandishments and concessions while punishing the poor with higher charges, just as the privatised energy suppliers did until regulators stepped in? How can the government prevent this net exclusion? Will it come under pressure to subsidise internet companies to service the less well off? Will more reliance on keyboarded text make it even harder for the less literate to hold their own in society?
fields.body:
Internet service providers are not charities (BT rivals scorn £30 internet package, March 9). They will only provide internet access free at the point of use if somebody, somehow, is paying for it. Who will offer free internet access to users who are too poor to subscribe to other telecommunications services, or to be worth advertising to? Will service providers "cherry pick", competing to reward the already rich with further blandishments and concessions while punishing the poor with higher charges, just as the privatised energy suppliers did until regulators stepped in? How can the government prevent this net exclusion? Will it come under pressure to subsidise internet companies to service the less well off? Will more reliance on keyboarded text make it even harder for the less literate to hold their own in society?

As a director of a knowledge-based business which, largely thanks to the internet, can now run as a "virtual organisation", with colleagues based where they please all over the UK and no central office, I know it's a wonderful tool for some purposes. But internet access for all will be neither as easy to achieve, nor as unalloyed a blessing, as the prime minister (with perhaps naive enthusiasm borne of relative lack of practical experience) seems to think.

Roger Levett
London rl@cagconsult.co.uk

 I can't be alone in permitting myself a hollow laugh when reading about the current internet hyper-ventilation. I recently spent two days trying to log on to the Go website; eventually I gave up and telephoned instead, which enabled me to listen to a message that told me that the easiest way to book with Go was via their website. I flew Easyjet, booked by phone.

Yesterday I wasted two hours trying to log on to thetrainline.com (sorry, maximum number of site users exceeded). I finally managed to enter my details as a "new user" and then attempted to access the timetable page. Result: "sorry". Solution: a 15-minute walk to the local railway station where a very helpful man issued me with a timetable. With the prospect of a massive increase in net users, things can only get better? Not yetawhile they won't. I certainly wouldn't fancy basing a business solely on the internet.

Neil Annat
Exeter, Devon

 Will universal access to the internet come about before or after the eradication of homelessness, poverty and illiteracy in Britain?

Jan Ross
(Prison education tutor)
Exmouth, Devon

keri.ross@virgin.net

 I read in the Guardian (March 7) that GCHQ is to get new headquarters at a cost of £800m. Your report says it would ensure the centre's "...readiness for the hi-tech national security and intelligence gathering challenges of the 21st century".

Later I heard Tony Blair extolling his aspiration that everybody should be connected to the internet within five years. Clearly this would result in a massive increase in electronic communication? Should a cynic assume a link between the two items?

Dennis Rodgers
Nairn, Highland

 Tony Blair is right when he says we should embrace the internet. I have just enrolled with my bank's online service. With just a few clicks of my mouse I was able to bring up the direct debit for my Labour party membership and, with a final click, delete it.

Ken's got a good site by the way.

Paul Turley
London

fields.headline: Hosts of questions
fields.trailText: In the 1980s rightwingers were vigorous opponents of sanctions against South Africa, ostensibly on the grounds they hurt ordinary people without undermining the racist regime. Some 15 years later, the left uses similar arguments (Leader, March 8) to question sanctions against Iraq. How do today's liberals explain the collapse of apartheid?

Some 15 years later, the left uses similar arguments (Leader, March 8) to question sanctions against Iraq. How do today's liberals explain the collapse of apartheid?

Phil Woodford
Teddington, Middx copy_master@hotmail.com

 Thank you for giving us dozens of column inches of information on America's super Tuesday elections, which I presume must be of interest to someone. Might we expect similar in-depth coverage of the Russian elections?

Glynnis Jones
London

 If the US presidential primaries continue down the road they seem to be taking, then it will be Bush versus Gore. At least we know the name of the next American president will be a four-letter word before he takes office.

<>B> Tom Robbins
Nottingham

 Has McCain now had his chips?

Wymondham, Norfolk jturner@paston.co.uk

 Your Catholic contributor, Leanda de Lisle, (I'm backing the Pope, March 7) mentions people "who see themselves as convinced atheists". This seems rather patronising from someone who believes that the creator chooses to manifest himself on a weekly basis in the form of millions of tiny biscuits.

David McKeegan
Coventry dave@mckeegan.u-net.com

 In The name game (G2, March 8), Ken appears on the Monopoly board in Old Kent Road - the first to pass Go.

Sue Moys
Fareham, Hants rhm@thelaunchpad. freeserve.co.uk

fields.headline: The key to security
fields.trailText: John Carr says of the regulation of investigatory powers (RIP) bill (Letters, March 8), that people should not look for a solution "that will still fit cosily with the norms of a pre-internet age". That "cosily" is a giveaway. Which particular "norms" does he have in mind - justice, fairness, accountability, privacy, the rights of the individual, democratic control of the police and secret services? How many of these does Mr Carr propose compromising in order to stumble towards an answer?
fields.body:
John Carr says of the regulation of investigatory powers (RIP) bill (Letters, March 8), that people should not look for a solution "that will still fit cosily with the norms of a pre-internet age". That "cosily" is a giveaway. Which particular "norms" does he have in mind - justice, fairness, accountability, privacy, the rights of the individual, democratic control of the police and secret services? How many of these does Mr Carr propose compromising in order to stumble towards an answer?

Roger Whitehead
Oxted, Surrey

 The regulation of investigatory powers RIP bill updates vital powers for a changing technological world in a way consistent with the requirements of the European convention on human rights (Leader, March 7). These powers will be subject to safeguards and external supervision more tightly drawn than ever before.

As for encryption, the technology is clearly good for e-commerce and individuals' privacy. But it is also a boon to criminals. Accusations that we've reversed the burden of proof to an unacceptable degree miss the central element of the new decryption proposals. The burden falls on the prosecution to prove, beyond reasonable doubt, that the accused is, or has been, in possession of a key. Then there are statutory defences for individuals who have lost or forgotten a key. These need only be established to the lower level of proof - the balance of probabilities.

We lead Europe in updating the law for the digital age. You compare the position in the UK with that in Ireland. We understand that the Irish are proposing to rule out mandatory key escrow. fields.headline: Asking for trouble
fields.standfirst:
Why were secrets known to so many?

Kosovo: special report
fields.trailText: The long history of the cold war taught us that spies do little damage. The constant search for fourth and fifth men, the paranoia about moles, the Romeos and the honey traps were all part of the background noise in the ideological shouting-match between east and west. The difference in values between the systems was real enough, as was the awesomeness of the weapons of mass destruction which went with it on both sides. But spies were bit players and it was no wonder that we talked of a spying "game". Few took their contribution very seriously, especially as we now know how poor and inaccurate their assessments often were.
fields.body:
The long history of the cold war taught us that spies do little damage. The constant search for fourth and fifth men, the paranoia about moles, the Romeos and the honey traps were all part of the background noise in the ideological shouting-match between east and west. The difference in values between the systems was real enough, as was the awesomeness of the weapons of mass destruction which went with it on both sides. But spies were bit players and it was no wonder that we talked of a spying "game". Few took their contribution very seriously, especially as we now know how poor and inaccurate their assessments often were.

In a hot war, however, spies carry altogether greater weight. Any military information they pass on has real-time significance. If it refers to issues as sensitive as targeting, it is dynamite - or rather, counter-dynamite, since it may make the difference between bombs having an effect or having none at all. It is therefore incredible that Nato launched its air strikes a year ago without taking the elementary precaution of restricting its data on targets and aircraft flight paths to the narrowest possible circle. What next Sunday's BBC2 programme Moral Combat has uncovered, and which we reported in detail yesterday, reveals an extraordinary state of affairs in which as many as 600 people were on the distribution lists. It took several days before the lists were reduced to 100, though even this seems excessively high.

Nato officials may argue that a 19-member alliance is an unwieldy beast and the requirements of equal consultation demand wide disclosure of target information among the military. But this does not square with the fact that American planes frequently operated independently during the war on Yugoslavia. Nato may also claim that counter-intelligence searches during the bombing campaign revealed no evidence of a spy or any leaking of target data. It is certainly true that Nato concentrated on fixed targets rather than tanks or armoured vehicles in the first two weeks of the air strikes, and that the Serbs had taken their troops and other personnel out of their barracks and military installations long before the first bombs fell. The timing of the start of the air strikes was no secret. So any leak of target lists would not have helped the Serbs at that stage. But a leak of flight paths is another matter, especially as an American Stealth fighter was shot down in the first week of the campaign. Nato denies any spy involvement there, but this ought to be re-evaluated now. A new inquiry needs to be held.

If it is found that there was a spy, the issue is in one way academic since the war with Yugoslavia is over and it will be a long time before Nato embarks on any other. Wherever the supposed spy was, he or she has probably been reassigned. In the grander scheme of Nato's mistakes during the war, both tactical and strategic, this scandal is not the worst offence. This newspaper supported the principle and necessity for military intervention over Kosovo, though we had criticisms of the exclusive use of air power, the decision not to fly below 15,000 feet, and the policy of destroying power stations, factories, and other infrastructure which penalised civilians. But we did expect higher standards of competence. What we now know from this episode is that Nato set out on its first hot war with unacceptable arrogance. The alliance's own "intelligence" told it Milosevic would surrender within days. That being so, no one, it seems, thought to worry about sloppy distribution of target lists.

fields.headline: A routine election
fields.standfirst: In Spain that is something to celebrate
fields.trailText: Another Sunday, another election. But the sense that democracy has become routine is itself a cause for celebration in Spain, where voters will pick a new government this weekend. In folk memory at least, the 1930s civil war is not that long ago.
fields.body:
Another Sunday, another election. But the sense that democracy has become routine is itself a cause for celebration in Spain, where voters will pick a new government this weekend. In folk memory at least, the 1930s civil war is not that long ago.

Echoes of that convulsive nightmare were to be heard in the reaction to Joaquin Almunia's decision to lead his Socialists into loose electoral alliance with the communist-led United-Left coalition. It is only 25 years since Francisco Franco died and the fascist era finally ended. And it is a mere four years since Spain's current prime minister, Jose Maria Aznar, head of the Popular Party, was able to render leadership from the right respectable once again. His enforced reliance in parliament on regional parties, in particular that of Jordi Pujol, the Catalan nationalist jailed by Franco, eased the concerns of those mindful of former times. But the centrist instincts of Mr Aznar himself gave added reassurance. Spain, after Felipe Gonzalez's long, turbulent reign, did not want more flamboyance and furore. Many saw in Mr Aznar the steady, consensual hand of a modern technocrat.

Indeed, Mr Aznar, a former tax inspector, is to flamboyance what Francis Drake was to the Armada and the conquistadors to Inca self-determination. But he is widely credited with sound economic management, with reducing unemployment, and with Spain's successful (and popular) entry into the euro. Growth is running at an above EU average 3.7% annually and the budget is heading for surplus, bolstered by the government's $26bn privatisation programme. Mr Almunia and the left complain that Spain's new wealth is not being fairly distributed; that job insecurity is growing; that unemployment, at 15%, is still the highest in the EU; and that privatisation is a taxpayer rip-off. This is the familiar discourse of a pluralist society with legitimate choices to make. Pollsters tip Mr Aznar to win another term but it may well be close.

What is less than normal is the attempted intimidation of the democratic process by a handful of Basque terrorists. These wayward heirs of Iberian fascism have relaunched a pro-independence bombing campaign in defiance of majority opinion in their own region. Their political violence is as despicable as it is out-dated. Killing settles nothing; it just delays peace. Of that Spain's not so distant history offers conclusive proof.

fields.headline: Behind the spy story
fields.standfirst:
There is a broader agenda here. It might explain the motive for disclosure of an anti-Nato report

Kosovo: special report
fields.trailText: An interesting string of reactions yesterday greeted the Guardian's article about a secret US report concluding that a Nato spy provided Serbs with details of allied bombing plans in the early days of the Kosovo conflict.
fields.body:
An interesting string of reactions yesterday greeted the Guardian's article about a secret US report concluding that a Nato spy provided Serbs with details of allied bombing plans in the early days of the Kosovo conflict.

The report, revealed to the experienced and respected BBC foreign correspondent, Allan Little, was drawn up by the US air force for the joint chiefs of staff. It said that as soon as the numbers entitled to see the distribution list of highly classified "air tasking orders" were reduced from 600 to 100, the impact on what the Serbs appeared to know about Nato's targeting plans was immediate.

Jamie Shea, Nato's spokesman, moved into action. "There is absolutely no evidence that Yugoslavia had any kind of information to allow them to be more effective in shooting our planes down," he insisted. "This is a rumour" he said. "There is no beef". He insisted there was "no proof, no evidence" of a Nato spy.

He described the Guardian's report as "speculative" - bureaucratic-speak for "truthful", perhaps. For Shea added that Nato had not been told about the US report, inviting the retort that if his organisation was unaware of it, how could its chief spokesman possibly comment on it?

Maybe he had been kept in the dark, just as he was by Nato military chiefs when he tried to explain away its mistaken bombing of civilians during the Kosovo campaign. In Ankara, Lord Robertson, Nato's secretary-general, was more circumspect. "No evidence [of spying] has been presented. It is simply an allegation," he said.

Nato officials subsequently confirmed that a US study had indeed investigated Serb behaviour in the early days of the campaign and had concluded there could have been a leak of information. As the day wore on, more came out.

A Nato military official confirmed to Reuters news agency that the report - by a now retired US air force general, James McCarthy - indeed found targeting information had been leaked to Belgrade. However, the conclusion, he then said, was based on "circumstantial evidence, no solid evidence we were compromised". A Nato counter-intelligence team had investigated Nato procedures and found no evidence of spying or air operations being leaked.

Subsequently, however, diplomatic sources were quoted as saying that the air tasking orders were potentially available to thousands of people. "There would be no way for anyone to know if some of it had leaked," said one.

And Wesley Clark, Nato's supreme commander, was certainly sufficiently concerned that he made sure access to Nato's secret plans was progressively narrowed down and some sensitive information was kept off them.

In London, meanwhile, Downing Street said the PM had no reason to believe there was a spy in Nato. The ministry of defence said it had no evidence of its own. It was only too happy to let Nato deal with media inquiries.

So after first denying all knowledge of the US report and dismissing the Guardian/BBC story as pie in the sky, Nato not only acknowledged the existence of the report, it named its author and confirmed its conclusions. All we lack is hard evidence pointing to a particular spy in a particular member country.

There is a broader agenda here which might explain the motive of whoever disclosed the existence of the report. It certainly helps to explain Nato's nervous, not to say unconvincing reaction. Relations between the US and its European allies are going through a particularly difficult period in the aftermath of the Kosovo conflict, the first war in the organisation's 50-year history.

Paradoxically, the legacy of the Kosovo conflict - a supreme test of Nato unity - has left the allies fractious, with mutual suspicion threatening to open up deep cracks across the Atlantic.

Washington is making clear that never again will it be prepared to carry the overwhelming military and financial costs of a European crisis. It was dismayed by the lack of European aircraft able to carry out round-the-clock bombing and refuelling missions, and the lack of European transport planes.

When the European allies responded by pledging to set up a European rapid reaction corps of 60,000 troops in place by the year 2003, Washington was deeply sceptical about whether they could achieve such an ambitious aim. Many of the European allies, including Germany, are cutting defence budgets.

Having relied on the US to pay for the war, the Europeans promised to pay for the peace. Yet they have failed to honour their pledges to contribute to a civil police force in Kosovo or come up with adequate money for the much-trumpeted stabilisation fund for south-east Europe.

The EU is also establishing a European Security and Defence Identity, leading Washington to accuse the Europeans of setting up bureaucratic structures without contributing men and machinery.

And senior US air force officers in particular still rankle about the way the Kosovo war was conducted, and what they regard as unacceptable interference by European political leaders.

The McCarthy report was written against the same background. It reflects US suspicions of the Europeans.

fields.headline: Barak and Arafat kick-start talks
fields.standfirst: Israel and the Middle East: special report
fields.trailText: Words of optimism from their Egyptian host yesterday rounded off three days of talks in which Israeli and Palestinian leaders seemed to kick-start peace negotiations that have been suspended for a month.
fields.byline: Mona Eltahawy in Cairo and  Jack Redden in Beirut
fields.body:
Words of optimism from their Egyptian host yesterday rounded off three days of talks in which Israeli and Palestinian leaders seemed to kick-start peace negotiations that have been suspended for a month.

The mood in the Egyptian Red sea resort of Sharm el-Sheikh made a big contrast to the recriminations and tension in evidence since the two sides parted in early February. But this good humour is likely to add to Syria's nervousness that such reconciliations could leave it sidelined.

After a brief and largely symbolic meeting with the Palestinian Authority president, Yasser Arafat, and the Israeli prime minister, Ehud Barak, President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt said: "We met here in a very friendly atmosphere [and] overturned so many obstacles ... The good relations between the leaders is giving great hope."

It was at Sharm el-Sheikh last September that Mr Barak and Mr Arafat signed a peace agenda they have been struggling to keep to since.

As the main sponsor of the peace process, the US sent its special envoy, Dennis Ross, to chair this week's meetings in Israel and the West Bank. On Wednesday he announced that the two sides would resume negotiations on a peace treaty in Washington around March 20.

An interim or framework agreement is meant to be hammered out by May and a final peace deal by September 13, though this is unlikely.

In the next few days Israel is meant to withdraw from a further 6.1% of the West Bank. But, after Mr Arafat bowed to US pressure, it appears this will exclude certain areas the Palestinians sought adjoining Jerusalem. They are to get areas near the city instead.

In Beirut, where Arab foreign ministers are gathering for a summit this weekend, the atmosphere will be far less optimistic than in Sharm el-Sheikh.

Having repeatedly demanded that Israel end its 22-year occupation of southern Lebanon, leaders in Beirut and Damascus are nervous about the Israeli forces going - as Mr Barak intends - by late July, without putting in place a peace agreement with Israeli's two northern neighbours.

This would include a commitment to return the Golan heights to Syria and to give the 360,000 registered Palestinian refugees in Lebanon the right to return home.

fields.headline: Spy report shakes Nato
fields.standfirst:
Alliance admits existence of secret US investigation which suggests leaks to Belgrade

Kosovo: special report
fields.trailText: Nato last night was forced into an embarrassing climbdown when it admitted that, contrary to earlier denials, a secret US report exists suggesting it had a spy in its ranks in the early days of the Kosovo war.
fields.byline: Richard Norton-Taylor, Julian Borger  in Washington and  Ian Black  in Brussels
fields.body:
Nato last night was forced into an embarrassing climbdown when it admitted that, contrary to earlier denials, a secret US report exists suggesting it had a spy in its ranks in the early days of the Kosovo war.

After first denying knowledge of the report, it admitted that a senior US air force officer had carried out an internal Pentagon investigation into the vulnerability of Nato's secret "air tasking orders" giving daily details of allied bombing raids, including targets and reconnaissance flights.

Jamie Shea, Nato's chief spokesman, at first insisted there was "no evidence" of a spy and Nato had no knowledge of the US report. Lord Robertson, Nato's secretary general, said during a visit to Ankara: "We have no knowledge and no evidence that the air tasking order was ever leaked to the Serbs or otherwise compromised".

Javier Solana, Nato's secretary general during the Kosovo war, told the Guardian he had no knowledge of a spy at Nato, and had not seen any US report on the subject. He added that in one case - an attack on the town of Novi Sad - there were suspicions that Belgrade had had some prior knowledge of Nato plans.

However, Nato officials later confirmed a report had indeed been written. A definitive "lessons learned from Kosovo" study had been drawn up by James McCarthy, a now retired US air force general, for the deputy secretary of defence John Hamre and general Joe Ralston, vice-chairman of the US joint chiefs of staff.

The McCarthy report says that after Nato reduced the number of people with access to bombing raid orders from 600 to 100, the effect on what the Serbs appeared to know about Nato's plans was immediate. It says that the Serbs appeared to know when Nato spy planes and unmanned reconnaissance drones would be deployed. General Wesley Clark, Nato's supreme commander, has admitted that concern about Nato security led to particularly sensitive information being omitted from the tasking orders.

The report was discovered by Allan Little, the BBC's foreign correspondent and reporter for a BBC2 programme, Moral Combat: Nato at War, to be broadcast on Sunday night. It was first revealed yesterday by the Guardian.

A senior US air force source tells the programme that Gen Clark told colleagues: "I know I've got a spy, I want to find him".

Yesterday, a Nato military official described General McCarthy's conclusion as based on "circumstantial evidence". In Washington, US air force spokesman, Lt Colonel Vic Warzinsky said that while the report provided no conclusive evidence of a spy within Nato, "there was a sense in Nato headquarters that the Serbs were pretty well informed about what we were doing."

He said Serb intelligence could have come from a number of sources, including ground spotters positioned at the end of Nato runways in Italy, passing on information to Belgrade by satellite phone on the numbers and types of aircraft being launched. The Serbs were also listening in to unscrambled radio traffic, to glean whatever indirect information they could about air force activities.

He acknowledged that Nato targeting appeared to have become more effective after the distribution list was shortened, though he said that could have been the result of a number of different factors, including the destruction of Serb communication and command-and-control centres in the first days of the bombing campaign.

However, diplomatic sources said the tasking orders - placed on Nato's coded computer system, called Chronos - were potentially available to thousands of people once it reached the capitals of Nato's 19 governments. "There would be no way for anyone to know if some of it had leaked," said one source.

The McCarthy report appears to have been withheld from America's Nato partners, including the British government. The ministry of defence said it intended to question Washington about the report. Senior British government sources said they had not seen it, and expressed surprise that it had taken so long to leak.

Menzies Campbell, the Liberal Democrat defence spokesman, said: "This was the most sensitive information of all available at that time in the campaign and for 600 people to have access to it seems fairly contrary to the principle of need to know. These revelations will only serve to increase political tension within the alliance."

They come as the US and the European allies are at odds over defence spending, Washington's plans for a national anti-missile defence shield, and for increased military cooperation within the EU.

Mr Solana, the EU's security supremo, made it clear he is anxious to avoid any suggestion of problems within Nato as he advances the delicate business of trying to construct a European "defence identity" and capabilities that some US officials have warned will undermine the western alliance.

Iain Duncan-Smith, the shadow defence secretary, said the disclosure "begs the question of whether it is ever feasible to operate with all the Nato nations having access to the most sensitive information, regardless as to whether they are committed in a military sense or not".

He added: "The lesson to learn is that there will always be a core that will go ahead and operate under the umbrella of Nato while others will go along politically but do not necessarily need to be kept alongside militarily, so as to avoid the temptation for them to use that information to weaken Nato."

He joined Francis Maude, the the shadow foreign secretary, in calling for an inquiry into the handling of the Kosovo conflict.

There is no spy

After first denying knowledge of the report, it admitted that a senior US air force officer had carried out an internal Pentagon investigation into the vulnerability of Nato's secret "air tasking orders" giving daily details of allied bombing raids, including targets and reconnaissance flights. Jamie Shea, Nato's chief spokesman, at first insisted there was "no evidence" of a spy and Nato had no knowledge of the US report. Lord Robertson, Nato's secretary general, said during a visit to Ankara: "We have no knowledge and no evidence that the air tasking order was ever leaked to the Serbs or otherwise compromised". Javier Solana, Nato's secretary general during the Kosovo war, told the Guardian he had no knowledge of a spy at Nato, and had not seen any US report on the subject. He added that in one case - an attack on the town of Novi Sad - there were suspicions that Belgrade had had some prior knowledge of Nato plans. However, Nato officials later confirmed a report had indeed been written. A definitive "lessons learned from Kosovo" study had been drawn up by James McCarthy, a now retired US air force general, for the deputy secretary of defence John Hamre and general Joe Ralston, vice-chairman of the US joint chiefs of staff. The McCarthy report says that after Nato reduced the number of people with access to bombing raid orders from 600 to 100, the effect on what the Serbs appeared to know about Nato's plans was immediate. It says that the Serbs appeared to know when Nato spy planes and unmanned reconnaissance drones would be deployed. General Wesley Clark, Nato's supreme commander, has admitted that concern about Nato security led to particularly sensitive information being omitted from the tasking orders. The report was discovered by Allan Little, the BBC's foreign correspondent and reporter for a BBC2 programme, Moral Combat: Nato at War, to be broadcast on Sunday night. It was first revealed yesterday by the Guardian. A senior US air force source tells the programme that Gen Clark told colleagues: "I know I've got a spy, I want to find him". Yesterday, a Nato military official described General McCarthy's conclusion as based on "circumstantial evidence". In Washington, US air force spokesman, Lt Colonel Vic Warzinsky said that while the report provided no conclusive evidence of a spy within Nato, "there was a sense in Nato headquarters that the Serbs were pretty well informed about what we were doing." He said Serb intelligence could have come from a number of sources, including ground spotters positioned at the end of Nato runways in Italy, passing on information to Belgrade by satellite phone on the numbers and types of aircraft being launched. The Serbs were also listening in to unscrambled radio traffic, to glean whatever indirect information they could about air force activities. He acknowledged that Nato targeting appeared to have become more effective after the distribution list was shortened, though he said that could have been the result of a number of different factors, including the destruction of Serb communication and command-and-control centres in the first days of the bombing campaign. However, diplomatic sources said the tasking orders - placed on Nato's coded computer system, called Chronos - were potentially available to thousands of people once it reached the capitals of Nato's 19 governments. "There would be no way for anyone to know if some of it had leaked," said one source. The McCarthy report appears to have been withheld from America's Nato partners, including the British government. The ministry of defence said it intended to question Washington about the report. Senior British government sources said they had not seen it, and expressed surprise that it had taken so long to leak. Menzies Campbell, the Liberal Democrat defence spokesman, said: "This was the most sensitive information of all available at that time in the campaign and for 600 people to have access to it seems fairly contrary to the principle of need to know. These revelations will only serve to increase political tension within the alliance." They come as the US and the European allies are at odds over defence spending, Washington's plans for a national anti-missile defence shield, and for increased military cooperation within the EU. Mr Solana, the EU's security supremo, made it clear he is anxious to avoid any suggestion of problems within Nato as he advances the delicate business of trying to construct a European "defence identity" and capabilities that some US officials have warned will undermine the western alliance. He joined Francis Maude, the the shadow foreign secretary, in calling for an inquiry into the handling of the Kosovo conflict. webTitle: Interpreters' walkout leaves Europe's diplomats tongue-tied

fields.headline: Interpreters' walkout leaves Europe's diplomats tongue-tied
fields.standfirst: The European Commission: special report
fields.trailText: It was not the main item on the agenda, but it was still a highly sensitive matter: the Spanish ambassador had raised concerns about the failure to use the language of Cervantes in a key European Union institution.
fields.body:
It was not the main item on the agenda, but it was still a highly sensitive matter: the Spanish ambassador had raised concerns about the failure to use the language of Cervantes in a key European Union institution.

He was not alone. His Italian colleague on the powerful committee of permanent representatives (Coreper) was equally angry about discrimination against his own native tongue.

And then, in the babel that is Brussels, the interpreters all walked out.

Wednesday was another difficult day for routine EU business, which is now subject to escalating industrial action by the men and women who sit in those little glass booths.

Disaster was averted because the 15 ambassadors - sophisticated diplomats all - managed to get by in French and English. But that only reinforced the very problem they were discussing: countries feeling hard done by in this highly multilingual organisation.

Freelance interpreters are unhappy because of a long-running dispute over whether they are entitled to pay EU tax rates, which are lower than national rates.

Most EU member states think the freelancers deserve this perk, but Belgium, the host country, is implacably opposed for fear of a precedent that could benefit other freelance workers.

The interpreters' walkout has been given real muscle as meetings of ambassadors and hundreds of working groups face disruption and a switch to French and English, the two languages that nearly everyone can manage.

"It's not actually bringing the wheels of the EU institutions to a grinding halt, but people are starting to notice that the interpreters have a real grievance," one diplomat said yesterday. "And it is highlighting the difficulty of the language issue, which is clearly only going to get worse."

With 11 official EU languages already and 10 candidates lined up to join an enlarged union, Polish, Hungarian, Czech, Estonian and Slovene are all likely to be necessary soon.

Further down the line, the costs of Romanian, Bulgarian, Latvian, Lithuanian, Slovak and Maltese will have to be added to the 686m euros (£417,000) currently spent on interpretation and translation.

Spain is frustrated because the EU's Kosovo reconstruction agency in Salonika, Greece, works only in French, English and German. Italy shares parallel concerns about the racism monitoring centre in Vienna.

"Everyone thought the problem with the freelance interpreters had been solved, but then the Spanish abstained at the last minute," said one Brussels veteran. "They are playing a game of machismo. They want to ensure that they don't lose out as the EU moves towards enlargement."

Italy is in the same boat - but is less prickly than Spain. Romano Prodi, the European commission's Italian president, speaks better English than French, but French journalists have complained that their language is infrequently heard at daily press briefings.

And there is no north-south split to explain away these passions: even the usually placid and highly anglophone Swedes are losing patience with the lack of facilities for using their own language in the heart of Europe.

fields.headline: Let's hope Gore wins
fields.standfirst:
He might not be setting any hearts on fire, but next to his Republican rival he looks very good

The US elections: special report
fields.trailText: As the light of the world Al Gore is not much to look at. He's a poor fish, lugubrious and somnolent. His minders goad him into flapping his fins a bit but there is no spark in his fishy eye. However, physiognomy and charm aren't everything. Yet again liberal America will have to make do with an imperfect candidate. But contemplating the threat of a George W Bush victory, their man starts to seem prime presidential material. Al Gore is all there is and the fate of the world now depends on his success.
fields.body:
As the light of the world Al Gore is not much to look at. He's a poor fish, lugubrious and somnolent. His minders goad him into flapping his fins a bit but there is no spark in his fishy eye. However, physiognomy and charm aren't everything. Yet again liberal America will have to make do with an imperfect candidate. But contemplating the threat of a George W Bush victory, their man starts to seem prime presidential material. Al Gore is all there is and the fate of the world now depends on his success.

Observing him perform at close quarters, he does not, alas, improve: television soundbites flatter him. Plodding painfully in a speech to the Irish American Forum in Manhatten, he read monotonously through a respectable enough detailed commitment to the peace process - "I've been studying up on it" - and he had, he had. (He is a slow but thorough study.) European ears have to screen out the yuck in all American electioneering: it's a foreign language to us. Maybe it's to Al Gore's credit that he is so bad at it that the whole room winces when he tries the down home stuff: "Tipper and I have just become grandparents. Any other grandparents here? Let's see those hands! Great. Give me some lessons, I'm just a rookie!"

There's none of that Clinton magic, intelligence and warmth that could win over the coldest audience. But if he lacks Clinton's skills, he also lacks his faults. All his life, this senator's son has been groomed for this moment, mainly by his mother who looked just like him standing behind him on the platform as he celebrated Super Tuesday's results. He has rarely put a foot wrong, never done anything to excess, wore a tie every day as a young journalist and never drank a beer on duty. He is a manufactured man who sometimes over-boasts his achievements (no he didn't invent the internet, though he was the first senator to promote it).

Those who knew him young say all danger and therefore all character was nipped at his mother's breast. His minders try to humanise him by revealing that he doesn't wear pyjamas. Because of Clinton, this election will turn on "character": if that's just keeping his trousers on and no skeletons, Al Gore's their man. Bush tries to tar Gore with Clinton's sins. "This is the end of the Clinton/Gore era!" he keeps shouting but it won't stick. Every day that passes Al Gore looks more like his own man.

The important question is what has he learned from the Clinton era? As it draws to a close Tony Blair, who took so much from Clinton's third way, must also be asking what went wrong. How with so little achieved? Clinton, could have moved mountains with a golden economy and his powers of persuasion, but he didn't.

Long before Lewinsky, Clinton lost his daring, tenacity and vision. True the checks and balances of the US constitution stymied him at every turn, but that was only part of the story. After the great disaster of his failed health reforms, he rarely tried again to do anything bold. All was compromise. His third way meant ducking tough choices, appeasing and eschewing ideology until he was left with none. He could always spin a mean speech, but fine words were a substitute for action. Tony Blair risks the same fatal loss of momentum. Clinton's hyper-caution stopped him rushing the citadels of conservatism while the force was still with him. Has Gore learned? Might he surprise us yet with a daring belied by his stolid dullness?

It's encouraging that so far Al Gore's television ads have never trimmed to the right. Night after night he has pumped out a strong liberal message - pro choice on abortion, pro gun control, pro health care for the poor, universal health care for children. Bush is stranded too far out on the right, lost somewhere on the Bob Jones campus and he struggles to get back towards the centre. But so far the signs are that Gore will stay firmly where he is and hold to his message, which is a very good one.

With his strong pitch on radically reforming campaign finance, he takes on the McCain mantle. He's earned unusual respect in that much mocked role as vice-president by beavering away at technology, the environment, education and foreign policy (He was more in favour of intervening in the Bosnian tragedy than Clinton.) A policy wonk by nature, he likes the nitty-gritty which is no bad thing. And he assembles good advisers.

So even if he sets no hearts afire, even if his every move is stiffly calculated, he'll do. George W Bush will make this the dirtiest, most vitriolic campaign ever fought. The rest of the world will look on, as usual, aghast at the spectacle of how the world's great guarantor of democracy conducts its own elections. We will watch every twist and turn in the terrible process with bated breath because so much hangs in its balance. On the vagaries of ever-diminishing numbers of US voters dimly informed by mendacious 30-second commercials too much depends. Those who fear any move towards more global governance should consider how already the future of so many countries rests to a large degree on the outcome of something over which we outsiders have no control at all - this great rambunctious, mendacious, shameless four-yearly extravaganza in America.

In a Bush victory there is the prospect of an isolationist America, wastefully rearming with useless hi-tech weapons while reneging on international disarmament treaties and dangerously rousing the Zhirinovsky tendency in Russia. Republican refusal to play the global policeman will demolish America's new-found sense of responsibility for universal human rights. The outlook for the UN would be grim in that changed atmosphere. World free trade would become a worse battle ground for naked US interest, risking large parts of the global economy and thus ultimately America's own. An already shameful refusal to accept heavy responsibility for global warming or to make sacrifices in energy use would be even worse under a Texas oilman who uses cheap energy as one of his campaign themes.

On all these questions Al Gore says the right thing. What would or could he do? As with Clinton or with Blair, there is little doubt about where all their true convictions lie. In the end what matters is a leader's skill, bravery and determination to deliver, unknowable until too late.

It's neck and neck now with Gore in the lead but a long run-in to November. If he loses it will be the death of a key part of the Blair project too - that pivotal link between social democratic Europe and a Democrat in the White House. No more third way in foreign policy. Blair will be obliged to turn back towards a Europe that is culturally so very much more like us: America never seems more alien than at election time, fascinating but monstrous too.
