webTitle: McCain bids farewell to presidential dream

fields.headline: McCain bids farewell to presidential dream
fields.standfirst:
Clear road ahead for Gore and Bush, as Democrat Bradley also pulls out of White House race
The US elections: special report
fields.trailText: Senator John McCain of Arizona called off his reformist challenge for the US Republican party's presidential nomination yesterday. His advisers styled it a suspension of the McCain bid, but it effectively conceded victory to the Texas governor, George W Bush.
fields.body:
Senator John McCain of Arizona called off his reformist challenge for the US Republican party's presidential nomination yesterday. His advisers styled it a suspension of the McCain bid, but it effectively conceded victory to the Texas governor, George W Bush.

Mr McCain very conspicuously declined to give his backing to Mr Bush. Instead, he offered his "best wishes", about as minimal a gesture as he could have made without being accused of sour grapes.

Mr McCain's announcement meant that both he and the challenger for the Democratic party's nomination, Bill Bradley - the nearly men of the 2000 party races -pulled out within an hour of one another yesterday during events at opposite ends of the United States.

The two men bowed to the verdict of voters in this week's Super Tuesday primaries. Their announcements leave the way clear for the Democratic vice-president, Al Gore, and George W Bush to get their parties' nominations at conventions in July and August and then go on to fight the election in November.

The vanquished challengers swallowed their considerable pride, spoke sometimes movingly of what might have been and the issues that matter to them most, and then they prepared to go on vacation.

Mr Bradley, a former senator, announced his withdrawal at his headquarters in West Orange, New Jersey. Mr McCain spoke an hour later at his country home outside Sedona, Arizona.

Their speeches showed that they accepted the political reality of their defeats on Tuesday, but they were not entirely willing to submit entirely on their opponents' terms, and both sought to place conditions on their departures from the party races.

Mr McCain, in particular, hinted that he intended to remain a factor in the contest, if only from the sidelines.

"A majority of Republican voters made clear that their preference for president is Governor Bush," he said. "I respect that decision. I am no longer an active candidate for my party's nomination."

McCain aides described the Vietnam veteran's move as a decision to suspend the campaign, rather than to abandon it, though the distinction is unlikely to matter much to Mr Bush. Mr McCain has won contests in seven states, capturing 231 delegates to the summer national convention.

Mr Bush, who was campaigning in Colorado yesterday, so far has 617 of the 1,034 delegates he requires to secure the nomination.

Advisers say that Mr McCain wants to hold on to his options. They include running as a third-party candidate - a course which some of the senator's advisers favour - and continuing to rally his supporters for campaign finance reform from within the party.

Much will depend on whether Mr Bush makes any conciliatory moves towards the McCain camp.

"I hoped our campaign would be a force for change in the Republican party. I believe we have set a course that will ultimately prevail in making our party as big as the country we serve," Mr McCain said.

In the Democratic contest, Mr Bradley said unequivocally that he would withdraw and support Mr Gore for the presi dency. However, the former New Jersey senator pointedly refused to use the word "endorse" in connection with his rival.

He also said he would not release his 412 Democratic convention delegates from their commitment to him, in a signal that he is determined to have his say on prime-time television in Los Angeles in August, when the party officially selects Mr Gore.

"The vice-president and I had a stiff competition, and he won," Mr Bradley said. "I congratulate him. He will be the nominee of the Democratic party and I will support his bid to win the White House."

Although both of yesterday's events were marked mostly by dignity - and a little residual defiance - there were unmistakeable signs of the huge catharsis which the two men's withdrawal involves, not just for them, but for families and supporters whose lives have been dominated by months of campaigning.

Before Mr Bradley began his withdrawal speech, his wife Ernestine broke down in tears and had to leave the room to compose herself for the ordeal.

The withdrawal speeches saw a curious role reversal. Mr Bradley made his announcement and then, unusually for him, took questions and gave mementoes to the press.

Mr McCain, whose campaign has been marked by his accessibility to, and cordial relations with, the media, simply read his statement before leaving with his wife Cindy, questions unasked and unanswered.

fields.trailText: Fresh evidence came to light last night of a ministry of defence cover-up over the crash of a Chinook helicopter on the Mull of Kintyre that killed leading members of the security services.
fields.body:
Fresh evidence came to light last night of a ministry of defence cover-up over the crash of a Chinook helicopter on the Mull of Kintyre that killed leading members of the security services.

A memo written by an RAF officer a few days before the crash revealed that the ministry knew about but ignored safety concerns over computer software used to fly the helicopter, undermining its claim that the crash was caused by pilot error.

Twenty-five intelligence officers were among the 29 people killed in the crash in 1994.

The memo, leaked to the magazine Computer Weekly, showed that the RAF was short of helicopters, which led to the Chinooks being pressed into early service.

It said the aeroplane and armament experimental establishment in Boscombe Down, Wiltshire, had halted trials of the Chinook "because of their concerns about the safety of the new full authority digital engine control system (Fadec)".

This halt was ignored by the ministry, the memo said. "Their ongoing stance contrasts sharply with the considerable efforts being made by the front line to bring the aircraft into service and maintain a capacity," the officer wrote. "It also does nothing to engender aircrew confidence in the aircraft.

"In sum, I find A&AEE's attitude quite incredible."

The row over why the Chinook could be unsafe depended on the type of testing used by Boscombe Down. The RAF and the MoD tested it by simulating 70,000 hours of flying. Boscombe Down wanted to test whether two unrelated and rare software failures could trigger a disaster, but the ministry told them that this was inappropriate.

Menzies Campbell, the Liberal Democrat defence spokesman, said yesterday: "This simply confirms my original judgment, which was shared by the sheriff at the fatal accident inquiry, that the RAF's preferred explanation of the crash has not been established in the evidence available."

The Chinook crashed on the Mull of Kintyre in Scotland 18 minutes after it set off from RAF Aldergrove near Belfast, killing 25 intelligence officers and four special forces crew. It was the RAF's worst peacetime accident.

The MoD inquiry blamed the two pilots, Flight Lieutenants Jonathan Tapper, 28, and Rick Cook, 30, both special forces pilots with exemplary records. Flt Lt Tapper, the captain, had a total of 3,165 military flying hours. Flt Lt Cook, who was at the controls, had 2,867 hours.

fields.headline: Scientists crack meningitis code
fields.trailText: Scientists have unravelled the complete genetic code of the microbe behind more than half the meningitis cases in Europe and North America - and used the knowledge to begin designing a new kind of vaccine.
fields.body:
Scientists have unravelled the complete genetic code of the microbe behind more than half the meningitis cases in Europe and North America - and used the knowledge to begin designing a new kind of vaccine.

The entire 2.27m letter DNA "recipe" for the bacterium neisseria meningitidis B has been deciphered by a team of scientists from the institute of genomic research in Maryland, the institute of molecular medicine at Oxford, and the immunological research institute of Siena in Italy. They publish their results today in the journal Science. Safety trials of a vaccine based on the research could begin in 2001.

Meningitis - inflammation of the membranes around the brain and spinal cord - has more than one cause.

Most vaccines are based on recognition of the sugary coat or sheath of the invading pathogen. That could not work for the B microbe, according to Rino Rappuoli of Siena, who worked on trials of the meningitis C vaccine in 1992. The microbe's polysaccharide coating was very like one that protected the human nervous system.

So scientists began targeting specific proteins on the bacterial surface. There was a successful vaccine in Cuba, and another in Norway. But neither of these worked anywhere else, because the strains of the microbe varied so dramatically. The hunt was on for a protein common to all, or at least most, strains.

"It was going to be impossible to find such proteins unless a new technology came in," said Dr Rappuoli yesterday.

"The new technology was the genomic approach, the one we used. You don't isolate one protein at a time, you go to the genome and say: how many proteins can this bacteria make? You take all those and ask, out of these 2,158, is there one that doesn't change from strain to strain and can be used in an ideal vaccine?"

The researchers said they found promising proteins on the surface of the bacterium which seemed to be present across a wide range of strains. They have also shown that the proteins could stimulate the production of antibodies capable of killing the invader: a sign that they could be on the track of an effective vaccine.

The meningitidis microbe is found only in humans - and millions of people in Britain are carriers. It colonises the noses and throats of humans and for the most part causes no symptoms. But in a very small number of people the microbe gets into the blood stream, and then invades the meninges of the brain, often fatally.

webTitle: Research reveals how air pollution can stop rainfall

fields.headline: Research reveals how air pollution can stop rainfall
fields.standfirst: The weather: special report
fields.trailText: Air pollution from heavy industry, power plants and oil refineries can prevent rainfall locally, according to researchers who have tracked plumes of smoke across the surrounding countryside.
fields.body:
Air pollution from heavy industry, power plants and oil refineries can prevent rainfall locally, according to researchers who have tracked plumes of smoke across the surrounding countryside.

The tiny aerosols of dust, soot and chemicals from factories can "stifle" rain-bearing clouds, reports Daniel Rosenfeld of the Hebrew university of Jerusalem in the US journal Science today, because the rain droplets become too small to fall.

Clouds are made up of microscopic drops of water, but these will not fall as rain until they have "seeded" around some thing, and coalesced. It takes about 1m tiny droplets to merge to form one raindrop large enough to fall without evaporating on the way down.

In polluted clouds, Dr Rosenfeld found too many small droplets and too few big ones. Smaller droplets were slower to freeze and form ice crystals, so pollution also reduced snowfall.

Using satellite data Dr Rosenfeld tracked plumes of pollution over Turkey, Canada and Australia, and used other satellite instruments to map what happened in rainclouds. The data showed that raindrops and ice crystals formed in unpolluted clouds - but the process was turned off in those parts crossed by the long, narrow plumes.

webTitle: UK leads world in carbon dioxide cut

fields.headline: UK leads world in carbon dioxide cut
fields.standfirst:
Switch from coal and fulfilment of manifesto pledge for 20% reduction in greenhouse gas for 2010 will pay off with £100m 'carbon credit'
The weather: special report
fields.trailText: Britain will exceed its target for reducing carbon dioxide emission by such a large amount that it will have as much as £100 million worth of carbon credits to sell to the United States or any other country that will buy to meet its legally binding target.
fields.body:
Britain will exceed its target for reducing carbon dioxide emission by such a large amount that it will have as much as £100 million worth of carbon credits to sell to the United States or any other country that will buy to meet its legally binding target.

John Prescott, the deputy prime minister, said yesterday that the United Kingdom would be in the "happy position" of having a huge surplus of credits to trade on the world markets if the government chose to do so.

He was launching the government's climate change strategy, which confirmed Britain as the world leader in fighting climate change by delivering on Labour's manifesto pledge of reducing carbon dioxide emissions by 20% for 2010. In doing so, the government will exceed its United Nations legally binding target of 12.5% and, as a world market develops in carbon credits, will be able to sell them to countries unable to meet their own binding pledges.

Britain's lead in this area is partly luck, brought about because of Lady Thatcher's hatred of the miners when prime minister, causing a mass switch to gas generation - a far less polluting means of generating electricity. Britain is set to achieve a 15% reduction on 1990 levels this year mainly because of the switch to gas.

However, increased economic activity and more traffic growth would have meant the totals rising again, except that policies adopted in the last two years are designed to maintain the downward trend, as it has become clear that climate change is accelerating and is a serious threat.

Mr Prescott said yesterday that the UK's strategy went much further than any other country in the world in taking reduction beyond its legally binding target. "There is no doubt that climate change is the greatest threat to the future of mankind. The floods in China and Mozambique, the damage hurricane Mitch did to central America, they are all symptoms of what we can expect as climate change takes hold. These measures we are putting in place are to save us from the worst effects of global warming."

The UK's targets would allow the country to take a lead in renewed international negotiations due in the Hague in November; Mr Prescott hoped Europe would ratify the Kyoto protocol that gave binding targets to all countries, and would allow international carbon trading to begin. So far the UK had not decided whether to sell its surplus or keep it "in the bank", he said. Estimates vary about how much a ton of carbon will be worth in international trade but it could be as much as £15. Britain will have up to 8m tonnes to sell.

Among the initiatives announced yesterday were revised energy efficiency targets in homes. From 2002 elderly people and families on low incomes will be helped by electricity and gas suppliers to insulate their homes. There will be an internal UK carbon trading market to encourage businesses to save carbon and sell on credits to other industries. The government has also finalised its climate change levy on industry, which is expected to be the incentive for a cut in emissions of 2.5m tonnes.

The government has also given industry notice that hydrochlorofluorocarbons, the successors to chlorofluorocarbons in refrigeration, have no long term future and will be phased out, since they too are a powerful global warming gas. Michael Meacher, the environment minister, said: "The 20% cut is only the beginning. Scientists say we must cut 60% to 70% to peg the carbon dioxide in the atmosphere to double what it was before the industrial revolution. We must move into renewable energies, fuel cells to drive cars, and other technologies that cause no carbon pollution."

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Death of former Labour MP
fields.body:
Death of former Labour MP

Robert Parry, the former Labour MP for Liverpool Riverside, died yesterday aged 67 in hospital after a short illness.

Known as a leftwinger, he had been an MP for 27 years when he retired at the last general election after a stroke and heart bypass; he was also a diabetic.

Police question GP over death

An unnamed family doctor from Harlow, Essex, is being questioned by police over a 17-year-old patient for whom he prescribed methadone, a heroin substitute, and who died in September 1997.

His health authority has asked that he be suspended, and the General Medical Council will investigate.

Crufts judge denies cruelty

Caroline Gatheral, 65, an authority on King Charles spaniels, is among the judges at today's Crufts show in Birmingham.

She and her sister, Mary, 63, are to stand trial in a fortnight for alleged cruelty to 83 dogs in their care, which they deny, at their kennels in a former stately home in Co Durham last year. The Kennel Club said entrants to the spaniel category had been told she would be judging.

Firefighters' time wasted

In the 12 months to April last year Gloucestershire fire and rescue service sent crews on 2,666 genuine "shouts" and rescued 13 people. In the same period, the brigade scrambled pumps, each carrying five crew, to 2,733 false alarms, of which 400 were thought to be deliberate hoaxes.

The brigade was also sent to 1,532 calls that included people trapped in car crash wrecks and children trapped in fences or kitchen appliances. Firefighters are trying to cut down wasted calls by giving talks at local schools and contacting firms.

Girl excluded for kicking head

A 12-year-old has been permanently excluded from Wilton CE middle school near Salisbury after attacking her headteacher with kicks and punches when reprimanded in class.

The chair of governors said: "The whole school is in shock - you read about this sort of thing in rough city schools, but in rural Wiltshire it is unknown."

£11,147 cost of marital bliss

The average British wedding costs £11,147 - double what it was in 1989.

According to a Wedding and Home magazine readers survey, the average age of brides this year is 28 and 30 for grooms. Half of couples will marry in church.

fields.headline: Edwina Currie wins libel action
fields.trailText: Edwina Currie is not the vilest woman in Britain.
fields.body:
Edwina Currie is not the vilest woman in Britain.

For those who may have been in some doubt on the matter, it was resolved yesterday in the high court in London when the novelist and former Tory minister won a public apology and £30,000 in libel damages from a newspaper which had accused her of holding this special place in the nation's heart.

The article, written by the Express's political columnist Peter Oborne in September 1997, had made a number of "offensive" allegations about the ex-Tory MP, the court heard.

But it was the headline, How Edwina is now the vilest lady in Britain, which had particularly upset Mrs Currie, her counsel Edward Garnier QC said, because it could have been taken by readers to compare her unfavourably with the Moors murderer Myra Hindley and the serial killer Rosemary West.

The article claimed that there were rumours sweeping Westminster that Mrs Currie was about to join the Labour party to breathe new life into her "clapped out" political career.

Mr Oborne wrote that she would be no more acceptable to Tony Blair's inclusive new Labour administration than "a mass murderer", a "serial rapist" or "an active officer in Radovan Karadzic's death squad".

Mrs Currie was unaware of any rumours that she was about to leave the Conservative party and they were, in any event, untrue.

Other allegations in the article had been put to Mrs Currie in televison and radio interviews as though they were established facts, Mr Garnier told Mr Justice Morland.

Kate Macmillan, solicitor for the newspaper, expressed "sincere regret" that the article had caused Mrs Currie any upset and damage.

She added: "The article and headline in particular were not meant to be taken literally but were intended to be a strong piece of political comment."

The newspaper accepted without reservation that the headline - which was not written by Oborne - and parts of the article went beyond the acceptable ambit of fair comment.

Mrs Currie, who was MP for South Derbyshire from 1983 to 1997 and a junior health minister from 1986 to 1988, also received her legal costs.

Afterwards, she said: "I'm delighted it's done and delighted it's over. I never wanted a fight with the Express."

webTitle: MPs put conditions on support for Turkey dam

fields.headline: MPs put conditions on support for Turkey dam
fields.standfirst:
Select committee Ilisu Dam report

RiverNet: Ilisu Dam
fields.trailText: The government's backing of the Ilisu dam project in Turkey was thrown into doubt last night after MPs delivered a stinging report into the affair.
fields.body:
The government's backing of the Ilisu dam project in Turkey was thrown into doubt last night after MPs delivered a stinging report into the affair.

Members of the trade and industry select committee said plans to spend £200m of taxpayers' money on the dam would have to be dropped unless the Turkish government agreed to certain guarantees.

The main stumbling block is trade secretary Stephen Byers' insistence that Turkey consult Syria and Iraq on its proposal to restrict the flow of the river Tigris into their territory. Turkey will not do so according to Olcay Unver, president of the Turkish adminstration in charge of the project.

Yesterday the committee investigating the export credit guarantee department's involvement in the project criticised the government for secrecy over the deal.

MPs expressed surprise that it had not been brought to ministers' attention at all until the Guardian revealed British support for the plan last March.

MPs conceded that British commercial interests in Turkey and political relations between the two countries would be damaged if Britain did not pledge the £200m. "At the same time it would be quite wrong to go ahead regardless of the potential ill effects of the dam in the hope that matters would sort themselves out."

The committee demanded that Mr Byers obtain assurances from the Turkish authorities that they had consulted downstream neighbours before agreeing the project. "Objections from neighbouring states, however charged in the political context, deserve to be taken seriously."

MPs said yesterday their worst fears were for the Kurdish people whose homes would be drowned and their livelihoods lost. The failure to consult even the mayors of the affected towns was "lamentable."

The committee said: "The principal result of the dam will be the movement yet more people from the land to overcrowded cities ... and the absence of remedies in the courts for those aggrieved will leave many people without access to justice."

The committee "shares the view of ministers that the greatest remaining obstacle to granting export credit for the dam is the prospect of a programme of displacing thousands of local residents without proper consultation, compensation and resettlement".

On the issue of secrecy the MPs demand that the ECGD "address the deplorable and counter-productive lack of transparency in the way in which documentation has been kept from the public on the Ilisu dam project".

It also criticised the government's delayed publication of environmental and resettlement reports until just before parliament rose for the Christmas recess so that MPs could not raise any issues involved.

Tony Juniper, policy director of Friends of the Earth, said: "This report highlights how the government's commitments to the environment, human rights and democracy and ethical foreign policy are not reflected in the policies of the ECGD. Mr Byers should refuse support for the Ilisu dam and instead concentrate on overhauling the rules that decided which British companies gain taxpayers' assistance for their work overseas."

webTitle: Families of bus crash victims may sue

fields.headline: Families of bus crash victims may sue
fields.trailText: The families of two women crushed to death by a runaway bus are considering legal action against the vehicle's makers after the collapse of a dangerous driving trial yesterday.
fields.body:
The families of two women crushed to death by a runaway bus are considering legal action against the vehicle's makers after the collapse of a dangerous driving trial yesterday.

Crown court judge David Hodson ordered the jury at Newcastle upon Tyne to acquit 64-year-old Gordon Clifford, whose single-decker Dennis Dart careered into passengers waiting at a crowded bus station in Sunderland in December 1998.

Mark Laprell, defending, told the jury during the nine day hearing that because of engineering tolerances the accelerator could be higher than the brake in one bus but lower in another which was otherwise an identical model.

The mother of student teacher Janine Harrison, who was 19 and died after being dragged 200ft beneath the bus, collapsed in the public gallery after the judge made his ruling.

The court was suspended while Lesley Harrison was taken to Newcastle royal infirmary where she was recovering last night.

webTitle: Boy ferried between three hospitals dies of meningitis

fields.headline: Boy ferried between three hospitals dies of meningitis
fields.trailText: An investigation has been launched after a child died of meningitis following a 90-mile trip by ambulance between three hospitals in search of an intensive care bed.
fields.body:
An investigation has been launched after a child died of meningitis following a 90-mile trip by ambulance between three hospitals in search of an intensive care bed.

Tyler Foster, 23 months old, was taken to the accident and emergency department at Grantham and District hospital in Lincolnshire after his mother spotted a purple rash on his neck.

The child, from Gonerby Hill Foot, Lincolnshire, was transferred by ambulance to the Pilgrim hospital in Boston, because Grantham hospital does not have intensive care facilities for children.

Doctors at the Pilgrim, which is also without a paediatric intensive care unit, then decided that Tyler needed to go to a third hospital in Nottingham where he could receive specialist treatment.

The child, who eventually arrived at the Queen's Medical Centre in Nottingham 10 hours after he was first taken to the Grantham hospital, died of meningococcal meningitis on February 26 after four days in intensive care.

After the boy's parents complained, Grantham and District hospital yesterday said it would investigate why the decision had been taken to take the child to Boston rather than Nottingham.

Sarah Temple, 27, the boy's mother, said: "Meningitis is every mother's worst nightmare and Tyler should have been taken to the right hospital straight away. Nothing will bring Tyler back but the important thing now is that this does not happen to another child. The wrong decision was made and we want to prevent that happening again."

A Grantham hospital spokesman said: "We have launched a full investigation which will take about two weeks to complete. We are following up every aspect of the treatment he received."

The hospital has not had paediatric facilities for the last two years, he added.

The child's father, Simon Foster, said: "I do feel sometimes that I want to turn round to people and say, if you have a sick child, get them to the best place possible and in my eyes at the moment Grantham is not the best place."

Christopher Birch, medical director at Grantham and District hospital, said: "We would very much like children to be treated here as inpatients if that was feasible.

"But a decision was made to withdraw inpatient children's services here for a variety of reasons."

webTitle: Dublin court bails IRA man wanted for murdering SAS officer 20 years ago

fields.headline: Dublin court bails IRA man wanted for murdering SAS officer 20 years ago
fields.standfirst: Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: One of the IRA's most notorious killers, still wanted in Northern Ireland for the murder of an SAS captain 20 years ago, was freed on bail yesterday after a day of legal confusion in Dublin.
fields.body:
One of the IRA's most notorious killers, still wanted in Northern Ireland for the murder of an SAS captain 20 years ago, was freed on bail yesterday after a day of legal confusion in Dublin.

The high court ordered an inquiry into why Gardai arrested Paul "Dingus" Magee, 52, on Wednesday at his home in Co Kerry. He had lived there openly since he was freed under the Good Friday agreement last year.

Mr Justice Aindreas O'Caoimh granted Magee leave to challenge his extradition and freed him on £9,700 bail after state counsel offered no objections. He was released from his handcuffs, and left the court without comment.

Magee was arrested in Tralee on an extradition warrant issued after the supreme court ordered in October 1991 that he must be returned to Belfast to serve a 30-year sentence for the May 1980 murder of Captain Richard Westmacott. He had jumped bail before the ruling.

Magee later joined an IRA active service unit in England and shot dead police officer Glenn Goodman, 37, in Yorkshire in June 1992.

The British authorities repatriated him to Ireland to serve the remainder of his life sentence two years ago. He was freed from Portlaoise Prison on temporary release last September.

Magee, a member of the feared IRA M60 gang, appeared first before the supreme court yesterday. But it ruled the high court should decide whether he be sent back to Northern Ireland, and his lawyers successfully argued he should be allowed bail.

Angelo Fusco, 43, who also belonged to the M60 gang, was arrested in January in Co Kerry. He is in custody as he fights extradition.

Magee's lawyers argued the extradition warrant had expired. They called for an inquiry under the republic's constitution into the legality of his detention. A full hearing is expected next month.

Sinn Fein pointed out the British authorities had allowed him to serve his sentence in Ireland while fully aware of his conviction in Belfast. It said Magee could have been held at any time since his release in September, and claimed he travelled regularly into Northern Ireland to see his family in west Belfast. Magee, Fusco and six other IRA prisoners shot their way out of Belfast's Crumlin Road jail in June 1981, two days before he was jailed in his absence for murdering Captain Westmacott, 28. He was the highest ranking SAS officer to die in the Troubles.

Magee was subsequently arrested with Fusco in the Irish Republic in January 1982, and jailed for 10 years for the jail-break. He was served with extradition papers just before his release, and began his legal fight to avoid being sent back to Northern Ireland.

Police in the Irish Republic were yesterday unable to explain the timing of his arrest. One source indicated it was simply a cleaning-up operation, though there are suggestions that police in Kerry are unhappy at seeing ex-IRA prisoners from Belfast settling there.

Captain Westmacott was shot dead as he led an eight-man SAS operation against the M-60 gang - named after the heavy-duty, rapid firing machine gun they used - in north Belfast. The gang, which claimed the lives of at least eight members of the security forces, was forced to surrender.

Captain Westmacott, whose wife was pregnant with their first child at the time, prevented an attack on a police Land Rover at the nearby RUC base.

He was posthumously awarded the Military Cross.

fields.headline: Fayed's £3.5m bill ends Rowland feud
fields.standfirst: Harrods boss must pay £1.4m plus costs to rival's widow over gems that went missing from safe deposit boxes
fields.trailText: The final curtain fell yesterday on one of the most acrimonious feuds in British business history when Mohamed Al Fayed agreed to pay the widow of Tiny Rowland more than £1.4m for gemstones "stolen" from the late head of Lonrho's safety deposit box at Harrods.
fields.body:
The final curtain fell yesterday on one of the most acrimonious feuds in British business history when Mohamed Al Fayed agreed to pay the widow of Tiny Rowland more than £1.4m for gemstones "stolen" from the late head of Lonrho's safety deposit box at Harrods.

The millionaire Egyptian businessman and three of his employees admitted liability in 1998 over the unlawful break-ins to the safe deposit box, paying Josephine Rowland more than £250,000 in damages. He is also liable for costs of the case, which are estimated at £2.1m over its three-year duration.

But in accordance with her husband's last wish that she should continue with the civil action to the bitter end, Mrs Rowland pursued the Harrods owner over the value of the collection of 20 emeralds, seven rubies and four tanzanite stones that were lost "because of the wrongdoing of the defendants".

Christopher Moger QC, representing Mrs Rowland, told the high court in London yesterday that the the process of getting Mr Fayed and the other defendants to pay compensation was "a process akin to drawing teeth", adding: "I would like to emphasise that this is not a settlement or a compromise. It is a submission by Mr Fayed and the other defendants for the whole of the claim."

Mrs Rowland said yesterday that the case was not about money. "Those stones were selected by my husband as gifts for our daughters and were a very great loss to us. My children will never be able to say these stones came from daddy's mines."

Humiliating

Of all the mud that was thrown between Mr Fayed and Mr Rowland during their 14-year feud over the control of Harrods, the safety deposit box allegations have proved to be possibly the most humiliating and damaging for the Harrods owner.

His consuming passion to be granted a British passport was dealt a fatal blow by the theft claims last year when Jack Straw ruled that Mr Fayed was unfit to be given British citizenship on the grounds that he had made "improper and unethical" cash-for-questions payments to MPs and because of his failure to report the deposit box break-in to the police.

The saga began in 1997 when a former employee of Mr Fayed, Robert Loftus, contacted Rowland and told him that on December 6 1995 he had shown a still picture taken from a closed-circuit security camera of Rowland visiting the Harrods vaults. The Harrods owner was said to be furious that his enemy had managed to keep personal belongings right under his nose and ordered his security staff to break into the safe deposit box.

Bodyguard

A Surrey locksmith who had been asked to perform a "special job" was brought to Harrods, while the deposit box manager was told not to go through the alarm procedures for the evening and leave the security cameras switched off.

After the store closed Mr Loftus took the locksmith down to the safe deposit boxes where they were joined by John Macnamara, Mr Fayed's head of security, Mark Griffiths, his personal assistant, and Paul Handly-Greaves, his bodyguard.

As soon as the box was opened it was taken up to Mr Fayed's office suite on the fifth floor, where, in the chairman's presence, Mr Griffiths and Mr Macnamara put on plastic food-handlers' gloves from the store's world-famous food hall and removed the contents.

Rowland reported the matter to the police. He claimed the items missing from the box - rented over 30 years earlier - contained documents and mementos relating to his wartime activities, emeralds, rubies, Tibetan coins, a Tibetan stamp, a gold cigarette case and audio tapes.

He alleged the items had been removed to blackmail him into falsely claiming that he had paid the former home secretary Michael Howard £10m as a bribe to launch the DTI inquiry into Mr Fayed's takeover of Harrods.

In March 1998 the Harrods chairman and a number of his employees suffered the indignity of being arrested and released on police bail after voluntarily going to a central London police station to be questioned about the allegations. Rowland was devastated when in July that year the crown prosecution service advised the police that there was no real prospect of a criminal conviction. Mr Fayed greeted the decision as a "triumph for the truth", claiming the allegations of theft had been a "total fabrication".

But the matter refused to go away. It dominated the final days of Rowland's life and before he died he made his wife promise that she would go on with a civil action he had launched. The case reached the courts in November 1998. Mr Fayed admitted the safe deposit box had been broken into, but denied any involvement, claiming he had only found out afterwards. But after two weeks Mr Fayed paid costs, estimated at £2m, and damages totalling £253,465, to Mrs Rowland, including £2,400 for the missing cigarette case, £1,000 for the Tibetan coins, £150,000 for reducing the value of Row land's archive when personal letters were copied and £100,000 special damages.

Yesterday was the third time that the owner of Harrods has been forced to pay out a considerable sum of money in an attempt to make the allegations go away. Bob Loftus accepted "generous" undisclosed damages from the Harrods chairman after he accused his former security guard of instigating the opening of the box while in the pay of Mr Rowland.

Latest in a week of legal setbacks

Yesterday's payment to the widow of Tiny Rowland completes what has been a very bad week for Mohamed Al Fayed, the fabulously wealthy owner of Harrods.

On March 3 it emerges that the City of London police have launched an investigation into allegations that Mr Fayed had paid £10,000 for legal documents stolen from the dustbins of the disgraced former minister Neil Hamilton's lawyers before the start of his libel trial against the Harrods owner.

The papers, allegedly taken by Benjamin Pell, are said to have contained details of the strategy to be employed by Mr Hamilton's legal team in their cross-examination of the Harrods owner.

Mr Hamilton was able to win a stay on paying £500,000 of the £2m in costs he owes Mr Fayed.

Lord Harris of High Cross, the coordinator of Mr Hamilton's £400,000 fighting fund, also won a stay on an order that he should disclose the names of those who donated more than £5,000.

On March 6, lawyers for Mr Fayed failed to gain an injunction against the Daily Telegraph over the publication of extracts from a forthcoming book by Trevor Rees-Jones, The Bodyguard's Story.

In the book, Mr Rees-Jones places the blame for the crash which killed Diana, Princess of Wales, and Dodi Fayed squarely with Mr Fayed's son, describing him as reckless, dangerous and unpredictable. He claims Dodi overruled those appointed to take care of security, changed travel plans at a moment's notice and travelled without back-up.

Mr Rees-Jones portrays Mr Fayed as a fantasist who, in order to disguise his son's culpability, invented incredible conspiracy theories involving MI5 and the British establishment.

He also rejects the contention that the couple were intending to marry, dismissing suggestions that Dodi had bought Princess Diana an engagement ring. Mr Fayed has claimed that the couple chose a ring in Monte Carlo before their deaths, but Mr Rees-Jones, who accompanied them on the trip wrote that they "never went into a jewellery store".

webTitle: Labour's most powerful women call truce

fields.headline: Labour's most powerful women call truce
fields.standfirst: New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: By the standards of historic truces it may one day rank alongside Hitler and Stalin's non-aggression pact of 1939.
fields.body:
By the standards of historic truces it may one day rank alongside Hitler and Stalin's non-aggression pact of 1939.

After more than a year of feuding, two of the most powerful women in the Labour party have decided to bury the hatchet and forge an alliance.

Margaret McDonagh, the party's general secretary, and Sally Morgan, the prime minister's political secretary, who have repeatedly clashed over Labour's "Stop Ken" campaign, have told friends that it is in both their interests to make up.

"Margaret and Sally have realised that their differences are not doing either of them any good," one friend said.

"They both realise that if one goes, the other is likely to follow soon afterwards."

Tales of clashes between Ms McDonagh and Ms Morgan have provided an endless source of gossip for Millbank watchers during the ham-fisted campaign to block Ken Livingstone from standing as London mayor.

Insults - all off the record and spun by friends - have been hurled between Downing Street and Millbank where each woman presides over a half of the prime minister's political empire. As Labour's general secretary, Ms McDonagh runs Labour's Millbank headquarters, while Ms Morgan holds sway in Downing Street as the prime minister's political secretary.

Their greatest clash came as the Labour hierarchy struggled to draw up a plan to block Mr Livingstone from winning the Labour nomination for London.

Ms McDonagh found herself in the firing line for opting for the controversial electoral college which handed the Labour nomination to Frank Dobson in a discredited way which appears to have made Mr Livingstone unstoppable.

Ms Morgan has been criticised by Millbank for failing to focus the prime minister on the threat posed by Mr Livingstone until it was too late.

The McDonagh-Morgan non-aggression pact is a demonstration of the concern at the highest levels of the Labour party that personal feuds are proving highly damaging. The feud between the Blair and Brown camps destabilised the government in the first two years after the general election, although the prime minister and chancellor maintained good relations.

Ms McDonagh and Ms Morgan's friends will hope that their pact lasts.

"Margaret and Sally have realised that their differences are not doing either of them any good," one friend said. "They both realise that if one goes, the other is likely to follow soon afterwards." Tales of clashes between Ms McDonagh and Ms Morgan have provided an endless source of gossip for Millbank watchers during the ham-fisted campaign to block Ken Livingstone from standing as London mayor. Insults - all off the record and spun by friends - have been hurled between Downing Street and Millbank where each woman presides over a half of the prime minister's political empire. As Labour's general secretary, Ms McDonagh runs Labour's Millbank headquarters, while Ms Morgan holds sway in Downing Street as the prime minister's political secretary. Their greatest clash came as the Labour hierarchy struggled to draw up a plan to block Mr Livingstone from winning the Labour nomination for London. Ms McDonagh found herself in the firing line for opting for the controversial electoral college which handed the Labour nomination to Frank Dobson in a discredited way which appears to have made Mr Livingstone unstoppable. Ms Morgan has been criticised by Millbank for failing to focus the prime minister on the threat posed by Mr Livingstone until it was too late. The McDonagh-Morgan non-aggression pact is a demonstration of the concern at the highest levels of the Labour party that personal feuds are proving highly damaging. The feud between the Blair and Brown camps destabilised the government in the first two years after the general election, although the prime minister and chancellor maintained good relations. Ms McDonagh and Ms Morgan's friends will hope that their pact lasts.

webTitle: Tory warning as council taxpayers face 6% rise

fields.headline: Tory warning as council taxpayers face 6% rise
fields.standfirst: Tories in opposition: special report
fields.trailText: Council tax bills in England and Wales will rise on average by more than three times the rate of inflation next month, according to a survey published today by a research institute representing local government accountants.
fields.body:
Council tax bills in England and Wales will rise on average by more than three times the rate of inflation next month, according to a survey published today by a research institute representing local government accountants.

In spite of government claims of a record Whitehall subsidy to authorities this year, the Chartered Institute of Public Finance and Accountancy says householders face increases of 6.3% - bringing the annual tax on the average band D property to £837.

After an extensive survey, the institute points to wide variations: Welsh taxpayers face increases of 9.8%, and Londoners almost 7% - part of which will pay for the elected assembly and mayor; elsewhere in England, it varies from 4.9% in Bedfordshire to 9% in Worcestershire.

Councils have said that the extra cash will be largely taken by education -pay for teachers, more pupils, and support for government schools initiatives.

The city of Westminster presently has the lowest band D of £350, and Liverpool the highest at £1,171 - although the latter's Liberal Democrat council has frozen the rate for this time.

Archie Norman, the shadow environment secretary, claimed last night that Labour had been hitting taxpayers by stealth while cutting grants for essential services - a charge strenuously denied by the government. Ministers blame councils, some Labour-controlled, for failing to manage services effectively.

With council tax certain to be an issue in local elections early in May, Mr Norman claimed that, since the government took office, the average band D tax had increased by a "massive" 23%, or £160. He added: "The average household will have to pay at least £50 more in tax this year, on top of above-inflation increases last year. Voters will have Labour to blame for bigger council tax bills and cuts in services."

Liberal Democrats, now Labour's main opponents in cities, said councils were having to cut services and increase charges to keep within Whitehall spending limits.

The local government minister, Hilary Armstrong, has previously announced that support from Whitehall grants and business rates distributed to English councils will rise by more than twice underlying inflation, and be set at £42.8bn - an increase of 5.5%. Council tax raises a fifth of total town hall spending.

Steve Freer, the institute's chief executive, said councils faced difficult choices: pressure from government to spend on priority services such as schools, and local pressure to maintain the roads, libraries and other services.

fields.headline: The bigger they come
fields.standfirst: Last night's TV
fields.trailText: TV Nightmares IV (ITV) was one of those shows where the programme-makers string together old clips for the benefit of a delightedly screaming studio audience. The "nightmares" were celebrities' embarrassing or frightening moments: Richard Madeley eats some hot sauce which is hotter than he was expecting. Anna Walker sees a hippo in a river in Africa. Barbara Windsor trips coming down the stairs in an episode of EastEnders.
fields.body:
TV Nightmares IV (ITV) was one of those shows where the programme-makers string together old clips for the benefit of a delightedly screaming studio audience. The "nightmares" were celebrities' embarrassing or frightening moments: Richard Madeley eats some hot sauce which is hotter than he was expecting. Anna Walker sees a hippo in a river in Africa. Barbara Windsor trips coming down the stairs in an episode of EastEnders.

In fact, those were the better clips. Although all of them had to be accompanied by extensive interviews with their stars to explain what the actual nightmare element was - ie that the hot sauce was really hot, that the hippo was really scary. Some of the other "nightmares" were simply ordinary people falling over on foreign TV programmes, with helpful voiceover: "If you thought that was funny, look at this". Just in case you failed to laugh.

Many of the segments did not seem to fit the nightmare theme. Keith Chegwin came on and watched long clips from an obscure programme called Starsearch which he apparently once hosted on some satellite channel. The Starsearch concept appeared to be that a panel of microcelebs amused themselves by judging a series of very poor amateur talent acts. So we saw some clips of very poor talent acts and Keith Chegwin and the microcelebs wetting themselves about them. Which was the point of the original show. So perhaps the nightmare aspect was Keith Chegwin being reminded that he once hosted this obviously piss-poor show.

The whole thing was presented in an elaborate and lividly lit studio set (this is expensive TV really) by someone called Steve Penk. Steve Penk was amiable enough in a charisma-free way, but it was hard not to feel he'd been picked up at IKEA. No doubt he'll go far with his infectious catchphrase: "Now that's funny."

Coming Home (Channel 4), the latest in the series Great Undertakings, which takes a quiet look at the mechanics of the funeral business, opened with Mr Freestone, a funeral director, turning the yellowed pages of a ledger. He has arranged some 8000 funerals. A funeral is, he says "the last possible kindness that a widow may give her husband or a son to his mother..." The episode then followed two funeral stories loosely linked by the homecoming theme.

Wilma's husband had come to this country many years ago from Poland and had told her to "put me in the garden" when he died, but Wilma found an article he wrote evincing his nostalgia for Krakow and decided to transport his ashes to Poland to be placed in the family tomb. Eventually, she is told she can carry him in her hand luggage.

Anita died of cancer on holiday with her sisters in Skiathos, and her partner Adrian and son George are arranging her return to England and her funeral. The young funeral director explains firmly but gently that she is not in an ideal condition for viewing.

This is a rare steady look at death which also turns into a moving evocation of love and grief. Wilma sits on the train with her husband beside her in a leather bag. She follows her husband's ashes through a lush green graveyard, and watches the tiny casket, incongruously adorned with pink roses like a wedding cake, be clumsily interred.

In a later scene, Wilma is a small un-self-pitying figure at the glossy nuptials of a great-niece. "It was a little more difficult than I had imagined, just a fraction, but now I get on with my life."

George talks to camera about his mother and Adrian "It was the love of his life....I can't imagine what he's going through." The two men select the details of her funeral together, the glass carriage for the coffin, the horses with their waving plumes: "We chose the horse carriage because it was beautiful, just like Mum". They walk down the street together, awkwardly linked by loss.

Adrian selects a leopardskin coat to go in Anita's coffin - her fun-night-out coat ("She looked damn good in it") - and Don't Worry, Be Happy to play at her funeral. There is a strange change-of-gears moment when a hand presses a button marked "committal" and the coffin vanishes into the wall.

It was a bare half hour of television which neatly skirted the maudlin. The restrained camerawork lingered on faces and somehow served to invest ordinary objects with the potency of symbols and a kind of spiritual weight.

webTitle: Who are you? What the Tango ad says about you

fields.headline: Who are you? What the Tango ad says about you
fields.trailText: The ad: A naughty one this: it's just been banned. The ad opens with a voiceover announcing "James Rayner dislikes the untamed aggression of Orange Tango", depicting a rather tubby Mr Rayner sitting at home sipping on a bottle of cola. "Well James, we know where you live," continues the voice, as a bunch of orange-haired men burst through his front door, armed with megaphones. They surround him and menacingly bully him, repeating everything he says into their loudspeakers. Eventually he is beaten into submission, as the scary men chant: "Call for your Tango megaphone and join the fun".
fields.body:
The ad: A naughty one this: it's just been banned. The ad opens with a voiceover announcing "James Rayner dislikes the untamed aggression of Orange Tango", depicting a rather tubby Mr Rayner sitting at home sipping on a bottle of cola. "Well James, we know where you live," continues the voice, as a bunch of orange-haired men burst through his front door, armed with megaphones. They surround him and menacingly bully him, repeating everything he says into their loudspeakers. Eventually he is beaten into submission, as the scary men chant: "Call for your Tango megaphone and join the fun".

The jargon: The aim of this commercial is to directly challenge "cola", which is the dominant fizzy drink, and to out non-Tango drinkers, continuing in the fine tradition of irreverent, edgy advertising that has been Tango's speciality.

Personality: The creative epicentre is 19-year-old males and females, according to agency HHCL. It takes a lot to get them off the sofa and react because they have been brought up on a diet of visual stimulii and video games.

Financial status: Tango is only a soft fizzy drink, priced around 40- 50p, so it's not like a pair of Nike trainers. "We don't have to worry about people not being able to afford it," says HHCL.

Telling lifestyle detail: You could be working, you could be a student or you could be living at home, but you probably play PlayStation and are highly advertising-literate.

Other relevant data: Before the ad was pulled, over 70,000 youngsters had called up to buy the megaphones. But complaints flooded in from teachers, worried about playground bullying, and even from the Royal National Institute For The Deaf, which claimed it could provoke deafness by making kids shout into megaphones.

fields.headline: Hear this
fields.trailText: This month's extensive BBC campaign to persuade people to stop smoking finds Barbara Myers inviting addicts to phone Check-Up (3.0pm, Radio 4) for practical advice.
fields.body:
This month's extensive BBC campaign to persuade people to stop smoking finds Barbara Myers inviting addicts to phone Check-Up (3.0pm, Radio 4) for practical advice. Over the past 30 years adverse publicity has reduced the number of British smokers by half but that still leaves 12 million adults dependent on the weed. Worse, something like one in four British 15-year-olds smokes, in spite of the law making it illegal to sell tobacco to under-16s.

The Afternoon Play, Postcards From Shannon (2.15pm, Radio 4), is a moving docudrama about one young victim of Pan Am Flight 103. Shannon Davis was a 19-year-old student at Syracuse University, enjoying a term's research in Europe. Her suitcase was discovered by a volunteer searcher, Phil Haigh, who then arranged its return to her mother. Shannon's bubbly messages home, her mother's recorded memories, and Haigh's grim account of his search bring home the ghastly reality behind the headlines.

fields.headline: Small is beautiful
fields.standfirst: Ever unpredictable, having established himself as a director of blockbusters, Tony Scott decided to try his hand at TV: quirky stories aimed at late-night audiences. He talked exclusively to  Richard Vine  about his change of direction
fields.trailText: The career path of a Hollywood director is an established trajectory: go to film school, make a few shorts, get a showreel together, scramble around for your first feature, and once you've made one, don't ever look back.
fields.body:
The career path of a Hollywood director is an established trajectory: go to film school, make a few shorts, get a showreel together, scramble around for your first feature, and once you've made one, don't ever look back.

British director Tony Scott, on the other hand, started out in commercials, moved to film, and in between shooting The Fan with Robert De Niro and Wesley Snipes in 1997 and Enemy Of The State with Will Smith and Gene Hackman the following year, decided to make a TV show, The Hunger. A collection of offbeat stories, designed with the late-night adult audience of its US cable home, Showtime, in mind, it's an anthology series in the tradition of Alfred Hitchcock Presents or The Twilight Zone, shot, as Scott would have it, in a style that's "bridging the gap between MTV and half-hour television shows."

For the second series, which starts tonight, (Sci Fi Channel, 8.30pm) he's managed to convince David Bowie to take on the Alfred Hitchcock/Rod Serling presenter role, bookending the stories with his customary deadpan delivery from an abandoned prison facility in Canada.

Speaking from his carphone in America, Scott explained why he had wanted to make the move to television after establishing himself as a director of blockbusters.

"Film is so hard, it's like running a marathon. Commercials and television are like sprints, so it's nice to be able to change the pace of your life and have a little more time to experiment or try stuff, especially with commercials, that you would never get time to do in a movie.

"The Hunger is a way of exercising different ideas, a chance to do something weird and strange, some supernatural shit. I love doing them. I've always made a conscious effort to move and try to do things that aren't in the normal box for me. I follow my nose creatively, whether it's a commerical or an episode for television - I like to try to do something different."

He argues that the success of his action films, like Top Gun ("mainstream popcorn") and Crimson Tide, has seen him stereotyped by a Hollywood system that "will only cross reference material that's directly relevant to what they are now offering you."

"I think with the movies that I've done - directing mainstream movies, basically Americana - I've been pigeonholed with action films. With Top Gun or Enemy Of The State I kept getting put into that box, but my favourite movie of mine is True Romance, and it's hard for me to get out of the other box and into the True Romance box, where its true strength was Tarantino's writing. But that is Hollywood. It's very hard once you get boxed to get out of it."

Scott had worked with Bowie before on his first feature, the 1983 version of The Hunger, with Catherine Deneuve and Susan Sarandon, a slick vampire flick that he describes as "a very strange, esoteric, artsy fartsy piece", perfect for a rainy afternoon and a joint. "The series is really an off-shoot, in terms of content, in terms of strangeness and weirdness and otherworldliness."

In the first episode, Bowie takes centre stage as a performance artist who has dropped out of the public eye. Holed up in his forbidding prison, a dystopian panopticon of surveillance cameras and grey concrete, he takes in a young man on the run, who he coerces into helping with a gruesome, visceral swansong.

"The way I managed to get Bowie to do this was that he loved the material. I came to it with the idea of doing a rock and roller terrified of getting old, a rip-off of Performance, a rocker who's become a recluse because of his fear of showing his age to the public, and David said: "Hell, I've been there, I don't want to do that - let's look at the performing arts world."

"It was an interesting process with Bowie and with the writer and myself doing this original from scratch involving him and his ideas. David's pretty smart, very articulate. The other half of his life is the art world, so he was our intro into this performing arts world. The script was put together in three weeks, and it was a quick scramble, but that's what I like, the immediacy of television."

Scott thinks the reason more filmmakers don't follow the move he and other directors like David Lynch have made into television is simple: money.

"It's not very good, and there's a stigma about television as there is with commercials, which is ridiculous. If something is good, it's good, and I want to do it."

fields.headline: Behind the screen
fields.standfirst: Janine Gibson's TV gossip
fields.trailText: In telly-land the winter is over and it's time to celebrate the arrival of spring and summer. It may be hard when contemplating Castaway-style weather conditions to focus on what you'd like to be watching in June, but nonetheless this is the season of schedule launches.
fields.body:
In telly-land the winter is over and it's time to celebrate the arrival of spring and summer. It may be hard when contemplating Castaway-style weather conditions to focus on what you'd like to be watching in June, but nonetheless this is the season of schedule launches.

First off the block last week was Channel 4 announcing its Big Brother hidden camera show which we told you about months ago. Rumour is that the "lock people in a house for a week" format will be stripped through the schedule, running every weekday night. But Channel 4 has found itself in sticky situations with such things as Brookside trying to strip-schedule shows in the past, so don't hold your breath.

In a similar vein, a new game show will hit the screens in May. Flatmate will follow a group of roomies searching for a new tenant - the interview process, the move and the consequences. Winning candidate gets the first month rent-free, while the viewer gets the "warts and all" portrait on how they fared. Mmmm. Sometimes Channel 4's new programme ideas just make us feel very, very old.

Delving further into the treats on offer, we discover the intriguingly titled Why Trains Crash. Sadly it's not a Fox network-style clip show along the lines of When Insects Attack, but a four-part series investigating railway safety with a proper spin-off book (priced £14.99) and everything. We still think there's a possibility the audience may be misled by the title...

Elsewhere, the obligatory theme night indulging our love of archive US television will celebrate the king of soaps, Dallas. Dallas Night will feature a documentary about the show and interviews with its creator David Jacobs, plus, throughout the evening, quiz questions to test the knowledge of the devoted fans. As a warm-up, here's your starter for ten: How many of the 20m viewers who tuned in to find out who shot JR will watch Channel 4's Dallas Night ? Nearest correct answer receives the key to Southfork and a discarded stetson.
fields.bodyText: In telly-land the winter is over and it's time to celebrate the arrival of spring and summer. It may be hard when contemplating Castaway-style weather conditions to focus on what you'd like to be watching in June, but nonetheless this is the season of schedule launches. First off the block last week was Channel 4 announcing its Big Brother hidden camera show which we told you about months ago. Rumour is that the "lock people in a house for a week" format will be stripped through the schedule, running every weekday night. But Channel 4 has found itself in sticky situations with such things as Brookside trying to strip-schedule shows in the past, so don't hold your breath. In a similar vein, a new game show will hit the screens in May. Flatmate will follow a group of roomies searching for a new tenant - the interview process, the move and the consequences. Winning candidate gets the first month rent-free, while the viewer gets the "warts and all" portrait on how they fared. Mmmm. Sometimes Channel 4's new programme ideas just make us feel very, very old. Delving further into the treats on offer, we discover the intriguingly titled Why Trains Crash. Sadly it's not a Fox network-style clip show along the lines of When Insects Attack, but a four-part series investigating railway safety with a proper spin-off book (priced £14.99) and everything. We still think there's a possibility the audience may be misled by the title... webTitle: Holyrood's hole in the ground swallows cash

fields.headline: Holyrood's hole in the ground swallows cash
fields.standfirst: Devolution in Scotland: special report
fields.trailText: There's a big hole where Scotland's parliament should be: an empty site gouged from Edinburgh's historic heart that is swallowing ever-increasing amounts of money and casting long shadows over Donald Dewar's administration.
fields.body:
There's a big hole where Scotland's parliament should be: an empty site gouged from Edinburgh's historic heart that is swallowing ever-increasing amounts of money and casting long shadows over Donald Dewar's administration.

Almost a year since devolution, the Holyrood building that was to symbolise Scotland's pride has not progressed beyond an outdated scale model.

"There are 35 cement pourers on that site, and they have not poured as much as a teaspoon of cement," said Margo MacDonald of the Scottish National party. "It's the quietest construction site in the town."

And it's an ominous silence. No one is prepared to explain why the cost of the building has leapt from around £40m in 1997 to more than £200m. No one will say why no plans have been produced, why the opening date may be pushed back more than a year, whether the whole project may have to be scrapped.

"It has become Scotland's state secret," said an architect. "Someone, somewhere has been keeping lots of people quiet."

Even before the devolution referendum, plans for a parliament building had been taking shape. Once the vote was cast an international competition was launched to find a noteworthy architect.

Out of 80 entrants the judges picked the renowned Catalan Enric Miralles, who promised to create a dramatic political campus, built around an "upturned boat" design, at the bottom of the Royal Mile. Initial estimates were between £10m and £40m.

Within months the blueprint was changing and the costs rising. Members of the Scottish parliament, in their temporary home on the Mound, wanted more space. Numerous adjustments were made.

The project manager quit and revealed this week that he had been concerned about rising costs and an unwillingness by senior civil servants to make them public.

In June last year, Mr Dewar was talking about £109m. In the past week he has been confronted with £230m. An independent study of the project, initiated by the parliament's presiding officer, Lord Steel, is due to report by the end of the month. He has said he cannot rule out shelving the scheme.

Meanwhile, Mr Miralles has criticised the "sentimental" attitude of his clients. He said the figure of more than £200m was invention but warned that further interference would only push the price up further.

"I have never come across problems like this, but the team are trying not to let the controversy over costs hold us back," he said. "This is a tremendously important building which must be built to last hundreds of years. At the end of the day the cost should not be the overriding concern."

There are fears in parliamentary circles that he might quit.

"He's just so affronted that anyone is asking: Excuse me, but how much is this costing?" said one MSP. "He's bound to be saying to himself: What is this doing to my international reputation?"

Mr Dewar, beset by scandals and policy setbacks, can ill afford another crisis. There have been accusations - angrily dismissed - that he knew about the spiralling costs and wanted them glossed over.

Some MSPs say he ought to have known.

Ms MacDonald takes no comfort in saying she told them so. It was she who first raised concerns about the project. She noticed the lack of activity on the site. She spoke to architects and lobbied other MSPs.

"The role of the civil service in this has to be questioned," she said. An inquiry was needed into the professional, administrative and the political management of the project.

"The executive are worried now, and it's the strangest thing: my job has been to tell them not to panic. There is no fantastic wrong done - other than to public confidence."

fields.headline: Good day/ bad day
fields.trailText: Good day
fields.body:
Good day

Tory mayoral hopeful Steve Norris was given the nod all candidates hope for - a ringing vote of confidence from Lord Archer. Jeffrey revealed in the Spectator that he would casting his second preference vote for Ken Livingstone in the forthcoming ballot, but added: "My first choice remains Steven Norris - dead or alive."

Better day

Joyous news for The Point, the BBC's beleaguered programme covering Welsh politics. After scoring a zero audience rating one day last month, the political broadcast of assembly proceedings picked up a healthy 42,000 viewers for a repeat showing put out at Sunday lunchtime. A BBC source said: "Perhaps people find Welsh politics easier to digest before their Sunday lunch rather than coming home from the pub on a Thursday night."

Bad day

Ken Livingstone, duped into believing he was about to gain £100,000 for his mayor campaign. The MP was given a telephone number said to be that of an anonymous lottery winner:"I invited him to my office, but he never appeared."

Today

webTitle: Scottish devolution is working, insists Blair

fields.headline: Scottish devolution is working, insists Blair
fields.standfirst: Devolution in Scotland: special report
fields.trailText: Tony Blair used his historic first visit to the Scottish parliament yesterday to insist that devolution was working, amid growing evidence to the contrary.
fields.body:
Tony Blair used his historic first visit to the Scottish parliament yesterday to insist that devolution was working, amid growing evidence to the contrary.

He praised the Edinburgh parliament's achievements and condemned as "corrosive" the views of those who criticised its efforts.

Mr Blair said he was disappointed that journalists observers who had inititially shown a passion for devolution now showed an equal passion for knocking it down.

"Scepticism is healthy. Cynicism is corrosive. And there is no cause for it. That fact is that the Scottish parliament is innovating and it is working in partnership with the rest of the UK."

But events beyond the chamber directly challenge his buoyant claims. Labour faces a trouncing in next week's Ayr byelection, a contest seen as a verdict on the performance of the Holyrood administration. One newspaper poll suggested yesterday that Labour would not only lose the seat, but come third behind the Tories and the Scottish National party. Mr Blair will not be visiting the constituency.

Questions also remain over first minister Donald Dewar's leadership with recent high-profile attacks on his authority from his own backbenchers. Then there is the growing disquiet over the cost, management and viability of the new - as yet unconstructed - parliament building; and the continuing row over the administration's handling of the repeal of section 28.

Mr Blair said yesterday: "Nobody is saying this body is perfect, any more than any other parliament is perfect. Nobody is saying mistakes will not be made.

"This is a new world and we, all of us, politicians and the media, have a responsibility to make it work precisely because it is the will of the people." Mr Blair used the parliament's anti-drug efforts to call for a Europe-wide war on drugs with minimum penalties for traffickers across the European Union. "Dealers must know that they will face severe penalties wherever they are caught," he said.

He also stressed he wanted tough action in countries applying to join the EU. "Much of the heroin in the UK comes here through applicant countries. That creates problems for them as well as us."

He later visited a drug rehabilitation project in Glasgow with the drug tsar Keith Hellawell. Nearly 300 young people die from drug misuse in Scotland ever year. Ian McCartney, the Cabinet office minister, lost his son Hugh to a drugs overdose in Glasgow last September.

There were protests from farmers and students as Mr Blair arrived at the parliament. Several SNP members refused to applaud during his speech. As the prime minister left the chamber, the independent MSP Dennis Canavan - an exiled, former Labour MP - leapt to his feet and, with a broad smile, waved a poster at the podium. "Vote Ken," it said.

webTitle: Second guessing Norris predicts he will beat Livingstone in crucial mayoral vote

fields.headline: Second guessing Norris predicts he will beat Livingstone in crucial mayoral vote
fields.standfirst: The London mayor: special report
fields.trailText: A confident Steve Norris yesterday told Conservative supporters not to "waste" their second preference vote in the election for mayor of London because he intends to beat Ken Livingstone in the second, decisive round.
fields.body:
A confident Steve Norris yesterday told Conservative supporters not to "waste" their second preference vote in the election for mayor of London because he intends to beat Ken Livingstone in the second, decisive round.

The Tory candidate based his optimism on what he called "hovering pencil syndrome" in the polling booth: the hunch that, if Frank Dobson comes third and is eliminated on May 4, both loyal Labour voters and Liberal Democrats will be found to have cast their second votes for Mr Norris rather than for the former GLC leader.

They would say "this guy Norris is a non-loony, sensible, even-handed, tolerant kind of guy, but he has also been in business, been a minister and can deal with government", he argued.

"If Ken does not win (outright) on the first ballot, Ken is dead. Is he going to get Labour second votes? You're kidding," said Mr Norris. He was speaking during a visit to the Guardian on a day when leading candidates and their deputies, right, joined forces to launch Operation Black Vote, designed to encourage minority voters, almost one third in London, to use their political clout and vote.

In his Guardian interview the former London transport minister, who rightly predicted he would replace Jeffrey Archer as the Conservative candidate, portrayed himself as a social liberal in Tory terms - strong on minority rights, civil liberties and tolerance - while an instinctive rightwinger on economic issues. He is anti-abortion, but pro-choice as well as pro-hanging.

Yesterday he stressed: "I am not going to use the office to score party political points off Blair or Brown or anyone else." Calling the job essentially non-party and 95% management he said his support is "wholly unideological, it's about trains that work and buses that turn up on time".

Mr Norris pledged himself to make better bus services his priority, because more can be done quickly in that area than in improving trains. But he is opposed to a congestion tax for cars as unworkable and unfair to poorer Londoners, to whom he also promised a better share of London's unfairly distributed wealth.

He promised to appoint women to half the mayor's staff jobs and ethnic minorities to a third of them. If elected, he will resign all outside jobs, including charity posts, and put his shares into a blind trust.

The ex-MP for Epping on the London borders who now chairs a private bus group was kinder towards Mr Dobson, the official Labour candidate than towards Mr Livingstone - whose huge opinion poll lead he says will "fall faster than he will like". Mr Dobson is "a decent chap and a perfectly competent minister, but he just looks as if he is losing and people pick that up," he said.

webTitle: Beach house neighbour seen as threat to Pinochet

fields.headline: Beach house neighbour seen as threat to Pinochet
fields.standfirst: Pinochet on trial: special report
fields.trailText: General Augusto Pinochet's planned move to his beach home in El Melocoton has been complicated by revelations that his next-door neighbour will be the former logistical chief of the Manuel Rodriguez Patriotic Front (FPMR), a guerrilla organisation which tried to blow him up in 1986. Several bodyguards died in that failed attempt on his life.
fields.body:
General Augusto Pinochet's planned move to his beach home in El Melocoton has been complicated by revelations that his next-door neighbour will be the former logistical chief of the Manuel Rodriguez Patriotic Front (FPMR), a guerrilla organisation which tried to blow him up in 1986. Several bodyguards died in that failed attempt on his life.

Just over a year ago, Rolando Amador Escobar Ibanez, a former senior FPMR member, began renting a house in the Santiago resort of El Melocoton. The house is located right beside Gen Pinochet's residence, separated only by a ditch and 300 metres of grass.

Mr Escobar Ibanez was exiled to Argentina during the dictatorship years, accused of planning to kidnap the Chilean army commander, Carlos Carreno, in 1987. The charges against him lapsed when the guerrilla chief accepted an amnesty drawn up by the former Chilean president Patricio Aylwin in 1990.

According to the Chilean press, military intelligence officials declared a state of alert concerning Mr Escobar Ibanez and sent a formal report to Santiago's military court, saying they had detected the presence of several more FPMR guerrillas in the El Melocoton district.

Meanwhile, Santiago appeal court judges yesterday began wading through 10,000 pages of documents to determine whether Gen Pinochet may be stripped of his immunity.

Denying that the former dictator had escaped prosecution when he left Britain, Chile's interior minister, Raul Troncoso said: "It is clear that all the complaints will go forward. Justice works in Chile and all the criticism and doubts expressed abroad were baseless."
