fields.headline: Andy Sojka
fields.trailText: In 1979 Andy Sojka, who has died of multiple myeloma aged 48, formed, produced and recorded the five-strong music group, Atmosfear. The first fruit of the liaison was their single, Dancing In Outer Space. Thus did he pioneer a new British dance music.
fields.body:
In 1979 Andy Sojka, who has died of multiple myeloma aged 48, formed, produced and recorded the five-strong music group, Atmosfear. The first fruit of the liaison was their single, Dancing In Outer Space. Thus did he pioneer a new British dance music.

Dancing In Outer Space fused disco, funk, jazz and psychedelic production. It sold 100,000 copies - and the tune survives, still played and frequently sampled.

Educated at Kingsbury high school, north London, in the late 1970s, Sojka opened All Ears, a dance music shop in Harlesden. It quickly became a focus for the 12in 45rpm dance single boom, which had begun in the United States. Many of the customers at All Ears were DJs buying American imports and the British releases that followed.

After Dancing In Outer Space, in 1980 Sojka discovered and named Level 42, and signed them to his Elite label, producing their first single, Love Meeting Love, and The Early Tapes album.

In the 1980s, Elite Records became a home for the new independent British dance music, and releases by DSM (Danny D), Beverley Skeete, Projection, Atmosfear, Sahara and many others featured regularly in the dance music charts. With his music championed by the late Larry Levan at the Paradise Garage, Andy became a cult figure in New York.

Between 1986-88 he worked with Garry Hughes, producing two experimental world music crossover albums. In 1987, a rhythm and blues label was formed. Its first release was Keni Stevens's Blue Moods, a classic album of British soul music.

In the mid-90s Andy established three new labels, Jump Cut, Meta4, and Chemical Discs, whose catalogue included such notable works as Atmosfear's Trance Plants (1994) and Jangala Spirits (1997). His last major project was Altered Slates (1998), made with the US group, Masters at Work, the U2 producer Francois Kevorkian, and Dimitri from France. In 1999, he began writing Groove World, an album by Atmosfear due for release later this year.

Sojka is survived by his wife, Karen, and two children.

 Andy Sojka, record producer, born July 10 1951; died February 12 2000.

fields.headline: Bill Kendall
fields.standfirst: Trade union leader and early master of the soundbite
fields.trailText: Bill Kendall, who has died aged 76, was the sort of trade union leader who was always willing to provide that somewhat disreputable band of industrial correspondents with good stories and apt and witty quotes.
fields.body:
Bill Kendall, who has died aged 76, was the sort of trade union leader who was always willing to provide that somewhat disreputable band of industrial correspondents with good stories and apt and witty quotes.

He was general secretary of the Council of Civil Service Unions from 1976-83, and earlier of the Civil and Public Services Association (1967-76), and, with his jovial Irish press officer Jimmy O'Dea, he enjoyed the raffish company of journalists. He was perhaps one of the earliest users of the soundbite, devising methods of spin-doctoring a story with greater effect and more honesty than current practitioners. But then he did not fit the stereotypical image of a trade union leader.

Studious, with a touch of mock melancholy and a vast number of quotations at his fingertips - drawn from his ability to absorb a wide range of literature (Dr Johnson and Chesterton were his favourites) - he could easily have passed as an academic despite his lack of formal schooling.

As a teenager in South Shields, Kendall was an active communist. By the time he came out of the RAF, he had married his childhood sweetheart, Irene. Having benefited from the leftish educational courses provided in the forces, he had decided to train as a teacher but, needing immediate employment, he joined the new National Insurance Central Office at Newcastle. He quickly became branch secretary in the Civil Service Clerical Association (CSCA), the largest civil service trade union.

Kendall then rejoined the Communist party, but left after a year because it failed to provide him - in theory or practice - with what he felt he wanted. He joined the Catholic Church and, unlike many ex-communist converts, his catholicism tended towards liberation theology. He became a full-time officer in the CSCA in 1952 and was promoted to general secretary in 1967, by which time it was the Civil and Public Services Association.

At the time, the CPSA conference, never famous for its moderation, called for a strike policy. In drafting that programme, Kendall recognised that while, in theory, it would be possible to call an all-out civil service strike, the effect on ordinary people, particularly the vulnerable users of the welfare state, would be devastating. Over the years, he therefore developed the strategy of selective strike action, only calling out those members where the government - rather than ordinary people - were affected, for example, collection of revenue, computer installations and the machinery of government.

These tactics were used with financially crippling effect on the government and virtually no cost to the union. They even generated a measure of public support when, in 1979, the newly elected Thatcher administration withdrew long-established pay bargaining machinery from the civil service. In that way, the civil service unions avoided the obloquy associated with the "winter of discontent".

Kendall became titular head of all the civil service trade unions in 1976 but, although regularly nominated, he was never elected to the TUC general council. The old carthorse drivers were not likely to trust a left-wing Catholic and ex-communist with a savage wit and the ability to capture more media attention than they did.

fields.bodyText: Bill Kendall, who has died aged 76, was the sort of trade union leader who was always willing to provide that somewhat disreputable band of industrial correspondents with good stories and apt and witty quotes. He was general secretary of the Council of Civil Service Unions from 1976-83, and earlier of the Civil and Public Services Association (1967-76), and, with his jovial Irish press officer Jimmy O'Dea, he enjoyed the raffish company of journalists. He was perhaps one of the earliest users of the soundbite, devising methods of spin-doctoring a story with greater effect and more honesty than current practitioners. But then he did not fit the stereotypical image of a trade union leader. Studious, with a touch of mock melancholy and a vast number of quotations at his fingertips - drawn from his ability to absorb a wide range of literature (Dr Johnson and Chesterton were his favourites) - he could easily have passed as an academic despite his lack of formal schooling. As a teenager in South Shields, Kendall was an active communist. By the time he came out of the RAF, he had married his childhood sweetheart, Irene. Having benefited from the leftish educational courses provided in the forces, he had decided to train as a teacher but, needing immediate employment, he joined the new National Insurance Central Office at Newcastle. He quickly became branch secretary in the Civil Service Clerical Association (CSCA), the largest civil service trade union. Kendall then rejoined the Communist party, but left after a year because it failed to provide him - in theory or practice - with what he felt he wanted. He joined the Catholic Church and, unlike many ex-communist converts, his catholicism tended towards liberation theology. He became a full-time officer in the CSCA in 1952 and was promoted to general secretary in 1967, by which time it was the Civil and Public Services Association. At the time, the CPSA conference, never famous for its moderation, called for a strike policy. In drafting that programme, Kendall recognised that while, in theory, it would be possible to call an all-out civil service strike, the effect on ordinary people, particularly the vulnerable users of the welfare state, would be devastating. Over the years, he therefore developed the strategy of selective strike action, only calling out those members where the government - rather than ordinary people - were affected, for example, collection of revenue, computer installations and the machinery of government. These tactics were used with financially crippling effect on the government and virtually no cost to the union. They even generated a measure of public support when, in 1979, the newly elected Thatcher administration withdrew long-established pay bargaining machinery from the civil service. In that way, the civil service unions avoided the obloquy associated with the "winter of discontent". fields.headline: Dame Roma Mitchell
fields.standfirst: Woman at the forefront of legal reform in Australia
fields.trailText: Dame Roma Mitchell, who has died from bone cancer aged 86, was known as Roma the First because of her achievements as Australia's first woman queen's counsel, supreme court judge, human rights commissioner, university chancellor and state governor. But despite all her groundbreaking appointments, she always described herself as a "conservative sort of feminist".
fields.body:
Dame Roma Mitchell, who has died from bone cancer aged 86, was known as Roma the First because of her achievements as Australia's first woman queen's counsel, supreme court judge, human rights commissioner, university chancellor and state governor. But despite all her groundbreaking appointments, she always described herself as a "conservative sort of feminist".

Mitchell worked for the rights of women, Aborigines and the disabled. When she retired from the bench, she spent three years delivering food for Meals on Wheels and continued a love of surfing well into her 80s. As the vice-regal representative in South Australia, it is said that when she opened the Adelaide Festival in 1994 and God Save The Queen was played, even the republicans stood - out of respect for Dame Roma. Australia's present governor-general, Sir William Deane, said that her pioneering role in law, and helping women and minorities, made her "among the greatest of all Australians".

Mitchell, the youngest of three daughters, was born in Adelaide. Her father, Harold, practised law, but was killed in France in 1918. When the telegram arrived, Roma went to meet her eldest sister from school to tell her the news. When her mother, Maude, asked her why, the four-year-old replied: "I wanted to save you."

The family was not well off, but Roma was a brilliant student, and her lifelong Catholic faith saw her excel at St Aloysius's College. She won a bursary to study law at the University of Adelaide and graduated with distinction in 1934. She was admitted to the South Australian bar and, for 28 years, practised most branches of the law - apart from crime, where she considered the all-male jury system might prejudice her clients' chances.

In 1962, Mitchell became Australia's first female queen's counsel; three years later she was appointed as the first female supreme court judge and sworn in as Justice Mitchell on the South Australian bench. Her appointment caused great controversy as to what she might wear, if she should be addressed as "Mr Justice" (like every other judge) or even if it was proper for a woman to be able to condemn a man to die - South Australia did not abolish capital punishment until 1973.

During her years on the bench, Mitchell successfully campaigned to have women sit as jurors, and chaired a criminal law and penal reform committee, which produced the influential five- volume Mitchell report of 1977. Some saw this as her greatest achievement, with its reforms on the procedures relating to rape and other sexual offences influencing many courts. She also wrote two books, The Law And Women's Liberation and Aborigines And The Law.

Reflecting later on her appointment to the bar, Michell said: "I remember saying at the time that I hoped I lived long enough to see that such an appointment received no more publicity than the appointment of a man, and I think I've nearly done so."

In 1981, she took up the post of inaugural chair on the Australian human rights commission, effectively the judge of how the country's federal laws affected human rights. She became a lively voice for Aborigines, the disabled and minorities, saying that her job required her to attract attention, something - as a private and patrician person - she had carefully avoided in the past.

The next year she was made a dame commander of the British Empire, and in 1983, 50 years after she started at Adelaide university, was elected as the first woman outside the royal family to be invested with the chancellorship of any university in the Commonwealth.

In 1986, Dame Roma left the human rights commission but, true to form, refused to quieten down. She accepted appointments as an auxiliary judge, a member of the court of appeal on the small Pacific nation of Kiribati, and as a tireless worker for Meals on Wheels.

It was nonetheless a surprise when, in 1991 at the age of 77, she was appointed as the Queen's official representative in South Australia - the first female governor in Australian history. For five years, she was a very popular figure, travelling the large state widely and doing everything from visiting workplaces to opening fetes. She also exercised her constitutional role wisely, because for most of her term the state government was hung.

Three months ago, Dame Roma was accorded her final honour when the Queen made her a commander of the Royal Victorian Order. The award was presented by Sir William Deane at a simple bedside ceremony just before her death.

Dame Roma never married, and once said that law was the great love of her life. She was in good health until last month, when she was treated for back pain and diagnosed with terminal bone cancer.

 Dame Roma Flinders Mitchell, barrister and public servant, born October 2 1913; died March 5 2000.

fields.headline: Max Godden
fields.standfirst: Bomber pilot who turned to the Church
fields.trailText: The Venerable Max Godden, who has died aged 76, was a golden-haired, smiling, heavy-smoking wartime bomber pilot, who became the profound, enchanting, holy - and grey-haired - archdeacon of Lewes and Hastings in the 1970s and 80s.
fields.body:
The Venerable Max Godden, who has died aged 76, was a golden-haired, smiling, heavy-smoking wartime bomber pilot, who became the profound, enchanting, holy - and grey-haired - archdeacon of Lewes and Hastings in the 1970s and 80s.

Educated at Sir Andrew Judd School, Tonbridge, he read history at Worcester College, Oxford, graduating in 1950 after wartime service in the Royal Air Force Volunteer Reserve. He was to remain in touch with his bomber crew for the rest of their lives. Mentioned in dispatches, he ended the war as a pilot instructor in Canada. In 1945, he married Anne Hucklebridge, and two years later left the RAFVR.

After Oxford, Godden trained at Chichester Theological College, where he learned the habits of prayer, study and self-discipline which were to mark the rest of his life. At Chichester, he was also influenced by the 19th-century, high-church Oxford movement, and John Keble and John Henry Newman in particular.

A year as deacon at Cuckfield, Sussex, in 1952 was followed by four years as a curate at Brighton parish church, and five years, from 1957-62, as vicar in Hangleton, a Hove housing estate. The parish hummed with activity and, at its centre, was the jovial figure of the young vicar with his wife and family, teaching the flock and training the curates. Here was someone to be reckoned with, given major responsibility early.

Then, before he was even 40, Godden completely changed direction, moving to the country as incumbent of the three small Sussex parishes of Glynde, Firle and Bedingham. Godden became a complete country parson. Why? No one can know for sure, but it was something about the balance of prayer and activity; its roots may well have been in the inner experience of the wartime pilot.

For 26 years, Godden remained at Glynde, tended the parishes, knew the big landowners and the small farmers intimately, kept his garden and kept his soul. In 1972, he was made archdeacon of Lewes and, three years later, of Hastings as well. He stayed on at Glynde, but now roamed over East Sussex.

The role suited Godden's talents. He was interested in power, and didn't mind having a little of it himself. He was good at administration, and could be formidable. He was usually right in any argument. All the time, you were aware of the depths of his inner resources. And he still tended his three parishes. He was a friend and support to bishops and clergy, though he could say plain words to both. Members of the laity regarded him highly.

After he retired, Godden filled his time with prayer, reading, gardening and caring for his friends, but not with further church activity. Few other priests had complete sets of both Keble's and Newman's sermons on their shelves, fewer still would include - as part of their spiritual exercises - the daily reading of two of these sermons.

His beautiful and scrupulous gardening further reflected the man, and his family were cherished and loved. He remained the fascinating, magnetic, affectionate and profound being that his friends and family knew him to be. He was a quiet glory of the Church of England.

Godden is survived by Anne and their four daughters.

 The Venerable Max Leon Godden, priest, born November 25 1923; died March 1 2000

webTitle: Colombians braced for fight on all fronts

fields.headline: Colombians braced for fight on all fronts
fields.standfirst: Villagers fear for their lives and livelihoods as US steps up aid to those spearheading Washington's war on drugs
fields.trailText: Bracing himself against the heavy machine gun at the bow of a speeding patrol boat, the marine sergeant ratchets the magazine and the overgrown banks of the Putumayo river echo with the clatter of .50 calibre rounds.
fields.byline: Martin Hodgson  in Puerto Leguizamo, Colombia
fields.body:
Bracing himself against the heavy machine gun at the bow of a speeding patrol boat, the marine sergeant ratchets the magazine and the overgrown banks of the Putumayo river echo with the clatter of .50 calibre rounds.

Today's operation is a training exercise, but the marines can't afford to drop their guard. The dense jungles of southern Colombia are a lawless frontier zone where thousands of leftwing guerrillas protect clandestine laboratories churning out more than 70% of Colombia's cocaine.

For as long as anyone can remember, the Puerto Leguizamo naval base has been on red alert.

Last year, the 90th Riverine battalion destroyed 68 laboratories and seized 201kg of cocaine base, and 77,700kg of coca leaves. At the front line of Washington's war on drugs, the battalion was among the first Colombian military units to receive US training and equipment.

Now the marines are hoping to benefit once more from an extra $1.6bn in aid under debate in the senate.

If approved, the money will go towards an ambitious two-year strategy aimed at fighting Colombia's illegal drugs trade, reviving its ailing economy and ending 36 years of bloody civil conflict.

US aid to Colombia has grown 10-fold since 1995, reflecting growing concern that this Andean country is heading towards crisis. Last year alone, Colombia received $366m in equipment and training - including four river combat courses for the marines in Puerto Leguizamo.

"US training is useful here because they gained so much experience on the rivers in Vietnam. They lost a lot of men, but they learnt plenty," says Lieutenant German Arenas, who was trained by the US Green Berets.

It is a comparison that makes US politicians wince. The US interest in Colombia is clear: 80% of the world's cocaine - and most of the heroin sold in the US - comes from Colombia. But in Washington many fear that increased military aid may again drag the US into a complex and unwinnable jungle war.

Colombian and US officials stress that "Plan Colombia" is not just a military strategy: the package includes money for judicial reform, human rights protection and economic development. But the largest element of the US aid will pay for the loan and maintenance of 63 combat helicopters.

The aircraft will support three new US-trained anti-narcotics battalions as they push into southern Colombia, clearing the way for planes to spray drug crops with herbicides.

Inevitably, this will bring them into direct conflict with rightwing paramilitaries and the guerrillas of the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia (Farc), who rake off millions of dollars in drug kickbacks and protection fees.

Since last year, the 15,000-strong rebel group has participated in slow-moving peace negotiations with President Andres Pastrana, but has refused to sign a ceasefire. The rebels regularly take pot-shots at fumigation planes, and are rumoured to have obtained ground-to-air missiles.

Rebel commanders say the increased militarisation of anti-narcotics operations is just a pretext for stepped-up counter-insurgency action, but US officials insist they have no interest in straying deeper into Colombia's labyrinthine internal conflict.

In the jungles of Putumayo, however, the distinction is harder to maintain. "We don't differentiate between counter-insurgency and counter-narcotics operations - it's the same thing. We do a raid on the drug traffickers, and we know we're hitting the guerrillas," says the 90th battalion commander, Lieutenant-colonel Jose Leonidas Mufloz.

Some 350 miles north-west of Puerto Leguizamo, many people in the town of Curillo fear that increased US aid will fuel the war. "We're expecting the most atrocious violence. They say this aid package is to bring peace, but it will be the peace of the tomb," says one villager, Emlio Vivero.

Deep in the southern savannah, Curillo is a typical town in the remote backlands dominated by the Farc. A few miles down the road, uniformed rebels man a checkpoint. On a hill above the town centre is the burned out shell of the police station, abandoned after a Farc attack in December.

Three police died in the assault and eight were captured. Three months later, nobody has dared remove the portrait of the Farc commander-in-chief, Manuel Marulanda, which the rebels left hanging in front of the mayor's office.

On a shady porch above the Caqueta river, a peasant leader, Lucas Caquimbo, says: "The government doesn't care if the guerrillas are here or not - it's got nothing to lose. The only state presence in this town is when they collect taxes or fumigate the crops."

As if on cue, two 0V-10 planes for reconnaissance and fumigation buzz low. "We've grown used to that sound," says Mr Caquimbo.

But despite nearly three years of spraying, US and Colombian figures show that coca production in Colombia has more than doubled since 1995. Evidence suggests that after fumigation, large-scale coca growers merely move further into the jungle.

In Curillo, many small coca producers say they would destroy their illegal crops - if there was a financially viable alternative.

"People are tired of coca. People want to change, but they don't want to end up with empty bellies," says the local ombudsman, Hever Gomez.

Hundreds of miles from the nearest markets, and with agriculture prices undercut by cheap imports, peasants in the Colombian south find it virtually impossible to survive from legal crops. But coca can still bring in a living wage.

"What's the point of planting yucca if nobody will buy it? At least with coca I make just enough to feed the family," says Albeiro, a farmworker, 33, unloading bales of coca leaf at a makeshift coca "kitchen".

The United Nations and the Colombian government have experimented with tropical fruits, dairy farming and fish breeding, but nobody has yet found a crop as profitable as coca leaf.

And as fumigation continues, the rural poor will face fewer and fewer options for survival, says Gabriel Pena. He counts himself lucky: when his family's coca plot was eradicated, they had enough money saved to buy a grocery shop.

But most youngsters face a stark choice. "They join the army, they join the guerrillas or they join the paramilitaries. In Curillo there are 300 unemployed men, but who'll give them work? At least in the guerrillas they give you food and clothes," he says.

The US aid package includes $145m earmarked for social development projects. But human rights groups predict that a military campaign in southern Colombia could force tens of thousands from their homes.

"We hope that Plan Colombia will bring help for ordinary Colombians, not just helicopters and bullets," says Mr Caquimbo. "If it doesn't, the conflict will just get worse."

webTitle: Child sex accusations rock Latvian cabinet

fields.headline: Child sex accusations rock Latvian cabinet
fields.trailText: The Baltic state of Latvia is in the throes of a child abuse scandal that allegedly reaches to the very heart of the cabinet, threatening to bring down the government and end the careers of several of the country's top politicians.
fields.body:
The Baltic state of Latvia is in the throes of a child abuse scandal that allegedly reaches to the very heart of the cabinet, threatening to bring down the government and end the careers of several of the country's top politicians.

As a result of information unearthed by Riga journalists and a parliamentary commission, six men are in jail awaiting trial on charges of child abuse, pornography involving minors, and selling children into sexual slavery abroad.

The prime minister, Andris Skele, 42, is fighting to salvage his reputation and his political life after being named - controversially - in parliament as possibly being embroiled in the paedophile ring.

Latvia's prosecutor general, Janis Skrastins, is alleged to have tried to cover up the matter, along with several colleagues who have been sacked.

And the justice minister, Valdis Birkavs, who is also implicated, has just called off a hunger strike staged to protest at the failings of the judicial system he supervises and has done much to shape. Critics called his strike farcical, and newspaper cartoons depicted the minister - who is a former prime minister and foreign minister - tucking in to lavish meals.

Janis Adamsons, a leftwing MP and former interior minister who heads the 12-member parliamentary inquiry into the affair, stood up in parliament two weeks ago and sparked uproar by naming the prime minister and justice minister as suspects in a scheme that entailed Riga vice kings providing underage boys for sex.

"I named names because they were trying to thwart the commission's work. It was a closed circle between the government and the prosecutor general's office. I was at the end of my tether. This was the only way to break the circle," he says.

"I've questioned 40 witnesses including 12 male participants now aged from 15 to 23 years old. We have evidence that these ministers may be involved, but I can't reach a juridical verdict and prove it. That's for the prosecutor's office," says Mr Adamsons.

The US state department last week reported that Latvia was a key transit point for the flourishing east European sex trade, with adult and child prostitution rampant in Riga and mafias highly active in trafficking in women, including underage girls, for sale into western Europe's sex industry.

The investigation into the government scandal, mainly involving males, is centred on a Riga-based "video model agency", Logos. Its boss, Juriy Juriyev, a psychiatrist, is in custody. Logos had 3,000 minors on its books, 85% of them boys, many of them from orphanages, says Mr Adamsons.

Another agency involved, Riga's Private Photo, offered underage boys to western clients "for 1,500 US dollars a month and more" for engagement as "photo models, escorts and home boys".

Vairis Stasans, a Riga television journalist who triggered the furore by broadcasting interviews with victims last September and reporting that unnamed government ministers were involved in the paedophile ring, says the children were blackmailed, drugged or plied with drink while being inducted into prostitution.

"The boys told me which government ministers they had sex with but we did not broadcast the names," he says.

The prosecutor general, Mr Skrastins, denounced the TV report as a "falsification", while the prime minister, Mr Skele, said the report was aimed at undermining a police investigation into the allegations.

But Mr Adamsons' all-party parliamentary commission was convened, and in January, 57 of Latvia's 100 MPs delivered a vote of no confidence in Mr Skrastins. He tendered his resignation but is still at his desk. Other senior police officials then were forced to resign and this week the prosecutor in charge of the investigation also stood down.

Western diplomats in Riga say rumours of high-level political involvement in sexual abuse of children have been circulating for 18 months. During the 1998 election Mr Skele's campaign posters were defaced by opponents who scrawled allegations that the married prime minister and father of two was gay.

The scandal is heavily politicised but, Mr Stasans, the journalist, says: "If this is just about bringing down the government, there are other and better ways of doing it. We change our governments in Latvia every year anyway."

But Mr Adamsons is himself in a difficult corner at present: under Latvian law, he could lose his right to hold office, if accusations that he was a KGB collaborator are proven. During the Soviet era he was a coast guard officer for 15 years in the Far East in the Soviet border troops which were - a Riga court decided this week - subordinate to the KGB.

fields.headline: Slow dawn for Arctic's millennium
fields.trailText: The world's northern-most village, Longyearbyen, situated 620 miles north of the Arctic circle, is celebrating its first sunrise of the new millennium this week.
fields.body:
The world's northern-most village, Longyearbyen, situated 620 miles north of the Arctic circle, is celebrating its first sunrise of the new millennium this week.

Its 1,200 villagers last saw the entire sun from town in mid-October, so when it returned for about 10 minutes early on Wednesday afternoon, they were ready.

Townspeople gathered to watch the first rays and sing songs to celebrate the sun's return during their traditional Sun Week festival.

"The first rays hit the steps of the old hospital," said a government official, Terje Carlsen. "The hospital was torn down, but the steps were still there."

Mr Carlsen said the sun had peaked over the steep hills flanking town earlier in the week, but it was blocked by snow. Bad weather had also threatened visibility on Wednesday - designated the village's first official sunrise of 2000 months ago.

But to the delight of locals, the skies cleared just before the sun made it's brief appearance and, in keeping with local tradition, everyone watched the light hit the old hospital steps.

The return of the sun "is always a big event", said Mr Carlsen, adding that the days were quickly getting longer.

By late next month the midnight sun, with its 24-hours of daylight, will have returned to the archipelago's islands.

Asked when villagers last saw the sun from town, Mr Carlsen was stumped. "No one seems to notice when it disappears, only when it comes back."

fields.headline: Ban on Greek bestseller
fields.trailText: In a rare act of censorship, a judge in northern Greece has banned a bestselling book criticised by the Greek Orthodox church because of passages about the possible sexual longings of Jesus Christ.
fields.body:
In a rare act of censorship, a judge in northern Greece has banned a bestselling book criticised by the Greek Orthodox church because of passages about the possible sexual longings of Jesus Christ.

Sitting in Salonika, Judge Maria Robbi said yesterday that she was banning sales in the north of the country to prevent "outbreaks of violence", after religious zealots threatened to take action against the author - the former communist MP Mimis Androulakis - and shops selling the book, M to the Power of N.

webTitle: Anglo-Indians wounded by Cotton Mary portrayal

fields.headline: Anglo-Indians wounded by Cotton Mary portrayal
fields.trailText: The director Ismail Merchant, whose period dramas with James Ivory have adorned British cinema for two decades, has come under vicious attack for his latest film from one of India's most venerable communities.
fields.body:
The director Ismail Merchant, whose period dramas with James Ivory have adorned British cinema for two decades, has come under vicious attack for his latest film from one of India's most venerable communities.

The film, Cotton Mary, has been lambasted by Anglo-Indians, a term used to cover anyone of mixed Indian and European descent. They accuse Merchant of portraying them as lazy, promiscuous and obsessed with all things British.

Set in 1954, Cotton Mary tells the story of an Anglo-Indian nurse who insinuates her way into a English family, adopts their manners and finds herself ultimately rejected by both her British and her Indian neighbours.

Madhur Jaffrey stars as Cotton Mary, and James Wilby and Greta Scacchi play the English couple who take her in.

The film has already been withdrawn because of local Anglo-Indian pressure in the south-western state of Kerala, where it was shot. It was also facing a sticky reception last night at its premiere in Madras, capital of the south-eastern state of Tamil Nadu.

"The film is a terrible caricature of our community and shows as if our girls are easily available and the men are lazy drunkards. Cotton Mary is portrayed as a petty thief and her niece Rosie as a tart, flirting even inside a church," Beatrix D'Souza, a Madras MP who is Anglo-Indian, said in an interview. "There have been earlier stereotype films showing us in a poor light but this one is really too much."

Ms D'Souza, who has called on the Indian censor to re-examine the film, and has vowed to raise the controversy in parliament, added: "We are a 500-year-old community which is dynamic and evolving and growing. They should realise we would not have lasted this long time, with a separate identity, if we did not possess certain basic values, such as having a strong family structure."

D K Francis, president of the Anglo-Indian Association of South India, yesterday added to the protest, saying Merchant should withdraw the film and apologise: "Cotton Mary is terrible in denigrating our entire Anglo-Indian community. Every one of us is furious."

Cotton Mary's producer, Nayeem Hafizka, yesterday hit back, calling the movie's critics "pathetic" and "small-minded". The movie, he said, was "not a naturalistic picture of India. It is a fictional story."

After the film's recent Delhi premiere, Merchant struck a more conciliatory note. "We never wanted to portray Anglo-Indians in a bad light," he said. "It [the film] talks about how the Anglo-Indian community at a specific point in history - 1954 - had been brainwashed into believing, like many other Indians, that British was best. There is no attempt to demonise them."

India, with a population of about 1bn, has some 100,000 Anglo-Indians, some of whom trace their ancestry back to the Portuguese settlers who arrived in the 16th century. Once favoured by the British, whose railways they managed, they fell on hard times after independence.

Their rights were later enshrined in the constitution as a scheduled group. Most live in south India, though there is a large Anglo-Indian population in West Bengal, where moves are also afoot to have the film banned. Nostalgia for Britain persists, despite denials: in the Kerala town of Cochin, Anglo-Indians still play bingo in a church hall, where the cry goes up "Number 10 ... Downing Street".

Cotton Mary opened in Britain last month. In the Observer, Philip French described it as "clumsy and overacted"; the Evening Standard, "a long crawl through the worst of all postcolonial worlds".

webTitle: Versailles' jardin anglais to bloom again

fields.headline: Versailles' jardin anglais to bloom again
fields.standfirst: Last winter's storms in France cleared the way for Marie-Antoinette's original garden to be recreated
fields.trailText: Marie-Antoinette's much-loved - if inaccurately named - English garden at Versailles, which was all but wiped out during fierce storms in France in December, is to be replanted almost tree for tree according to its original design.
fields.body:
Marie-Antoinette's much-loved - if inaccurately named - English garden at Versailles, which was all but wiped out during fierce storms in France in December, is to be replanted almost tree for tree according to its original design.

But rather than combing Britain for copies of the seeds and saplings ordered by the ill-fated queen more than 200 years ago, a team of gardeners from France's best-known chateau will tomorrow board a plane for the United States.

"It may sound strange, but almost all the trees in the jardin anglais were in fact brought to France from the United States. At the time they were very new, very exotic and so very, very fashionable," said Alain Baraton, the head gardener.

"We call it an English garden because of its more natural and informal appearance, in contrast with the far more stylised French layout of the rest of the grounds. But in terms of its flora, I'm afraid to say it's very much American."

Louis XIV, known as the Sun King, dazzled foreign visitors with his magnificent chateau and gardens, some 20 miles outside Paris, during the first fetes he held there in the 17th century. Today, the palace and grounds remain one of France's top tourist attractions, drawing 9m visitors a year.

But the usually peaceful gardens at Versailles were badly hit by last year's winter storms, which killed some 80 people and destroyed an estimated 300m trees across France. The chateau's 2,000 acres of grounds and parkland lost a catastrophic 10,000 trees.

Nor did the English garden dreamed up by Marie-Antoinette, the Austrian-born wife of Louis XVI who was beheaded in 1793, escape the carnage. Several trees more than two centuries old - including her favourite, a Virginia tulip she planted near the mock country hamlet she had built for her amusement - were among the victims.

The palace, too, was battered in the initial storm in December, but workers made repairs before rain could damage the interiors.

The garden's original 1777 layout has been altered over the years with successive replantings. It will now be recreated as accurately as possible using a list of species that the queen's staff collected in the course of several hazardous voyages to America in the late 1770s and 1780s.

"Purely by chance, we recently uncovered a full list of 300 species dating from 1795 in the chateau archives," said Laurent Choffé, chief botanist at France's historic monuments commission. "We spent a lot of time matching the 18th-century Latin names to their present-day equivalents. We're almost there."

The Versailles gardeners will confine their quest for seeds and saplings to the states of Virginia and Georgia, where more than 90% of the original specimens came from.

The saplings will be shipped from the US and planted this autumn - with the sole exception of a symbolic Virginia tulip tree, which Mr Baraton will bring back personally and plant in the original spot on March 20, the first day of spring.

webTitle: Miami judge to rule on divisive Cuban boy saga

fields.headline: Miami judge to rule on divisive Cuban boy saga
fields.standfirst: More about the Gonzalez case
fields.trailText: A judge is expected to deliver a crucial ruling within the next week which could determine the future of the six-year-old boy who has been the subject of an international tug-of-war since he was found clinging to an inner tube off Florida.
fields.body:
A judge is expected to deliver a crucial ruling within the next week which could determine the future of the six-year-old boy who has been the subject of an international tug-of-war since he was found clinging to an inner tube off Florida.

After a hearing yesterday, Miami judge Michael Moore must decide whether he can intervene in the dispute for custody of Elian Gonzalez or whether he must allow him to be sent back to Cuba, where there are regular demonstrations for the boy's return.

The case has damaged relations between the US and the Caribbean island, even though Washington believes Elian should be returned to Cuba to his father, who says he did not know that his former wife planned to make the doomed voyage to Florida.

Armando Gutierrez, a spokesman for the boy's Miami relatives who have been looking after him for more than three months and want him to stay in the US, said: "The family is praying and very hopeful."

Most of the boy's Miami relatives believe he would have a better life if he stayed in the US and argue that his mother died trying to liberate him from Cuba when their boat capsized in November.

The US government says that Elian is too young to seek political asylum and backs an immigration and naturalisation service (INS) ruling that his father is the legal guardian and that Elian should go back.

Legal experts believe that Judge Moore is likely to decide that he has no jurisdiction and agree with the INS. But whichever side of the family loses is likely to appeal.

Fidel Castro, the Cuban president, speaking at a protest rally, blamed US immigration policy for the impasse. He specifically targeted the Cuban adjustment act of 1966, which allows people who reach American soil from the island to stay and apply for political asylum.

"How many lives has this law cost our nation?" he asked. "How many lives of innocent children pulled out of school by mothers and fathers who are irresponsible or tricked by illusions?"

The US president, Bill Clinton, and the attorney general, Janet Reno, have said Elian should leave the US. Congress, which has received a bill to grant the boy US citizenship, has agreed not to act before Judge Moore's ruling.

Marisleysis Gonzalez, a cousin who has been helping look after the boy in Miami, told a congressional committee that she believed his father wanted him to remain in the US, but that the Cuban government prevented him from saying so.

"He knows that he is in a country of freedom, where he is protected," she said.

But Manuel Gonzalez, a great uncle from the other side of the family, said: "Help return this child to his father, who needs him ... that child is going through a shock.

"He doesn't know where he is and one must act urgently and give this child the attention he needs."

Politicians are just as divided. "This is not just a custody issue," said the senate judiciary committee chairman, Orrin Hatch, a Republican, "but a case where one of the options considered is returning this child to one of the last prison nations in the world, Fidel Castro's wretched communist dictatorship."

But Patrick Leahy, the senior Democrat on the committee, said: "A young boy belongs with his parent, not with distant relatives.

"Just because we oppose Fidel Castro does not mean we should oppose this boy being with his father."

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Haider attack on Chirac
fields.body:
Haider attack on Chirac

Jörg Haider, the far-right Austrian politician, called France's president, Jacques Chirac, a "pocket Napoleon", in comments published yesterday, and likened the European Union to an occupying force.

Mr Haider also attacked the Austrian president, Thomas Klestil, and others unhappy with the Freedom party's role in Austria's government. According to the daily Kurier, Mr Haider made the comments on Wednesday in a town in Upper Austria. - AP, Vienna

Radicals seize Communist HQ

Radical nationalists seized the headquarters of the Ukrainian Communist party yesterday and demanded access to television to call for a ban on the party. Police said the Kiev building had been doused in gasoline inside to keep them from storming it. - AP, Kiev

Six arrested for Tijuana murder

Six people who were working for drug traffickers have been arrested in Mexico in connection with the killing of the police chief of Tijuana.

Late on Wednesday Baja California's attorney general, Juan Manuel Salazar Pimentel, said the men had admitted working for Vicente Zambada Niebla, the son of a notorious drug trafficker. - AP, Mexico City

French anti-terrorist police raided a bomb-making factory used by the Basque separatist group ETA in south-west France yesterday, but failed to find any explosives. Police said the building in the French Basque village of Guiche contained sodium chlorate, a chemical used to make bombs. - Reuters, Bordeaux

Five dead in Nigeria clashes

At least five people were killed near the Nigerian capital of Abuja in clashes between supporters of two rival claimants to the leadership of the local emirate, police said yesterday.

The fighting erupted on Wednesday night in Suleja, 20 miles outside Abuja. Order was restored yesterday, police said. - Reuters, Abuja

The deputy commander of UN police in Mitrovice was relieved yesterday after complaining that French troops contaminated a crime scene after a shooting in which 16 French peacekeepers and 24 civilians were injured. A kangaroo was killed when a branch sawn from a tree fell into her enclosure, zoo authorities in Rapperswil, Switzerland, said yesterday. - AP, Rapperswil

fields.headline: Fires threaten rare Ethiopian wolves
fields.trailText: Some of the world's rarest animals are in extreme danger as Ethiopian forest fires close in on a national park south of the capital Addis Ababa, a wildlife official said yesterday.
fields.body:
Some of the world's rarest animals are in extreme danger as Ethiopian forest fires close in on a national park south of the capital Addis Ababa, a wildlife official said yesterday.

The fires, which have been raging since early last month, are approaching Bale mountains national park, home to more than half the country's endemic species, according to Ermias Bekele, of the Addis Ababa office of the World Wide Fund for Nature.

Animals in the 880 square-mile park, 135 miles from Addis Ababa, include 200 of the country's estimated 400 Ethiopian wolves - the most endangered of all the wolf species - the Mountain Nyala antelope, red foxes and the Menilik bushbuck, according to Mr Ermias.

"It is critically important because Bale national park has something like 52% of the endemic mammal species in Ethiopia," he said. "Unless there is immediate intervention by all those concerned, there is definitely a risk to all these animals. Just as important is the plant and natural forest species we are losing."

Ethiopia asked in late February for international help to quell the fires, which have destroyed more than 20,000 hectares (49,400 acres) of timber in the southern Bale region.

An estimated 50,000 farmers, government workers and police have been fighting the fires, but only seven international helpers have arrived, according to Tamiru Habte, head of the Ethiopian forestry department.

South Africa, which has led rescue missions in flood-stricken Mozambique, has been one of the first to offer assistance.

Mr Tamiru said one fire within 30 miles of the national park was being contained by between 200 and 500 people. "We are concerned," he said. "The fires were activated by humans. The local community who want to expand their agricultural land, and people can ignite them again."

fields.headline: FBI hunts man given 845 years
fields.trailText: The FBI is carrying out an international manhunt for a nightclub owner who has been sentenced to 845 years in prison, believed to be the longest term ever imposed by a US court.
fields.body:
The FBI is carrying out an international manhunt for a nightclub owner who has been sentenced to 845 years in prison, believed to be the longest term ever imposed by a US court.

Last month a Florida judge sentenced the absent Sholam Weiss for his role in a $450m (£275m) insurance scam. He had disappeared while a jury was deliberating the 93-count indictment against him on charges of racketeering, money laundering and fraud.

The 46-year-old, with a penchant for gambling and drugs, is understood to have disappeared with a 30-year-old girlfriend and up to $30m of stolen cash. His departure came at the expense of a $500,000 bond secured on the house of his ex-wife, the mother of his five children.

The FBI and insurance regulators are offering up to $120,000 for information leading to the arrest of the Brooklyn-born criminal, who is also known as Sheldon and Shalom.

Weiss was convicted of masterminding the complicated but effective looting of the National Heritage Life Insurance, a Florida-based company, in the early 1990s. Thousands of US citizens lost their life savings in a case described by the FBI as one of the largest insurance company failures in the history of the country.

In court papers filed last month, Judith Hunt, an assistant US attorney in Orlando, described Weiss as a veteran fraudster. "Weiss is in hiding, enjoying his millions in illgotten gains, while his minions face extended periods of incarceration," she said. "The sophistication and scope of his frauds is truly amazing."

About 15 of Weiss's associates have either pleaded guilty or been convicted for their involvement in the collapse of the insurer.

A previous record and obstruction of justice increased Weiss's sentence, as well as his central role in the fraud. Judge Patricia Fawsett said she had no trouble recommending that he be removed permanently from society. Weiss was also ordered to pay $125m in restitution to his victims.

Weiss's life of crime included a conviction for fraud in 1994. While serving that sentence he received permission to spend a weekend with his family and promptly fled to Atlantic City for a $70,000 gambling binge with his girlfriend.

The son of a fruitstall owner, Weiss built a $20m plumbing business and was part owner of Studio 54, the New York nightclub.

fields.headline: The British are coming
fields.standfirst: A Cannes restaurant has won its first Michelin star within six months of opening. But it's not the speed of its success that has incensed the French - it's the fact that it's run by a foreigner.  Jon Henley  met owner-chef Richard Neat
fields.trailText: A stone's throw from the Palais des Festivals," says the Guide. "Pleasant dining room, partly vaulted, recently redecorated: pearl-grey walls, plum furniture and careful lighting. Specialities: foie gras in a potato ribbon; fillet of bass in mussel soup; passion fruit sorbet."
fields.body:
A stone's throw from the Palais des Festivals," says the Guide. "Pleasant dining room, partly vaulted, recently redecorated: pearl-grey walls, plum furniture and careful lighting. Specialities: foie gras in a potato ribbon; fillet of bass in mussel soup; passion fruit sorbet."

But the bit that matters lies just to the left of that sober piece of text: a single, discreet rosette. It was awarded, last week, to a new Cannes restaurant called Neat, named after its chef, Richard. He has just become the first British restaurateur since the second world war to win a Michelin star in France.

Words like coals and Newcastle may spring forcefully to mind, but Neat - formerly of the ritzy two-star London eatery Pied à Terre - insists he is not out to prove any kind of nationalist point, even if five out of the six kitchen staff in his new venture are English and it only took him six months to pick up the honour.

"I suppose it would have been sensible to be a little apprehensive," he says. "But to be honest, I didn't even think about it. I'm surrounded by professionals, and provided you're honest, provided you serve up a quality product for a reasonable price, you'll do well. That's always been my philosophy, and it's the same here."

Nor, he points out diplomatically, can the quality product he is serving up be described as English in any meaningful sense of the word. Having served under such Gallic gurus as Raymond Blanc at the Manoir aux Quat' Saisons and Joel Robuchon in Paris, and spent 14 months with "the great unwashed" Marco Pierre White to boot, he is definitely more cuisinier than cook.

"In a way, I'm a pure product of France," he says frankly, drawing on a post-lunch cigarette. "I've been working in France or with French people for the past 18 years. It wouldn't be honest or sensible of me to be aggressively British about anything - and I'm hardly about to bite the hand that feeds me."

Nonetheless, his rapid promotion to one-star status in France, an honour for which many French chefs spend years slaving over hot vol-au-vents, has raised eyebrows. The local press has had a field day, and even national television has made the trip down to the chic Mediterranean resort town where Neat, 33, settled with his French wife Sophie in September 1998.

Cannes was, he says, a very deliberate choice for his new venture. It was a challenge he set himself after chucking in Pied à Terre, exhausted, in 1996, getting married and taking off on a two-year extended honeymoon to India (during which, Neat admits, he did very little except perfect his crawl in various hotel swimming pools and become a "really rather good" amateur chess player).

"This was a good place for a lot of reasons," he says. "Sophie studied at Nice just along the coast, and the south of France is her adopted home."

"Cannes has a longer season than anywhere else. There are film, TV and music festivals here, conferences and congresses from January to November. And there are 150,000 Brits living within 45 minutes' drive, plus another 50,000 every summer."

It took the couple and their business partner, Frenchman Bruno Asselin, some time to find the right venue, on the Place Mérimée about 30 yards from the Congress Centre. When they first arrived, the place had just been bought by a former French textiles executive who "rather fancied running a little bistro to keep himself from getting bored in his retirement," Neat says.

That being no way to run a restaurant, the Frenchman was "practically on his knees, begging us to buy it" seven months later; Neat was born, and at roughly half the price its owners would have had to pay for it half a year earlier. The restaurant, redecorated by Sophie, seats 45 in winter and will take 55 when the terrace is open in summer.

Finding the right staff was no problem, Neat says - though in the end they came from a somewhat unexpected source. The first hire was Mike, an old acquaintance from the Manoir, who was on holiday in Cannes and visiting a girlfriend at the Carlton hotel down the Croisette.

"He recognised the name and showed up two weeks after we opened," Neat says. "He came in for a coffee and about half an hour later was asking for a job. I told him working here was different to being on holiday, but he was back in a week with his knives. It was a fait accompli."

A month later came Elliot, a friend of Mike's "who does the pastry". Then Warren, Neat's old sous-chef at Pied à Terre, pitched up, and finally Jimmy, who was a good friend of Warren's. It's the best way to recruit people, Neat says: everyone can vouch for everyone else.

A battalion of Brits behind the saucepans didn't exactly go down a bundle with the local restaurateurs, however, particularly when the sought-after star came Neat's way. The reaction from the local trade was, he concedes, "underwhelming". But his customers - the congress business, a highly enthusiastic British community, and a small but growing band of Frenchmen - are delighted.

"Sophie tells me the French who come in here are a little bit sceptical at first," Neat says. "But they take the plunge, they see it's a professional operation, they like what they eat - and they come back."

Neat's three-course lunchtime menu is priced at 220 francs, and the dinner equivalent is 270 francs: good value by Cannes' standards and a downright steal by London's. The dishes, with the exception of his trademark escargots with morilles and garlic purée, are all new since the chef's Pied à Terre days.

There are many in Britain, and a growing number in France, who will dispute the value to a restaurant of a Michelin star. The venerable red guide, which this year celebrates its 100th anniversary, is accused of favouring the traditional over the inventive, and of placing as much emphasis on the fripperies as on the food. More than one chef in both countries has turned down a star.

But Neat, unashamedly, is not one of the doubters. "I've worked in gastronomic restaurants for 13 years now," he says. "I like working in them because you can charge enough to buy the best produce, to get top personnel, and to attract the best clientele - people who really enjoy their food, are knowledgeable about what they're doing.

"It's a fact that gastronomy is judged in certain ways. Now I didn't set the goalposts, but I know what they are, and Michelin is the most creditable organisation currently giving ratings to gastronomy. I want to run a restaurant I'm proud of, and Michelin is the measure."

So would he like a second star? "One, two, three, I don't know," he says. "I want to run a good restaurant, but I want a life too. Right now the most important thing is that I can do that right here - and wear shorts and sunglasses 10 months of the year."

fields.headline:
No: 1591
 Padma Lakshmi
fields.body:
Age: 29.

Appearance: Goddess.

Job: Model (topless at times), actress, TV star (she hosted an Italian gameshow, usually in a bikini), writer, girl about town.

Which town? Currently New York, though it has been Milan, Los Angeles and Delhi.

Boyfriend? 'Fraid so.

Brad Pitt? Nope.

Johnny Depp? Jude Law? Denzel Washington? Salman Rushdie.

NO!!!! So you're saying that a little 53-year-old bald bloke with specs, a badger beard and a price on his head gets to go out with the girl with dozens of adoring Italian websites devoted to her? Well, he is a writer of some repute. And how do you know about those websites?

Anyway, isn't Salman married? He is - to third wife Elizabeth West, with whom he has a two-year-old son. But he's thinking of moving to New York.

To be with Padma? And to get away from the gossipy pettiness of the British press.

Pass Notes? That sort of thing.

So where did they meet? At the launch party of Talk magazine.

And now he worships the ground beneath her feet? Let's not go down that Rushdie title avenue.

Shame. Stop it!

So she's a writer, too. What's she written? Easy Exotic.

An autobiography? A cookbook. "A model's low-fatwa recipes from around the world."

No! Not really low-fatwa? Of course not, it's low-fat. Just a little joke. She has recipes for Spaghetti Di Capri and Bali baked fish, and she does a great raita.

And now she's doing a great writer! So who publishes her? Padma met Miramax chief Harvey Weinstein at a party (where else), told him her dream was to write a cookbook, and a few days later she was sorted with a deal with Hyperion, in which Miramax has a stake.

She'll be in one of his films next. There is said to be a script on its way.

Do say: "Mine's a Salman en crote."

Don't say: "But he's old enough to be your father."

fields.headline: Life after death
fields.standfirst: He was the most private of men before he was hurled onto the world stage by the tragic crash that killed the Princess of Wales. Then the witch hunt began. Trevor Rees-Jones tells Simon Hattenstone how he had to go public to clear his name
fields.trailText: Trevor Rees-Jones says he's said it before and he'll say it again: "I am more than a car accident. There is more to me than just a car accident." The unfortunate thing is, for those of us who don't know Rees-Jones, that is exactly what he is.
fields.body:
Trevor Rees-Jones says he's said it before and he'll say it again: "I am more than a car accident. There is more to me than just a car accident." The unfortunate thing is, for those of us who don't know Rees-Jones, that is exactly what he is.

He entered a Mercedes unknown, and came out a mangled cause célèbre: the one who survived. Diana died, Dodi died, the driver Henri Paul died, but bodyguard Rees-Jones somehow managed not to. He was rushed to hospital in an induced coma with his face as flat as a cartoon character's. The surgeons set about rebuilding the bones that had been crushed to powder. Meanwhile, we speculated. Would he live to tell the tale? Did he have a tongue to tell the tale with? Had he been silenced? Was he part of the conspiracy that Mohamed Fayed railed against?

After the initial reconstructive surgery, Fayed rushed him off to see his personal doctors, to protect him, to help him remember. But Rees-Jones couldn't remember the incident, probably never would. Fayed grew impatient when Rees-Jones didn't deliver; the bodyguard left his employment, and Fayed accused him of betrayal. Actually, said Fayed, it was worse than betrayal - Rees-Jones and his fellow bodyguard Kez (who didn't actually travel in the car) were partly responsible for the crash, because they had neglected their duties. Which is why we are here today.

Rees-Jones has just recorded his version of events in a book, The Bodyguard's Story. His publishers have chosen an environment that seems both at odds with Rees-Jones and also surprisingly appropriate. We are sitting in the type of five-star hotel that you could imagine Fayed happily owning and Rees-Jones cautiously prowling, just out of view. He is tall, broad and stiff. Maybe stiff like bodyguards tend to be, or stiff with anxiety.

Half his face is untouched, the other half etched with angular scars and permanently numb. His dodgy eye still looks indented, his new nose is perfect. "Much better than the old one," says Kez. "He was no oil painting, you know."

"Yeh, definitely," agrees Rees-Jones with a brittle Welsh laugh. Actually, he was a very good-looking man. Kez says that Trevor is the same bloke he always was, same sense of humour, same interests in rugby and drinking, just a few more scars. No difference? "I think he's more guarded than he used to be."

He is a strong man who talks about honesty, trust, loyalty; a man who enjoyed serving the powerful and privileged - whether it be during his six years in the army (including a stint in Northern Ireland) or the Fayed family. He really did believe that discretion was the greater part of valour.

He says he doesn't do emotional stuff, poignant stuff; he doesn't hug or cry readily, but he admits Fayed's allegations against him hurt badly. "When they came out it was so frustrating because we had no way of replying. We felt like two normal blokes who were just out on a limb, and when this opportunity came up . . ."

It was important to be able to put things in his own words, not to have them "twisted, controlled by others". Not only did he have to recover from the injuries and the trauma of the deaths, but suddenly he was a public figure to be milked. Now he believes the only way of regaining his privacy is to speak out.

Over the past couple of years, he has learned a lot about betrayal. Fayed's betrayal, and that of his former wife who sold the video of their wedding to American television. "It was a big shock to me then. It's such a personal thing. So, yeh, that was quite hurtful," he says. "But there's no point in crying over spilt milk. It's been done."

While Fayed was urging him to talk, others were urging him to stay silent. "I had phonecalls when working in the sports shop saying keep your mouth shut or we'll sort you out, we know where you are. They said they were from MI6. I think it was just some sort sort of crank, not worth getting flustered about." Was he ever debriefed by the security services? "No . . . no." He looks away.

Rees-Jones says the book advance has been useful in helping him buy a two-bedroom place close to his parents' house in Oswestry on the Welsh border, and in settling his legal bills. He also wanted to use the book to pay tribute to his mum and stepfather, who have been "brilliant". But the most important thing is to vindicate himself and Kez. He explains in words that seem at once clumsy and practised: "I am confident in myself of what I did. I am confident that I did as much as I could do in that situation. I've got to look in the mirror every day and be confident with the actions I took that night. And I'm happy to do that now." You sense that however many times he repeats this, there will still be doubts.

He points out that Dodi was the boss, and he had no right to stop him doing whatever he fancied. Dodi decided he and the princess would leave by the back entrance with no security. Rees-Jones intervened and insisted that they travelled with at least one security man - him.

He talks without bitterness of the way he has been treated by Fayed. "People are looking for a great outpouring of anger, but if we did that we'd still be living two and a half years ago." Has it made him more cynical? He answers questions eliptically. "When at first I was recovering, I was trying to keep everyone happy, trying to keep all the balls in the air, and the only person I wasn't looking after was myself." He is alluding to the fact that when Fayed first suggested the conspiracy theory, he didn't quash it - he couldn't because he didn't have a clue what had happened. Fayed took this as Rees-Jones's tacit acceptance of an orchestrated crash.

How is he looking after himself now? "By doing this." With his version on the record, he hopes people will stop filling in the gaps, although the main gap, four minutes either side of the accident, will never be filled. He insists he never believed in a conspiracy, but he understands why so many of us are anxious to find one. "I think the problem is that it is such an ordinary end for a person put on a pedestal. People can't believe that the Princess of Wales died in such a tragic but normal way."

Why was the Fiat that is said to have scraped the Mercedes never traced? "I try not to think about that," he says distantly. "I try not to remember all the detail." He remembers the broader picture - the summer cruise with the Fayeds and Diana, happy times. He says it would be dishonest to pretend he had an intimate relationship with the princess, but he liked what he knew. "What surprised me was how ordinary and natural she was. She was the sort of lady I'd be willing to take down the pub, and that's as big a compliment as I can say."

And Dodi? "I had a very professional relationship with him. He was polite, never rude, always please and thank you, and good morning and good night, and that's a pleasant atmosphere to work in." But the way he describes Dodi in the book makes him sound so infantile - the voracious boy who counted up his cars and played all night long. "That's the conclusion you've drawn. I want people to draw their own conclusion."

"He's not the kind of bloke you'd want to go out for a beer with," says Kez. Why not? "Because I'd probably end up paying . . . We're from different backgrounds, have different interests." But Diana was also from a different background. Yes, says Rees-Jones, that's why her normality was so amazing. Did he fancy her? "Very attractive. I'm not going to say. I thought she was very attractive," he mumbles.

What did she see in Dodi? "Obviously something did click. She made the decision to go on that holiday. As far as I'm concerned, that holiday was a success, they seemed very happy." Then again, who wouldn't enjoy a free trip round the Mediterranean on a luxury yacht, he adds.

When I ask whether Dodi and Diana were physical with each other, both men bristle. Kez warns that we're getting into kiss-and-tell territory, "and as blokes we're not like that. Even if we did see that kind of crap, we wouldn't tell anybody. And we were working our balls off by the way, working 18 hours a day, and the last thing we were doing was peeping through keyholes."

Rees-Jones is now working again, helping set up a security firm. Is he still haunted by the accident? He returns to the mantra. "No, I'm confident. I'm happy with the investigation's conclusion. I'm happy with what I did that night, and I've moved on from that."

However much he has put it behind him, he has to live with the fact that Dodi and Diana "died on my shift", as he puts it. He used to dream about the crash: he saw Fiats and motorbikes and heard Dodi's voice, and he became so confused he never knew if it was real. "At the time, I wanted to know. I was desperate to know." Rees-Jones says he hates labels, but sometimes you can't avoid them. "If you like, it's 'survivor's guilt'. I thought a while ago it would be a lot less hassle if I wasn't around, and things could have moved on."

Did he get depressed? "I had a time two Christmases ago when I thought, 'Hold on, you're not as happy as you claim to be.' You have to admit you're not Superman, you do have down periods. You have to accept it happened." He sits up straight and certain. "I'm not the kind of person who would get depressed anyway."

He admits that it has been odd when strangers have walked up to him, called him Trevor and shaken his hand; and he says it would have been upsetting had they not been so supportive. It must be so distressing to be a cypher for the emotion or ghoulish curiosity of others, I say. He tells me of the time he was walking through his village, head pointed down to his feet, anxious for anonymity. It dawned on him that he had started to walk like Diana.

But now, he says, he is better, and perhaps the book is the final stage of recovery. He talks about the three who died in the car, the friends he has who are now wheelchair-bound after sports injuries, while at 31 he's playing rugby for Wrexham at a higher level than he ever has done. "I've got nothing to complain about whatsoever. I'm very lucky."

The Bodyguard's Story by Trevor Rees-Jones with Moira Johnston is published by Little Brown at £16.99.

webTitle: Should I try to maintain a relationship with my four-year-old in the US?

fields.headline: Should I try to maintain a relationship with my four-year-old in the US?
fields.trailText: My ex-partner will soon be moving to the US, taking my daughter, four and a half, with her. She claimed the move was for two years to further her career. I have since discovered that her contract is permanent, rather than fixed-term, and she will not give any commitment - more a vague "intention to return after two years". Also, she is engaged to a US citizen at the same company. I believe the idea of moving for two years was to mislead me and the court welfare officer so she could be granted permission to take my daughter.
fields.body:
My ex-partner will soon be moving to the US, taking my daughter, four and a half, with her. She claimed the move was for two years to further her career. I have since discovered that her contract is permanent, rather than fixed-term, and she will not give any commitment - more a vague "intention to return after two years". Also, she is engaged to a US citizen at the same company. I believe the idea of moving for two years was to mislead me and the court welfare officer so she could be granted permission to take my daughter.

My dilemma is over what to do to cause the least emotional harm to my daughter. For the past 18 months she has lived with me at least four days every two weeks. The only contract proposed is a weekly telephone call, five weeks each summer and a week at Christmas. Would it be kinder to my daughter for me to fade away, painful as that will be, rather than inflict the potential confusion and conflict of trying to maintain a long-distance relationship in the face of negative influence from my ex and her partner?

Go for the hard slog

I am sorry to say that you are facing a very difficult situation. If you decide to try to prevent your ex-partner returning to the US with your daughter she is likely to feel very resentful, and this in turn will have a negative effect on your daughter, who is at a very vulnerable age. On the other hand, if you let your ex-partner go this means that as a father you will, however unwillingly, have practically vacated the scene.

In my case, my son was taken away by his mother (who was American) when he was just six weeks old, and I had to fight very hard - and at no little expense - to get access. Then, when he was five years old, his mother decided to return to the US. I could have legally prevented her from doing this, but after agonising over the matter, I decided to give my permission for her to go. This was mainly because I wanted to disperse the poisonous clouds that had formed around my son because of his parents' strife and had definitely harmed him.

Now he is 14, considers the US his home, and I have managed to visit him for three months a year, to his great contentment. Two years ago, my ex-wife actually apologised to me for having tried to prevent me from being my son's father and congratulated me for my persistence in maintaining as much contact as possible. Of course, she could easily do this because she is in much the stronger position. But our relations now are good and my only problems (though formidable ones) are logistical and economic.

I am glad to have opted for the hard slog because I know that what children hate most is warfare between their parents. Even if you are getting the thin end of the wedge, stick it out and your daughter will be all the more grateful as she grows up and understands the situation. Remember that "Time is a gentleman" and that she will increasingly ask herself why she is not spending more time with you. Good luck.
Peter Turton, London

Never, ever give up

I'm writing to you as a woman who has survived a similar situation to that which you described. My parents emigrated, then split when I was four. My mother brought me back to England; my father stayed in Canada. Although as an adult I eventually managed to create a very loving and warm friendship with my dad (I saw him just three times when I was growing up), nothing can heal the sense of anger and loss that I was denied the chance to really know him as a child - for exactly the reasons you have mentioned, to avoid "confusion and conflict", but also the inevitable result of a distance of thousands of miles.

Your daughter remains your daughter. Nothing can bring those years back for me - I'm 35 now and it still hurts like hell. Do everything you can to keep your contact with her alive and as regular as possible. Holidays and phonecalls are not enough. Your ex-partner is putting a job and her new life above the rights of your daughter to maintain that contact with her dad. One day your daughter will want to know why, and believe me, there will be plenty of "conflict and confusion" then. Don't ever, ever, ever give up. Good luck!
Name and address withheld

Why not move with her?

Under no circumstances, no matter how much pain you may suffer, should you ever contemplate the notion of defeat, for that is essentially selfish. I'm afraid that you and your feelings do not matter; it is your daughter's long-term welfare, happiness and sense of identity that are paramount. To achieve this you have to maintain contact, overcome all obstacles and present yourself as her father, regardless of how short-sighted or vindictive your ex-partner's attitude may be.

There is a way - if you really want to, you'll find it. Parenthood, by definition, is for life, irrespective of circumstance. Quite frankly, you have no choice.

Remember also, the world is shrinking. People, ex-partners, jobs and attitudes are not etched in stone and daughters always need dads. There is plenty of hope for you if you seek it. Accepting defeat now is a move that you will regret for ever, not to mention the potential effect it could have on your treasured daughter.

I know. I've been there. I've done it and it paid off. Though, yes, it was hard and at times caused me unbelievable pain, when I look at my daughter now and consider our relationship and marvel at her potential, it's difficult to imagine I considered any alternative course of action. Well, I didn't really.

By the way, you talk of your ex-partner's negative influence; don't worry. Kids are very bright and soon learn to filter out adult nonsense. Please, just be there for her. Work hard to pay for air fares or else go and live there. Why not?
CP Coulson, Hampshire

Next week

My older brother was taken into care when he was 15 and I was six. He blames many of his problems on this, and now claims he was abused in care. I was kicked out by my parents when I was 15, and dropped out of school. After many difficult years, I am now fairly comfortable; though I am separated and semi-disabled, I have a good relationship with my 13-year-old son, and last year got a degree.

Recently my brother got in touch again after 10 years. He came to stay for three days, and I found him almost unbearable. He is long-term unemployed, and tells tales to convince me, and himself, that he is important and popular. In short, he is not the sort of person I'd want to know if he wasn't my brother, and I am not the person he wants me to be. However, I colluded with him to spare his feelings. I would rather have a more honest relationship with him, but that would require some harsh truths to be aired.

He says he wants regular contact again. My question is: should I repress my own feelings to spare his? Or should I stand up for myself and risk damaging him more?

Private Lives appears every Friday. Each week we publish a letter to which readers are invited to respond. Replies, giving an account of your personal experience, should reach us by Thursday. Readers are also welcome to propose other problems, of around 300 words. Write to Private Lives, The Guardian, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER, fax 0171 239 9935, email privatelives@theguardian.com (please do not send attachments).

Recently my brother got in touch again after 10 years. He came to stay for three days, and I found him almost unbearable. He is long-term unemployed, and tells tales to convince me, and himself, that he is important and popular. In short, he is not the sort of person I'd want to know if he wasn't my brother, and I am not the person he wants me to be. However, I colluded with him to spare his feelings. I would rather have a more honest relationship with him, but that would require some harsh truths to be aired. He says he wants regular contact again. My question is: should I repress my own feelings to spare his? Or should I stand up for myself and risk damaging him more? Private Lives appears every Friday. Each week we publish a letter to which readers are invited to respond. Replies, giving an account of your personal experience, should reach us by Thursday. Readers are also welcome to propose other problems, of around 300 words.
