webTitle: Deutsche Bank tries to quell City job fears

fields.headline: Deutsche Bank tries to quell City job fears
fields.standfirst: Breuer denies he plans to dismember newly acquired investment operation
fields.trailText: Deutsche Bank yesterday insisted Dresdner Kleinwort Benson was a "jewel" and not an investment bank threatened by closure following its €80bn (£50bn) groundbreaking merger with its smaller domestic rival.
fields.body:
Deutsche Bank yesterday insisted Dresdner Kleinwort Benson was a "jewel" and not an investment bank threatened by closure following its €80bn (£50bn) groundbreaking merger with its smaller domestic rival.

Deutsche admitted 1,600 investment banking jobs face the axe across its operations in London and New York, but refused to indicate how many of them would be lost in the City where the two investment banks employ more than 12,000 people. Responding to anxieties that up to 6,000 job cuts were on the cards at DKB, the chairman of the old Deutsche Bank and joint chief executive of the new company - bearing the same name - said: "Any fears in London are absolute rubbish.

"We have no idea whatsoever to close or sell Dresdner Kleinwort Benson. It is a jewel and we want to keep that jewel," said Rolf Breuer, who admitted he would step down as joint chief executive in 2002.

While his words appeared to be reassuring, they did little to boost sentiment yesterday at DKB's operation in London where many still felt resigned to redundancy. While the two banks saw the deal as a merger of equals, the ratio for existing shareholders in the banks is likely to be 60-40 in Deutsche's favour.

In total the combined bank will shed 16,000 jobs from its 140,000 workforce over a three-year period as it streamlines its domestic branch network with the help of Allianz, the German insurance group which holds stakes in both banks. With the exception of its fund management business, every operation is to be restructured to remove overlaps in an effort to squeeze out €2.9bn of costs a year.

While Mr Breuer heralded the deal as the beginning of consolidation in the German market, it can also be expected to put pressure on his rivals in Europe. The new Deutsche will be second in terms of stock market size in Europe only to HSBC, bigger than Lloyds TSB and UBS of Switzerland.

Mr Breuer said the deal was good for Germany as a whole by creating "a European powerhouse". His counterpart at Dresdner Bank, Bernhard Walter, backed rejection of City rumours about Dresdner Kleinwort Benson's fate, describing them as "pure and utter nonsense"

Both German banks have built up their investment banking presence by buying up top City names, Deutsche through Morgan Grenfell and Dresdner in acquiring Kleinwort Benson.

Mr Breuer admitted yesterday that Dresdner's acquisition had been more successful than his bank's deal with Morgan Grenfell although he had learned from the mistakes of the past through the recent purchase of Bankers Trust of the United States which involved 5,500 job cuts last year.

"In hindsight the Kleinwort Benson deal went more smoothly than Morgan Grenfell," Mr Breuer said, admitting that Deutsche had been too slow to integrate Morgan Grenfell - whose name has now been eradicated from the City - with its own operations.

webTitle: Allianz moves in on merged banks

fields.headline: Allianz moves in on merged banks
fields.trailText: Munich-based insurer Allianz yesterday ruled out a full scale move into the banking business despite the news that it is to take a strategic stake in the retail banking arms of Deutsche and Dresdner banks when the two merge.
fields.body:
Munich-based insurer Allianz yesterday ruled out a full scale move into the banking business despite the news that it is to take a strategic stake in the retail banking arms of Deutsche and Dresdner banks when the two merge.

Allianz will initially take a 49% stake in Deutsche's retail business, Deutsche Bank 24, but that stake will be reduced when Dresdner's retail operations are added in. Bank 24 will eventually be floated.

Under the terms of the deal announced yesterday Allianz will buy Deutsche Bank's asset management business DWS and the DeutscherHerold insurance business. The move will mean a substantial unwinding of the three institutions' cross shareholdings. At present Allianz holds 21.7% of Dresdner shares and a little over 5% of Deutsche Bank while Dresdner and Deutsche have 10% and 6.9% of Allianz. However once the deal has gone through Allianz will have around 5% of the merged bank which will, in turn, have 5% of the insurer.

"With the reduction of their cross-shareholdings, Allianz, Deutsche Bank and Dresdner Bank will provide the basis for more transparency in the German financial services sector," said Henning Schulte-Noelle, the chairman of Allianz's management board.

fields.headline: Schröder hijacks Blair's IMF vote
fields.trailText: Gerhard Schröder yesterday attempted to bounce Tony Blair into supporting his new nominee for the top job at the International Monetary Fund.
fields.body:
Gerhard Schröder yesterday attempted to bounce Tony Blair into supporting his new nominee for the top job at the International Monetary Fund.

The German chancellor talked up Horst Köhler's chances by telling reporters after meeting the Dutch prime minister, Wim Kok, that both the Netherlands and Britain had declared their support for his candidacy.

"We are well on the way to wards reaching a European consensus on this question," Mr Schröder said.

However, Downing Street maintained a diplomatic silence on the subject, suggesting Mr Blair had yet to make up his mind between Mr Köhler and the other candidate, Giuliano Amato, the former Italian prime minister.

Observers said Mr Schröder is under political pressure at home to ensure Mr Köhler gets the job of IMF managing director after the humiliating rejection of his first candidate, Caio Koch-Weser, by Washington and that his comments were designed to force the British government off the fence. The Italian government has pushed its own candidate, accusing Mr Köhler, head of the London-based European Bank for Reconstruction and Development, of lacking the authority and status to be the new IMF boss.

While achieving a consensus among EU countries will be crucial for the success of either candidate, the winner will also need the support of the US, the IMF's largest shareholder. Washington has refused to discuss the merits of Mr Köhler but it is understood that the Clinton administration is less hostile to him than his predecessor, who was considered too lightweight.

Berlin hopes Mr Köhler will be formally nominated as the EU's candidate at next Monday's meeting of EU finance ministers - although it acknowledges that a decision could be delayed until the next EU summit in Portugal later this month.

webTitle: Wine merchant that duped Irish clients wound up

fields.headline: Wine merchant that duped Irish clients wound up
fields.trailText: A wine merchant, whose cellars were full of gaping holes where customers' bottles of vintage claret ought to have been, was last night in the hands of the official receiver.
fields.body:
A wine merchant, whose cellars were full of gaping holes where customers' bottles of vintage claret ought to have been, was last night in the hands of the official receiver.

Croft & Dupont, formerly of New Bond Street, London, charged its mainly Irish clients roughly double the price on offer from a UK wine shipper, it is thought.

As a sideline, Croft sold also champagne with the customer's name printed on a personalised label. Trade and industry secretary Stephen Byers is asking the high court to wind the company up "in the public interest" following an investigation by his department.

Croft specialised in supplying wine from the Bordeaux region of France to Irish customers, apparently cashing in on the recent boom in wine consumption in Ireland.

According to the DTI: "The sale price included storage of the wine for five years. The [section 447] inquiry revealed that a substantial proportion of the wine ordered by customers has not been purchased by the company, which appeares to have ceased trading".

The total money owed to Croft clients has not been disclosed. As yet, the authorities in the Irish republic have not been involved, because the corporate structure was based entirely in Britain.

Croft & Dupont was founded in February 1998, which means even its first clients may not be expecting to draw their stocks of wine until 2003 and may be unaware of the gaps in the company's cellars.

The first set of accounts ought to have been filed a year later, but none has been. Mr Byers's petition to have Croft wound up permanently will be heard on April 12.

 A record number of rogue directors were banned from Britain's boardrooms in 1999, DTI figures showed yesterday. The total reached 1,489, from 1,350 in 1998, with a confidential public hotline given credit by DTI minister Kim Howells for much of the increase.

Yesterday the DTI was granted a 10-year ban on Keith Chorlton, of Chepstow, Monmouthshire, from serving as a director for serious misconduct as an executive of the now-insolvent dating agency Close Encounters of the Best Kind, including the transfer to himself from the agency of £464,000.

Dr Howells said this behaviour "is a perfect example of how a director can get himself a date with the court".

According to the DTI: "The sale price included storage of the wine for five years. The [section 447] inquiry revealed that a substantial proportion of the wine ordered by customers has not been purchased by the company, which appeares to have ceased trading". The total money owed to Croft clients has not been disclosed. As yet, the authorities in the Irish republic have not been involved, because the corporate structure was based entirely in Britain. Croft & Dupont was founded in February 1998, which means even its first clients may not be expecting to draw their stocks of wine until 2003 and may be unaware of the gaps in the company's cellars. The first set of accounts ought to have been filed a year later, but none has been. Mr Byers's petition to have Croft wound up permanently will be heard on April 12.  A record number of rogue directors were banned from Britain's boardrooms in 1999, DTI figures showed yesterday. The total reached 1,489, from 1,350 in 1998, with a confidential public hotline given credit by DTI minister Kim Howells for much of the increase. Yesterday the DTI was granted a 10-year ban on Keith Chorlton, of Chepstow, Monmouthshire, from serving as a director for serious misconduct as an executive of the now-insolvent dating agency Close Encounters of the Best Kind, including the transfer to himself from the agency of £464,000. Dr Howells said this behaviour "is a perfect example of how a director can get himself a date with the court".

fields.headline: £2,000 for John Lewis staff
fields.trailText: Some 40,000 staff at the John Lewis department stores group are in line for a bonus equal to around eight weeks pay even though the group yesterday unveiled a 7% drop in profits last year.
fields.body:
Some 40,000 staff at the John Lewis department stores group are in line for a bonus equal to around eight weeks pay even though the group yesterday unveiled a 7% drop in profits last year.

The payout, which will total £77.8m, will be 15% of annual salary for each "partner" within the John Lewis organisation, which also includes the Waitrose supermarket group. It will average some £2,000 per worker, but is down on the 19% payouts they received last year.

The downturn was caused by a poor first half at the group, when trading profit fell by 22%. In the second six months, especially over Christmas, the store chain recorded an impressive turnaround in its fortunes, but it was not enough to make up all the lost ground and pre-bonus profits were down from £237m to £195m.

Over the full year group sales were ahead 7% to £3.75bn, but chairman Sir Stuart Hampson said profits had been hit by the lack of price inflation. "Prices for the goods sold in our stores actually fell last year," he said, "with the effect particularly noticeable in clothing, electrical and audio-television. In Waitrose too we saw declines in fruit and vegetable prices."

Nevertheless, he forecast that profits would be restored above £200m in the coming twelve months even though "it will be tough because pay con tinues to go up and distribution costs are rising as fuel costs increase".

Department store sales last week were up 9.7% on last year's levels, while Waitrose sales were showing a 10.6% improvement. Sir Stuart said the best performing departments were furnishings, audio, computers and upmarket fashion.

The group is investing heavily in new department stores. Last year it opened in Glasgow and at Bluewater in Kent and in the coming two years there will be outlets in Southampton and Solihull. Its Peter Jones shop in Chelsea is among three being refurbished and the group's Waitrose division has bought 11 stores from ailing rival Somerfield for rebranding. There are also six supermarkets under construction.

Sir Stuart added that the department store was also working on expanding its waitrose.com e-commerce site, but indicated it would be some time before John Lewis merchandise was available online.

He also revealed that the group was reviewing its trademark "never knowingly undersold" price promise in the face of new competition from rival e-tailers.

He added that there was no chance that demutualisation would come back on to the agenda this year. Last year there were calls for the group to be sold, some believing it could have generated payouts of £100,000 per head for staff.

fields.headline: Generosity eludes windfall winners
fields.standfirst: Two-thirds of club members snub fund for low paid staff and promise of aid to widows goes unfulfilled
fields.trailText: More than two-thirds of the 12,000 members of the RAC Club who each received windfall payouts of £34,000 last year following its demutualisation have refused to donate £100 a head for the club's low-paid staff.
fields.body:
More than two-thirds of the 12,000 members of the RAC Club who each received windfall payouts of £34,000 last year following its demutualisation have refused to donate £100 a head for the club's low-paid staff.

A proposal to help the widows and orphans of members who died just before the cash handout has also come to nothing.

The staff fund was set up to benefit the 300 chefs, waiters, greenkeepers and cleaners who run the RAC's Pall Mall clubhouse and its country club, Woodcote Park, in Epsom, Surrey, when the memers voted to sell the RAC breakdown service for £450m and share out the spoils.

When the cheques were sent out last summer the club included a request that each member should hand back £100 to staff as a token of thanks. That request has been largely ignored.

The parsimony of the club's members, who include numerous lords, knights, politicians, TV personalities and senior businessmen, was described by club secretary George Kennedy as "a private matter".

Mr Kennedy refused to comment on the size of the fund but it is understood that it totalled only £387,000 late last year. In an attempt to boost that, the club sent out additional pleas with membership renewal forms at the start of the year.

If all 12,000 members had handed over the suggested £100 each, it would have generated a total £1.2m, or £4,000 for each worker. Instead they are in line to receive £1,200. The fund was closed at the end of January.

This contrasts with the £570,000 pay-off awarded to chief executive Neil Johnson after the breakdown business was sold to Lex Service.

Mr Johnson originally planned to sell the operation to NCP car parks owner Cendant but that deal was blocked by the government.

Mr Kennedy said: "The club staff are properly remunerated and I am delighted that they have benefited directly from the sale of RAC Motoring Services." Every member had contributed to the staff "as part of the settlement" but he refused to explain in what way.

However, some club members have attacked the miserly behaviour of the majority.

One recently wrote to the club magazine: "It is inconceivable to me that any member would begrudge contributing £100 out of the very special windfall which we have all received and I do hope that we will not fail to reach a contribution rate of no less than 100%.

"To my mind the club has an excellent and long-standing calibre of staff and I would not wish them to consider that they have been snubbed by an overwhelming majority of members."

Another wrote that the initiative "deserved better support than this".

However, the staff will receive some payment. Other groups will receive nothing. At the special meeting in Westminster Central Hall which approved the sell-off, chairman Brian McGivern promised to set up a fund to help the widows and orphans of RAC members, and invited members to make donations. His offer came in response to calls from the floor of the meeting to give 1% of the proceeds to staff and widows.

Yesterday Mr Kennedy confirmed the fund had not been set up. He said "it would not be helpful for me to comment" on the matter.

Louise Merrett's husband Kevin was a club member but died of cancer at the age of 39, days before the sale was finalised. He was therefore deprived of a payout. Mrs Merrett said: "I think it stinks."

She had tried to contact Mr Kennedy but had been repeatedly rebuffed. She has now joined an action group of 1,200 seeking compensation from the RAC. "My kids have been punished. They have lost their father and with him the lifestyle they were used to. We have had a dreadful time."

Yesterday the Guardian tried to contact a number of RAC members, including Sir Ian Prosser, chairman of Bass, transport minister Lord Macdonald, Sir Christopher Foster of Railtrack and PricewaterhouseCoopers, and former Metropolitan police chief Sir Paul Condon. They were all unavailable for comment.

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText: Company failures down
fields.body:
Company failures down

Company failures dropped 29% in February compared to the previous month and were 18% lower than in February 1999. The total of administration and receivership orders - 122 last month - is now broadly the same as the 118 issued in February 1998. In 1999, in the backwash from the worldwide economic scare, receiverships and administration orders in Britain totalled 1,479, against 1,383 the previous year and 1,441 in 1997. Last year saw the highest total since the 1,595 clocked up in 1996, as the country was emerging from recession. The figures, compiled by accountants Deloitte & Touche, do not include liquidations, whether compulsory or voluntary, nor do they include personal bankruptcies. London and the south-east accounted for the biggest share last year, with 605 orders, followed by the north-west (228), the west Midlands (197) and Yorkshire-Humberside (162). Northern Ireland is not included.

UBS plans e-services

Swiss banking group UBS said that it will invest SFr250m (£94m) in launching a pan-European e-services personal investment business. Net profits for 1999 were SFr6,300m, more than double the previous year's total. The group's investment bank, UBS Warburg, had a good year, reporting a pre-tax profit of SF2,484m. Performance-related pay at UBS Warburg meant personnel costs climbed by more than 50% to SFr6,861m.

Luxuries upturn for LVMH

Luxury goods group LVMH turned in sharply higher profits for 1999. Net income rose 40% to €738m (£449m) for 1999 while the group yesterday reported overall sales up 41% for the first two months of the current year. LVMH is trialling its e-luxury project which is expected to be launched in the US in May. It will offer a number of luxury brands in addition to those owned by LVMH. BAA reports 8.1% lift BAA yesterday said its seven UK airports saw 8.1m passengers pass through in February, an 8.1% rise in passenger traffic over the previous year. Stansted airport yesterday began breaking ground for the construction of a £200m terminal extension

webTitle: Club founders had rule against profiteering

fields.headline: Club founders had rule against profiteering
fields.trailText: The golden payout to RAC members should never have taken place. The rules setting out the non-profit making nature of the century-old organisation specifically ruled out any "dividend, bonus or . . . profit to the members".
fields.body:
The golden payout to RAC members should never have taken place. The rules setting out the non-profit making nature of the century-old organisation specifically ruled out any "dividend, bonus or . . . profit to the members".

The founding memorandum proposed that any spare cash should be given to ventures associated with promoting the motor car.

It stated: "If upon the winding up or dissolution of the company there remains . . . any property whatsoever, the same shall not be paid to or distributed among the members of the company but shall be given paid or transferred to such public museum or to such institution . . . connected with the objects of the company."

That constitution had to be overturned by a high court judge for the club to sell its roadside breakdown business and divide up the spoils between its 12,000 members.

But when Frederick Richard Simms and Charles Harrington Moore translated the constitution of the Automobile Club de France into English and created the basis for the RAC in 1897 they were determined that any surplus generated by the club should be used to promote what was then widely known as the "horseless carriage".

Support for the 1903 motor act, which increased speed limits, and the 1905 introduction of driving certificates coupled with the first Tourist Trophy (TT) race firmly established the RAC as the voice of the motorist in Britain.

The organisation's illustrious history looked in danger in the 1970s when financial difficulties struck and the RAC's future looked in doubt. Then began a programme of expansion and refurbishment which helped create an organisation wealthy enough to shower £34,000 on each of its members.

fields.headline: PO signs global alliance
fields.trailText: The Post Office yesterday signed up to an international alliance to deliver business mail around the world.
fields.body:
The Post Office yesterday signed up to an international alliance to deliver business mail around the world.

The new venture, which has been hailed as the first of its kind, links the British postal operator with Holland's TPG and Singapore Post in an operation spanning 200 countries with an initial annual turnover of 1bn euros.

The Dutch group will take 51% of the new venture, which will have its head office in Belgium, while the Post Office and Singapore Post will have 24.5% each - a split which represents the assets being put into the new business, according to the Post Office.

"This innovative venture heralds a new era in the global mail market by creating the world's largest business mail ing partnership," said Post Office chief John Roberts.

The alliance is being put together ahead of the full liberalisation of the market for postal services within the EU which the European commission hopes to implement by 2003, but which is running into opposition from some providers because of the question of universal services.

A number of European postal service providers such as Deutsche Post, France's La Poste, the Post Office and TPG are already building up international networks.

However the inclusion of Singapore Post in the Dutch-British venture gives the new alliance a crucial position in the Asia Pacific market, and there is speculation that it may look for a US partner. There was disappointment in Holland that the deal did not include United Parcel Services in the US. The growing competition within the postal services market was underlined by Deutsche Post, which has expanded aggressively in the parcel delivery sector but which said it too was turning its attention to letters.

"We will increasingly turn our attention to the mail market. We want to expand our letter activities wherever it is possible. That is the next stage in our strategy," a spokesman said yesterday. He said it would look at joint ventures or co-operation agreements as well as acquisitions.

However, he called on the commission to ensure that the planned deregulation of the EU postal market produced a level playing field.

"In two years' time in Germany the monopoly will go. In Britain and the Netherlands they are only talking about it but not doing anything." Yes terday's announcement of the new joint venture was met with some reservation by members of the communication workers union.

Derek Hodgson, the general secretary of the union, said yesterday: "We should be able to greet with enthusiasm joint ventures like that announced today, but until the government puts into legislation an unequivocal guarantee of majority public holding we must be suspicious of this type of development."

However, the department of trade and industry said that it did not plan to impose a limit on the "slices" of the Post Office which could be passed on to another firm in an alliance because that might handicap good deals for the British mail operator. The department added that any share disposals would in any case require parliamentary approval.

fields.headline: Dog days
fields.standfirst: Sony contract helps Saatchi to reach record year
fields.trailText: Advertising agency Saatchi & Saatchi scooped more than $1bn (£625m) of new business worldwide last year but saw its profits slip at home after losing a contract to promote the National Lottery.
fields.body:
Advertising agency Saatchi & Saatchi scooped more than $1bn (£625m) of new business worldwide last year but saw its profits slip at home after losing a contract to promote the National Lottery.

The company's biggest new customer was Sony Europe, which will generate billing of over $100m. Sony is poised for a European launch of Aibo, a mobile electronic dog which has been a big hit in Japan.

Saatchi chairman Bob Seelert said: "It's been the best new business year for us ever. We've really led the industry."

Saatchi gained $340m of extra contracts from Procter & Gamble, the US household products group, and $200m of revenue from internet start-ups.

Excluding exceptional items, operating profits increased 10.2% to £34.6m.

However, the UK contribution fell 7.9% to £7m after Saatchi's It Could Be You campaign was dropped by the lottery operator Camelot.

Mr Seelert said: "We created icons in British advertising - people still remember our stuff more than lottery stuff which has been done since.

"But new people came into the business and new people want to work with people they've worked with before. It all started going wrong."

Saatchi's shares slipped 20p to 417p.

fields.headline: Bond escapes jail on appeal
fields.trailText: Australia's most infamous corporate jailbird, the British-born former brewing baron Alan Bond who swindled a company out of A$1billion, has again caused controversy after the high court ordered his release on a technicality.
fields.body:
Australia's most infamous corporate jailbird, the British-born former brewing baron Alan Bond who swindled a company out of A$1billion, has again caused controversy after the high court ordered his release on a technicality.

Bond, aged 61, who has said he would return to Britain when he is free, walked out of a Perth prison a few hours after the court upheld the appeal against his prison sentence being increased from four to seven years.

He made his name when his company, the Bond Corporation, bought the maker of Castlemaine XXXX lager in a A$1.2bn deal, then Australia's biggest takeover.

For a brief period he also became the world's largest gold producer. His career peaked in 1983, when he became the first foreigner to win the America's Cup yacht race competition from the US. After a lengthy legal battle Bond was sentenced in 1997 for his part in stripping the Bell Resources company of more than A$1bn during the 1980s and for an art fraud.

The federal government successfully appealed against the leniency of the sentence but Mr Bond claimed they did not have the power to appeal against a sentence imposed by a state court and won.

"It's been an ordeal, there's no point saying otherwise," he told reporters. "I'm just going to spend some time now and get my life back together. It's still a bit emotional, to be frank."

The attorney general of Western Australia said the constitution should be changed to prevent the likes of Bond escaping on technicalities, and the Australian Shareholder's Association said investors who lost millions in the fraud were disappointed.

"There's a feeling among a lot of investors that people who are involved in so-called white collar crime don't get penalised in the same way as people involved in other sorts of crime," said the association's Ted Rofe.

webTitle: Work runs out for Samson and Goliath

fields.headline: Work runs out for Samson and Goliath
fields.standfirst: News Analysis - Shipyard's plight bridges the sectarian divide
fields.trailText: They are called Samson and Goliath, and for generations they have dominated the Belfast skyline, standing astride the Harland & Wolff shipyard. Now, however, the scrapyard beckons for the two yellow cranes as the shipbuilder faces the most serious crisis of its 139-year history.
fields.body:
They are called Samson and Goliath, and for generations they have dominated the Belfast skyline, standing astride the Harland & Wolff shipyard. Now, however, the scrapyard beckons for the two yellow cranes as the shipbuilder faces the most serious crisis of its 139-year history.

Workers were scuttling away from Queen's Island in east Belfast yesterday after a lunchtime mass meeting to discuss the owners' decision to issue protective 90-day notices to 1,745 employees, almost the entire workforce. The yard's order books are empty and there is no work after it completes two oil drilling ships for US company Global Marine in June.

Some were defiant, believing the yard was simply trying to force through new arrangements, including a three-year no-strike agreement rejected last year. Others were cowed, long anticipating the yard would fall victim to the decline of British shipbuilding.

There was no mistaking the gloom in predominantly loyalist east Belfast. But there was the odd glimmer of hope.

Cunard last night insisted that Harland & Wolff was still in the running to win the contract to build Queen Mary II, said to be the world's first ocean liner in 30 years. The contract is worth an estimated £400m and would provide vital publicity.

Harland & Wolff is up against the French firm Chantiers de l'Atlantique, a highly successful company with a full order book. It can spread its overheads, and its bid is lower.

Larry Pimentel, Cunard's president, who trumpets the liner as the most fa mous ship in the world even before it is built, this week appeared to rule out Harland & Wolff. He suggested the French were hot favourites, prompting the redundancy notices.

He believed the French firm had a proven track record as an established builder of cruise ships and said its ability to do all aspects of the contract within its yard was an important advantage.

Harland & Wolff's last cruise ship was the Canberra in 1961. Yet the Belfast yard would be able to concentrate on the Queen Mary II and is seen as more likely to complete the work on time. The 150,000-tonne ship, three football pitches long and able to carry 2,500 passengers, is expected to be launched in 2003.

Harland & Wolff met Cunard executives in Miami last month and soon revised the firm's bid. It no longer plans to contract fitting work to Lloyd Werft, a German company, but to British firms.

The aim is twofold: to cut costs and to emphasise the British origins of the new vessel. That is a key consideration for Cunard, and deputy prime minister John Prescott, a former Cunard steward, three months ago had dinner with Mr Pimentel.

In a breakthrough, Stephen Byers, trade and industry secretary, yesterday settled a Cunard worry over the Belfast yard's cashflow situation. The DTI announced it will provide a loan under the home shipbuilding credit guarantee system for up to 80% of the value of the contract.

It is believed to be the largest ever such loan and is repayable on completion. The DTI said details would remain confidential.

Mr Pimentel had been worried about Harland & Wolff's £130m contractual dispute four months ago with Global Marine. Former US senator George Mitchell, in Belfast to broker political negotiations leading to devolution, helped settle that row.

Cunard had been expected to announce the winner of the contract this week but that has been postponed, to give the firm enough time to re-evaluate Harland & Wolff's new bid.

A Cunard spokesman said yesterday: "It is still 50/50 between Harlands and Chantiers de l'Atlantique. Chantiers did have the advantage but now H&W has resubmitted its bid and we are evaluating the details. I expect a decision will be reached early in April and we plan to make the announcement in London."

Harland & Wolff's supporters say the yard could yet prove to be a roaring success. They point to the widely anticipated increase in demand for value-added vessels, particularly cruise ships.

One shop steward said yesterday: "If only we win the Queen Mary II contract, the future could be really bright. There are several more big tenders in the pipeline. The trouble is, without the Cunard contract we may not be about to bid for those contracts."

Under the ownership of Norwegian magnate Fred Olsen, the yard posted profits of £5m last year, its first surplus in 20 years. It had begun to concentrate on constructing oil rigs and exploration vessels.

Suspension of the fledgling government institutions at Stormont last month has hampered attempts to save the yard. Politicians of all parties in Northern Ireland agreed on that yesterday. Pat Doherty, Sinn Fein vice-president, who had chaired the assembly's enterprise, trade and investment committee, spoke up for Harland & Wolff workers. The yard was formerly a bastion for sectarianism.

Its shipbuilders played a lead role in the loyalist workers' strike of 1974. That protest scuppered the Sunningdale executive, the last attempt until last year at power sharing in Northern Ireland.

High water marks

Workers are still angry that the yard founded by Yorkshireman Edward Harland and German Gustav Wolff at the peak of the industrial revolution is best known for building the Titanic . It sailed from Belfast in triumph in 1912 only to sink on its maiden voyage with the loss of 1,500 lives.

Harland & Wolff has built 1,700 ships. It was the world's most prolific builder of liners as the 20th century dawned.

During the second world war it built 140 ships for the navy and 140 merchant vessels, equivalent to one a week.

Harland & Wolff employed 35,000 people at its peak in the 50s.

fields.headline: Focus
fields.standfirst: Biocompatibles
fields.trailText: The road to recovery is proving bumpy for healthcare company Biocompatibles, a one-time wonder stock which has been through the wars.
fields.body:
The road to recovery is proving bumpy for healthcare company Biocompatibles, a one-time wonder stock which has been through the wars.

The company's core technology is a unique slippery substance called PC, which replicates natural bodily fluids.

Biocompatibles puts PC on contact lenses, to make them more comfortable. It also uses the stuff to coat coronary stents - tiny pieces of scaffolding used to hold open damaged blood vessels.

A couple of years ago, a big distribution deal with US company Johnson & Johnson collapsed, sending Biocompatibles' shares plummeting. But recently, the market's hi-tech enthusiasm has revived them - the price has surged five-fold in a year and the company is now valued at nearly £600m.

But yesterday's annual results provided a reality check. Losses declined from £43.8m to £19.2m but a problem with contact lens packaging has been seriously damaging.

The seals on some lens cases were unsafe, and boxes were arriving wet. Biocompatibles had to recall two months' worth of US products - hundreds of thousands of lenses.

That meant eyecare revenue stopped growing in the second half. It made chief executive Crispin Simon's target of making profits from the division by this July difficult.

Conveniently, the company yesterday said it was buying Hydron, a profitable contact lens maker, for £38m, which means Mr Simon's target will be met. Shareholders are being asked to fund the acquisition through a £31m placing of shares at 465p. The price edged up 9p to 496.5p.

On the other side of the business, coronary stents sales jumped 51% to £5.4m. But Biocompatibles still only has 5% of the European market and has had to replace its distributor in Germany - which accounts for a quarter of continental demand.

Competition is hot in stents and new versions keep coming on the market. Biocompatibles' technology is good but it needs to become less accident-prone if it ever wants to make money.

fields.headline: Movers
fields.trailText: The extraordinary renaissance in British Telecom pulled the whole of the London market higher yesterday.
fields.body:
The extraordinary renaissance in British Telecom pulled the whole of the London market higher yesterday.

Having already surged from the 960p level in mid-February, the shares jumped another 144p to £13.15 yesterday - a move of 12% - as the company unveiled aggressive plans to take mobile internet services to a mass market.

The jump in this one stock was worth around 40 points on the FTSE 100 index, which eventually closed 120 points higher at 6,532.1. Yesterday's decision by the monetary policy committee to keep interest rates on hold was largely ignored by the market.

Other big telephony companies were also in demand, with Vodafone Airtouch moving up from 378p to 385p, Energis up from £35.63 to £38.55, while Cable & Wireless gained 37p to £15.07.

And there were also plenty of buyers for the big technology stocks, such as mobile computing chip designer ARM Holdings , which ended the session at £48.20, up 512p and now back close to its high of £50.08 set in early February. Market darling Baltimore Technology put on £11.50 to £133.50.

On the media side, Reuters surged from £14.44 to £15.71p - the move apparently triggered by a jump in the price of Tibco, the networking specialist which the British group demerged on to the Nasdaq market last year. Reuters retains a stake of just over 60%.

Other media stocks on the move included BSkyB , up 160p at £21.20, and Reed International , which bounced from 391p to 419p. Reed's shares plunged earlier in the week amid worries over its internet strategy.

The only significantly weak sector proved to be the banks, where Barclays shed 29p to £14.79 and Lloyds TSB gave up 16p to 517p.

There were some high jinks lower down the corporate ladder - as usual.

Lotterking jumped from 12p to 16p, but the company denied reports circulating on internet bulletin boards that it was about to land a major European contract.

Glenchewton , meanwhile, added 8p to 135p before the shares were suspended.

This distributor of houseware goods is probably best-known for the involvement of John Gunn, the former boss of British & Commonwealth and it announced in February that it was talking with an unnamed party about a "substantial transaction."

Yesterday, it added the detail that this would amount to a reverse takeover of the group.

webTitle: What's a nice girl like Sue doing in a place like this?

fields.headline: What's a nice girl like Sue doing in a place like this?
fields.standfirst: Alison Powell on Girl, Interrupted and the American art of going mildly, stylishly loopy
fields.trailText: Alison Powell on Girl, Interrupted and the American art of going mildly, stylishly loopy
fields.body:
In 1967 Susanna Kaysen, instead of heading for a prestigious American university, checked into a mental hospital. The 18-year-old had taken a bottle of aspirin chased with a bottle of vodka, and there were bad bruises on her wrists. She signed herself into McLean hospital outside Boston and spent the next two years on a ward for teenage girls. Actually, make that rich, privileged, teenage girls. These are no crazed low-lifes; they are the nice but troubled daughters of even nicer (and probably more troubled) parents.

From that stay came first Kaysen's best-selling memoir, Girl, Interrupted, and now the screen version starring Winona Ryder and Angelina Jolie. This is not One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest in cashmere twinsets. It is a pitch-perfect take on a very American conceit: that going crazy in a controlled, socially acceptable, relatively well-dressed way is, well, kind of romantic.

The story begins at a pivotal point in Susanna's life. She is on the brink of graduation from high school and without direction. We know hers is a good school: not only is she the only member of her class not going on to college, but she is the first person in the history of the place not to go on to higher education. Susanna's pals belong on campuses that make up the east coast's fabled Seven Sisters, such as Wellesley, Radcliffe, and Vassar. Susanna's path is decidedly less social. She "plans to write". And write she does, through her endless hours on the ward. There is certainly no shortage of material.

The girls of Claymoore (as the hospital is renamed) - Daisy, Georgina, Polly, Lisa and Susanna - are an awkward yet vivid bunch. They are the moneyed miserable, the cared-for neglected, the loved unwanted. The movie and the book ask you to root for them. It's a tough sell. Not because the characters don't deserve our compassion, they do. Georgina is a pathological liar; Polly once doused herself with gasoline and then tossed the match; Daisy has a pitiful eating disorder, the tip of a large iceberg; Lisa is a sociopath. These young women are clinging to wire-mesh windows instead of going on dates or learning to live on their own. But the very idea of them seems to beg for some championship eye-rolling. Kaysen's assessment of her situation is tart and clear-eyed, "Angst of these dimensions is a luxury item. You need to be well-fed, clothed, and housed to have time for this much self-pity."

For all its prep-school winsomeness, the film is deftly cast. Winona may have sworn off "teen angst bullshit" some time after Heathers, but this is her story to tell (she was co-producer) and no one treads the line between pissed off and repentant better. Her Susanna's ennui is of the finest porcelain. Ryder herself skipped college and put herself briefly into a facility where she could take time out from her rampag ing early fame, as well as get a good night's sleep. Jolie's depiction of Lisa has earned her an Oscar nomination.

The girls' link between the solipsism of mental illness and the world beyond the ward is a nurse called Valerie, played with typical stoicism by Whoopi Goldberg. Her diagnosis of Susanna's condition is more Sister Act than Sigmund Freud: "You are a lazy, self-indulgent little girl who's driving herself crazy". The viewer can't help but agree.It's hard to tell whether Susanna is truly sick or not. In the late-60s, depression, homosexuality and resistance to marrying appliance salesmen, could all be deemed signs of clinical mental instability.

For the audience, though, there is something else going on, something far more relevant to our lives than the shaky constitution of a well-read, sensitive girl. A doctor advises Susanna: "You need a genuine rest," and in the dark of the cinema, we'll all be sighing, "Doctor, who doesn't?" Watching 1967 from 2000, we don't see a tough road back to health, we see a vacation. Ryder shuffles around in darling Peter Pan collars and natty black pants, her pixie-ish haircut sweeping stylishly off her glowing face. When not tricked out in the dream student wardrobe - cardigans, sneakers, pea coats - Ryder curls up in cute pyjamas. Smoking, pyjamas, all-day television: this is a spot-on description of the residents of my college dorm most days.

Even Kaysen says in her book, 'For many of us, the hospital was as much a refuge as it was a prison. Though we were all cut off from the world, we were also cut off from the demands and expectations that had driven us crazy ... As long as we were willing to be upset, we didn't have to get jobs or go to school. We could weasel out of anything except eating and taking our medication."

Substitute cruise ship or religious retreat for hospital and you're getting closer to the real allure of checking out, or rather checking in. Imagine the comfy white clothes, courtesy of Donna Karan's new Pure line, minimalist decor, and low sodium cuisine. Valerie lays out the set-up and neatly voices the audience's sentiments: "I worked in a state-run hospital. This is a five star hotel." And let's face it, aren't five star hotels and spas actually low-security asylums? Where does group therapy end and Club Med begin?

But Susanna is on a different trip. "It's so nice to go insane, no one asks you to explain," sang Helen Reddy in her creepy 1974 hit, Angie Baby. Susanna could hardly have chosen a better site than McLean's for her tutelage. Other former clients include musicians James Taylor and Ray Charles and poets Robert Lowell and Sylvia Plath. (Taylor's classic Fire and Rain was written about a girl he met while in McLean.) Susanna's goals are simple and reasonable. She intends to make a life out of boyfriends and literature and she exposes her roman tic predilections early. In getting to know her new roommate, Georgina (Clea Duvall), Susanna explains that her brand of cigarettes is Gauloises: "The French Resistance smoked them, I think." She keeps a diary, develops a worshipful crush on crazier-than-thou Lisa, and mourns a boyfriend whose draft number is due up any time.

F Scott Fitzgerald's novel Tender is the Night, about his unstable wife Zelda, portrays the beauty of the half-mad heroine. And sure enough, Scotty and Zelda's breakdowns became a profound influence on his work, not to mention his literary legend. From southern gothic to Northern Exposure, kookiness is how we get our kicks. America can, after all, be an inauthentic place and craziness is one way to get real. Rather than be repelled by the harpy in the attic, we long to be the first Mrs Rochester. Not for us the centred, resolute Jane, forever doing right and never pitching a fit. In the 1970 movie Diary of a Mad Housewife, for example, there was only one character in the whole business worth knowing - the one having the meltdown. Dorothy Parker's depression, William Burroughs's drug habit and Kurt Cobain's alienation all bear witness to an emotional life not encouraged in the scrubbed suburbs. How else can we explain Depeche Mode's unflagging popularity in the Los Angeles basin?

The most significant graduate of McLean's psychological finishing school was Sylvia Plath. It has been said, cruelly, that suicide was her smartest career move. It is probably just a coincidence that both Ryder's Kaysen and Plath travelled with matched white Samsonite luggage. As a symbol of middle-class normalcy and order, there are few neater. Emotional baggage indeed.

There is something downright literary about the girls' school experience in a country where such adventures are rare. If the defining run at rebellion can't be unleashed at boarding school (if you are super-rich), it can be a sorority house - author Joan Didion was a Tri Delt at Berkeley - or it can wait until that first job in publishing. Or, a clean mental hospital where you can have your own room. Setting yourself against even the puny establishment of an all-girl's dorm may be as close as some girls ever get to challenging their status quo. Defiance, yes, but also a comforting togetherness.

Next up on the angst front is Sofia Coppola's directorial debut, The Virgin Suicides, about a family of beautiful, mysterious suicidal sisters. With a soundtrack by Air and a story filtered through the hip gauze of Coppola's retro-savvy, this adaptation of Jeffrey Eugenides's novel set in the 70s American suburban Elysium should add a dark new spin to the form.

 Girl, Interrupted is released on March 24

Ryder shuffles around in darling Peter Pan collars and natty black pants, her pixie-ish haircut sweeping stylishly off her glowing face. When not tricked out in the dream student wardrobe - cardigans, sneakers, pea coats - Ryder curls up in cute pyjamas. Smoking, pyjamas, all-day television: this is a spot-on description of the residents of my college dorm most days. Even Kaysen says in her book, 'For many of us, the hospital was as much a refuge as it was a prison. Though we were all cut off from the world, we were also cut off from the demands and expectations that had driven us crazy ... As long as we were willing to be upset, we didn't have to get jobs or go to school. We could weasel out of anything except eating and taking our medication." Substitute cruise ship or religious retreat for hospital and you're getting closer to the real allure of checking out, or rather checking in. Imagine the comfy white clothes, courtesy of Donna Karan's new Pure line, minimalist decor, and low sodium cuisine. Valerie lays out the set-up and neatly voices the audience's sentiments: "I worked in a state-run hospital. This is a five star hotel." And let's face it, aren't five star hotels and spas actually low-security asylums? Where does group therapy end and Club Med begin? But Susanna is on a different trip. "It's so nice to go insane, no one asks you to explain," sang Helen Reddy in her creepy 1974 hit, Angie Baby. Susanna could hardly have chosen a better site than McLean's for her tutelage. Other former clients include musicians James Taylor and Ray Charles and poets Robert Lowell and Sylvia Plath. (Taylor's classic Fire and Rain was written about a girl he met while in McLean.) Susanna's goals are simple and reasonable. She intends to make a life out of boyfriends and literature and she exposes her roman tic predilections early. In getting to know her new roommate, Georgina (Clea Duvall), Susanna explains that her brand of cigarettes is Gauloises: "The French Resistance smoked them, I think." She keeps a diary, develops a worshipful crush on crazier-than-thou Lisa, and mourns a boyfriend whose draft number is due up any time. F Scott Fitzgerald's novel Tender is the Night, about his unstable wife Zelda, portrays the beauty of the half-mad heroine. And sure enough, Scotty and Zelda's breakdowns became a profound influence on his work, not to mention his literary legend. From southern gothic to Northern Exposure, kookiness is how we get our kicks. America can, after all, be an inauthentic place and craziness is one way to get real. Rather than be repelled by the harpy in the attic, we long to be the first Mrs Rochester. Not for us the centred, resolute Jane, forever doing right and never pitching a fit. In the 1970 movie Diary of a Mad Housewife, for example, there was only one character in the whole business worth knowing - the one having the meltdown. Dorothy Parker's depression, William Burroughs's drug habit and Kurt Cobain's alienation all bear witness to an emotional life not encouraged in the scrubbed suburbs. How else can we explain Depeche Mode's unflagging popularity in the Los Angeles basin? The most significant graduate of McLean's psychological finishing school was Sylvia Plath. It has been said, cruelly, that suicide was her smartest career move. It is probably just a coincidence that both Ryder's Kaysen and Plath travelled with matched white Samsonite luggage. As a symbol of middle-class normalcy and order, there are few neater. Emotional baggage indeed. There is something downright literary about the girls' school experience in a country where such adventures are rare. If the defining run at rebellion can't be unleashed at boarding school (if you are super-rich), it can be a sorority house - author Joan Didion was a Tri Delt at Berkeley - or it can wait until that first job in publishing. Or, a clean mental hospital where you can have your own room. Setting yourself against even the puny establishment of an all-girl's dorm may be as close as some girls ever get to challenging their status quo. Defiance, yes, but also a comforting togetherness. Next up on the angst front is Sofia Coppola's directorial debut, The Virgin Suicides, about a family of beautiful, mysterious suicidal sisters. With a soundtrack by Air and a story filtered through the hip gauze of Coppola's retro-savvy, this adaptation of Jeffrey Eugenides's novel set in the 70s American suburban Elysium should add a dark new spin to the form.  Girl, Interrupted is released on March 24

fields.headline: What they're reading in South Africa
fields.trailText: South Africa's history being what it is, and change taking the time that it does, it is hardly surprising that the biggest-selling book in the country at the moment is the autobiography of a white, Afrikaans-speaking rugby player. But supporters of the new order can take comfort from the fact that one of the most ardent fans of the former Springbok captain, François Pienaar, is Nelson Mandela, the man who presented him with the rugby World Cup in 1995.
fields.body:
South Africa's history being what it is, and change taking the time that it does, it is hardly surprising that the biggest-selling book in the country at the moment is the autobiography of a white, Afrikaans-speaking rugby player. But supporters of the new order can take comfort from the fact that one of the most ardent fans of the former Springbok captain, François Pienaar, is Nelson Mandela, the man who presented him with the rugby World Cup in 1995.

The autobiography, Rainbow Warrior (Jonathan Ball), records that most epic of victories, which arguably did more to reconcile race groups in South Africa than any other single event. It also gives sports-lovers some insight into the Byzantine politics of what is thankfully - although painfully slowly - becoming a truly national sport.

Disgrace, by J M Coetzee (Random House)
Unusually for up-market fiction here, Coetzee's Booker-winning novel has become a galloping bestseller.
Biography and bibliography
Buy it at BOL

No Future without Forgiveness, by Archbishop Desmond Tutu (Random House)
Examines the moral imperative by which the "rainbow nation" was forged.
Buy it at BOL

Country of my Skull, by Antjie Krog (Random House)
Important and anguished book based on the testimony of the Truth and Reconciliation Committee, by a leading Afrikaner poet.
Poems in Africaans
Buy it at BOL

Iron Love, by Marguerite Poland (Penguin South Africa)
This rites-of-passage novel set in a South African public school during the first world war has sold out twice in South Africa and will shortly be published internationally.

fields.headline: What they're reading in Austria
fields.trailText: Austrians read significantly less than the Germans or Swiss. Indeed there is a dearth of bookshops in the capital, Vienna. The 1990s was a decade of enervation and disorientation, partly influenced by the dominance of the English language. In reaction, many younger writers are experimenting with the German language to create something different, but this has often rendered their works untranslatable and inaccessible to an English-speaking audience.
fields.body:
Austrians read significantly less than the Germans or Swiss. Indeed there is a dearth of bookshops in the capital, Vienna. The 1990s was a decade of enervation and disorientation, partly influenced by the dominance of the English language. In reaction, many younger writers are experimenting with the German language to create something different, but this has often rendered their works untranslatable and inaccessible to an English-speaking audience.

Ironically, the rise of Jörg Haider's far-right Freedom party has created room for writers to move out of the sidelines. Novelist and playwright Elfride Jelinek recently banned her plays from performance in Austria in protest. Haider in turn has used their opposition as a tool.

The Piano Player, by Elfride Jelinek (Serpent's Tail)
This republished 70s novel charts the degradation of a music teacher who finds that Beethoven and Mozart are no protection against cruelty and violence in society.
Buy it from BOL
Elfride Jelinek
Basic but informative page from the University of Huddersfield's School of German.
Homepage
Run by the author herself. Contains many texts in German and a couple which have been translated into English.

Concrete, by Thomas Bernhard (Chicago)
Bernhard, who died in the early 90s, made loathing for his country his theme in his plays and novels. In Concrete , a dissatisfied Viennese music critic meditates on the rottenness of his family, his lover, his society, himself.
Buy it from BOL
Thomas Bernhard
Comprehensive site in German.

The Terrors of Ice and Darkness, by Christoph Ransmayr (Grove Press)
Fictional reconstruction of the Austro-Hungarian expedition to the North Pole in the 1870s which sets the jingoism of adventuring against its tough realities.

My Year in the No-man's Bay, Peter Handke (Farrar Straus Giroux)
The screenwriter for Wim Wenders's film Wings of Desire has hit the press with his eccentric views on Yugoslavia. In this novel, he intertwines them with ideas of walking and complicated routes taken around a Paris suburb.
Buy it from BOL
Article: Peter Handke
On European public opinion and the war in Yugoslavia.

fields.headline: What they're reading in Russia
fields.trailText: Russia's greatest writer is living out the last years of an epic life in a three-storey brick mansion on the wooded outskirts of Moscow, which Russia's bloated capitalists laughingly miscall a "cottage". Alexander Solzhenitsyn refuses all interviews and eschews contact with the outside world. His last major work, an impenetrably dense four-part fictional work on the horrors of Bolshevism, was a huge literary flop.
fields.body:
Russia's greatest writer is living out the last years of an epic life in a three-storey brick mansion on the wooded outskirts of Moscow, which Russia's bloated capitalists laughingly miscall a "cottage". Alexander Solzhenitsyn refuses all interviews and eschews contact with the outside world. His last major work, an impenetrably dense four-part fictional work on the horrors of Bolshevism, was a huge literary flop.

Solzhenitsyn's literary problem has also been Russia's. The capitalist revolution of 1992 did for Soviet dissidents what Boris Yeltsin did to the communists: consigned them to the margins. What arrived in their place was the pulp fiction of Stephen King. Famous book-shops became French-owned hard-currency supermarkets.

English translation of Solzhenitsyn's 1970 Nobel lecture.
Extract from The Gulag Archipelago.

A Baize-Covered Table with a Decanter in the Middle, by Vladimir Makanin (Readers International)
Makanin won the second Russian Booker Prize in 1993 with this novel.
English translation excerpt from The Captive of the Caucasus.

Buy A Baize-Covered Table at BOL

The Crime of Olga Arbyelina, by Andreii Makine (Sceptre)
The Prix Goncourt-winning author made a boating accident in Paris the starting point for his latest investigation of the Russian emigré soul.

Buy it at BOL

The Funeral Party, by Ludmila Ulitskaya (Victor Gollancz)
In her first novel to be published in English, Ulitskaya mourns her country with gentle irony through the story of a Russian emigré artist, Alik, who lies dying in his Manhattan flat.

Buy it at BOL

The Life of Insects, by Viktor Pelevin (Faber)
Born in 1962, Pelevin is a satirist, a master of the grotesque. This riotous novel led many to think they had found the new Gogol. It is set in a sleazy Black Sea resort where his characters turn into insects.
'Sigmund in a Cafe' translated into English.

fields.headline: What they're reading in Australia
fields.trailText: Australians like stories that reflect their own history, as seen through these recommendations. But they're not squeamish about looking at the dark side of that history. Hence the success of Roger McDonald's Mr Darwin's Shooter, and also of John Birmingham's supposed Olympic celebration of the harbour city which instead, in the author's words, wandered down a darker alley of 200 years of scandals and horrors, of modern-day police corruption and colonial greed.

webTitle: What they're reading in the Czech Republic

fields.headline: What they're reading in the Czech Republic
fields.standfirst: Resources on Czech culture
fields.trailText: Foreigners probably think of Milan Kundera's The Unbearable Lightness of Being as the archetypal Czech novel when in fact many Czechs are not even aware of its existence - since Kundera lives in exile in Paris. The complete works of playwright president Vaclav Havel appeared at the end of last year, but it says something of his current standing that he paid for publication himself.
fields.body:
Foreigners probably think of Milan Kundera's The Unbearable Lightness of Being as the archetypal Czech novel when in fact many Czechs are not even aware of its existence - since Kundera lives in exile in Paris. The complete works of playwright president Vaclav Havel appeared at the end of last year, but it says something of his current standing that he paid for publication himself.

The fashion now is for non-fiction, particularly heavy political volumes and vicious kiss-and-tell books such as Confessions of a Personal Assistant by Milos Ryc, in which the former assistant of the president's wife spills the beans about the presidential marriage.

Headed for the Blues, by Josef Skvorecky (Faber)
This Canadian-based Czech has found success both during and after communism. In Headed for the Blues - a memoir and 10 short stories - he tells of romance and subversion under a repressive regime.
Interview from Dalkey Archive Press

Sister, by Joachim Topol (Catbird Press)
One of the emerging young writers of the Czech Republic, 36-year-old Topol draws on his experiences of life in a working-class district of Prague for his novels.

I Served the King of England, by Bohumil Hrabal (Picador)
Hrabal's best-known novel is a charming, racy tale about the effect of history on a sharp-witted Czech waiter, from before the Nazi takeover to the onset of Communism.

fields.headline: What they're reading in Spain
fields.trailText: History, mainly their own; novels, mainly by foreigners; dictionaries, grammars, a smattering of self-help books and travel guides make up the Spaniards' spring reading list.
fields.body:
History, mainly their own; novels, mainly by foreigners; dictionaries, grammars, a smattering of self-help books and travel guides make up the Spaniards' spring reading list.

History ranges from a biography of Phillip V by Yale historian Henry Kamen, to a new book on Charles V, Man and Emperor, by home-grown historian Manuel Fernandez Alvarez, linked to the 500th anniversary of Charles's birth this year.

Among the novels that are riding high are La Agonia del Dragon (The Agony of The Dragon), by Juan Luis Cebriana (a former editor of Spain's leading newspaper El País), set during Spain's transition from dictatorship to democracy in the 70s.

All the Names, by Jose Luis Saramago (Harvill)
Nobel laureate Saramago is actually from Portugal, but his novels are very popular in Spain. In All The Names, a registry officer's obsession with reconstruction sets him on the trail of a woman with no history.
Jose Luis Saramago Homepage
Biography and bibliography
Buy it at BOL

The Notebooks of Don Rigoberto, by Mario Vargas Llosa (Faber)
The septuagenarian Peruvian writer is on top form in this novel of an insurance executive taken over by pornographic fantasies in his wife's absence. Meanwhile, Llosa's most recent novel, La fiesta del Chivo , on the excesses of Latin American dictator Leonidas Trujillo, is already being described as the book of the year in Spain.

Buy it at BOL

Journey to the Alcarria, by Camilo José Cela (Granta)
In the summer of 1946 Cela sets out to look for the heart of Spain in one of the all-time great travel books.
Biography and bibliography

Buy it at BOL

fields.headline: What they're reading in Germany
fields.trailText: When the nine-year-old Marcel Reich-Ranicki left his home town in Poland, his teacher said to him: "My son, now you're going to the nation of Culture." The country was Germany and the date 1929. Mein Leben, Reich-Ranicki's story of a life that saw him survive a Third Reich ghetto to become Germany's best-known literary critic, has been 20 weeks at the top of the non-fiction bestseller list.
fields.body:
When the nine-year-old Marcel Reich-Ranicki left his home town in Poland, his teacher said to him: "My son, now you're going to the nation of Culture." The country was Germany and the date 1929. Mein Leben, Reich-Ranicki's story of a life that saw him survive a Third Reich ghetto to become Germany's best-known literary critic, has been 20 weeks at the top of the non-fiction bestseller list.

But if you measure the impact of a work by the stink it causes, then the literary flashpoint right now is Tristesse Royale, co-authored by the so-called Pop Cultural Quintet, which recounts a weekend-long conversation between five snobbish, frivolous young friends who could just be the authors. Reviled by the critics, it has nonetheless been seen as marking a departure from the gloom- and guilt-laden reflection that has infused much of German post-war literature.

The Reader, by Bernard Schlink (Phoenix, £6.99)
Word-of-mouth hit dealing with the rancid aftermath of Nazism in the life of a young man. Buy it at BOL

Rings of Saturn, by W G Sebald (Panther)
Sebald, a long-term emigré who still writes in German, hit the big time with this elliptical meditation as he walked the Suffolk coast.
Buy it at BOL

fields.headline: What they're reading in America
fields.trailText: Washington DC is a one-industry town. Politics books inevitably occupy a larger amount of shelf space in the city's many and, for America, still nicely eclectic range of bookstores. That's not to say that the usual bestsellers aren't the bestsellers and buzz-creating books in Washington too. The line for the JK Rowling signing session at the Politics and Prose bookshop on Connecticut Avenue a few months ago was amazing. Rowling, John Grisham, Stephen King, Frank McCourt and the other usual mega-sellers always do well here. Washingtonians are compulsive book-buyers and book-discussers.

Rowling, John Grisham, Stephen King, Frank McCourt and the other usual mega-sellers always do well here. Washingtonians are compulsive book-buyers and book-discussers.

Faith of My Fathers, by John McCain (Random House)
The Arizona senator, along with his ghostwriter Mark Selter, do a first-class job of telling the Republican presidential wannabe's extraordinary Vietnam-era story.
Official site for McCain's book.

Shrub, by Molly Ivins (Random House)
A short, quirky but wickedly written subversion of the man who has put McCain out of the presidential contest, George W Bush. Shrub. Geddit?
Shrub page from Random House.

The Hunting of the President, by Gene Lyons and Joe Conason (St Martin's Press)
Forget Lewinsky. This is an attempt to expose the far seamier political conspiracies beneath the drive to get Clinton out.

Shrub. Geddit? Shrub page from Random House. The Hunting of the President, by Gene Lyons and Joe Conason (St Martin's Press) Forget Lewinsky. fields.headline: Best undergoes hospital tests
fields.trailText: Soccer legend George Best was in hospital tonight after suffering stomach pains.
fields.body:
Soccer legend George Best was in hospital tonight after suffering stomach pains.

Best's personal assistant Philip Hughes said the 53-year-old former Manchester United idol was spending a second night in the Cromwell Hospital, west London, where tests were being carried out.

Hughes confirmed a newspaper story that Best is unwell but denied a suggestion that one of soccer's greatest names was fighting for his life.

"He is unwell and may be in hospital for a few days or could be out as soon as tomorrow," said Hughes.

"But I left him sitting up in bed earlier this evening watching television and he's been talking about how Chelsea beat Marseille on Wednesday night.

"He isn't well but it's not life threatening - at least I hope not."

Hughes said Best had made the appointment a week ago and attended hospital yesterday when it was agreed he would stay in for a few days.

The Sun quoted Best's 27-year-old wife Alex as saying: "He is in hospital and looks terrible. We're all worried about him."

There was no answer to calls to the couple's home tonight.

Sister Bernadette O'Gorman, in charge at the hospital overnight, refused to comment on the seriousness of Best's condition.

fields.headline: Net firm heads for £1bn float
fields.standfirst:
Brown warning on dot.com frenzy as float may hit £1bn
E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: The frenzy surrounding internet stocks reached a new high on the stock market yesterday when Lastminute.com, a 19- month-old loss-making on-line retailer, said unprecedented demand from investors had forced it to hike the price of its share sale by more than two-thirds.
fields.body:
The frenzy surrounding internet stocks reached a new high on the stock market yesterday when Lastminute.com, a 19- month-old loss-making on-line retailer, said unprecedented demand from investors had forced it to hike the price of its share sale by more than two-thirds.

Financial bookmakers believe the rush for shares in Lastminute could push the company's value towards the £1bn mark when it floats on the stock exchange on Tuesday. The company's two founders, Brent Hoberman, 31, and Martha Lane-Fox, 27, would see their combined shareholdings valued at almost £200m.

Lastminute's announcement came just hours after Gordon Brown urged caution as investors continue to pour money into internet stocks in the hope of making their own instant dot.com fortunes.

Concern is growing within the City of London that newly launched internet companies are becoming overvalued and that a shake-out could cause many of their share prices to fall back significantly or some firms disappear altogether. If that occurs private investors and institutions stand to lose hundreds of millions, if not billions, of pounds.

The chancellor urged caution when asked on BBC Radio 4's Today programme about the surge in investor interest that has seen several young hi-tech firms push long-established brewers, housebuilders and supermarkets out of the FTSE-100 index.

"I said we had got to be cautious and I am cautious in most instances," Mr Brown said. "And in this particular instance obviously people will want to look at the performance of each of these individual companies."

The chancellor's comments came a day after a warning from Howard Davies, the chairman of the City watchdog the financial services authority. Mr Davies said: "These stocks are extremely difficult to value. These companies for the most part have never made a profit, have never paid a dividend, and have no intention of paying a dividend, so the normal basis on which you value a company is no longer relevant.

"When a company is valued more on hope than on expectation, then you can expect it to be a volatile stock. We know from previous experience that many of the companies around at the moment will not be around in three to five years, because there will be a lot of creative destruction in a new economy of this sort."

Alan Greenspan, chairman of the federal reserve board, which sets interest rates in the US, has previously likened investing in internet companies to playing the lottery.

Private investors in particular do not appear to have heeded the warnings. Financial bookmakers said frenzied buying among individuals, rather than the big investment and pension funds, had forced up the price of Lastminute shares.

"This flotation has generated more interest than any of the others," said David Morrison of Financial Spreads. "We just see buyers coming in. This one has really caught the public's imagination."

IG Index believes Lastminute shares could reach 560p by the end of the first day's trading. Morgan Stanley, the investment bank coordinating the float, wants to sell the shares at around 350p each.

City analysts believe Lastminute.com could emerge as a definitive test case of the strength of Britain's fast- emerging internet sector. Young, fashionable and fun, the company is everything that the internet is supposed to be.

Although revenues are growing fast, turnover in the third quarter of last year, which also included the Christmas buying season, totalled just £409,000 on £4.3m of transactions. Many analysts were surprised they were so low when details were released last month.

"Lastminute is a wonderful brand but valuing it at £1bn? That's crazy," one said.

If Lastminute's valuation does reach the £1bn mark, its 28,687 customers will be valued at £34,858 each.

Some sceptical commentators have asked if Miss Lane-Fox could become the Sophie Mirman of her generation. Ms Mirman shot to national fame in 1987 when massive investor demand forced the value of the 30-year-old's Sock Shop retail chain up to £258m.

However, strategic errors and an end to the City's love affair with speciality retailers saw Sock Shop slide into administration three years later.

Individuals who have opted to invest some of their savings in internet stocks have had a rollercoaster ride. A week ago Freeserve, the UK's largest internet service provider, was valued at £9.2bn - putting it above Marks & Spencers, Sainsburys and British Aerospace in the corporate heirarchy. On Monday, competition concerns wiped £1.7bn from its share price and further falls left it worth £6.4bn at the end of trading yesterday.

Individuals who have registered an interest in buying shares in Lastminute.com have until 5pm today to send in their cheques. They have until 5pm tomorrow to agree to buy shares at the new higher level.

fields.headline: A dose of castor oil
fields.standfirst:
Primal Scream
Rock City, Nottingham/ touring
***
fields.trailText: If you or I set out to make an album aimed at rock critics, what would we do? Kick out the jams with MC5 guitars, throw in a few Chemical Brothers grooves perhaps, add PiL and Can to taste? Then recruit Bernard Sumner for that authentic Joy Division wall of sound and top the whole thing off with some of the most fiery rhetoric since the Sex Pistols and the Pop Group.
fields.body:
If you or I set out to make an album aimed at rock critics, what would we do? Kick out the jams with MC5 guitars, throw in a few Chemical Brothers grooves perhaps, add PiL and Can to taste? Then recruit Bernard Sumner for that authentic Joy Division wall of sound and top the whole thing off with some of the most fiery rhetoric since the Sex Pistols and the Pop Group.

Sadly for us, Primal Scream have got there first. Their recent Exterminator album duly received some of the most ecstatic reviews in rock history, and compounded the feat by scorching into the top three (although it has already left the top 40). The band have certainly satisfied their fan base, but the question the wider public presumably want answering is "Yes, but are there any tunes?"

In fairness to the Scream, this is exactly the kind of apathy they are setting themselves up against. It's as if they have taken it upon themselves to shake pop - and politicians, hippies, milkmen, anything you've got - out of the current national collective torpor.

If inviting Exterminator home feels a bit like placing a Molotov on the mantelpiece, the live experience feels like walking into a nuclear war. From the moment Bobby Gillespie shouts "We're going to tear the roof off this place!" things are going to be painful.

Snatches of lyrics such as "the illusion of democracy" and "civil disobedience" struggle to be heard amid an aural cacophony, complete with wailing saxophones, guitars like electric drills and PiL-esque soundscapes like walls of sheet metal clattering from a tower block. It comes to something when the jazz terrorism of If They Move, Kill 'em (from their previous album) comes as light relief.

Gillespie says little, adding to the impression of austerity, but the message is clear and if it isn't, lines such as "don't sell your soul" ram it home. As for the tunes, however, only the DAF-prototype electronic funk singles, Swastika Eyes and Kill All Hippies, escape a sonic mauling. During one particularly unlistenable moment, the punter next to me walked out. Meanwhile, the recently shorn Gillespie sways magnetically. However much this Glaswegian Clash fan is aware of pop's pose and iconography, he genuinely believes.

This is pop being given a dose of castor oil. It may eventually make the patient better, but it tastes bloody awful at the time.

 At UEA, Norwich (01603 508050), tonight, then tour.
